HEADLINE: Race Fight at Boston High School Evokes 1974 Uproar Over Busing

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 7

 BODY:
The streets of South Boston were calm today, and school officials prepared to reopen classes next week in phases. But uneasiness lingered in the largely white neighborhood after Thursday's racially motivated fight outside the public high school.
For many people here, Thursday's disturbance recalled the disturbances over busing 19 years ago. But unlike 1974, when whites vented their fury at black students being bused in, today there were more shades of opinion. 
 In a park at the Mary Ellen McCormack housing project, a group of white students from the high school, which had been closed for the day in the wake of the melee, responded to a reporter's questions with racial slurs. Mike Millhous, 15, boasted that he had thrown bottles at black students in Thursday's fight.
But around the corner, two white women, Linda Copell and Marie Masse, sat on the stoop outside their apartment talking about their fears that their neighborhood would be unfairly portrayed as a bastion of racism.
"We're not racists," said Mrs. Masse, an unemployed cafeteria manager who grew up in the projects. "I have friends who are black. My son's best friend is black. Things have not been bad here for years."
Her son, Bryan, a 19-year-old senior, said he was deeply disturbed by Thursday's fight. "This shouldn't be happening," he said. "It's a school. It's there for learning, not fighting."
Mrs. Masse said the fight, which involved 200 students, stirred painful memories of 1974, when she was a senior at South Boston High School. "It was hell," she said. "There were soldiers on every rooftop. It turned blacks and whites against each other."
The high school's student population, which was overwhelmingly white 19 years ago, is now 27 percent white, 37 percent black, 24 percent Hispanic and 12 percent Asian. Most of the nonwhite students are bused in from other neighborhoods.
Michael Brown, an 18-year-old black senior, rides the subway to the high school every day from the predominantly black Roxbury neighborhood just west of the South Boston area. He said that despite the problems, he felt fortunate to attend South Boston High School.
"South Boston is one of the better inner-city schools," Mr. Brown said. "There is a lot of tension right now in the school. There is a feeling of war between blacks and whites. In the boys' bathroom, it says, 'We hate niggers' on the wall." And he added that the bathroom graffiti also says, "We hate honkies."
There were not many black faces on the streets of South Boston today. But neither were there Federal troops, as there were in 1974, when hundreds of white residents took to the streets in protest, shouting racial slurs and sometimes hurling rocks. And although Boston police patrolled the neighborhood today, unlike 19 years ago there were not hundreds of them and they were not dressed in riot gear.
 
Incident vs. Disorder
 As he drove through the neighborhood, Ed Jesser, a political consultant who was born in the Mary Ellen McCormack project, was struck by the quiet. "Twenty years ago there were flotillas of police officers, day after day," he said. "Yesterday was an incident; 20 years ago there was civil disorder."
The school superintendent, Lois Harrison Jones, announced that seniors would return to South Boston High School on Monday, juniors on Tuesday and the rest of the school on Wednesday.
At an emergency meeting at City Hall today, black and white political leaders and school officials talked about ways to prevent a recurrence of Thursday's incident. "What happened at South Boston could have happened anywhere," said Dianne Wilkerson, a black state Senator from Roxbury.
In an interview, James Kelly, the white City Councilor who represents South Boston, blamed blacks for the racial tensions in his district. "They're going into mom-and-pop stores and taking whatever they want," he said. "You get 15 black males who all look like Mike Tyson's brothers, and there's one merchant. Is he going to say something to them? No."
Mr. Kelly attributed fear and tensions in the high school to black students, "a good portion of whom act like a bunch of terrorists."
Mayor Raymond Flynn, who spent today walking the streets of South Boston and the Roxbury neighborhood, described plans to install hand-held metal detectors at the high school. The Mayor, a lifelong resident of South Boston who initially opposed busing but has since become a symbol of racial healing, was meeting with students about school safety on Thursday morning before the fight began.
The mayor and the police said that reports of weapons had been greatly exaggerated. One gun and 20 knives were confiscated from students at the high school this year, the Mayor said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Raymond Flynn of Boston said yesterday that plans are under way to install hand-held metal detectors at the South Boston High School. The mayor, a lifelong resident of South Boston, had been meeting with students at the school on Thursday to discuss safety before the fight outside the school began. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ex-Gov. Hunt Is Sentenced To 1,000 Hours of Service

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 7

 BODY:
Guy Hunt, the part-time preacher who became Alabama's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction, was ordered to pay $210,000 and serve 1,000 hours of community service today after his conviction and removal from office last month for illegally converting money from his inauguration for his own use.
Mr. Hunt, a farmer and former Amway salesman whose unlikely rise and catastrophic fall became one of the most unlikely political stories of recent years, avoided going to prison when Judge Randall Thomas of State Circuit Court suspended a five-year prison sentence. Mr. Hunt left the courthouse unrepentant, telling supporters at a rally on the Capitol steps that an appeal would put him back in the Governor's office. 
 "When I return to this office here you elected me to, we'll just all get together and have the biggest old cry you've ever seen," he told about 200 admirers who gathered in the sweltering midday sun for an emotional rally in which his removal from office was compared with the crucifixion of Jesus.
Skeptics said Mr. Hunt's legacy would be another dour chapter in the history of a state still struggling to emerge from the quarter century, ended in 1987, in which George C. Wallace dominated the political landscape.
 
Footnote in History
 "He was totally out of his depth," said Carl Grafton, a political science professor at Auburn University at Montgomery. "He never should have been Governor in the first place. Historically, this will be worth one sentence in the history books 20 years from now."
But Mr. Hunt may not be down yet. His lawyers contend, and many legislators agree, that his conviction reflected a judge's charge to the jury that held him to higher standards than were reflected in state law or common political practice.
Mr. Hunt combined the down-home piety of a country preacher with a street politician's nose for raising money. He had a Reaganite contempt for government programs and a sovereign's love for the trappings of power.
A part-time Primitive Baptist preacher, farmer and former rural county probate judge with a high school education, Mr. Hunt first ran for Governor in 1978 and received 26 percent of the vote.
 
Victorious 'Sacrificial Lamb'
 He continued to stay close to politics, serving as chairman of Ronald Reagan's campaign in Alabama in 1980, a position he had also held in 1976. He was viewed as a Republican sacrificial lamb in 1986 in a state that had not elected a Republican governor since Reconstruction. But he was the beneficiary of a murderous Democratic primary in which the party nominee, the conservative Attorney General Charles Graddick, was ruled off the ballot and replaced by the man Mr. Graddick had defeated in the Democratic primary, a relatively liberal former Attorney General named Bill Baxley. When the smoke cleared, Mr. Hunt, was Governor.
"Somebody pinch me," he said.
Mr. Hunt was popular with white rural voters, and his anti-tax, laissez-faire agenda fit in well with the spirit of the times. He confounded critics and the powerful Democratic Party by winning re-election in 1990.
Republicans say Mr. Hunt's pro-business stance was good for the state's economy, which grew at a faster pace than that of the nation while he was in office.
"He was a pretty good Governor," said Marty Connors, a former executive director of the Alabama Republican Party. "He brought in creative business types who revamped many state agencies, and while we may not have gotten the Nissan-type contracts, for the first time in years we saw ourselves on many companies' short list. One of the disappointments was that we had a chance to set a very proactive agenda, but we didn't."
Others say that is a polite way of saying the Governor had no real legislative achievements for a state grappling with fundamental problems of poverty, bottom-of-the-barrel schools and an outdated tax code. In his second term, he played no significant role in the legislative process, legislators and political analysts say.
 
Earlier Complaint of Abuses
 And the conviction is not the only blow to Mr. Hunt's image of small-town probity.
In 1981, as a reward for his service to Mr. Reagan, Mr. Hunt was given the full-time post of State Executive Director of the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. After an employee of the agency complained of irregularities in November 1984, a Department of Agriculture report found that he had repeatedly claimed reimbursement for travel to his home when no official reason for the trip was evident.
Six subordinates gave sworn statements that he had his underlings produce on government time political mailing lists, correspondence, budgets and other political work in anticipation of his next race for Governor. Such political activity is a violation of the Federal Hatch Act. Employees also said he had tried to obstruct the inquiry.
Mr. Hunt resigned to run for Governor shortly after the Federal report in April 1985 said the evidence already produced "is more than sufficient to require Hunt's immediate removal from the Federal service."
After being elected Governor, Mr. Hunt showed a selective appetite for the perquisites of power. His regular use of the state plane to go to preaching engagements started the inquiry that led to his indictment. When the State Ethics Commission ruled that he might have violated the law by using the state plane for 18 preaching trips in which he pocketed $10,000 in donations, he said the ethics law did not apply to him.
While most Governors get by with minimal security, Mr. Hunt traveled with a Presidential-style contingent of security personnel, who ended up worming cattle and pruning fruit trees on his farm when he went home. He said the work was voluntary.
His supporters say he did nothing out of keeping with regular political practice. Prosecutors say that by using a nonprofit inaugural fund rather than campaign money, he had illegally used his office for political gain.
"By the judge's standard, 90 percent of the elected officials in Alabama could go to jail," Mr. Connors said.
 
Problems of Alabama
 Still, to many, the tragedy of his administration is that Alabama, which has lagged behind other Southern states in modernizing state government, has six more years to make up for.
"The business community in this state encouraged the people of the state to re-elect an individual that they wouldn't consider hiring for their own company," said Bill Barnard, a history professor at the University of Alabama. "I think many of them came to rue the role that they had played."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Guy Hunt, the former Governor of Alabama, was sentenced yesterday to pay a $210,000 fine and to serve 1,000 hours of community service for illegally converting money from his inauguration for his own use. With him outside the state Capitol in Montgomery was his wife, Helen. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Grocery Workers Begin Strike in New Jersey

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Striking grocery store workers formed picket lines at some northern New Jersey supermarkets yesterday, while management began locking out employees at nearby stores and reopening with temporary workers.
Some 28,000 workers at 312 supermarkets in three states could join the striking workers now that contract negotiations have broken off because of a dispute over health care. 
 A spokesman for ShopRite, Foodtown, Grand Union and Pathmark supermarkets confirmed that union employees at some stores were being replaced by temporary workers.
 
'Sound Economic Policy'
 "We have initiated lockouts at a select number of stores in a contiguous area to those being picketed," said the spokesman, Donald Vaillancourt. "We are simply following a sound economic policy."
Mr. Vaillancourt would not say how many stores were being selected for lockouts.
Frank Margiotta, a spokesman for United Food and Commercial Workers Union Local 1262 said that 10 Pathmark and Foodtown stores in northern New Jersey were being staffed with replacement workers. He said picketing could spread to other stores over the weekend.
Local 1262 represents workers at New Jersey stores in Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean, Passaic, Somerset, Sussex, Union and Warren counties. In New York the strike could affect all of the ShopRites in Dutchess, Sullivan and Ulster counties and some of the Grand Unions and ShopRites in Orange and Rockland counties. One Grand Union in Milford in Pike County, Pa., could also be affected. The strike will not affect stores in Connecticut.
 
No Contract Since April 10
 Members of Local 1262 have been without a contract since April 10.
Luella Hardy, an employee at the ShopRite in Jersey City, said she had been chastising those crossing the line.
"I've been saying to my customers, 'Shame on you,' " said Ms. Hardy, 58, of Jersey City. "They say, 'Well, I have to eat.' Some say they have to buy food for their cat, or food for their dog. No way can anyone tell me a good reason for crossing a picket line."

HEADLINE: Reno Questions Drug Policy's Stress on Smuggling

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Attorney General Janet Reno today questioned the wisdom of spending billions of dollars a year to stop the production and transportation of narcotics from abroad and vowed to take steps that would make treatment for drug abusers more widely available.
In her most extensive comments on national drug policy since she took office nearly two months ago, she said more serious consideration had to be given to alternatives to prison sentences for drug offenders. 
 Ms. Reno suggested what she called "a carrot and stick approach," in which drug offenders are offered counseling by case managers instead of prison sentences. Offenders would be threatened with incarceration if they failed to complete treatment programs. She also said that Federal courts had been taking on too many small cases involving drug abusers that would be better handled by the states.
Her comments, before a national drug conference here attended by judges, prosecutors, academics and lawmakers, largely echoed the oratory of the Clinton Presidential campaign, and they stood in sharp contrast to the law-and-order speeches of her predecessors over the last decade. The Reagan and Bush Administrations spent billions of dollars increasing the role of the Federal Government in prosecuting narcotics cases, and considerably less on rehabilitation and prevention.
 
Difference With Clinton
 But Ms. Reno's remarks were somewhat contrary to the drug priorities in the Clinton Administration's budget, which was completed just as Ms. Reno took office in March. By seeking almost $2 on law-enforcement operations for every $1 on treatment programs, the Clinton budget of $13.04 billion for fighting drugs largely continues the Bush Administration's policy.
Among the most criticized elements of the Reagan-Bush drug policies were the expensive and largely unsuccessful efforts to stop overseas farmers from producing the raw material for cocaine and opium and to block the smuggling of the drugs into the United States.
Mr. Clinton cut financing for some international operations in South America and Asia by 8 percent. That would trim $44 million from spending last year of $536 million. But he added $19 million for fighting smuggling, bringing spending in that category to $1.765 billion, much of it going to the Defense Department.
Ms. Reno stopped short of criticizing the Republican drug policy or the White House's budget, but it appeared from her remarks that they did not reflect her own preferences. She put more emphasis on treatment and less on pursuing cocaine and heroin producers in South America and Asia.
 
Questioning Drug Seizures
 "In terms of interdiction, we've got to ask questions," Ms. Reno said, noting that at best, 25 percent of the drugs entering the southeastern United States had been confiscated. Law-enforcement authorities say 75 percent would have to be seized before putting a real dent in drug use, a goal she called "economically prohibitive."
Ms. Reno said the Justice Department had begun to review whether too many minor drug cases were being handled by the Federal Government and courts. She suggested that those cases be prosecuted instead by local authorities, with more sharing of prisons by Federal and state authorities.
She also criticized the long minimum prison sentences that are mandatory for relatively minor drug offenses, saying they had begun to hamper the criminal justice system. She has announced a review of such sentencing procedures, and Justice Department officials say she will probably recommend new legislation this year and changes in the way Federal prosecutors prepare low-level cases.
Ms. Reno said the mandatory minimum prison terms and tough treatment under the Federal sentencing guidelines had been established with "no regard as to whether we have the prison cells to match the sentences."

HEADLINE: Airlines Reluctantly Match Northwest's Fare Cuts

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Most major airlines agreed yesterday to match the summer fare cuts announced by Northwest Airlines late Thursday evening, but what started as a routine announcement of matching fares turned into a mini-seminar on such industry problems as competition, accusations of price-fixing, incipient price wars and the financial health of individual carriers.
The day began as routinely as a takeoff or landing, with most airlines saying they would match the Northwest cuts, which on average slice 20 to 30 percent off regular fares but are loaded with restrictions. 
 However, American Airlines, the industry leader, waited until late afternoon to say it would match, and even then added that it could not talk about its purchase dates until it advertised them nationally.
 
Influence of Antitrust Suit
 That is in keeping with American's earlier decision not to respond to such questions from reporters for fear of running afoul of Justice Department recommendations that were made as part of a civil antitrust suit. The suit accused eight airlines of fixing prices and restraining price competition.
Most of the carriers are fighting the accusations, but several including American have agreed to abide by the recommendations, hoping that will protect them from private triple-damage lawsuits by consumers.
The travel industry, consumer groups and many members of Congress have criticized the Justice Department recommendations, contending the guidelines themselves are likely to restrain price competition.
Northwest, which had introduced another fare sale two weeks ago, said it had decided on the new one to bring in "incremental revenue" at a time when the economy remained soft.
Phillip Brannon, a high-yield bond analyst at the Mabon Securities Corporation in New York, said that Northwest's strategy suggested that the privately held, financially troubled airline was desperate for money -- a suggestion that Northwest denied.
Mr. Brannon cited several reasons for his assessment. Among them is the statement that Northwest filed with the Transportation Department on Dec. 31 listing assets of $1.3 billion and liabilities of $2.1 billion. "Combined with that you have the balance sheet for the fourth quarter, where they lost $160 million on an operating basis, and for all 12 months of 1992 they lost $309 million," he said.
Mr. Brannon also said that Northwest officials knew that their strategy of cutting fares at a time when the industry was losing money, and especially cutting them during the busy summer months, put Northwest at risk of retaliation from American.
The two carriers set off last summer's money-losing fare war when Northwest adopted a two-for-one sale and American countered with a systemwide half-price sale.
"Northwest is the carrier that can least afford a sustained fare war," Mr. Brannon said, "yet they are the ones that most often announce sales that are likely to start them. I can only conclude from that that they are desperate."
Mark Abels, a Northwest spokesman, said in response, "The logic that having a promotion or sale is a sign of unusual distress is not very compelling."
Standard & Poor's said this week that NWA Inc. and its Northwest unit remained on credit watch with negative implications. "If Northwest is able to reach satisfactory labor agreements," the agency told Aviation Daily, "parent NWA would greatly increase its chances of restructuring its bank and other private credit facilities to extend debt maturities. Without such a financial restructuring, NWA would find it very difficult to meet large repayments due in 1994."
After losing billions of dollars in recent years, the airlines have been trying desperately to raise fares, but they have been thwarted by a sluggish economy and overcapacity. In a speech on April 30, Robert L. Crandall, American's chief executive, said that in the last decade average industry revenue per seat mile had dropped 25 percent after inflation.
Mr. Abels said Northwest's sales were carefully specified, tickets could be bought only during an 11-day period, and seats were limited on each flight. "Our thought is to do a targeted and limited promotion that will yield profits," he said, "and we have every reason to believe that's what we're doing."
 
Variety of Restrictions
 Under the fare sale, which ends at midnight May 18, travel must begin on or after May 27 and be completed by Sept. 15. Tickets must be bought at least 14 days before departure, and fares on some routes are cheaper if travel is completed by June 30. Seats are subject to availability and a Saturday stay is required.
With the new fares, flights between New York and Los Angeles will be $378 round trip, compared with a regular 14-day advance fare with Saturday stay-over of $530; a New York-Washington round trip will drop to $118 from $160, and New York-Chicago will be $198, down from $290.

HEADLINE: Canada Wins Victory on Its Lumber Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 7

 BODY:
A binational trade panel has handed Canada a major victory in a long-running dispute with the United States over trade in softwood lumber.
The five-member Free Trade Agreement panel late Thursday essentially found that the Commerce Department had not made its case that Canada subsidized exports. On the basis of those subsidies, the United States imposes $200 million a year in duties on Canadian softwood, used mainly in home building. 
 The panel said that the Commerce Department had not considered all the evidence or followed its own regulations in setting the duties. It instructed it to re-examine its findings on each of the key issues in the case and respond within 90 days.
The duties stay in effect during the reconsideration process.
In terms of trade volume, the softwood dispute is by far the most significant between the two countries under terms of the free trade pact. Canada last year shipped $4.4 billion in softwood to the United States. Despite the 6.5 percent tariff, shipments were up 14.6 percent form 1991.
Canada's Trade Minister, Michael Wilson, hailed the decison as "very positive." Exports to the United States account for more than half of total Canadian lumber production. The industry is one of the major employers in Canada, where joblessness is 11 percent, half again as high as in the United States.
In the last 40 years, the United States has used more lumber than it has produced and Canada has made up the difference. But in the last decade the American industry has been up in arms over what is now Canada's 29 percent penetration of the American market and has accused Canadians of unfair trade practices.
A major complaint has been that the fees that Canadian provinces charge companies to harvest timber are less than what American lumber companies have to pay to cut timber on public and private land in the United States. The disparity, American producers say, gives Canadian exporters an unfair advantage, which entitles the United States industry to the protection of duties.
The panel, addressing that point in its ruling, said the department should have considered whether provincial timber fees distorted normal competitive markets before concluding that they were a subsidy against which duties might be imposed.
The Commerce Department had set the 6.5 percent countervailing duty a year ago. Many analysts here think the department will have to either eliminate or reduce it to meet the panel's standards.
Adam Darling, a spokesman for the Commerce Department's International Trade Administration, said the department was "obviously disappointed." He declined further comment, noting that the department still had to digest the panel's "very dense" 170-page report.
A Washington-based body representing the domestic American industry, the Coalition for Fair Lumber Imports, said the panel had "exceeded its authority" and "substituted its judgment for that of the responsibile U.S. agency."
The Canadian lumber industry was ecstatic. "It's hard to imagine how we could have had a stronger decision from a binational panel," said Tom Buell, chairman of the Vancouver-based Canadian Forest Industries Council. "The binational panel today flunked the Commerce Department in Economics 101."
 
Panels Set Up Under Pact
 Under the four-and-a-half-year-old Free Trade Agreement, binational panels are set up to determine whether laws of either country are correctly and fairly applied in trade decisions. Canada had insisted on this to allay its fear of arbitrary rulings by American Government agencies responding to protectionist pressures.
Panels have been convened on dozens of trade fights with Canada in the last four years, with many decisions favoring Canada. Last month, a Canadian position was upheld in a conflict over exports of live swine that resulted in a refund to Canada of nearly $10 million in duties.
The lumber panel comprised five trade experts: three Canadians and two Americans. Two each were initially chosen from each country and together they agreed on the fifth.
Lumber prices rose dramatically last year, reflecting the shortage in the United States combined with an increase in home building and environmental restrictions on logging. Lately, prices have softened.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Skittishness About Bosnia Helps to Push Dollar Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher against major foreign currencies yesterday as traders, nervous about possible military intervention in Bosnia, bought the American currency ahead of the weekend.
The broad advance came despite April employment figures that were slightly worse than expected. While the dollar initially moved lower on these numbers, it rebounded after not droppping below a key psychological level against the German mark. 
 Gold slipped late yesterday after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell 70 cents an ounce, to $356.70. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $356.30 an ounce, off 70 cents.
Currency traders said they were first disappointed by the Labor Department's report that nonfarm jobs rose by 119,000 in April; a 150,000 gain had been expected by economists.
But when the dollar did not fall below 1.5800 German marks, many traders decided that the currency had reached a bottom and began to cover their short sales by buying it back. (In a short sale, traders sell borrowed investments in the hope that they can profit by buying them back at a lower price.)
In New York, the dollar ended the day at 1.58375 German marks, up from 1.57405 on Thursday.
 
No Clear Relationship Seen
 Analysts said the increased tension in Bosnia in itself had not convinced traders to buy dollars, which are often viewed as a safe haven during international conflicts. But many participants were hesitant to go into the weekend short of dollars.
"There doesn't seem to be a Bosnia, good-dollar, bad-dollar relationship," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.
Also helping to prop up the dollar against the Japanese yen were unconfirmed reports that the Bank of Japan intervened in Tokyo trading with purchases of about $500 million.
The dollar fell as low as 109.65 yen in Tokyo before closing at 110.10, down 0.09 yen from Thursday's close. Later, in New York, it ended the day at 110.30 yen, up from 110.03 yen on Thursday.
"The market sees 110 yen as where the market expects the central banks to start showing up," said Ronald Leven, global currency analyst at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5730, from $1.5699 Thursday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.5720 late yesterday afternoon, down from $1.5805 Thursday.

HEADLINE: Arms Makers Vie to Build Rail Cars

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 7

 BODY:
In what public officials here are billing as the first serious effort to steer the declining weapons industry toward commercial work, five of the nation's largest military and aerospace contractors are competing for a contract to build rail cars for this city's new mass transit system.
The military contractors have each joined forces with established rail-car manufacturers to bid for the contract, which is seen as a test case of whether the companies can successfully transfer decades of high-tech weapons production into marketable products for the rapidly expanding transportation equipment and services market.
The contract, with an estimated value of $200 million, is to be awarded by the end of June. It covers the building of 87 cars for the city's Green Line, scheduled to open in late 1994, and to develop technologically advanced transportation products that can be used in Los Angeles cars and other transit systems worldwide.
"Unlike some businesses that the defense contractors are considering entering, transportation is still an underdeveloped market, and a lot of the skills used in defense are applicable to mass transit," said James Raffel, a research analyst for the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, a Washington group.
Rail-car industry executives appear pleased to form partnerships with military contractors, which they said had developed a variety of technologies that would benefit future mass transit systems.
They may include lightweight frames for rail cars and buses, made from the same composite materials that the military contractors use in their rocket and missile designs. The contractors may also use their knowledge of aerospace electronics to develop safer braking and more fuel-efficient propulsion systems for the rail cars.
"Most of this technology has been too expensive for us to develop for the current market, and a lot of it has been kept confidential or classified as sensitive because of its use by the military," said Thomas J. Smith, president of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation's rail system group, which has teamed with the Hughes Aircraft Company and the Lockheed Corporation. "It's a unique opportunity for us to get our hands on some of it."
Many weapons industry experts and executives have long maintained that the skills the contractors gained in building complex weaponry like missiles, jet fighters and radar have direct applications to transportation. Even critics say that if military contractors are at all successful in commercial ventures, they will most likely be transportation related, mainly because that market remains largely undeveloped.
 Yet Mr. Raffel said that military contractors were unlikely to enter the market for transportation equipment and services, despite its predicted fast growth, unless the Federal Government made a considerable investment in the development of new technologies and in the rebuilding of roads, bridges and mass transit.
As an example of why such conversion efforts are prone to fail when there is no Government support, Mr. Raffel cites the Boeing Corporation's early success in building rail cars and trolleys after the Vietnam War. But the Seattle-based jet builder ultimately abandoned its rail-car efforts when financing from the Urban Mass Transit Administration was cut during the Carter and Reagan Administrations and the market became unstable.
President Clinton has said he intends to increase Federal investment in transportation and rebuilding roads and the like, but no specific plans have yet been formulated.
The American Public Transit Association, an industry group, estimates that transit systems across the United States will have to spend about $8.1 billion by the end of the decade to replace rail vehicles and keep them in proper working order. That amount compares with $4.5 billion spent in 1990.
Los Angeles plans to spend $150 billion over the next 30 years on a 400-mile metro system that includes light- , heavy- and commuter-rail systems. About $70 billion will be spent on the light-rail system, which will require hundreds of rail cars.
 
 
Motive Was Loss of Jobs
 Officials of the Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Authority said that the region's loss of some 150,000 aerospace and weapons jobs in the last five years prompted them to structure the rail-car procurement as an enticement for military contractors to consider transportation work to offset the decline in military business.
"We've worked very hard to encourage local aerospace and defense firms to form these partnerships with the rail-car industry to help them make the transition into the emerging surface transportation industry," said Mike Antonovich, chairman of the Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The four bidding teams are: the Northrop Corporation with the Bombardier Corporation; Lockheed, Hughes and Morrison Knudsen; TRW Aerospace, the AAI Corporation and the Siemens Duewag Corporation, and the Rockwell International Corporation with the Sumitomo Corporation.
Under the contract, the winning team will receive up to $10 million to develop product ideas, which will be tested on two prototype cars and possibly be included in some of the 87 cars ordered. The winning team is expected to be well positioned to compete for other transit rail contracts and to sell its products across the country and overseas.
But some critics and supporters of conversion alike say that the military contractors have yet to show a real commitment to transportation and that the companies' participation in the Los Angeles rail system is only window dressing because it requires little capital investment.
 
Union Is Skeptical
 "If they are serious about transportation, why aren't they creating design and development centers within the companies to study the new technologies and make prototypes?" asked Don Nakamoto, research director for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers District 727 in Los Angeles. "They are very reluctant to take the first step."
Mr. Nakamoto, whose union strongly supports conversion for jobs growth, said he believed the city's effort to get military contractors to participate in the rail-car procurement was partly political. After the metropolitan transportation commission canceled a $121.8 million contract it had awarded to Sumitomo for the Green Line cars, amid a storm of criticism about the selection of a foreign-owned company, it was forced to find American companies to bid with foreign rail-car makers, Mr. Nakamoto said.
Gwendolyn Williams, manager of contracting for the vehicle acquisition project for the Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said that initially the rail-car makers responded coldly to the idea of teaming with the military contractors because the two were in totally different businesses. After months of collaboration, however, the rail-car makers have expressed optimism that the partnerships will prosper.
Greg Fountain, Lockheed's manager of advanced product development for commercial systems, said that the Los Angeles procurement represented an opportunity to test ideas. "The critical issue here is that we in the defense business must learn to assess the needs of the market and match those needs with the appropriate technology," he said. "In the past we were just given requirements and we met them."
Mr. Fountain said that if Lockheed was successful in developing new transportation technologies, he believed the new area of business could amount to as much as $100 million in annual revenue and possibly more in the long term.
 
Rockwell Sees Advantage
 Officials of Rockwell International said they believed they had an advantage over other military contractors competing for the Los Angeles rail contract because of the company's history of translating military technology into transportation products.
Using its military navigation and electronics skills, Rockwell recently developed satellite navigation and communications systems that are being used by trucking companies, transit systems and railroads to track vehicles and provide the latest type of communications. The contractor is also developing so-called intelligent vehicle highway systems, a traffic management tool, and it is a major supplier of car and truck components and systems.
"It's not hard to imagine transportation being half of Rockwell International," Mr. Black said. "The same technology that we put in infrared sensors can be used for traffic-lane monitoring or even for collision avoidance in cars. The trick is correctly identifying the market and applying the technology."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Women See a Future And the Collars Are Blue

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
WHILE one group of women learned about double-headed nails in carpentry, another group built up upper-body strength on weight machines in a renovated firehouse on West 20th Street, where Nontraditional Employment for Women prepares future plumbers, electricians and construction workers.
It was a week after Take Our Daughters to Work Day and the women, many of them single mothers, talked about the day. "I wish we had that when I was young," said one participant in the 13-week program. But it turned out that none had brought daughters to the classes. "It's good for the girls coming up," said a woman from the Bronx, "but we're more interested in the here and now." 
 The 18 students in the current cycle ranged in age from early 20's to 30's. Some had dropped out of high school, others had graduated from two-year colleges. Many were on public assistance and almost all had spotty employment records, mostly short stints of this and that, working in stores, baby-sitting, clerical jobs, that fizzled out far short of a meaningful future. All said they heard of Nontraditional Employment for Women, or NEW, on the street.
"I saw this woman driving a crane and when I asked her how she got the job, she told me about the program," said Bernadette Blocker, a 30-year-old who, like the other women in her class, puts in eight-hour days learning practical skills, lifting weights and taking courses on the history of women in the workplace. "I just wish I'd known about it years ago," said Ms. Blocker, who hopes to apprentice as a union electrician.
In fact, NEW started 14 years ago. As explained by Gardenia White, its executive director, up to 300 women a year are being helped to find blue-collar jobs that pay at least $8 an hour. "It's an extremely focused program," she said. "The women come to us, we provide the training and we help them get the jobs." Close ties have been established with employers like Con Edison, New York Telephone and unions in the building trades.
All the trainees are poor and unemployed, 78 percent are single heads of households, 66 percent are high-school dropouts and 98 percent are black or Hispanic. Of the 2,500 women hard hats working in New York City, more than half were trained at NEW. This is still a tiny percentage of all such workers, but each year the number has been rising and currently as many as half the apprenticeships in some important unions are going to women.
For students like Ms. Blocker, such statistics are comforting. They encourage hopes that after many zigzags, flights of fancy and dead ends, real change is about to take place in their lives. At lunch they recite pay scales of various jobs like mantras that will assure them success in a short time, if not quite here and now. They look for confirmation in the records of earlier graduates.
There is, for example, Frieda Maldonado, a 49-year-old single mother of four, who talked about her life on a break from her job as the operator of a front-end loader at a paving job on Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street. Minutes earlier she had expertly backed the machine into traffic and nudged a two-ton metal plate over an excavation. "I love it, it's so exciting," said the woman, who earns $27.30 an hour as a journeyman operator in Local 15 of the International Union of Operating Engineers.
"Before I went to the NEW program I was on public assistance," she said. "I still remember when I went there and decided I'd go into construction, my kids said I was crazy. Now they think I'm great and my youngest daughter is going to take the test for the union. Maybe we'll make it a mother-daughter union."
Another role model is Angela Jeter, 31, who came back for a visit from her job as a general utility worker for Con Edison in Westchester. "I'm making good money and I'm on a track where I can make more," said the woman, who completed her course last October. "I work with transformers and I'm learning all the time. I started at $10.20 an hour, but that's going up as I learn new skills, first to $14.99 and then $16.38 and then to $21.89." She has plans to move out of the Bronx with her 8-year-old son and to buy a car. "Everything is possible now."
"But the best thing is how I'm feeling," she said. "I'm in control of my life. I've got confidence. I'm independent."
She said when she started at Con Edison two other women from NEW started with her. All the other workers were men. "For the first two months the men were real quiet. We expected that and just worked hard. Now it's like we have all these brothers."
She said her son, who backed her from the start, is very happy. "He's seen how I've changed and he thinks it's great that I come home from work as dirty as he comes home from the park."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Changes for Consumers in Treasury's Shift

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

 BODY:
The Government's decision this week to try to save money by borrowing for shorter periods is likely to affect consumers in important, though only slowly unfolding, ways.
The dominant Wall Street view is that by halting sales of new seven-year notes and shrinking sales of 30-year bonds -- replacing this financing with nearer maturities -- the Treasury will inevitably put upward pressure on short-term interest rates. 
 If so, one effect will be to lessen the present strong incentive for consumers to shift money from low-yielding certificates of deposit to bonds and stocks. C.D.'s, in other words, will be relatively more appealing and most of the riskier alternatives less so.
Another impact of the Administration's move will be on borrowers who have adjustable loans tied to short-term rates.
People will be more inclined "to take the plunge and lock into longer-term" fixed-rate loans, suggested David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. This would avoid the pain of a jump in, say,
monthly mortgage payments.
At the same time, investors who have grown fond of intermediate-maturity Treasury paper will still have a sizable choice of merchandise. While no new seven-year notes are to be issued, existing ones will continue to trade as will longer-term bonds that become seven-year securities through the aging process.
There may even be some pluses for consumers in the new financing strategy, though skeptics abound. To the extent the Government places fewer financing demands on the long-term, or 30-year, market this could allow corporate borrowers to tap this area more freely and thereby add to investor choice.
Some, of course, dispute the assumption that the shift in strategy will raise short-term rates -- or do anything really noticeable.
"The Government is a drop in the bucket in the long-term credit market," said David Ranson, president of H. C. Wainwright Economics in Boston.
But all Americans may lament the downgrading of the 30-year bond for one, albeit intangible, reason. Even though it has been auctioned regularly only since the late 1970's, its existence means that at least one country in the world enjoys a political and economic system of such stature that lenders willingly part with their money for a generation, confident their purchasing power will be preserved.
The standard in other nations is 10-year bonds, Mr. Jones noted, contending that the Administration has tarnished a national "badge of honor."

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
The Europe Group Turns Around, Finally

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The sorry course of the 28 mutual funds that invest in European issues has reversed this year, rising 8.3 percent through April 22 compared with a gain of only three-quarters of a percent for domestic stock funds. The Europe funds' stellar performance owes much to the German central bank for easing interest rates.
For Europe fund investors, it's about time. Except for gold, the Europe group has been the worst performer over the last five years. In the last three years, Europe produced a negative average annual return. 
 Many analysts say Europe's economy is two or three years behind the United States; thus, the thinking goes, Europe should be poised for a bull market similar to that in the United States in 1991. For contrarians, Europe seems a perfect bet.
But there are risks ahead. Much of Europe lingers in recession, one aggravated by the unexpectedly huge costs of German unification and the still very high interest rates this has brought, said Stephen A. Schoepke, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J.

HEADLINE: Profits Flow as Savings Banks Convert

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
It may not truly be a free lunch, but depositors who exercise their right to buy stock in savings institutions as they convert from mutual to stock ownership may think they have found the next best thing.
Mutual savings banks and savings and loans are owned by their depositors, but there has been little opportunity for the owners to share in the increased value of those banks as low interest rates have raised profits to record levels. But in the process of converting to stock companies, in which shares are offered at attractive prices to depositors and management, the former "owners" can earn a big profit while the savings institutions benefit by adding to capital. 
 Almost always the stock is offered at such a low price that the shares quickly increase. Among the savings institutions converting in the 15 months ended March 31, share prices rose an average of 30 percent in the first week of trading, according to SNL Securities of Charlottesville, Va.
The lure of big profits has attracted investors ranging from individuals with a savings account to large investment partnerships that have opened accounts in dozens of mutuals so that they will be eligible to buy stock if there is a conversion. In most cases, all depositors with accounts at a cutoff date may buy the same number of shares.
While there is no guarantee that stock prices of savings institutions will continue rising as they have recently -- most analysts agree that profits are at a peak and the era of biggest gains is over -- there is still opportunity for depositors to benefit from the quick rise in stock prices that has been the recent pattern.
"The offering price has to be a little on the low side, just to provide an incentive for people to move their money to a new company," said Michael A. Murphy, a managing director at the Trident Financial Corporation of Raleigh, N.C.
Mr. Murphy noted that shares of many savings institutions were trading for about 90 percent of book value, the net worth of each share after liabilities have been subtracted from assets. New shares, he said, are usually offered at 60 percent to 70 percent of book value. A few years ago, when the outlook for the institutions was bleak, new shares were offered at less than 40 percent of book value.
But despite higher offering prices, and the risk that savings stocks could decline, shares of recently converted savings institutions have done well. This week, for example, shares in Fidelity New York Federal Savings Bank began trading Monday at $13 a share, up from the offering price of $10.80, and by the end of the week had risen to $13.875. Stock in Sunrise Bancorp, the holding company for Sunrise Federal Savings Bank, Farmingdale, L.I., converted April 5 at $10 a share and has since jumped to $13.25.
Investors and securities dealers say they expect the success of recent deals to encourage more managers of the remaining mutual savings institutions to convert. High interest rates and falling real estate prices depleted the industry's ranks during the 1980's, but at the end of last year there were still over 1,200 mutuals, most in good financial health.
"Wall Street has been all over my case, pushing for a conversion," said George L. Engelke Jr., chief executive at the Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association in Queens.
Astoria Federal and the Green Point Savings Bank, also based in Queens, are two of the largest remaining mutuals in the country and are often mentioned as candidates for conversion. Among local banks that have announced such plans, Roosevelt Savings Bank, Garden City, L.I., has said depositors as of July 21, 1992, will be eligible to buy stock, but has not yet announced the price. The Columbia Federal Savings Bank of Queens also plans to convert.
Although many of the largest savings institutions that issued stock in the mid-1980's have fared poorly -- Goldome of Buffalo and Crossland Savings of Brooklyn, for example, have failed -- those memories have faded as low interest rates have improved profits at the survivors. To decide whether to buy stock in conversions, experienced investors offer several tips.
Glen Greenberg, head of Chieftain Capital Management, said investors should look for institutions in which management was buying a significant amount of stock. In recent deals, management has often bought at least 10 percent of the stock, with an additional 7 percent going to an employee stock investment plan.
Institutional investors also look for a conservative business plan where management will adhere to the business they know and not try to grow rapidly by making risky loans.
Many investors favor companies that say they will consider a stock buyback plan. Such repurchases help hold up the stock price and are a good sign that management is not looking to plunge into risky loans.
Mr. Greenberg said that after a savings bank increased its capital by selling stock, "the primary goal of its managers should be to preserve that capital so that they can eventually sell the company at a higher price" to a larger bank.
Harry Keefe, president of Keefe Bank Stock Advisors, an investment firm, said the stock price set in conversions was low enough that "the odds are pretty good" for depositors to make a quick profit on shares they buy. But he adds that there is enough risk that depositors should limit their purchases to amounts within their financial reach, without borrowing.
If you decide to speculate on conversions and try to open many new deposit accounts, be prepared for some blunt refusals. Many banks now reject deposits from outside their area to preserve any future stock offering for local customers. Others are wary of individuals who open many accounts at different banks because that is a common tactic in financial fraud.

HEADLINE: A Festival Of Theater Reaches 30 In Berlin

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 7

 BODY:
Imagine a theater festival in New York in which an impartial jury picks the best productions of the last year in the English-speaking world and brings them together over a three-week period. Along with them come all manner of readings of new plays and public discussions, and every other theater in the city -- assuming that New York boasted several major repertory companies -- stages special performances just to remain competitive.
The Germans have no need to imagine such a thing, because they already have it. The Theatertreffen, or Theater Meeting, which is celebrating its 30th anniversary, brings 12 productions to Berlin in the month of May from Germany, Austria and Switzerland. Spilling into several Berlin theaters, the event attracts eager audiences, roughly half of them theater professionals of one sort or another and a third from outside Berlin. 
 Unlike the midwinter Berlin Film Festival or the early-fall Berlin Festival devoted primarily to music and dance -- all these events are presented by the same umbrella organization, Berlin Festivals -- the Theater Meeting is little known outside the German-speaking world. Theater remains the most language-bound of the performing arts, and so even a festival showcasing the best finds little resonance in the rest of Europe, let alone in the United States.
While the Theater Meeting is a remarkable event, allowing audiences to experience top-notch German theater without searching for it from city to city, this year's festival was almost the last.
"Over the decades, it has been to our advantage that Berlin supported us along with Bonn," said Torsten Mass, deputy director of the Berlin Festivals and for the last five years co-director of the Theater Meeting. Mr. Mass was sitting outside a cafe behind one of the festival's theaters, the Freie Volksbuhne, while inside Botho Strauss, Germany's best-known playwright, was receiving a prize.
"From year to year, Bonn always raised our budget and Berlin matched it," Mr. Mass went on. "But now Germany has economic problems, and as usual politicians want first to snip at culture. Bonn reduced all theater support by 8 percent. We could live with that. But then Berlin said it had to cut, too, because Bonn had, and that would have been a real problem.
"Fortunately, artists always complain. The Theater Meeting is a huge prestige item for them; they scheme to be part of it every year. It wasn't intended to be this kind of Olympiad of the theater, but that's what it is for the artists themselves."
The upshot, Mr. Mass said, was that Berlin did not reduce its support, and Bonn, after threatening to end its subsidy next year, has now guaranteed continued assistance at this year's level.
The entire state and city subsidy comes to only about $1.5 million; Mr. Mass called it "the most cost-efficient festival in the world." The money is spent on theater rentals in Berlin and transportation for the non-Berlin productions and for sending the nine jury members, all journalistic critics, foraging about central Europe in search of excellence.
 
Selecting the Winners
 Each member sees some 200 performances a year out of about 6,000 in the German-speaking world. This year, 250 productions were considered and 82 were chosen as semifinalists and seen by a majority of the jury before the final 12 were selected. (After the reunification of Germany, the number of productions was raised to 12 from 10 and the jury was expanded to 9 from 7.)
The costs of paying the actors and touring backstage personnel are borne by the theaters lucky enough to be selected to participate. They are willing to pay partly because being chosen is enormously prestigious, but also because government-supported German repertory theaters have their personnel on annual contracts and must pay them wherever they perform.
This year, 5 of the 12 productions were staged originally by theaters from Berlin. Naturally, that reduces travel costs, but Mr. Mass insisted that the high number of Berlin productions had nothing to do with cost-cutting.
"In 1991 we had six Berlin productions," he said. "Ever since the fall of the wall, Berlin has become an unparalleled magnet for directors, designers and actors. All the artists want to come here. And whenever you have a theater with a new artistic director, you get a burst of good productions. Which is what happened in 1991 and 1993."
 
An Exercise in Excess
 The big burst of energy this year came from the Volksbuhne on the Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz in the eastern part of the city, where the director Frank Castorf took over this season as artistic director. Mr. Castorf's staging of "King Lear," an archetypally Germanic exercise in screaming, bloody excess that was really more about Mr. Castorf's ideas about Germany (he's agin it) than about Shakespeare, set the tone. (It was also full of a humor so leaden as to make the word "Teutonic" sound fluffy.)
Another Volksbuhne offering, by the Swiss director, author and composer Christoph Marthaler, had the untranslatable title of "Murx den Europaer! Murx ihn! Murx ihn! Murx ihn! Murx ihn ab!" Murx seemed to be a play on Marx, and the two hours consisted of a numbing if occasionally droll study of German, especially East German, fatuities.
The whole thing was like a rather more verbal and musical (and somnolent) version of Pina Bausch's rambling evenings of theatrical choreography, as was Mr. Castorf's "Lear," which was like one of Miss Bausch's variants on a classic (as in her take on Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle"). Somewhat inconsistently, given the frequency with which directors cross over from theater to opera, the Theater Meeting avoids opera. It also avoids dance, except for Miss Bausch. She is not personally represented this year, but a coming piece of "choreographic theater" by Johann Kresnik sounds Bauschian indeed.
 
The New Generation
 Berlin is also represented by productions from the Berliner Ensemble, the Schaubuhne and the Deutsches Theater, all of which have new directors. But the real scope of this festival can be seen in its attention to other cities and especially to the German provinces. This year there are offerings from Bochum, Bonn, Leipzig, Bremen and Heidelberg.
The star of the 1993 Theater Meeting, and emblematic of the direction Mr. Mass feels the festival is taking, is the young director Leander Haussmann. Last Saturday Mr. Haussmann's Munich production of "Romeo and Juliet" opened the festival, which continues until May 20. The festival also includes, within its mere 12 items, another Haussmann Shakespeare staging, this time "A Midsummer Night's Dream" from Weimar. And the Schiller Theater in Berlin just happened to open yet another Haussmann production of a classic, Schiller's "Don Carlos," right before the Theater Meeting began.
Mr. Haussmann, to judge from "Romeo and Juliet," plays almost as loose with Shakespeare's text as Mr. Castorf does. But the mood is defiantly different: fanciful, playful, sexy and even charming. Mr. Haussmann stretches for effects and has too many ideas for the good of any one play or production. But he is most definitely a talent.
Mr. Mass boasted that a new generation of directors, those who succeeded the stern modernists of the post-1968 generation, has now been certified by the festival jury, ever au courant. But many of the productions on view still seem pretty grim and earnest and, yes, Germanic.
Of course, any jury is suspect, and this one's choices may not truly reflect the full range of theater in Germany, Austria and Switzerland. One senses a lingering prejudice, despite Mr. Haussmann's success, against post-modernist playfulness and unabashed scenic beauty, and some of the older directors may be slighted simply because their work is now familiar.
Mr. Mass is used to such complaints. "Every year there is a controversy," he said happily. "Everybody who is not chosen considers it a scandal."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 569 words

HEADLINE: Hold It While I Focus

 BODY:
Twice recently Bill Clinton has said that the White House needs more "focus." Focus is today's Beltway buzzword to explain the Administration's shapeless start. It's not wholly clear what Mr. Clinton intends to do, but two obvious adjustments are in order.
His first task is to reaffirm the priorities he arrived with. The man who likened himself to a laser beam has grown diffuse. Unless he fixes his attention on the key items -- the economy, health care, ethics legislation -- Congress and public will begin to wander. So far, his vaulting legislative ambitions have produced an agenda so loaded with worthy ideas that it's in danger of stopping dead. 
 The second thing that needs to be snapped into focus is the White House staff. Mr. Clinton conceded as much when he promised to give his amiable chief of staff, Thomas McLarty, another deputy. Jimmy Carter showed what happens at a White House without a dominating chief of staff. George Bush demonstrated the hazards of sticking with the wrong chief.
Only Mr. Clinton knows whether he wants Mr. McLarty eased aside or whether he just wants to help him, but the matter cannot be allowed to drift. One lesson so far is that campaign zeal and eager talk about "re-inventing" government do not convert automatically to orderly government. Sooner or later, the President has to learn that amateurism is his enemy. He was right to proceed quickly with his stimulus package. But his aides set him up for a knockout punch from the opposition by dismissing the Republicans as "irrelevant" -- an act of hubris that did not go unpunished.
Further miscalculations could be fatal to programs that Mr. Clinton really cares about, like health care reform. Anything carrying a $150 billion price tag will require salesmanship. But Mr. Clinton's architects, chiefly Ira Magaziner, show no inclination to open their secret deliberations to inspection. With every day that passes, they miss another chance to build public and Congressional support for whatever is being cooked up behind closed doors.
Besides opening up, Mr. Clinton might also ease up. Just when he was touting the virtues of discipline, his policy-making machine coughed up yet another big item -- an $8 billion plan to revitalize the cities -- and dumped it on an agenda that Congress has already found indigestible.
No wonder the focus is blurred. Asked for their sharpest memory of Mr. Clinton's February address to Congress, most people recall his pledge to tame the deficit by cutting spending and then raising taxes. Since then, however, the public has been pelted with headlines about this spending initiative or that; these reports, combined with Ross Perot's drumfire, have set people to wondering whether Mr. Clinton has forgotten about the deficit.
Mr. Clinton seems to have grasped the point. "What I think we need to do, frankly, is to get the focus back on the things that I have been working on from the beginning. Passing the major programs . . . making sure that Congress will adopt the spending cuts . . . reaffirming that I have no interest in raising taxes until spending is cut. . . ."
Mr. Clinton also said, "After all, I just got here." He's said that before, too, just the way he keeps saying he needs focus. But as Jimmy Carter learned when he spoke of malaise, the public soon grows impatient with people who talk about their problems without really seizing them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Gowanus Expressway Should Be Demolished, Not Rebuilt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have been following with interest and dismay the public discussion on Brooklyn's Gowanus Expressway reconstruction. Once again we have negotiations focusing on the terms without first analyzing the premise: that the Gowanus should be rebuilt. The rationale is that the expressway is deteriorated and is in danger of collapse. This is cause to demolish it! 
 The idea of spending $500 million on 3.8 miles of roadway that not only makes no significant transportation improvement but also does not meet Federal design standards is appalling. Ten years of traffic chaos beginning in Staten Island and Long Island through Brooklyn and into Manhattan, on streets that were not built for this traffic, is equally appalling. And if the past is any judge, both cost and time estimates are just starting points. At least Westway, for all its faults, would have added some value.
The elevated structure should be demolished and an at-grade roadway built, similar to West Street in Manhattan. This could be done in two years at less than 20 percent of the project's estimated cost. Brooklyn's Third Avenue, over which the elevated structure sits, could easily handle six lanes of traffic, with Second and Fourth Avenues supporting the excess traffic.
These funds could be used instead for important projects with significant economic impact: structural improvements are needed for the transportation hubs in downtown Brooklyn, including the Atlantic Avenue Terminal of the Long Island Rail Road. There are high-speed ferries, which have already been proved, and trolleys, which should be re-examined. Let's not repeat past mistakes but move ahead with sound transportation planning.
 
JOHN P. LAUFER
Brooklyn, April 28, 1993
 
The writer, a transportation planner, was assistant commissioner for New York City Operations, N.Y. State Department of Transportation, 1976-78.

HEADLINE: VAT's Invisibility Is a Dubious Virtue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Value-Added Tax," your April 26 Business Day news analysis, contains the astounding assertion that economists are attracted to the tax because "it is largely invisible; consumers pay it, but often do not see it, because it is usually incorporated quietly into the final retail price." 
 I believe that mainstream economics has a very different view on the desirability of "hidden taxes": The government should not undertake any spending unless the benefits to the citizenry exceed the costs. Therefore, unless citizens know their tax burdens, they cannot form sensible opinions about how much spending is desirable, and communicate these opinions to their elected representatives.
A good system of public finance requires that people know their tax burdens, not that these burdens be hidden.
 
HARVEY S. ROSEN
Professor of Economics, Princeton University
Princeton, N.J., April 30, 1993

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
What's So Funny About Bananas?

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
The word banana makes people smile; why?
Maybe it's the spelling. Hubert Horatio Humphrey, who knew he had a tendency to speechify at great length, liked to say, "I'm like the little boy who knew how to spell banana, but never knew when to stop." 
 Perhaps it's the sound that gives the word a comical air. "You say ba-NAA-nuh, I say ba-NAH-nuh," goes the lyric to the Gershwin song "Let's Call the Whole Thing Off"; it could be the NAA pronunciation that triggers the amusement.
Or it could be the fruit itself, a sunny yellow curved in the shape of a smile, as if to say, "Have a Nice Day." Denuded of its skin, the fruit offers us a banana peel, on which one slips to the great hilarity of onlookers.
In old American slang, banana oil means "nonsense" (its humorous connotation far different from snake oil, meaning "fraudulent"). A top banana is a leading comedian. To go bananas is to go crazy, and the nonsensical meaning is reflected in the verse of another 1930's song, "But Not for Me," from the Gershwins' "Girl Crazy": "I never want to hear/From any cheerful Pollyannas/Who tell you fate/Supplies a mate;/It's all bananas!"
A banana republic was not just a country that produced profits for the United Fruit Company; it was a country with a rinky-dink government, having "backwardness" as its hallmark (until the name was adopted by an American retailer; now it has a yuppie connotation). A banana boat is a very slow boat.
Economists know it's funny, too. When Alfred Kahn, Jimmy Carter's anti-inflation czar, was told by his political superiors never to use the word recession, he agreed to substitute the word banana; he was soon heard muttering about "the worst banana you ever saw."
Perhaps it is the context that gives the word its humor. Let's deal with the word in a serious vein and see if a context of gravity wipes the smile off our face.
A recent front-page article in The New York Times, headlined "A Forbidden Fruit in Europe: Latin Bananas Face Hurdles," dealt with the crisis being felt by banana growers in the face of new quotas and tariffs by the European Community protectionists. That's surely serious, affecting profits, jobs, international relations, calling for all due solemnity.
In a letter to The Times, Daniel R. Katz, executive director of the Rainforest Alliance, swamped the banana growers with additional charges of using pesticides and fertilizers and converting rain forests into "monocultures" (evidently the bugaboo of multiculturalists). He wrote: "My organization has begun a voluntary program called the Smart Banana Project, to work with banana producers in improving their environmental standards without affecting productivity."
This line caused me to fall out of my chair. Why? Surely Mr. Katz's point -- "we support reform of the banana industry, rather than a boycott" -- is a serious one, not funny in the least. Then why do we smile at the prospect of the need for banana reform, and double up in consideration of the Smart Banana Project? If health reform is important, why is not banana reform? If smart bombs are not funny, why are smart bananas? (Just envision those smart bananas, dropped from a banana plane, zeroing in on the banana boycotters in the rain forest; oh, what a lovely war.)
Straighten those faces; let's try again. In the current issue of The International Economy, an article by Klaus C. Engelen, an editor of Handelsblatt in Dusseldorf, is headed "Is Helmut Kohl Cracking Up?" The piece discusses the pervasive Endzeitstimmung, the mood that the regime is coming to an end, and gives five reasons why Chancellor Kohl, though often highly regarded abroad, is so resented at home.
These reasons for the potential downfall of a Western leader range from "For not shutting the borders sooner on floods of asylum seekers" to "For letting bureaucrats from Brussels cause mass layoffs in Germany's steel plants."
Then comes the crusher: "For standing by as the French protect bananas from their former colonies, forcing the Germans to eat expensive, puny, shabby bananas."
Does Kohl realize he is about to be done in by the fallout from puny bananas? Is there a word in the German language for "shabby bananas," and does Helmut Kohl know it?
I rest my case: there is no way of dealing seriously with the Banana Question. Nobody with a straight face is going to fight for banana reform because bananas, smart or shabby, are inherently funny. ("When you get to my age," says octogenarian Milton Berle, "you don't buy green bananas.") Chomsky, get onto this: it must have something to do with the deep structure of the word itself.
 
 
WHENCE WHITE?
 THE WORD WHITE, AS A racial description that used to be euphemized as "Caucasian," is being blackened.
In one of his sprightly, insightful (why am I doing a blurb when he hasn't written a book?) essays in U.S. News & World Report, John Leo addressed "The demonizing of white men." He opened with a grabber of a lead: "Attention, men of the Caucasoid persuasion."
In a Washington Post article about the Financial Accounting Standards Board, Jay Mathews wrote that the F.A.S.B.'s (sometimes pronounced FAS-bee's) "members are drawn from the upper reaches of the accounting profession, and have so far been all male and all European American." My colleague Floyd Norris, in the Times financial news section, notes this usage and wonders: "The new euphemism for white?"
Caucasia is a region between the Black and Caspian Seas that takes in parts of Russia, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan, and is marked by the Caucasus Mountains. The term Caucasian was used by the German anthropologist Johann Friedrich Blumenbach around 1800 to describe whites, who he thought originated there; other 19th-century anthropologists expanded the area to Europe and North Africa, with the people of darker as well as lighter skins, but the whole racial category was abandoned by most scientists a century ago.
What, then, to call people who are not what used to be called black or yellow or brown or red? I see nothing that has to be euphemized about any of those colors, so long as you don't pretend it represents scientific differentiation. White is loosely nearly accurate, though a case can be made for the word chosen by the actor Peter Ustinov when asked his color; he wrote in "pink."
