HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Figuring the Cost of Car Rentals in Europe

BYLINE: By JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT; JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT is an editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
IF you think air fares are confusing, wait till you contemplate renting a car in Europe. Not only are there a multitude of variables to consider (type of transmission, mileage allowance, insurance coverage, taxes, car size and currency exchange), but there are also such questions as whether to make a reservation, whether to prepay, whether to pay a surcharge for the convenience of picking up the car at the airport and whether to choose longer-term leasing over short-term renting.
Even a survey of only three major rental companies with headquarters in the United States -- Avis, Hertz and National -- opens a can of worms. The companies were asked to supply details on the countries where a visitor to western Europe would be most likely to find the least-expensive economy cars for one week in the summer season and, for comparison, the cost of upgrading to the least-expensive car with automatic transmission. Only two of the three companies gave a breakdown of basic rates and rates with the collision-damage waiver (C.D.W.). Avis offered rates as an inclusive package with unlimited mileage, waiver and tax, or as an exclusive package with unlimited mileage only. All three offered unlimited mileage with a weekly rental; not all do for a one-day rental.
 
The C.D.W. Factor

As most people who have rented cars in the United States know, one complicating factor is the collision- damage waiver (C.D.W.), which is not actually true insurance. The car-rental companies are not selling a policy; they are collecting an extra fee for offering to forgive the cost of any damage. Like the basic car rental rates, the C.D.W. fee can be as much or as little as the traffic will bear. 
 Most major credit-card companies now offer coverage to protect cardholders who decline C.D.W.'s, but it is wise to make sure that the type of card being used has such a feature before deciding that the price of the the waiver -- typically $10 to $20 a day -- will not be a factor in figuring the final cost.
Because all three companies surveyed said that Americans would pay the least if they reserved a car before leaving the United States, packages requiring reservations were used for the following comparison. Avis cited two packages: Super Value, which sounded as if it would be the cheaper, and Discover Europe, which turned out to be the better deal. The name of the Hertz package is Affordable Europe, and the National package is called European Advansaver.
A driver considering either of the Avis plans must make a reservation in North America. For the Discover Europe rate, the reservation must be made at least 14 days before picking up the car; for the Super Value rate, the reservation must be made 48 hours in advance. In both cases, the caller will be quoted a rate in dollars based on the prevailing rate in the country and the exchange rate in effect on the day of the call. But the traveler will not have to prepay. The actual price may vary, however, because of a change in exchange rates by the time the car is picked up. The dollar amount may also be affected by the exchange rate in effect when the final cash or credit-card transaction is completed.
Like the least expensive Avis plan, the cheapest Hertz package also requires a reservation at least 14 days ahead, but the renter must prepay at the time of reserving. The price will be the rate prevailing in local currency on the day of the reservation, converted to dollars at that day's exchange rate.
The National plan also requires a reservation at least 14 days in advance and prepayment at the prevailing local currency rate, converted to dollars at the exchange rate in effect when the reservation is made.
All three companies charge a $50 fee if a reservation is canceled. Hertz also charges a $50 fee if changes are made in a reservation after 48 hours of the original reservation.
Here is how the rates for the three companies compared in late April for a car to be used this summer:
Avis said its least expensive economy-size car (a size above mini, which is generally regarded as too small for extensive travel) was a Volkswagen Polo with manual transmission for $257 in Germany. That rate included the C.D.W. and value added tax (V.A.T.) of 15 percent. Without the waiver, but with tax, it was $143. The next-cheapest Avis car was an Opel Corsa for $269 in Portugal, including the waiver and tax. With tax only, it was $253.
Hertz said its least expensive economy-size car was a Ford Fiesta (manual) for $215, including C.D.W. and 16 percent V.A.T., in Portugal -- but available at that rate only through June 30 and from Oct. 1 through March 31. Without the waiver, but with tax, it was $158. The rate from July 1 through Sept. 30 was $270 with waiver and tax, $253 with tax only. Hertz offers a Ford Fiesta in Belgium with waiver and 19.5 percent V.A.T. at the same price, $270. With tax but without waiver, the price was only $180.
National said its least expensive economy-size car was a Renault Clio (manual) for $223 in Britain. The rate included C.D.W. and V.A.T. of 17.5 percent. With tax only, it was $175. National's rates for a Renault Clio in Portugal through June 31 were $269 with waiver and tax, $180 with tax only. The rates from July 1 through Sept. 30 were $288 with waiver and tax, $220 with tax only.
Travelers who require automatic transmission pay a premium. To upgrade to the least-expensive class with automatic, the comparison showed that Avis would rent a VW Golf in Germany for $474, including C.D.W. and V.A.T. Without the waiver but with tax, it was $336. In Portugal, the Avis rates for an automatic (VW Vento) were $644 with waiver and tax, $588 with tax alone.
The Hertz rates for an automatic (Ford Sierra) in Belgium were $515 with C.D.W. and V.A.T., $378 with tax only. In Portugal rates for an automatic (Ford Orion) in the low season were $573 with waiver and tax, $501 with tax alone. In high season the rates were $645 with waiver and tax, $573 with tax alone.
National's rates for a Renault 19 with automatic in Britain were $354 with C.D.W. and V.A.T., $294 with tax alone. National's low-season rates for an automatic in Portugal (Renault 19) were $488 with waiver and tax, $454 with tax alone. In high season, the rates were $628 and $594, respectively.
One thing to keep in mind about automatics in Europe is that not all rental locations carry midsize or compact models, which means that the driver who insists on an automatic may have to rent a full-size car at much higher rates.
 
Variables Affecting Rates
 Another point to consider is that rates are subject to change. During research for this article, a call was made to Avis for more information, and it was learned that some rates had changed in just two weeks. "All rates are subject to change," the spokeswoman said.
Another factor that will throw off comparison shopping is surcharges at some airports. Austria imposes a 7 percent charge on the total bill. The charge in Brussels is 9 percent, in Italy 10 percent and in Switzerland 6 percent. A flat fee of about $6 is in effect in Germany and about $8 in Amsterdam. Renters wishing to avoid the surcharge will have to pick up their cars at downtown offices.
Those needing a car for more than a week are likely to save money by leasing, since longer-term rates are generally lower than weekly rates, especially starting after two weeks. A Ford Fiesta, for example, is offered by Auto Europe in France for $524 for 14 days and $704 for 21 days. The rates include unlimited mileage, C.D.W. and V.A.T. A similar longer-term arrangement, which works like a lease but is called purchase-repurchase, is offered by some manufacturers. Renault, for example, charges $695 for a Clio for 23 days; this includes C.D.W. No tax is required.
For further information and reservations, here are the numbers to call:
Auto Europe, (800) 223-5555.
Avis, (800) 331-1084.
Hertz, (800) 654-3001.
National, (800) 227-3876.
Renault Eurodrive, (800) 221-1052 and, in the western United States, (800) 477-7116.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1336 words

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
Jazz and Politics Meet Over the Keyboard

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
Gonzalo Rubalcaba was playing "Green Dolphin Street" on a beat-up electric piano at a Havana jazz festival in 1986 when the American bassist Charlie Haden, who has worked with most of the great jazz pianists of the last 30 years, saw him for the first time. He was immediately dazzled. "I fell on the floor and asked, 'Who is that guy,' his solo was so unbelievable," Mr. Haden recalled recently. "He was 23 at the time, but it was like hearing a combination of Art Tatum, Herbie Hancock and Bill Evans."
Since that encounter, which led to a recording contract and invitations with Mr. Haden to perform abroad, musicians and audiences around the world have had much the same response to Mr. Rubalcaba's music, a heady mixture of Latin and classical influences and jazz. 
 The 30-year-old Cuban pianist has been a featured artist at the Montreux Jazz Festival and performed acoustic piano duets with Chick Corea in Japan. Six of his albums have now been released in the United States to critical acclaim and comparisons to keyboard giants like Keith Jarrett and McCoy Tyner; three albums were recorded with his Cuban fusion group Proyecto through the German label Messidor, and three were piano trios released by Blue Note through a licensing agreement with a Japanese label. A new album, "Suites 4 and 20," is due out later this month on Blue Note.
But because of the mutual emnity between the United States and Fidel Castro, Mr. Rubalcaba (pronounced Roo-bal-CA-bah), like other Cuban artists, has never been able to obtain the visa that would allow him to perform in this country.
The Clinton Administration has taken a different tack, however, and on Friday Mr. Rubalcaba will make his American debut at Alice Tully Hall as part of the "Jazz at Lincoln Center" series organized by Wynton Marsalis. Mr. Rubalcaba will play in three different formats -- solo, with Mr. Haden and the drummer Jack de Johnette and as leader of an all-Cuban quartet.
Mr. Rubalcaba still cannot be paid for performances in the United States, and whether the exception granted him will be extended to other Cuban artists remains to be seen. But the magnitude of the moment does not escape him. "It is a political miracle," he said with a grin during an interview at the Santo Domingo apartment where he has lived since last year with his wife, Maria, and two young sons, Joao and Joan.
Cuba hardly ever grants artists the right to live outside the country, to decide when, where or with whom they will perform, or to keep the compensation for their services. That policy of controlling "cultural workers" has contributed to embarrassing defections that have robbed the Castro regime of some of its most prominent artists: the saxophonist Paquito d'Rivera, the trumpeter Arturo Sandoval, the painters Arturo Cuenca and Tomas Esson, and the dancer Jorge Esquivel. But Mr. Rubalcaba is one of Cuba's last internationally recognized cultural treasures and the Government, weakened by growing economic and social problems, has been forced to show unusual flexibility in dealing with him.
"I have not broken with Cuba and do not wish to do so, but neither does my situation follow the habitual model," Mr. Rubalcaba said. "In my specific case, there has been a reciprocal process. I presented myself to the Cuban authorities and told them that this was a time for me to advance my work outside the country, that I needed a space to develop. I had decided that I should be the source of my own economic support, and I told them all the conditions I needed to work, and it produced positive results from the start. I have my family here, but I maintain the connection with my country, which is something important to my work."
As a member of one of Havana's most distinguished musical families, Mr. Rubalcaba is very much aware of, and draws from, his roots in Cuban popular culture. His grandfather, Jacobo, was a conductor and composer remembered today as the author of "El Cadete Constitucional," one of the most famous songs of a style known as danzon. His father, Guillermo, is a well-known pianist who for many years played in the orchestra of Enrique Jorrin, inventor of the cha-cha. As early as age 4, Mr. Rubalcaba joined some of Cuba's finest musicians in jam sessions in his family's living room, playing not piano but his first love, percussion.
"To me at that point, the piano was nothing more than a piece of furniture that decorated the house and at which my older brother sat down to practice five or six hours a day," he said. "What I liked were drums, congas, tambourines, timbales."
By the age of 8, Mr. Rubalcaba was enrolled in a Havana conservatory, where he studied classical piano and Afro-Cuban percussion. He turned professional while still a teen-ager, and by the time he was 20, he had already toured Africa and France as a member of Orquestra Aragon, one of Cuba's most renowned dance bands.
More recently, he has maintained a presence in the pop world through Proyecto and by playing piano on two albums by the Latin music star Juan Luis Guerra and working with salsa and merengue performers in the Dominican Republic, a country he chose as his residence because "the food, the language, the culture, the weather, the racial composition are nearly the same as Cuba's."
In the end, though, Mr. Rubalcaba always comes back to jazz, a form of music eager to absorb Cuban influences. Mr. Rubalcaba was first exposed to swing and be-bop through the 78 r.p.m. records in his father's collection. "I have always been of the opinion that jazz, even more than Cuban music, offers the creative musician the greatest latitude," he said. "It allows one to express oneself with more freedom, and at the moment of sitting down at the instrument it permits a state of virginity that is profoundly refreshing."
Though a formidable composer himself, Mr. Rubalcaba is fond of taking Latin classics like "Besame Mucho" or "Perfidia" -- as well as pop standards ranging from Jerome Kern to the Beatles -- and adapting them to his own eclectic purposes. "These are the hymns of our time and our continent," he said. "They have been performed by so many people in so many different forms. They offer a world of subtleties and a means to recapture a time when melody and theme were dominant."
Mr. Rubalcaba's peers admire his quest for artistic freedom, but some, especially Cuban artists exiled in the United States, criticize his political attitudes. "Gonzalito is an incredible, amazing musician, but he is letting them use him," said Mr. d'Rivera, who is now an American citizen. "What they want is to avoid his escaping, so they give him more freedom than anybody in Cuba has. He is trying to live in two worlds, but the contradictions are too great, and a point comes when no matter how nicely you are treated, you have to be embarrassed to see other people persecuted and dying of hunger. In life, it's more important to live with dignity than to be a great artist."
But Mr. Rubalcaba argues that he is not obliged to conform to the expectations or dogma of either Communist bureaucrats in Havana or their opponents. "I don't think I should play the part of a political functionary," he said. "I wouldn't even know how to dress, much less act, the part. I think the artist does to a certain extent represent the values of a society, but I am not a spokesman for any particular attitudes. The only way I know to speak is through my music."
If the Lincoln Center appearance goes well and Washington permits, Mr. Rubalcaba would like to tour and record in the United States. He would also like to work with American musicians ranging "from Pat Metheny to Al Foster," he says, in an effort to reanimate the traditional dialogue between jazz and Cuban music that began with his idol, Dizzy Gillespie. Can he also imagine living in the country where jazz was born? "I haven't ruled it out, but it's not my decision to make," he said with a cautious smile. "You'll have to ask the State Department about that."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1070 words

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Investor Buys a Major Piece of Stamford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
ALMOST 20 percent of Stamford's 6.4 million square feet of prime downtown office space has been rescued from foreclosure by Zell/Merrill Lynch of Chicago, one of the nation's largest real estate investment concerns.
With the acquisition last month of 1.2 million square feet in five buildings, for which it paid $132 million, Zell/Merrill Lynch Real Estate Opportunity Partners Limited Partnership became the largest office landlord in Stamford, which has a total of 13.6 million square feet of offices. 
 Most of the newly acquired properties are on Tresser Boulevard: 300 Atlantic Street (on the corner of Atlantic and Tresser), Four Stamford Forum, Six Stamford Forum, and 301 Tresser Boulevard, formerly Eight Stamford Forum and once the headquarters of the Singer Company.
All the structures were built and owned by the F.D. Rich Company, local developers who rebuilt the downtown core under a 1960's urban renewal contract.
Brian Lipson, vice president for Zell/Merrill Lynch acquisitions in Chicago, said that Connecticut was the company's first stop in New England.
"We were waiting for pricing expectations to come into line with market values," he said, "and I suspect that if we had bought these properties earlier we would have paid 20 percent more."
The only Stamford acquisition that was not a Rich property is Canterbury Green, a 100 percent leased office-residential complex that wound up in foreclosure when J.C. Penney, one of the owners, divested itself of its real estate holdings. The Bank of New York sold it, together with 301 Tresser Boulevard, to Zell/Merrill Lynch. The rest of the buildings were bought from Citicorp.
The F.D. Rich family-owned empire began crumbling when overbuilding caught up with it as the recession took hold in the late 80's. Today, of the dozen central-business-district office buildings it once controlled it owns only the 250,000-square-foot Ten Stamford Forum and the 900,000-square-foot Stamford Town Center mall. The rest were taken back by lenders in foreclosures.
Even the Rich company's signature Landmark Towers, an 820,000-square-foot complex of five office buildings that houses the company headquarters, reverted to Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which had refinanced the complex in 1989 with $114 million.
Drawing on one of two $430 million acquisition funds comprising investments from some 30 corporate and public pension funds, Zell/Merrill Lynch "seeks to acquire well-located, well-built properties in markets we believe longterm are good places to be," Mr. Lipson said.
The company buys properties at considerably less than their replacement cost, manages them through six regional offices of its affiliate, First Office Management, and holds them for at least 10 years.
Properties are acquired with 50 percent leverage, so the full value is calculated at twice the amount invested, Mr. Lipson said. Citicorp financed 80 percent of the Rich property acquisitions, but "that will be balanced out by cash purchases elsewhere," said Mr. Lipson. The funds were set up in 1987 and 1991 and a third is expected to be capitalized soon at $500 million.
Excluding the new Stamford acquisitions, Zell/Merrill Lynch owns 72 buildings in 22 states. Its holding company, the Equity Group of Chicago, headed by Samuel Zell, owns a total of 250 properties valued at $5 billion, including the partnership's buildings.
ZELL/MERRILL LYNCH first ventured into Connecticut in November 1991 with the purchase of Shelton Pointe, a 162,000-square-foot building in Shelton, at the northern border of Fairfield County.
"A lot of people have invested in Shelton," said Mr. Lipson, citing the American branch of Auguste-Thouard, a major French real estate firm, and Robert Scinto, a Greenwich developer. "We are all having a good experience there."
In 18 months Shelton Pointe's occupancy has risen from 32 percent to 65 percent. Kevin Foley, the building's leasing agent from Rostenberg-Dorn in Stamford, said "outright purchases like this bring stability to the market and peace of mind to the tenants."
Some $500,000 has been spent upgrading the lobby, landscaping and parking area and installing a fitness room and cafeteria.
By early September a new northeast regional headquarters for the Zell/Merrill Lynch partnership will be established in Stamford off the lobby of Six Stamford Forum. Its function will be to acquire and manage properties from Virginia to Maine. Patrick D. Lerch, vice president of First Office Management, will be in charge.
In addition to increasing occupancy of the newly acquired buildings, which are 80 percent occupied and already producing substantial cash flow, Mr. Lerch said that "there will be a lot of hands-on, service-oriented activity. We want to attract retail and amenity tenants as well as office tenants."
HE said that 300 Atlantic Street, with its accessible, windowed ground floor, was well suited to retailers, while the Forum buildings would accommodate interior service businesses for tenants.
Margaret Carlson, a former Rich employee, is now the leasing agent at First Office Management for 300 Atantic Street, and Four and Six Stamford Forum, with an aggregate of 735,500 square feet, of which 24,000 square feet were rented in the past month.
Among the tenants in the five buildings are Price Waterhouse & Company, ABB Financial Services, American Tobacco Company, Re-Capital Corporation, Hewlett Packard's marketing/sales office and Reuters America's regional office.
Albert B. Ashforth Inc. of Stamford handles leasing for 301 Tresser Boulevard. According to Jeffrey H. Gage, a vice president at Ashforth, the 240,000-square-foot building "is half empty and has one of the largest blocks of vacant space available downtown -- floors 12 through 15 containing a total of 90,000 square feet."
Company downsizing has kept vacancies at a persistent 20-plus percent, with rental activity generally sluggish for more than three years. John Rostenberg, a principal at Rostenberg-Dorn, pegs sublease offerings at $12 to $27 a foot and direct space at $17 to $22 a foot. "Landlords are offering lower rent or free rent, but trying to stay away from expensive construction costs," he said.
Mr. Lipson said he believed bargains would continue to be found "even after the recession" because "with all the excess capacity it will be a long time before demand rises enough to push prices up."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: Williamsburg Houses;
A $35 Million Fix For a 1938 Complex

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
IT was one of the triumphal moments of modernism in New York: 12 city blocks of decrepit slums rebuilt into three superblocks of International Style housing.
But although Brooklyn's 1938 Williamsburg Houses did deliver on its promise of a new order of clean cities and factory-style garden apartments, it skipped established lessons of basic construction, and now the New York City Housing Authority is spending $35 million to repair the damage. 
 In 1936, under the direction of the Federal Public Works Administration, the city's Housing Authority began a giant complex of four-story buildings on a site in Williamsburg bounded by Bushwick Avenue and Leonard, Maujer and Scholes Streets. Selecting an architect involved accepting or repudiating modernism, a subject of bitter dispute in the architectural profession.
William Lescaze, a Swiss emigre and exponent of modernism, was chosen to head the architectural team and the resulting design was the first demonstration in the United States of the modern style in mass housing.
Instead of buildings in a long perimeter around a central garden court -- the approach used in the same year at the authority's Harlem River Houses -- the Williamsburg project was divided into 20 separate structures of staggered design and arrangement set at a slight angle to the street and surrounded by grass and playgrounds.
The concrete floor slabs were brought out and made part of the facades. The metal windows, plain brick walls and spare detailing gave the project a definite industrial air. Tenants for the 1,622 units were chosen for job stability and whether their current housing had been built before 1900.
Williamsburg Houses does make a striking and impressive statement against its surroundings of still-decaying wooden houses and walk-up tenements. But two leading critics of the period were not uniformly pleased. Lewis Mumford, writing in The New Yorker under the headline "The New Order," called the architect's contention that the odd angle increased the amount of sunlight "a little silly" and noted that the irregular building outline reduced that advantage.
Talbot Hamlin, writing in Pencil Points, said Williamsburg Houses was "a place where children would be glad to grow up," with landscaping, light, air and planning "better than the most expensive apartments of Park Avenue." But he also criticized the mechanical regularity of the design and the "shameful" construction, noting "walls full of water" and other problems.
"If we cannot build well in the newest and most loudly advertised ways, let us build well in the older, proven ways" he wrote.
Now is a good time to tour Williamsburg Houses. It still has a radically progressive atmosphere. But it also has giant scars along its brick walls and especially the concrete slabs. The water that Hamlin saw in the 30's continued to penetrate the outer walls. Perhaps a tenth of the bricks have spalled off badly and the rest are deteriorating. Internal steel reinforcing bars have rusted, popping off grapefruit-size chunks of concrete.
THE Federal P.W.A. construction workers were inexperienced and not supervised closely enough. They laid the steel reinforcing too close to the edge of the forms into which the concrete was poured.
But there was also a basic design problem: Lescaze's team left out the normal devices -- flashing and weepholes -- that permit internal water to escape. Rainwater was drawn into the wall at the bottom of each of the chamfered, concrete slabs, which did not have the ridge-like drip caps at the bottom.
Neil Cohen, director of design for the Housing Authority, feels strongly about the architectural significance of Williamsburg Houses and the authority has, voluntarily, approached the Landmarks Preservation Commission for approval of its project.
The buildings are widely considered notable works, but are not designated landmarks. The concrete slabs will be rebuilt, with drip caps, and the modernistic entranceways are restored to something like their original appearance. Every brick will be removed and replaced with new ones to match, about 5.7 million in all, says Douglas McNevin, assistant director of construction.
Most of the repairs are being designed by the engineers Goodkind and O'Dea, and the landmarks issues are being supervised by the architects Vincek & Petrocci.
Two recent alterations -- inappropriate new windows and crudely designed brick replacement on the stair towers -- will not be remedied, but the Williamsburg Houses are notable for the promises its original architects envisioned and the ones its current owners did not have to make.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 1,622-unit Williamsburg Houses in Brooklyn, built in 1938, will be renovated at a cost of $35 million. (Bettmann Archive, 1938)

HEADLINE: Officials Seek to Widen Jury-Duty Lists

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A RECENT survey by the Eagleton Institute of Politics shows that 63 percent of those summoned for jury duty in the state never actually serve. Included in that figure, some legal experts say, are many people who never respond to jury summonses.
What causes such numbers, experts say, are legal exemptions from jury duty, based on occupation, and lists that are inadequate to identify all potential jurors. In addition, thousands of residents simply disregard the summonses and are never pursued. 
 As a result, and in an effort to develop larger juror pools, the State Assembly is considering legislation that would eliminate all occupational exemptions from jury service and raise the fees paid to jurors. Meanwhile, court officials in some counties are threatening people who ignore their jury summonses with sanctions including fines and jail.
"We're losing more people than we should be losing," said Michael Garrahan, chief of the technical assistance unit of the Administrative Office of the Courts. "I think we're going to have to try a little harder."
Under current law, Mr. Garrahan said, jury panels in criminal and civil trials are chosen from juror pools made up of residents summoned by the Superior Court in the county in which they live. In New Jersey, jurors must be United States citizens without criminal records between 18 and 75 years old.
The names of prospective jurors, Mr. Garrahan said, are drawn from two statewide lists: one of registered voters and one of licensed drivers. He said those two lists were used because they provided court officials with the broadest compilation of names possible. "I guess the original intention would be to have everyone eligible for jury service," he said.
The two lists are merged into one by court officials in each county, who then draw names of potential jurors from the merged list.
But some officials say that doesn't insure that everyone eligible for jury service will be on the list.
"I know people who neither vote nor drive," said Lois Powers, jury manager for Gloucester County. "That lets out a lot of people."
Ms. Powers, and other jury managers interviewed, say it is impossible to estimate the number of eligible residents who are not summoned because their names do not appear on either of the two lists.
But that, Ms. Powers said, is only part of the problem. In many cases, she said, summoning prospective jurors is no guarantee that they will actually serve.
"We summon 300 jurors a day," she said. "And out of those 300 people we yield approximately 100 eligible jurors."
The 200 other people, she said, are excused for various reasons, the most common being statutory exemptions.
"A lot of people are exempt," Ms. Powers said, including police officers, fish and game wardens, hospital workers and people with minor children and no one else to care for them.
Legal exemptions reduce the juror pool by nearly two-thirds in some counties, but officials face another problem.
"I would say that word has gotten out that in New Jersey nothing is done if you don't show up for jury duty," Ms. Powers said.
In Gloucester County, she said, between 20 and 25 percent of those summoned and deemed eligible to serve fail to show up.
"Unfortunately, we're all understaffed," Ms. Powers said. "I would say that the solution would be that if they did not show up after two warnings, a warrant should be issued to appear before the assignment judge. But as yet, nothing of that nature has been done."
Martin L. Haines, a retired assignment judge from Burlington County, agreed that little is done about people who ignore jury summonses. Mr. Haines, who is now director of the Institute for Law and Justice Inc., a nonprofit public interest organization, said his organization had commissioned a study of the state court system by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.
Included in the study, conducted at the end of 1992, were questions on jury service that revealed that 44 percent of those summoned did not report and that 19 percent reported but did not serve.
"That sounded pretty poor indeed," Mr. Haines said, adding that he had written a column about the problem in a recent issue of The New Jersey Law Journal. "My column said that no one was really doing much about it," he said. "And neither did I when I was the assignment judge."
The main reason that court officials in some counties do not pursue those who fail to appear for jury duty is cost.
"Mailing costs for jury summonses are pretty high," Mr. Haines said. "It wouldn't take very many mailings to ruin your budget."
 
Many Incorrect Addresses
 But there is another reason, he said. "We, too, make mistakes," he said. "The addresses we have for people aren't always correct. I've brought people into court who didn't show up for grand jury and I ended up embarrassed," he said, explaining that the notices had been mailed to the wrong addresses.
"I hauled them in and wasted a half a day of their time, and it was really because our records weren't current," he said.
Officials in most counties provide prospective jurors with two notices for jury service. The first is a form questionnaire to determine eligibility; the second, a jury summons or a follow-up if the form isn't returned. If the person doesn't report for duty, or fails to respond to the two notices, officials may issue an arrest warrant.
But that threat is rarely followed through, officials say.
"They don't even arrest fugitives from justice," said John Cannel, executive director of the New Jersey Law Revision Commission, a state commission reviewing the state's laws.
"In the old days, you would believe that if you didn't fill out the form, lightning would strike you," Mr. Cannel said. "Nowadays, what are you going to get, a couple of warnings?"
 
Undermining of System Seen
 Mr. Cannel said blatant disregard of summonses and legal exemptions from service undermined the jury system.
"If you have to impanel a jury for a 12-week trial, are you really going to get a cross section of the community?" he said. "Who can give up their life for 12 weeks? Who can give up their job for 12 weeks? What you're getting are people who are retired and people who are on unemployment."
Defense lawyers agree.
"The younger people are scared to serve," said Walter Lucas, a former deputy attorney general now in private practice in Eatontown. "They say, 'If I miss two weeks of work, my boss will fire me,' " he said. Since that concern is insufficient for an exemption, the judge will typically require the juror to serve. But that, Mr. Lucas said, can cause problems for litigants.
"Do I want to risk having someone on the jury who is so preoccupied about losing their job that they won't follow the evidence?" he said.
 
Concern Over Neutrality
 Marcia Wenk, acting legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, agreed.
"One of the fundamentals we rely on in using juries is that they will be impartial and willing to serve," Ms. Wenk said. "If they are disgruntled, there is less of a likelihood that they will put aside biases and be neutral at the outset."
Small pools of prospective jurors, Ms. Wenk said, put added strain on the system.
"It means that many jurors are called more than once, and it places a greater burden on those willing to serve," she said. Moreover, she said, the current system of compiling prospective juror lists from drivers' licenses and voter registrations might also skew juror pools racially and economically.
"It will often exclude people from urban centers and minority jurors, because I think there is a very low voter registration rate in the minority community in some urban areas," she said, adding that the use of driver's license lists somewhat makes up for that shortcoming.
 
A Lack of Resources
 Mr. Cannel of the law revision commission said the current system was failing because it did not provide a broad enough pool of jurors, and because officials did not have the resources to enforce every jury summons that was ignored.
"It isn't that they don't want to know the answers," Mr. Cannel said. "It's just that they haven't gotten around to really figuring out what's going on."
One way to enlarge the juror pool, he said, is to eliminate the statutory exemptions. His commission has proposed legislation that would do just that. That legislation, he said, sponsored by Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg, Democrat of Fort Lee, is now on second reading before the Assembly.
Another bill, now before the State Senate Judiciary Committee, would increase the fees jurors are paid to $20 a day from $5.
Mr. Cannel said another way to increase the juror pool was to use other lists in addition to the registered voter and driver's license lists. One possibility would be those who file state income tax returns.
Even better, he said, would be lists of people on unemployment, welfare and Social Security. But those lists, he said, are not available because of Federal privacy laws.

 
'All the Excusing'
 Yet another way to increase the pool of prospective jurors, officials say, is to make sure that those who are summoned actually show up.
"We summon 400 jurors a week," said Elizabeth Domingo, assistant administrator of jury management for Hudson County. "But after all the excusing and postponing prior to the reporting date, we're down to half that many. Then, on the first reporting date, about 20 percent fail to report."
But rather than let that 20 percent fall through the cracks, Ms. Domingo said, court officials in Hudson County are tracking them down.
"After check-in, we pull the names of those who fail to report, and we call them," she said. If a person cannot be contacted by telephone, she said, a county sheriff's officer is dispatched to the person's home to find out why he failed to appear and to suggest that he contact the jury manager's office immediately.
"For those who still fail to respond, we send them 'contempt of court' letters," Ms. Domingo said, explaining that a contempt of court charge for ignoring a jury summons can result in a fine.
And in the event that doesn't work, she said, officials in Hudson County are now establishing a procedure whereby the assignment judge of the county can issue an order requiring an individual to appear before him to explain the reason the jury summons went unanswered. If the person fails to appear before the assignment judge, Ms. Domingo said, the judge can issue a bench warrant for the person's arrest.
"We haven't arrested anybody," Ms. Domingo said. "But we do go after them. We work on them on a daily basis."

HEADLINE: Jersey City Journal;
After Fires, Neighbors Seek to 'Pull Together'

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
THE effect of the four-alarm blaze that swept through the Bergen Hill historic district here early last month wasn't limited to the damage to eight Victorian row houses. Residents say the fire left a legacy beyond charred wooden beams, broken windows boarded over with cheap plywood and roofs mangled as if from the bite of a giant predator.
The fierce blaze, they say, also damaged a sense of confidence and security they had gained over the years. On Astor Place, the brick houses had been a monument to bygone days when drugs were sold only from pharmacies and the sound of sirens accompanied horse-drawn fire wagons, not the police. 
 "People around here have worked long and hard for what they have and beyond the financial investment in this area, what we have is pride," said Dennis G. Doran, a real-estate manager and treasurer of the Bergen Hill Neighborhood Association. "Something like this is a setback for us, but sometimes out of the ashes, greater things arise."
 
A Renewal of Respect
 "This crisis has motivated people to pull together," said Mary McLean Bateman, president of the Astor Place Block Association. "A tragedy like this, it renews the respect we have for our own homes and those who live here. The problem is that some surrounding this area don't have the same kind of respect for what we own and have worked so long and hard for."
Early on April 6, fire broke out in a vacant building at 25 Astor Place and quickly spread to an adjoining vacant building. Before the fire was put out by 20 fire units from Jersey City and elsewhere, eight buildings were damaged, five severely. Forty residents were evacuated, and nine families were given temporary shelter by the Hudson County chapter of the American Red Cross, said Joseph P. Lecowitch, the chapter's director.
The cause of the blaze is still under investigation, but residents suspect arson, since one of the two vacant buildings had burned the week before. Even though damage was limited at the time, for some residents the incident served as a harbinger.
 
Residents Join Cleanup
 On April 24, both neighborhood associations sponsored a blockwide cleanup of the area in which several dozen residents loaded fire debris into a rented trash container for hauling. Children played in the street, which was blocked off to traffic, while parents sought to repair the scars of fire damage.
The neighborhood groups, which also sponsored picnics and flea markets to raise cleanup money, ended the day with a potluck dinner and a forum open to City Council candidates. They also boarded up the damaged buildings against looting.
"As we're working, we noticed a couple of burglars exiting the rear of one damaged building with TV sets in their arms," Mr. Doran said with a shake of his head. "Mary Bateman wound up chasing after them, following them home and calling the police. Amazing!"
Recalling the incident, Ms. Bateman said, "We just want people to have a little respect and mercy for what we're trying to do here."
 
Neighborhood Block Watches
 Both neighborhood groups, which have 50 active members, also conduct neighborhood block watches.
"Someone sees something out of place, someone suspicious, it's our responsibility to call the police," Mr. Doran said. "We look out for our own interests because what affects one in this neighborhood, well, it affects us all."
Mr. Doran and other residents said the vacant buildings had long been a source of trouble.
Dealers have sold drugs from the buildings' entranceways. Police patrols scattered the drug traffic only temporarily, residents said, and when the sun set, the dealers returned.
"Just over a year ago, the problem got so bad that we needed to take some kind of action," Mr. Doran said. "A little light on the subject we felt couldn't hurt."
The Bergen Hill Association contracted with the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and installed a spotlight across the street that illuminated the two vacant buildings. It cost $20.40 a month, but "it was money well spent," Mr. Doran said, and the drug dealers moved on.
But they didn't move very far: nearby vacant buildings drew addicts and transients and accounted for an increase in burglaries and break-ins along the tree-lined streets in the shadow of the Jersey City Medical Center.
 
'I'm Going to Rebuild'
 But residents say the fire and its aftermath have brought many closer together in an effort to rebuild the neighborhood and their sense of security.
"My plans?" Russell L. Franklin said. "I'm going to rebuild, and while it's not going to be easy, it's something that I have to do." Mr. Franklin is a data-processing consultant who, in addition to his home, owns an adjacent building on Astor Place that was severely damaged by the fire. He said the building, a rental property with two apartments, was inherited from an uncle, who purchased it in the 1980's.
"He put a lot of work into that building, a whole lot of work with his own hands, and for that alone I don't want to see it go to waste," he said, estimating the damage at more than $100,000.
Some residents forced out by the blaze have returned because, they say, they have nowhere to go. Others, like Kathryn E. Landrigan, a Jersey City native and assistant controller for a women's-wear company, say that adversity brought on by the blaze can be overcome if one is resilient.
"Well, let's see," Ms. Landrigan said. "We don't have any electricity, the back of our house is burned and there's lots of smoke and water damage, but we'll get through this. It's nothing that can't be repaired." On the positive side, she said, there is still running water, and neighbors have been generous with help.
"In lots of ways, it's kind of like we've been camping out," Ms. Landrigan said. "My boyfriend and I have been showering by flashlight. It's kind of romantic, I suppose, but I want things back to normal."
While most residents have fire insurance, the cost of rebuilding the structures may exceed insurance outlays. In the case of the vacant building where the fire began -- its owner, neighbors say, has not been heard from in years -- rebuilding is an anxious question. Residents and neighborhood association officials hope that city funds earmarked for historic district preservation will be released for reconstruction, but applications, eligibility, hearings and red tape, they say, do not make for quick and easy solutions.
Earl Morgan, an Astor Place homeowner and columnist for The Jersey Journal, who lives down the street from the site of the fire, said that no matter what, the neighborhood would survive, because unlike other communities, the residents have roots they have chosen not to ignore.
 
'A Sense of Stability'
 "This block is different because there is a sense of stability here," said Mr. Morgan, who bought his row house some 12 years ago and who grew up around the block. "People know people here. They've spent their entire lives here. There's something to be said for that."
Mr. Doran says that neighbors working together in the Bergen Hill district have been its salvation, that pride in its history and accomplishments has its own kind of legacy.
The area, he said, was developed in the early 1880's, when Bernard Vetterlein, a wealthy cigar importer, died and his large estate was divided among heirs and sold off. Developers built 125 row houses on land bordering Summit Avenue and Astor Place to meet the needs of the factory workers who made up a majority of the city's population. In the 1960's and 70's, a failing regional economy forced the sale of some buildings to landlords who divided once grand dwellings into squalid illegal apartments.
 
'Things Turned Around'
 "Things turned around in the 1980's because people reinvested in the neighborhood and its history," Mr. Doran said. His own three-story row house, which he bought and renovated nearly 10 years ago, had at one time been divided into a dozen crude units.
For Angel E. Sanchez, who has rented an apartment on Astor Place for the last two years, the devastation across the street does not compare to other places he has known.
"What happened here we can come back from, because people have the will in their hearts to bring it back," Mr. Sanchez said. "Here they have taken a stand, and in other places where I have lived, like the South Bronx when people lose pride, their neighborhoods are gone forever."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
For Coffee, the Slump Goes On

BYLINE: By James Brooke

DATELINE: RIO DE JANIERO

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the average Brazilian coffee grower is tearing out bushes with both hands, large crops this year of Brazilian robusta coffee beans as well as Colombian arabicas are expected to prolong a slump in world coffee prices.
While worldwide coffee consumption is climbing slowly, thanks to Asia's newly affluent nations, per capita consumption in the United States and Brazil has been cut almost in half over the last 30 years. 
 In London last month, talks collapsed in the latest effort to re-establish an agreement between producing and consuming nations meant to smooth supply and pricing patterns.
Now, with prices already weak, everything depends on what producer countries do in coming months with their huge inventories. Last year, Colombia aggressively sold inventories, pushing its total export sales to a record 16.5 million sacks. This season, attention has turned to Brazil, with its coffee mountain of 17.5 million sacks.
"Sale of Government stocks in 1993 is out of the question," said Orlando Correa, president of the Coffee Trade Center, a private group that represents Brazilian exporters. "A quantitative and qualitative audit will have to be made of the inventory, and the audit will take six months."
Should Brazil indeed continue to hold stocks off the market, Colombia could well surpass Brazil in volume sales this year, snatching away a crown worn throughout this century by "King Coffee."
But since Brazilian coffee has been fetching as little as 40 cents a pound on world markets, the lowest price in inflation-adjusted terms since the early 1800's, and a far cry from the record $3.09 a pound posted in 1977, the question is whether it is worthwhile to sell. Only four years ago, prices were in the $1.15 to $1.50 range.
Prices are expected to remain depressed for another year, largely because of the large Brazilian and Colomian inventories, and because current production is close to worldwide demand. Meanwhile, while producers are stuck in the price basement, coffee roasters and retailers have resisted lowering what they charge consumers. Instead, most retailers have been pocketing greater profits.
The worst may be over for the growers, experts say, but a rebound is another matter. "Coffee is pretty much near the bottom of the commodity cycle now," said Lawrence Eagles, an analyst in London for GNI Ltd., a futures broker. "But a price shift in favor of the producer probably won't come for 18 months or two years," when the twin effects of lower prices and a shrinking crop finally lead to a shortage and a price rebound.
Here in Brazil, still the world's largest grower, the coffee outlook for now is bleak.
With production costs running almost 40 percent higher than world prices, growers have reduced the number of bushes by almost a quarter, to 3.2 billion today, from 4.2 billion in 1989, when an international agreement between coffee producers and consumers collapsed. In addition to replacing coffee bushes with orange or rubber trees, Brazilian growers have also cut back on the care of remaining coffee bushes.
"There has been inadequate crop care for three years," said Dean R. Burquist, a technical consultant to the Brazilian Federation of Coffee Exporters. "There is no question that people are investing less in coffee trees."
At the same time, Brazil's economy no longer revolves around King Coffee. In 1952, Brazil depended on coffee for 74 percent of its export revenues. Last year, Brazil's coffee exports, a total of $1.1 billion, accounted for a mere 4 percent of the total.
"Brazilian coffee cultivation lacks Government attention -- credit and financing," said Oswaldo Aranha Neto, president of the coffee federation.
Late last month, a Brazilian official briefed reporters here on an $860 million plan to revive the coffee sector but no Rio newspapers carried a story about the plan, either because of a general lack of interest in coffee affairs or because of skepticism that the Government would actually deliver the money to growers.
This year, good weather is expected to swell Brazil's coffee crop about 10 percent over last year's level, hitting 24 million 132-pound sacks.
Further postponing a shortage that would lift prices off the floor, a good crop is also expected in Colombia, the world's No. 2 producer.
Colombian coffee is cossetted by by the Government in Colombia, where about 20 percent of the people now depend on the crop for their livelihood. Despite the 1989 collapse of the International Coffee Agreement, a Government subsidy program in Colombia pushed that nation's annual crop up 42 percent, to 17 million bags last year, from 12 million.
With a million jobs at stake in a violence-prone nation, Colombia's National Coffee Fund, which adminsters the Government's support program, has spent $1 billion over the four years to prop up producer prices. The subsidies and an aggressive marketing campaign enabled Colombia to expand its world market share to 22 percent today, from 14 percent in 1989.
"Now the question is: is Colombia going to keep on subsidizing?" asked Mr. Aranha. To ease the hemorrhage of subsidy money, Colombia's National Coffee Federation, which buys from the growers, has started a modest program of paying farmers to eradicate unproductive and diseased coffee plots.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 2-7

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Job Growth Stalls, but New Jersey Screeches Into Reverse 

The week's top story? That depends. If you have a job, it's probably Bosnia; if you don't, it's probably unemployment. That story changed little last week -- except, say, in New Jersey. April's national jobless rate stalled at 7 percent, with businesses adding just 119,000 new jobs. But in New Jersey, the rate soared to 9.1 percent, from 8.3 in March and 7.4 as recently as January. That's the highest rate of the 11 most populous states. Even elsewhere, though, job growth is nothing to cheer about: gains have merely kept pace with population growth. Total jobs still fall more than a million short of the pre-recession peak of 119 million. So where does this leave the Administration, as the Bush economy slowly becomes the Clinton economy? Some see bad news and said the pressure was on to create jobs. But Laura Tyson, the top Administration economist, called the report "neutral to positive."
 
A Payroll Tax to Pay the Doctor?
 
It's simple to rebuild a health care system: just decide who foots the bill. The Clinton team could be close to that crucial decision. Administration officials said last week that employers could be asked to pay up to 7 percent of payrolls, with the premiums going to regional groups to buy coverage in bulk. This would smooth out some bumps in the price of health care, lowering costs for old-line industries heavy with retirees, while getting more from smaller companies. Of course, no matter how the plan works out, strong opposition is expected. In a pre-emptive strike at critics, President Clinton asked the nation "not to let the special interests spook and scare" Congress from "our manifest duty."
 
He won't ask that it be done just yet, though. Letting the deficit talk have center stage for now, the Administration will not send the health plan to Congress till June.
 
U.S. Joins the Rush to Refinance
 
Borrowers nationwide are cashing in on low interest rates -- often by refinancing a mortgage. So naturally the biggest borrower of all -- the Federal Government -- wants to get in on the action. When the Treasury borrows money for 30 years, it pays a lot more interest than for just a few years. So last week it slashed sales of 30-year bonds nearly in half and said it would sell more two- and three-year notes. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said the move would "produce real savings" and "is in the best interests of American taxpayers." But critics called it a gamble that short-term rates would stay low -- and said it was a bad bet. "It will cost the taxpayer money over time," one economist said.
 
Lobbyists' Gifts, Unwrapped
 
Most Americans often want to tell senators a thing or two, and about 10,000 of them do it for a living -- they're called lobbyists. A free dinner here, tickets to a baseball game there -- all legal, all secret, all to get a senator's ear. This practice has angered many people, and last week, against all odds, a reformer had his day. Citing what he saw as "systemic corruption," Paul Wellstone, a first-term Minnesota Democrat with a mission, proposed forcing lobbyists to report any gift worth more than $20. Comfortable habits die hard, so his colleagues resisted fiercely -- but when the showdown came, they followed like lambs. Seeing the drawbacks of open opposition to such an apple-pie issue, senators ducked, debated only briefly and passed the proposal quickly.
 
Putting Housing Bias to a Test
 
Study after study has shown it: Bias -- racial and otherwise -- is widespread in mortgage lending. One way to try to root it out is to send Federal agents to pose as borrowers and see how they're treated. Those who call for tough enforcement of fair-housing laws have long sought such testers, but bankers -- who stand to be embarrassed, or worse -- insist they're unreliable. Last week the Clinton Administration, to the cheers of consumer groups, decided to try testers. "It's very exciting," said Deepak Bhargava of the lobbying group Acorn. "It is a real, marked departure from the previous Administration's posture."
 
Open. Cook. Cook Some More.
 
Ground beef clearly needs no instruction book. Think again. Three recent deaths and many illnesses from tainted meat got the Agriculture Department's attention, and last week it said all raw meat and poultry must have cooking instructions. The next battle: what the labels will say. They could be warnings, plunging drumsticks into a class with cigarettes (which have no healthy uses), or instructions. "These will not be warning labels," insisted the American Meat Institute, but "care labels." But one consumer advocate called it the "dumbest thing I ever heard of" not to say why the label's there. Warning or no, one hopes a hamburger will be easier to operate than a VCR.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Chrysler Pro to I.B.M.'s Rescue
 
The help-wanted ad was daunting: Take the financial reins of a corporate giant lurching from crisis to crisis and persuade a highly skeptical Wall Street that you know which end is up. Experience should include performing this impossible task at another leviathan on the brink. Where else to turn but Chrysler, the decade's comeback kid? And that's just what I.B.M. did last week, plucking away Jerome B. York, who helped put the auto maker on its $3 billion diet, to be its chief financial officer. Taking on I.B.M.'s troubles, Mr. York said -- understating the case in the extreme -- will be "one of the most challenging business situations in the 90's."
 
He Put Wine on America's Table
 
Ernest & Julio Gallo. It's a brand name that has become part of the language, but last week the words took on a very human face when Julio, 83, was killed in a Jeep accident on a family ranch. The winery was born when Prohibition ended, in 1933. And the business the brothers built -- Julio was the president, Ernest the chairman -- was staggering in its success: this family makes one of every four glasses of wine this country pours.
 
Boesky Asks for Pocket Money
 
He'd done his time, his wife had split, and he needed a bit of her money to tide him over. What sum did Ivan Boesky have in mind? Oh, $20,000 a week ought to do it. Failing that, it was the flophouse for sure. (Such numbers were not unheard of in the courtroom: Ivana Trump and her husband had severed their ties within the same walls.) But last week Mr. Boesky started to talk real money. His wife, Seema, is worth -- in terrifyingly round numbers -- $100 million, and he was in court demanding half. Never mind where the money came from. What did Mrs. Boesky have to say? "My husband was a rat."
 
Donald Trump, Underdog
 
Donald Trump is now a victim of discrimination -- or so he seems to say in a Federal lawsuit. A 1988 law has enabled Indian tribes in various states to open casinos, and Mr. Trump and his Atlantic City colleagues are not at all happy about the competition. Now, some unhappy people see therapists, some go to court; Mr. Trump went to court. His suit contends that the 1988 law gives an advantage to "a very limited class of citizens" (Indians) at the expense of others (Mr. Trump, for instance). Mr. Trump may have been moved to act because the issue could soon be on his doorstep: New Jersey's Ramapough Indians are edging toward a gambling pact. And that tribe's reaction to Mr. Trump? Says a Ramapough lawyer: "This guy is unbelievable."
 
New Blow for Empire Blue Cross
 
Troubles keep piling up for Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. It lost $250 million on its insurance business in 1991 and 1992. Its reserves are dangerously low. Congress is looking into possible management problems across the Blue Cross organization. And last week the Government said its handling of $1.7 billion in Medicare claims was "abysmal" and that its contract might be canceled, which would mean a $63 million loss. For its part, Empire pinned part of the blame on a new computer system and said much of its processing had improved.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
What Price Human Rights?
 
President Clinton wants better human rights in China. Can he afford it? He must decide soon whether to extend most-favored-nation trading status -- campaigning, he'd said that would hinge on human rights. But as he's learning regularly, compromise is inevitable, and everything has a price. The price here: China buys an awful lot of stuff in this country -- jets, cars, oil-drilling gear -- and these purchases create 150,000 domestic jobs. The Chinese have raised the ante recently, going on a $1 billion spending spree, to make it as costly as possible for Mr. Clinton to cut them off.
 
While many companies are eager to trade with China, others balk. Levi Strauss said it was ending most business in China, citing "pervasive violation of human rights."
 
East Germans Present I.O.U.'s
 
For Germany, the cost of unity rises relentlessly. Workers in the east get about half what those in the west earn, and the Government promised to reduce that gap. But now employers say that with the nation's deepening woes, they just can't afford it. So last week thousands of steelworkers and metalworkers went on strike in the east, demanding what was promised. "This is not just about money," one strike leader said. "People here have simply had enough of the broken promises and lies that have followed unity."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 500 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Going Long: Bond Buyers Are Sanguine

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
There is no better indication of the confidence of a society in its industrial and financial system than its willingness to buy truly long-term bonds. It takes a lot of trust to lend money for 30 years or more on fixed terms. You have to believe the issuer will be around, and capable of repaying, for all that time, and you have to believe that the currency in question will retain its value.
By that standard, American confidence is growing, but it is not even close to the level it once reached. Both Texaco and Boeing have sold 50-year bonds this year, hitting a maturity that had not been seen for decades. The companies are betting that the current level of long-term interest rates is a bargain for issuers; buyers are hoping the reverse is true. Texaco hedged its bet by reserving the right to buy back the bonds in 20 years, but there is no such provision in the Boeing issue. 
 The peak in long-term confidence came more than a century ago, when some railroads were able to issue 999-year bonds. One such bond, issued by a company since acquired by the Canadian Pacific, is still paying 4 percent interest and is supposed to continue doing so until 2883.
The assumption that the rails would be around, and able to repay, for 10 centuries seems amazing now, but no more than the assumption that the currency would not depreciate. (Those bonds were usually denominated in gold, but governments effectively erased that protection during the Depression.)
Today, investors seem sanguine about risks. Jessica Palmer, the co-head of capital markets at Salomon Brothers, which underwrote the 50-year bonds, says that investors demanded only a tenth of a percentage point or less in extra yield to compensate them for the risk of going out 50 years rather than 30.
That spread seems a bit low, notwithstanding the fact that the buyers of the Boeing issue have profited as prices rose in the past month. After all, a lot can happen -- to a company and a currency -- in half a century. In 1943, Boeing had yet to build its first jet, and a dollar could buy 10 copies of The Sunday New York Times. The top ticket for the Broadway hit "Oklahoma" was $2.75 and long-term interest rates were under 3 percent. It proved to be a great time to issue long-term bonds, and a bad time to buy them.
While corporations now are eager to issue more long-term bonds, the Government has decided to cut back by selling fewer 30-year issues and more securities that mature in less than three years. If rates keep falling, that will be a wise move for the Government.
Unfortunately for the taxpayers, the Government's record as a bond-market timer is poor. It was just after World War II that it began to rely more on short-term borrowing, thus reducing the average maturity of Government debt. During the 1980's, the Government raised the amount it was borrowing on a long-term basis. In neither case was the decision a wise one, at least in terms of minimizing the Government's total interest payments.

HEADLINE: Downtown's Empty Feeling

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
It was once a proud building, as the gilded mosaic over one entrance testifies: An angel grasping a lightning bolt, symbol of technology's mastery over that era, adorns 67 Broad Street, built to house ITT's headquarters in 1928. But now, the 33-story lower Manhattan building is three-fourths empty, the mosaic entrance is unused, and the building was foreclosed upon in January.
Across the way, at 80 Broad Street, a whimsical quartet of metal seahorses hovers over the entrance of the stately 36-story building, which is 51 percent vacant. 
 This stretch of Broad Street, at the heart of New York's financial district, is eerily serene. The overbuilding of the 1980's, coupled with the city's economic problems and a wave of relocations to newer and better-equipped buildings in midtown, has left downtown's older buildings simply desperate. It is a tale echoed in many parts of lower Manhattan, as in downtown areas across the country.
In New York, the vast swaths of empty office space pose a stark problem for the owners of older buildings, as well as for city officials. Even as the economy recovers, the downtown vacancy rate has continued to rise, and no one is sure when -- or whether -- job growth will resume, increasing demand for offices.
The optimists speak of renovations that will make the buildings desirable again, or of converting the buildings into apartments or hotels. Others say that many can never be saved, and will have to be demolished. Such decisions, it seems clear, will be based not only on job growth, but on whether owners -- with or without public aid -- can invest enough to help bring a turnaround.
"It would really be a crime to lose them," said Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. "A number of them are architecturally significant, and they also tell the history of the development of the city, of New York as a skyscraper town. These canyons of stone shouldn't just be left to be rubble."
THE problems for the city are financial as well as esthetic.
"The City of New York stands to lose as much as half a billion dollars a year in tax collections if the decline in values continues unabated in lower Manhattan," said John H. Alschuler Jr. of Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler, a policy and management consulting firm. He said that figure represents about one-sixteenth of the city's property tax income. "The government needs to intervene constructively in order to preserve the property tax base that supports vital services needed by city residents."
For many owners, the problem is complicated by the fact that the vacancy rate is so high in the older buildings that money cannot be found for extensive renovations. This, in turn, affects their ability to rent space.
In the part of Manhattan roughly south of Chambers Street and the Brooklyn Bridge, the "secondary" or less desirable buildings -- a group that includes unrenovated older structures -- were 26.4 percent vacant as of March 31, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate brokerage and management company. In the middle stretch of Broad Street, a corridor anchored at one end by the New York Stock Exchange and at the other by the relatively new headquarters of Goldman, Sachs, the rate could be as high as 45 percent, the brokerage Edward S. Gordon estimates.
While the New York City figures are among the worst in the nation, other cities also face an overhang of empty space in older, less desirable buildings. In Dallas, secondary buildings are 39.1 percent vacant, according to Cushman & Wakefield, and in Philadelphia, the figure is 24.7 percent.
Along Broad Street, owners have not given up, despite long odds and huge costs.
For example, at 67 Broad, the Principal Financial Group of Des Moines, Iowa, has taken over the 544,000-square-foot structure and is studying what to do. "We'd like to fix it up a little bit and lease it up," said Steve Franzenburg, a director of the investment department at Principal Financial.
Deciding what to do is not easy. Many of these buildings need upgrades in their power capacity to accommodate computer wiring; the changes may require raised floors or dropped ceilings that make the work space unacceptably tight. Some need asbestos removal, air-conditioning work and upgrades or replacements for their lobbies and poky, shabby elevators. Also, there are potential problems in complying with the Americans With Disabilities Act, which requires easy access to entrances and lavatories.
Many of these problems can be fixed with enough money, but some cannot. Larger prospective tenants look for open space, with no columns or existing offices, and floor sizes of between 25,000 and 40,000 square feet, which is unusual in older buildings. They also want floors in regular rectangles or squares -- shapes that cannot be found in older buildings where the layout may be triangular (because of downtown's irregular streets) or H-shaped (to help air circulation in the days before air conditioning).
"The lobby you can modernize, the air conditioning you can modernize, the electrical system you can modernize -- but you can't change the size and shape of the building," said Raymond T. O'Keefe, head of the downtown office of the Edward S. Gordon brokerage.
A make-over is a tough job. A year ago, Galbreath Riverbank, a Manhattan real estate company, started work for GE Investments in renovating 14 Wall Street, a 960,000-square-foot, 37-story, pyramid-topped tower built in 1912 by Bankers Trust and expanded in 1932. Bankers Trust is still a major tenant in the building, which is 80 percent leased.
John V. Wheeler, who is in charge of the renovation for Galbreath Riverbank, said the work on the vacant space and common areas of the building, which is around the corner from the troubled stretch of Broad Street, would cost about $15.6 million. The project is to be completed later this year.
The plan includes a new roof, sidewalks, elevator mechanical systems, energy-efficient windows and repairs to the mortarwork. In the category of esthetics, the building is getting new elevator cars, remodeled corridors on multitenant floors, improvements to newly leased spaces and renovations in its lobby and entrance, which include replacing the two revolving doors with one flanked by wider swing doors that comply with the access requirements of the Americans With Disabilities Act.
The building's management has already added a hotel-style concierge station in the lobby and restored the soaring, gilt-trimmed bank office that is paneled in French cherry veneer. It is also refurbishing the restaurant at the base of the pyramid.
"The competition is so fierce, and there are so many options out there, that you have to be at your absolute best to attract new tenants," Mr. Wheeler said.
DESPITE the work to be done at 14 Wall Street, the building has advantages over other older structures. It has an ample power supply, and its ceilings are unusually high. It also has architectural distinction, easily seen in its airy and august lobby. And it has an owner with deep pockets as well as a steady income stream from tenants.
Not all owners are so well positioned, and the New York City Planning Department is coordinating a new study that will seek solutions for their problems.
One option is to convert older buildings to residential housing. Another often-mentioned solution is demolition for those buildings that cannot be used for other purposes, with the lots then left vacant for parks until the space is needed for a new building.
While even some preservationists agree that not all of the buildings can be saved, the practical side of demolition poses problems. It is expensive and difficult to take down a building in lower Manhattan's tight and winding streets. Also, the city's zoning laws, enacted after many downtown buildings were constructed, restrict the size of new buildings that could replace them.
Despite the gloom over the empty office space, the downtown area has history on its side in bouncing back from adversity. One notable comeback occurred in 1958, when warnings about its death led David Rockefeller to form the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association to examine the area's future. "Then he built Chase Manhattan Plaza, which was an immediate, very loud statement that downtown was indeed not dead," recalled Barbara L. Christen, president of the association.
Now the group is looking to the conclusions of the city study, expected in June.
"The theory is that every time lower Manhattan goes into the doldrums, there's a major development that pulls it out," said Mr. O'Keefe, the Edward S. Gordon downtown manager, as the bells of Trinity Church pealed the hour next door to his Broadway office.
"It's where this nation was founded, and it's where George Washington was first sworn in," he added, reeling off a list of downtown's attractions -- the South Street Seaport, the summertime opportunity to rent a sailboat, a winter breakfast at Fraunces Tavern and the fact that downtown is consistently cooler in the summer than midtown because it is surrounded by water. "It's just a nice place. And someone's going to figure that out again."
 
 
 
VISIONS OF 24-HOUR NEIGHBORHOODS
 How to avert the death of downtown Manhattan? That is the question the New York City Planning Department is trying to answer in conjunction with the city's Economic Development Corporation and the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association.
In their study of downtown's future, the groups are looking at the erosion of the area's employment base but are also examining potential new uses for old office buildings. One possibility is to convert some empty buildings to residential housing. The study estimates that about 45 buildings containing 4.2 million square feet of space are likely candidates for residential use.
Shirin Karanfiloglu, manager of the study, said about 110 buildings, most of them small structures in the southern Tribeca and South Street Seaport areas, have already been converted to residences. Only three buildings that are 15 stories or taller have been converted, she said.
Among the obstacles to conversion are the size and shape of the buildings, as well as zoning regulations. Further, the area is lacking in grocery stores, dry cleaners and other businesses that support neighborhood life.
"A major goal of our study is turning lower Manhattan into a 24-hour environment," Ms. Karanfiloglu said.
Another possibility for invigorating downtown is a plan to build a big new building to combine the American and New York Stock Exchanges. Early discussions have reportedly put a price tag of $1 billion on a 50-story tower including two 55,000-square-foot trading floors. The new building would clearly make some older structures even less competitive, but its supporters hope it would have a positive overall effect on the area's future.
Barbara L. Christen, president of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association, predicted that a variety of solutions would ultimately be found: a mix of traditional office space, residential conversions and space for innovative uses ranging from educational centers to computer software design laboratories.
"And then, when nothing fits, that's when you may have to take a building down and make a park, then bank it until such time as you have the money and the need to build a new building," she said.
