HEADLINE: Don't Joke About This Stock Market

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
In his private trading room at a local securities firm, Millions Yang peers intently at a parade of price charts flowing across a computer screen. Mr. Yang, a rotund former Red Guard who earned his nickname the easy way, by making millions in the stock market, breaks into a smile.
"Today I made 100,000 yuan," almost $20,000, he says, laughing. "Not bad for a day." 
 Outside Mr. Yang's office during one recent lunch break, several hundred small investors line up, eager to place orders when trading resumes two hours later. Millions Yang goes to the door and they ask him for advice.
"Millions Yang!" call dozens of voices. "Millions Yang, what should I buy?" one man shouts. "Give me some tips," yells another. Millions Yang -- which translates to Yang Baiwan in Chinese -- chats with those in front of the line. Heads crane as those in back try to overhear.
"I'm trapped in a loss," one woman tells him despairingly. "What should I do?"
"You must be willing to take a loss," he answers, and people nod, taking mental notes. "If it's going down, sell it and accept the loss. Otherwise you'll be stuck with a bigger loss."
That's the way it is at the Chinese stock market these days. The market used to be just a curiosity, a sort of masquerade in which Communists cross-dressed as capitalists and waved share certificates in place of little red books. American financiers and journalists dropped by the stock exchanges to chat patronizingly with the traders: "So, Mr. Yang, how much money did you make today? A dollar! That's wonderful -- you're going to be a rich man."
 
2 Million Shareholders
 No one is patronizing these days. Now China has two million shareholders, with the number growing by about 50,000 a week. The market index in Shanghai soared 167 percent last year, and these days even the small American investor can buy into the Chinese market, although some experts suggest it might be just as prudent to visit Las Vegas.
On a good day, the two-year-old Chinese market trades $350 million worth of shares, more than Hong Kong in a slow session. And it is growing at a prodigious rate: in the first quarter of 1993, the Shanghai Stock Exchange enjoyed a trading volume 2.2 times that of all of 1992. With the number of listings expected almost to double this year, some experts think that in a year or two the Shanghai market will regularly enjoy the highest volume in Asia outside Japan.
In short, the Chinese stock market is transforming itself from a curiosity to a major force. The metamorphosis is quite a spectacle. Thousands of Chinese companies yearn to go public, at home or on foreign exchanges. Hundreds of foreign accountants and lawyers are struggling to make sense of nonsensical Chinese balance sheets. Western investment banks are opening offices in China and paying huge sums for anyone who knows how to say "P/E ratio" in Chinese. Above all, tens of millions of ordinary Chinese are desperate to become shareholders. Last August, a million Chinese lined up for days under a fierce sun to buy stock -- more precisely, to pay several weeks' salary for an application form that would give them a 10 percent chance of being allowed to buy new shares. When the forms ran out, the would-be investors rioted. Securities executives in the West could be pardoned for feeling a bit envious.
The growth of the stock market is having an important effect on China as a whole. First, state-owned companies, perennially inefficient, begin to care about profitability. "You can see that when the companies issue stocks, they have to have a board of directors, they have to be audited, and they pay a lot more attention to efficiency," said Pan Muping, the Shanghai representative of Crosby Securities, a Hong Kong-based brokerage that was one of the first to be bullish on China.
More broadly, the rise of the market legitimizes the kind of quasi-capitalism that has been around for a dozen years but is steadily becoming less quasi and more capitalism.
Also, it helps create the kind of urban middle class that is the foundation for a modern civil society. In the past, the Communist Party was the sole source of power and prestige. While the party remains awesomely powerful, it is no longer the only show in town. Business interests are becoming an alternative power base, an alternative source of values, a rival source of prestige.
 
A Westerner Impressed
 The changes impress William A. Schreyer, chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, who was in China last month to open the firm's new office here in Shanghai. "The modernization of China's economy, I think, is one of the most exciting endeavors in this century," he said, "and we want to be there and be part of it."
Mr. Schreyer said he was impressed from the moment he took the road from the Beijing airport and saw what seemed a continuous construction zone. He grew more enthusiastic when Prime Minister Li Peng and Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin both received him and expressed interest in improving corporate accounting standards.
"If I were 25 years younger," the 65-year-old Mr. Schreyer said, "I'd study Chinese and ask Merrill Lynch to post me there."
He added that Merrill Lynch is positioning itself in China in the hope of growing with the local market just as it did in Japan 32 years ago.
What? Mention the Japanese and Chinese stock markets in the same breath? A couple of years ago that would have been regarded as foolish. Now it's regarded as visionary.
"China is the world's fastest-growing economy," said Duncan P. F. Mount, managing director of CEF Investment Management Ltd. in Hong Kong. "There are about 300,000 incorporated companies, of which about 70 are listed. In time, it's obviously going to be Asia's biggest stock market, probably bigger than Japan. The question is how long it's going to take, not is it going to happen."
 
Some Caveats
 To be sure, the same could have been said back in 1914, when Shanghai first opened a securities exchange. Fund managers and brokers who promoted Shanghai back then may eventually be proven to be visionaries, but from beneath their gravestones their clients will be unimpressed.
Even now, the Chinese market faces enormous challenges that Westerners do not always appreciate. Like the rest of the economy, the stock system is laced with corruption that alienates many ordinary citizens. Most of the trading is a speculative froth that bears little relationship to fundamentals, and some of the excitement seems to be of the flavor-of-the-month variety. At various times, other emerging markets -- South Korea, Indonesia, Taiwan, Mexico, etc. -- have been the toast of international investors, but often the small investor showed up as the party ended, just in time to pay the bill.
What is more, most of the Chinese companies that list stocks are from the state-owned sector, which is the weakest part of the economy. The companies that are behind the Chinese boom are the small township factories and private enterprises that operate on a small scale, bribe local officials, dodge taxes and keep miserable accounts. It is virtually impossible for foreigners to buy shares in them.
This may well be the make-or-break year for the Chinese stock market, which is still formally dubbed an experiment. If all goes smoothly, China's leaders are expected to decide next year that the experiment is over, and that they can implement the shareholding system on a far wider scale.
The stock market in its current form began in December 1990 with the formal opening of the Shanghai Securities Exchange. About the same time, the southern city of Shenzhen, next to Hong Kong, was also allowed to open an exchange.
These days the Shanghai exchange trades in 62 stocks, with several more to be listed over the next month. The exchange now has 600 seats; in June that will rise to 2,500. The Government has agreed in principle that 50 or 60 more companies from all over the country can list this year, issuing shares with a par value of $1 billion.
"Late this year or early next year, we'll regularly have higher trading volumes than Hong Kong," said Wei Wenyuan, the executive director of the Shanghai exchange. "Then it'll keep going up from there."
The Shanghai exchange has gradually left the Shenzhen exchange behind and become the premier market in the country. A half-dozen other cities are desperately trying to start their own stock exchanges, but the Government has refused to allow them to do so.
Many Chinese buy stocks with the giddy excitement they might show in entering a casino. Investors have heard about a few people who committed suicide after losing their money, but mostly they hear stories about folks like Millions Yang. The losers keep quiet. So the emphasis is on speculative in-and-out trading. Chinese speak of "chao gu," or stir-frying stocks, meaning to turn them over quickly.
Chinese do not telephone their brokers; instead they swarm into the brokerages. Each of the dozens of brokerages in Shanghai has a huge trading room in which individual investors stand shoulder to shoulder, watching a huge screen with share prices. To trade, they fill out a form and stand in a long line, sometimes for hours, to give it to a broker.
In Shanghai alone, more than 100,000 people have become professional investors. Some have quit their jobs; others -- in what local people say with a wink is a demonstration of the superiority of socialism -- simply don't show up at work while still being paid. They spend every day in the trading rooms of a brokerage.
The "da hu" -- big rollers, those with more than $90,000 in their accounts -- get favored treatment. At Shenyin Securities, for example, a da hu is allowed to pay $40 a month and get a pass to enter a basement room with sofas and computer monitors. A purchase order can be handed to a broker without waiting in line.
"A year ago we had 15 da hu here," said Zhu Weidong, a 22-year-old broker who looks after them. "Now we have 60." Mr. Zhu said the richest of them once had the equivalent of almost $2 million in his account.
The securities boom has created a shortage of employees in the field. Companies lure brokers by paying $200 a month, several times the prevailing wage, and offering bonuses.
For now, of course, the stock markets are essentially local ones in just two of China's innumerable cities. But this year they are supposed to go national. The Shenzhen exchange just listed a company from Hainan Province, and one or two major companies from each of China's 30 provinces are supposed to go public in Shanghai or Shenzhen in the coming months.
At the same time, the Shanghai exchange is eagerly targeting investors in other cities. Fifty cities, in every province but Tibet, are now hooked up to the Shanghai stock computer system. On April 26, the exchange began to broadcast share information by satellite to a network of receiving stations all over the country, and two-way trading by satellite is scheduled to begin in November.
The transformation of the Shanghai market into a national one would be hugely important. It would multiply the pool of potential investors by a hundred, and allow more long-term investors to join the speculators.
 
Little Regulation
 Still, the market faces a host of problems. One of the most important is that there is little regulatory control. A new Securities Regulatory Commission has been established, but nobody seems inclined to pay it much heed.
"The foundation for China's stock market is seriously inadequate, creating equally serious problems," a confidential Government report declared recently. The 18-page report, classified secret, strongly supported the continued development of the market but warned of far-reaching corruption, inter-ministry rivalries and other problems. In particular, the report warned against "power shares" -- gifts of stock to Government figures to win favors.
"We're approached by companies every day, banging on our door and saying that they want to go public," said Gao Xiqing, an American-trained lawyer who is chief counsel to the Securities Regulatory Commission. "It's remarkable how the whole country is so gung ho." Perhaps too gung ho. Because the Government is restricting the numbers that can go public, there is a natural temptation to offer bribes.
"Some people come in and offer us X number of shares in their company," said Mr. Gao, who is in charge of public offerings. "They don't have the concept of a conflict of interest. I say I can't take it, and they think I don't have the money. So they say it's free. And then when they understand that I just can't accept it, they say it doesn't have to be in my name."
Millions Yang acknowledges that there are problems in the stock market, but he thinks they will be easily overcome. Shanghai, he says, will eventually become the financial capital of the Far East.
Asked whether hard-liners might close the stock market after Deng Xiaoping dies, Mr. Yang paused for only a second. "I don't worry," he said, then offered a novel interpretation of Marxism: "The goal of the revolution was to make people rich, and now they're rich. The Government won't allow folks to become poor again."
 
VARIOUS WAYS TO GET IN ON THE CHINA PLAY
 ASIDE from rushing to Shanghai and "stir-frying" shares alongside Millions Yang, foreigners can participate in the Chinese stock market in several ways.
One of the simplest is to buy into one of the 30-odd China funds, with $1.3 billion in assets, offered by international securities firms. Some of these funds are traded, like shares, on the New York Stock Exchange and other exchanges, or are available directly through brokers.
The problem with that is that some of the funds are not what their names might imply. Some hold mostly cash rather than China stocks, or their "China holdings" may be almost entirely companies in Hong Kong that do business in China. The recent fascination with "China concept" stocks has led many Hong Kong companies to put China in their names so that they can enjoy the premium afforded to China plays.
Another possibility is to invest in Chinese companies listed abroad. One such company, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings, was listed on the New York Stock Exchange last year, and others hope to follow. In addition, nine Chinese companies are expected to list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange later this year. The best known is Qingdao Brewery, which makes Tsingtao Beer.
The final possibility is to invest directly in Chinese shares. While foreigners are not allowed to buy ordinary shares in Chinese companies, 10 companies in Shanghai and 9 in Shenzhen have listed a special kind of foreign currency-denominated stock -- called B-shares -- that only foreigners may purchase. Some large brokerages can arrange a purchase of the B-shares.
However, transaction costs in B-shares are relatively high, trading volume is low and the B-shares change hands at less than half the price of the A-shares held by Chinese investors.
One reason in the past for the limited demand was that the clearing system in Shanghai did not meet standards of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, effectively keeping out many American investors. But the Shanghai exchange has started a new settlement system, and last month the S.E.C. agreed to allow China funds to buy B-shares.
Buying by American fund managers may give the B-shares a boost, but they would get an even bigger boost if Chinese nationals were allowed to use their United States dollars to buy them. China's central bank and foreign exchange agency have so far blocked proposals to allow Chinese to buy B-shares.
 
 
 
RED GUARDS TO HOT PROFITS

BEFORE Millions Yang became an investment legend, he was active as a Red Guard during the Cultural Revolution from 1966 to 1976. Those were chaotic years in Shanghai. Vehicles were instructed to go forward at a red light and stop at a green light -- the Red Guards reasoning that red, as the revolutionary color, should not be associated with coming to a halt. Not all drivers got the message, however, and accidents were common. Finally traffic lights were given special dispensation to pursue their bourgeois ways. A red light again meant to stop.
After the Cultural Revolution, Mr. Yang, whose real name is Yang Huaiding, found that making money was more fun than making revolution. He entered the securities business in 1988, buying Government bonds in rural areas and selling them in Shanghai. This was a lucrative business, and partly as a result it was suspect. While there was no clear law against it, the authorities periodically denounced such arbitrage with the ugliest of words in the official vocabulary: speculation.
When the stock market opened, Mr. Yang began reading about equities, quickly developed a knack for trading and became the nation's most famous investor. In China, he says, it is still pretty easy to make a quick profit. "In New York, the market is more mature so it's harder to get a profit," he said. "Here everything is still being developed, so it's a lot easier."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Beating Some Unbeaten Paths

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
After spending three weeks in Brazil, Argentina and Morocco, J. Mark Mobius, the granddaddy of emerging markets investing, touched down in New York in mid-April to begin a two-week whirlwind city-a-day tour around the United States to visit clients. Then he left for Sri Lanka, all the while planning his summer trip to Russia, Poland and Czechoslovakia.
The agenda is typical for Mr. Mobius, who spends so much time in transit, circling the globe thrice a year, that he fills up passports in 12 months and donates all his frequent-flier miles to relatives. 
 His insistence on seeing his investments firsthand has paid off. He is one of only a handful of managers with emerging-markets experience, and "knowing the markets, and how they function, is imperative to delivering the returns," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., mutual fund researchers in Chicago.
Among Mr. Mobius's $1.3 billion under management in the United States, Britain, Canada and Asia is the Templeton Emerging Markets Fund, a closed-end fund set up in 1987 that returned 28.6 percent, on average, for the five years through April 30. Meanwhile, his mutual fund set up in November 1991 to invest in the same type of stocks, Templeton Developing Markets, gained 4.3 percent from inception through April 30, Morningstar said.
Unlike mutual funds, closed-end funds issue a fixed number of shares that trade on exchanges, often at a discount or premium to the value of their holdings. Templeton Emerging Markets has been trading at a hefty premium of roughly 30 percent, which even Mr. Mobius concedes is high. He recommends investors opt instead for the mutual fund.
Both funds draw their 60 to 90 issues from the same list of what he considers cheap stocks in developing countries, he said. As to which fund owns what stocks, Mr. Mobius said, that depends on "accident and the market mechanism." Over time, the portfolios should begin to look the same, he said, because he holds stocks for five years or more.
By his definition, emerging markets include everything but North America, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and Europe (except Portugal, Greece and Turkey). These developed economies account for roughly 90 percent of global market capitalization.
Why his faith in emerging markets? Because 85 percent of the world's population and natural wealth reside there, compared to only 15 percent of the world's output.
"The story is hope and growth," Mr. Mobius said. "We don't subscribe to the Malthusian disaster scenario." The emerging markets, he said, are growing more rapidly than the developed markets because the populations are young, people are living longer and literacy is increasing.
Nonetheless, emerging markets investments are not for the faint of heart. Investors will be rewarded only "with patience, and there will be some burnt fingers," he said.
Mr. Mobius, a 56-year-old bachelor who has a home on Lantau Island, Hong Kong, and an apartment in Singapore, figures he spends 80 percent of his time traveling, digging up information that, he says, is simply not available otherwise. "It's easier to hold on to purchases going down in price if I see the plant and how people work and I know the management," he said.
In the markets of developing countries, where regulatory standards are loose, if they exist at all, intangibles count all the more. Thus Mr. Mobius might investigate the reputation of a family that controls a company he is interested in, which makes it "important to be on the ground."
And in many countries, inflation is so high that accounting policies require more time for interpretation.
The biggest factor pushing emerging-markets growth is privatization, said Mr. Mobius. He noted that when Argentina, for instance, began privatizing railways, water, sewer and electric systems, the budget deficit, which had been created by supporting the inefficient state enterprises, began to fall.
A long-time value investor, Mr. Mobius looks for "undervalued situations." He asks how a company will perform five years hence, based on shareholder earnings after taxes and charges. Then, too, a company must be cheap "relative to its own historical price levels, its own market and similar companies around the world." He sells shares only "when I can buy something 50 percent cheaper than what I already own." As for hedging currencies, "I don't, because over the long run, equities are a hedge."
So where does the Indiana Jones of international investing see bargains today? Right now, each fund is about 40 percent invested in the Phillipines, Brazil, Turkey and Malaysia (about 10 percent in each country), with 4 to 6 percent each in Indonesia, Hong Kong, Greece and Portugal. Profit-taking over the last year reduced the funds' holdings in Thailand, Hong Kong and Argentina.
In Eastern Europe, Mr. Mobius says he is "investing in Hungary, nibbling at Poland and looking carefully at the Czech Republic."
Among his current stock favorites are Ottoman Bank in Turkey; United Plantations, a British-listed orange grower in Swaziland; Cycle and Carriage, an automobile distributor in Singapore, and Philex Mining, a copper and gold miner in the Philippines.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The New Challenges for the C.I.A. Are Open Secrets

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BEHIND closed doors these days, Congress and the Clinton Administration are agonizing over openness. Their task is to figure what best to do with American spies in a less secret world.
The agony is in some part pleasure: the post-cold war reassessment represents a reward. But if an open world leaves less reason to worry about the Russians, it appears more prone to unpredictability. For intelligence agencies, it probably raises more questions than it solves. 
 Even in recent days, there have emerged fresh demands -- reminders that the black and white of old disguised countless shades of gray. From France, an ally: the disclosure of a document instructing agents to seek American corporate secrets, a discovery that has prompted the United States to boycott the Paris Air Show in June. From Pakistan, a fast-fading ally: new signs of missile shipments from China that have added to fears of the Pakistani nuclear threat.
And from the former Yugoslavia, once obscured by the East-West divide: an ethnic splintering so vicious that reaction to an American military intervention remains anyone's guess.
But the lawmakers and spymasters facing such pressures have also found themselves forced to confront fiscal reality. On Capitol Hill, where wrangling over a still-classified spy budget has already begun, Democrats have voiced deep misgivings about a request whose $28 billion size is one of Washington's most public secrets. That is even more than Congress allotted last year, and in its defense Mr. Clinton and his Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, have made plain that in the future spies will have to make do with much less.
Striking a new balance between those resources and tasks is shaping up as a wrenching conversion. One plan calls for a 17.5 percent cut in intelligence staffs by 1997. There is talk of building satellites that can eavesdrop and take pictures at the same time.
Even efforts to simplify carry short-term complications. A plan by the Central Intelligence Agency to merge records kept separate for security reasons has been a computer technician's nightmare. And while a Presidential directive disclosed last week will lead to the release of hundreds of thousands of classified documents, it has opened an internal Government debate about what should still be kept secret.
Exactly what will come of the rethinking remains hostage to dozens of official reviews. But soundings from Congressional and intelligence officials have given hints about the emerging shape of the country's post-cold war spying enterprise.
Most suggestions that it be disbanded appear to have been replaced by acceptance of intelligence as cost-effective insurance. Moreover, intelligence agencies are likely to be spared the deep cuts inflicted on the military.
One reason is that unlike armies, spying cannot easily be compressed into a rapid deployment force. To be effective, a spy must be in place long before a crisis breaks. The other reason has to do with a metaphor favored by Mr. Woolsey. He describes the new world as a jungle in which a dragon has been slain but there remain many deadly snakes, and even his critics accept that the job for spies is to judge which might strike next.
Openness has certainly made that task easier; Bosnia, for all its fearsome hatred, has become a relatively penetrable place. But a generally accepted list of current intelligence priorities is a reminder of just how closed the world remains.
At its top are still the nuclear weapons of the former Soviet Union, still the stuff of secrets. Next in turn come North Korea and Iran, for their nuclear aspirations, support of terrorism and hostility to the West. Next are hair-trigger tensions between Pakistan and India, both becoming more deadly as nuclear powers.
For spies, the obstacles these countries now pose may be even more formidable than those presented by the cold war. North Korea is more closed than Moscow ever was; Pakistan has taken particular care to disguise its missile imports. To keep track of radical Islamic fundamentalism, the C.I.A. is beginning a major effort to teach employees Farsi and the Turkic languages of Central Asia.
Meanwhile, the targeting of American corporate secrets by French spies has renewed an appetite for the United States to respond in kind. Since prosperity is a measure of security, the debate is over how far spy agencies should go in pursuit of economic intelligence.
All signs are that the answer will be to stop short of industrial espionage, still an American taboo. Even if some allies have no qualms about stealing secrets for Government-backed industries, officials warn that the same approach would leave American spies favoring private companies. Officials say it is more likely that the United States will fend off the French and other advances with public protests.
But there is unmistakable new eagerness for missions not usually given much status in American spying. And the half-shrugs with which Government officials responded last week to the arrest of a State Department official for passing secrets to Greece hinted at new rules in which spying by allies has become a less-mortal sin. Just as the United States did its best to get advance tips about Soviet arms proposals, Government officials acknowledge that top priorities now include the positions that economic rivals intend to adopt in high-stakes trade negotiations.
 
Ecology and Rights
 The parallel shift in policymakers' attention to issues like the environment has also not escaped the spymasters' attention. The National Intelligence Council, responsible for issuing spy agencies' assessments about the world, has been expanded to include a 12th officer to oversee the environment, human rights and other so-called global affairs.
Almost no one pretends, however, that this is what spy agencies are best equipped to do. The impetus appears instead to come from an aspiration that intelligence be all-knowing -- and from a reluctance to admit that it cannot.
Asked where they might make do with less spying, officials sometimes point to Europe and Africa, no longer theaters of the cold war. But even that scale-back could leave them awkwardly telling the White House, "We don't know."
It may be years before choices made today are proven wise or foolish. But the greatest danger may be that intelligence will spread itself too thin. Perhaps most important is that officials stop thinking about what is possible, and start thinking about their needs.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Tearing Apart Of Yugoslavia: Place by Place, Family by Family

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BELGRADE

 BODY:
WHETHER or not peace is restored to the former Yugoslavia any time soon, the trauma and psychological dislocation of its inhabitants is already so profound after two years of fighting that peacemaking could well take generations rather than months or years.
Nowhere has the disintegration of Yugoslavia been more lacerating than in the former nation's many mixed marriages -- unions that cut across ethnic lines that have now become the frontiers of war. 
 Take Gordana Momcilovic, a 22-year-old bank employee who persists in calling herself a Yugoslav. Her father is a Serb, her mother a Croat, and her home once illustrated the blossoming of the idea of a nation uniting the southern Slavs.
When war broke out between Serbia and Croatia in 1991, the family was living in Croatia. In August that year, Ms. Momcilovic recalls, her father, a Yugoslav Army pilot, announced that they would have to move to Serbia. "He asked my mother, in front of me, if she wanted to stay in Croatia or come with us," she says. "In the end, my mother came."
By that time the question was highly poignant. Ms. Momcilovic's 23-year-old brother was already dead. He had opted to join the Serbian side when the fighting started. Croatian troops killed him near Osijek. Her father's three brothers also died in the same region.
"I cannot hate the Croats for killing my brother and my uncles, because if I did, I would have to hate my mother," Ms. Momcilovic says. "I am unable to hate my mother. Often I ask myself what I am now. The only answer I find is that I am a Yugoslav and will always be a Yugoslav."
Ms. Momcilovic's anguish is widely shared. The best estimate is that close to 15 percent of marriages in the former Yugoslavia were mixed. Many have been torn asunder.
Everywhere people go through painful rites, large and small, of separation and rupture. Duska Anastasijevic, a 25-year-old Serbian student and translator, struggles still with the painful realization that Croatia and its beautiful Dalmatian coast are now another country.
 
'A Sense of Loss'
 "We are full of a sense of loss," she says. "To me the worst, the least acceptable, and I am talking now of my emotional life and not the killings, is the loss of Dalmatia. I can still feel the stones of Dubrovnik beneath my bare feet -- their coolness, their smoothness, their ancient undulations.
"I cannot imagine that I will not feel those stones again. But Dalmatia is now in another land where I suppose I must be hated."
Faced with such jarring realizations, people ask why. They recall the time when they lived together and often did not know or care whether their neighbor was a Serb, a Croat, a Muslim or a Montenegrin; and they wonder now how that time could be washed away in a tide of hatred.
Some see international plots aimed at carving up the Balkans, arguing that it suits major powers like Germany and the United States to deal with small, militarily feeble, economically dependent countries.
Many blame the politicians, men like President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, who had been faithful Communist apparatchiks until it suited them to become nationalists in order to cling to power.
Others blame Yugoslavia's former Communist leader, Tito, for fostering the nation's great lie: that the savage civil war fought by Croats, Serbs and Muslims between 1941 and 1945 could be forgotten and buried without judgment.
When Tito's Communist clamp was lifted, an explosion fed by the simmering ethnic hatreds of the 1940's ensued. Gordon Babic, a businessman from Sarajevo with a Serbian father and Muslim mother, was caught in the middle. His family fled the Bosnian capital for Belgrade last year. "I used to believe the world was governed by the laws of Isaac Newton," he says, "but after a year of the Bosnian war I believe Satan pulls the strings. This is pure madness."
The madness is captured in the appalling proliferation of maps here. Mottled monsters, they chart the makeup of what was Yugoslavia by race, religion and nationality.
The maps are now sordid weapons of propaganda, pointed to in any argument over why some patch should belong to one ethnic group rather than another. But in better days, they demonstrated how intertwined, through marriage and movement, Serbs, Croats, Muslims and others had become.
"The ethnic map of prewar Bosnia, and indeed prewar Yugoslavia, was like a jaguar's skin," said Vuk Draskovic, the main Serbian political opponent of President Milosevic. "The peoples were inseparably mixed. No magician could make ethnic borders on such a jaguar's skin."
But all the armies have been trying. "Ethnic cleansing" -- the killing and forced shifting of people to create ethnically homogeneous areas -- has, in turn, become the most overused term in the land. Ibrahim Rugova, the leader of the majority Albanian community in the Serbian province of Kosovo, says Albanians are suffering "a quiet process of ethnic cleansing." He says Serbian oppression is forcing Albanians to leave.
Serbs in Kosovo, meanwhile, say they are suffering "ethnic cleansing" by the Albanians, who have been boycotting Serbian businesses to further their drive for an independent state.
This exasperates John Erath, an American diplomat. "Ethnic cleansing is an expression that is losing its meaning," he said.
Meaning is generally elusive today in what was Yugoslavia. Two years of war have bequeathed emotional exhaustion. "I'm O.K. because I have to be O.K.," says a woman in Belgrade. "Otherwise I'll die. And I don't want to die."
Young people are emigrating, perhaps as many as 200,000 from Serbia alone over the past year. Those that remain are in limbo. "People are tired," says one young woman. "They have no emotional energy left. Couples tend to stay together and single people do not get together. There seems to be no point in coupling."
This emotional emptiness means that it is hard to draw any reaction from people, even against leaders who have taken the country to economic disaster and ruin.
Every evening the desolating images fill the television screens: mutilated bodies, charred corpses, tales of rape and castration. There is a peculiar savagery to the butchery in Bosnia, even by the standards of war, a savagery also evident in the 1941-45 period, when babies were shot.
Why such horror? "You have to understand the fratricidal element to the bestiality," says Zarka Kovac, a prominent psychologist. "These are people with scarcely any physical differences. The Muslims are Serbs or Croats converted during the Turkish occupation. So you mutilate the person you have killed in order not to recognize your brother. This war is Cain and Abel."
Already, it is a war that has remade the Balkan map. Referring to the shape of Yugoslavia, which resembled a bird, and to the current slithering tangle of borders, Bojan Jovanovic, a Belgrade University anthropologist, said: "The bird that was Yugoslavia died in the night and in its place came several lizards."


GRAPHIC: Through all the debate last week over whether to intervene to stop the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbian attacks against Muslims continued. The United Nations Security Council proclaimed Sarajevo and four other besieged areas of Bosnia -- Bihac, Zepa, Gorazde and Tuzla -- to be "safe areas" but approved no measures to enforce its order. (The council declared the besieged eastern town of Srebrenica to be a "United Nations protected area." on April 16). Allied forces watched, from planes overhead, and waited.
 
BIHAC: Serbian forces last week mounted an unsuccessful infantry assault on this western enclave, whose predominantly Muslim population is estimated at 267,000, including many refugees. The city's prewar population was only 71,000.
 
BANJA LUKA: Bosnia Serbs were blamed for bombs that last week destroyed two 16th century mosques in the city where ther are 35,000 to 80,000 non-Serbs. The population has swelled because local Serbian extremists have expelled thousands of Muslims and Croats from districts surrounding the city, the largest in the Serbian-controlled swath of Bosnia.
 
TUZLA: Fighting in the area last week centered on the towns of Brcko and Gradacac, key Serbian targets because they control important sections of the overland corridor between Serbia and Serbian-held areas in western Bosnia and Croatia. The 725,000 people in the city of Tuzla and surrounding districts are connected with central Bosnia, and the outside world, by a single dirt road over high mountains.
 
SARAJEVO: The multi-ethnic Bosnian capital, under siege by Serbian forces throughout the war, experienced a relatively quiet week, with reports of only sporadic shelling and sniper fire. It population is 380,000, down from 526,000 before the war because many residents have fled. About 1,500 United Nations troops are there to supervise aid distribution and the airport.
 
GORAZDE: the area has been under siege for more than a year, though there were few reports of fighting last week. Its prewar population of 37,000 has swelled to 70,000 because of refugees fleeing Serb offensives. The only link with the outside world is a mountain track to central Bosnia crossed only on foot or horseback.
 
ZEPA: Unconfirmed reports from the eastern enclave spoke of fierce Serbian attacks and penetrations of Muslim defense lines. The enclave's population is estimated at 30,000 to 40,000 people, more than three-fourth of them refugees and about 8,000 of them children.
 
SREBRENICA: Though open warfare has waned, Bosnian Serb militiamen maintain their chokehold on the United Nations-protected town. Officials have expressed concern that malnutrition and poor sanitation might lead to epidemics. There are about 49,000 people in the enclave, thousands of them refugees.
 
UNITED NATIONS FORCES: Their safety is a primary concern as the United States and it allies consider intervention. There are 9,000 troops throughout Bosnia, primarily involved in relief efforts. Their main headquarters is in Kiseljak, near Sarajevo. An additional 14,000 peacekeeping troops are deployed in United Nations-protected areas of Croatia. Their headquarters is in Zagreb.
 
OUTSIDE FORCES
 
NO-FLIGHT ENFORCEMENT: Nearly 100 aircraft are involved, from the United States, France, Britain, the Netherlands, Turkey and NATO. The planes, including AWACS radar surveillance aircraft, fly from a variety of bases in the region, primarily Italy. Twelve American warplanes assigned to the mission fly from the carrier Theodore Roosevelt in the Adriatic.
 
SANCTIONS ENFORCEMENT: Seven NATO warships patrol in two groups in the Adriatic, along with five ships from the Western European Union. The effort also includes increased customs inspections and patrols along the Danube River.
 
STANDING BY: The United States carrier Theodore Roosevelt, cruising in the Adriatic with 5 other American warships, has more than 50 warplanes that could be used in bombing raids. There are also 6,000 marines on board. Presumably, United States Air Force planes would be sent to bases in Italy would also participate in air strikes.
 
THE VICTIMS: The Bosnian Government says 135,000 people have been killed in Bosnia, in addition to the more than 25,000 deaths in earlier fighting in the Yugoslav war, primarily in Croatia. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that the war has created 4.4 million refugees, equal to the population of Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1991.

HEADLINE: MAY 2-8;
Astronomers Rage Against the Light

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
For the past century astronomers have waged an unequal battle against the mounting glare of electric lighting across night skies -- a smog of light pollution that renders faint galaxies all but invisible.
Two of the latest threats to astronomy stem from America's faltering economy and a widespread fear of crime. 
 One potential victim is the mighty 200-inch telescope on Mount Palomar, Calif., which has led the world in observational astronomy since the late 1940's. In 1984, San Diego, some 40 miles away, acceded to astronomers' pleas and replaced its white street lights with low-pressure sodium lamps. Astronomers love the pure yellow light because it is easily filtered from their instruments. But San Diego residents believe it aids thieves (though there is no proof of this).
The San Diego City Council, hoping to revive its downtown, is moving to replace its lighting with a lamp that could seriously degrade deep-space observations from Palomar.
Meanwhile, a Georgia company, Space Marketing, has announced plans to put a one-mile-wide reflective panel into space some time in 1996. Ostensibly a platform for scientific instruments, this satellite, which would appear nearly as large as the full moon, would carry a commercial message or symbol visible from the ground.
"The time may not be distant," said one anguished astronomer, "when we'll have to move to the far side of the moon if astronomy is to survive."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
This Blessed Plot, This Glitzy Mall, This England

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: WEST THURROCK, England

 BODY:
IT rises like a pastel apparition from the surrounding English countryside, more than 1.35 million square feet of landscaped atriums, shops, fast-food restaurants, movie theaters, fountains and bubble elevators, all of it under a single roof topped by glass domes and surrounded by 9,000 parking places. The Lakeside Centre is metropolitan London's largest shopping mall, a two-year-old retailing fortress set among the rolling hills of far Essex, 17 miles east of central London. On its busiest weeks, it will draw as many as 350,000 shoppers and 175,000 automobiles, and cause traffic on the nearby London beltway to back up for miles in both directions.
More than three decades after the push toward the suburbs remade America's cities, and introduced the shopping mall as the permanent alternative to Main Street, the last 10 years have seen British retailers mount their own invasion of the shires and sleepy hamlets beyond London, Birmingham and other cities. 
 Developers were abetted by the aggressive philosophy of deregulation espoused by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, whose disciples loosened the viselike controls of local planning authorities in the name of competition and free commerce. Since the mid-1980's they have opened five regional malls similar to Lakeside and built more than 250 smaller retail clusters of outlet stores, mega-supermarkets and discount warehouses amid green hills and pastures once crossed only by hedgerows. According to one survey, the new suburban and exurban centers now claim more than 17 percent of the British retail market in 1991, a more than threefold increase in less than 10 years.
But with Britain's economic malaise blunting the zeal of property developers, a growing number of government planners, rural preservationists and even retailers have pressed their own counteroffensive to roll back what they describe as the Americanization of England's countryside.
"They suck the vitality out of the city at the same time they exacerbate the process of out-of-town sprawl," said Tony Burton, a senior planner for the Council for the Protection of Rural England, who believes that the projects have not only scarred the countryside, but also depreciated the urban areas as well. "This small island of Britain cannot be turned into America, because we don't have the space to waste which you do."
 
Cars and Fumes

 
 Responding to concerns that such sprawl was exacting a toll not only on the country's landscape, but its cultural and economic heritage as well, the environment and transportation departments have published new planning guidelines that focus the attention of developers and shoppers on Britain's aging town centers.
At the heart of the guidelines -- which the Government hopes to implement later this year -- is a determination to emphasize traditional retail patterns, many of which are served by public transportation, over new "out-of-town" development, which is far more dependent on the private automobile. The guidelines' sponsors argue that this plan will reduce both fuel consumption and harmful automobile emissions by 10 to 15 percent over the next 25 years. The policy will also reaffirm the country's commitment to long-standing land use and settlement patterns, which feature highly compact, densely settled urban centers surrounded by mostly open green belts, where both commercial and residential development has been cautiously restricted.
Lakeside's 380 stores have dealt a blow to the local High Streets -- the British equivalent of Main Street -- in nearby Basildon and Dagenham. Mr. Burton asserts that cookie-cutter malls, retail parks and discount warehouses are also eroding the singularity of Britain's landscape. "We are losing the sense of place and local character that we all cherish and believe has made the British countryside so special," he said.
Lakeside is a clone of a suburban American complex, with two McDonalds, Sam Goody and The Gap. Two theme restaurants, a mock riverboat called Old Orleans and a Chicago-style speakeasy named Capone's, overlook a lake that was once a gravel quarry.
 
Following Europe's Lead

 
 In recent years, even some retailers have questioned the rush to the suburbs, warning that by overdeveloping outside the cities, merchants and chain stores were robbing themselves of business in town. Ross L. Davies, a professor at Oxford's Templeton College and director of the Oxford Institute of Retail Management, said retailers, far from wanting the Government to proscribe such development, want it to urge local governments to measure more carefully the impact of a proposed development on existing retail patterns.
Europe, which flirted briefly with the idea of suburban retail development in the 1970's, decided to tighten its own planning regulations to concentrate on town centers. "That we are shifting back now too reflects thinking across the European Community, particularly in regard to automobiles," Mr. Davies said. "The overall feeling is that we've got to shift people to public transportation, and to achieve that we must reduce urban sprawl and emphasize existing routes."
This does not mean that the Government will bar large-scale outlying projects any time soon. Outside Manchester, developers say they intend to go forward with plans for a 300-acre complex on the city's outskirts, despite complaints from local governments that it will rob local towns of retail business and add to traffic congestion and pollution.
To the developers, the heart of the matter is satisfying consumer demands, not the abstract notions of planners. "Once people have gotten used to the idea of free parking, discounted prices, wide selection and climate-controlled shopping, the High Street just doesn't look the same anymore," said Brian Lucas, the manager of Lakeside.

HEADLINE: Clinton Reverses Policies at U.N. On Rights Issues

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Taking a more aggressive stance on international human rights issues than its Republican predecessors, the Clinton Administration is pressing for appointment of a High Commissioner for Human Rights at the United Nations, as well as a special envoy to investigate abuses against women.
The initiatives were part of a nine-page proposal presented this week to a human rights meeting in Geneva by J. Kenneth Blackwell, the head of the United States delegation. 
 "This is the new Administration's action plan," Mr. Blackwell said after presenting the plan in Geneva. "It builds on what the new Administration perceives as American traditions, values, and standards in regards to human rights and it also offers new ideas and a new assertiveness in other areas."
 
Rights Conference Planned
 The Geneva meeting was held to plan a major United Nations conference on Human Rights scheduled for June in Vienna. By the end of the meeting today it became clear that the Vienna conference would evolve into a showdown between Western nations seeking tougher human rights standards and developing nations, led by China, Iran and Pakistan, which oppose any new monitors of rights abuses.
Both Ronald Reagan and George Bush opposed the idea of a High Commissioner for Human Rights, who would coordinate the United Nations' human rights activities. The two Republican Presidents had argued that establishing such an office would add to the United Nations' bureaucracy.
The proposal put forward by the United States on Thursday would designate a United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights to oversee the implementation of decisions of all United Nations human rights bodies, assume responsibility for human rights issues related to peacekeeping and relief aid and have the authority to send special envoys to investigate allegations of human rights violations.
The commissioner would also have the power to bring to the attention of the Security Council allegations of gross human rights abuses.
The United States document also called on the United Nations to spend more money on human rights activities. The United Nations currently spends about $11 million annually -- about 1 percent of its total budget -- on human rights efforts.
Some American diplomats hope that the United Nations will increase spending in this area to about 5 percent of its total budget. These officials say they hope to reach that level by shifting funds that are already in the budget, not by asking governments to contribute more.
The document strongly emphasizes the rights of women. It recommends the appointment of a special envoy to investigate instances of violence against women, including "battering in the family, rape, female infanticide, honor killings and dowry murder."
But some women's groups criticized the United States proposal for failing to mention "reproductive rights," a phrase by which they usually mean women's access to family planning services, including abortion. Some also want the United States to support the idea that fear of persecution because of sex could be a basis for granting political asylum.
In March, the Clinton Administration also reversed previous United States policy when it supported a resolution expressing "deep concern" over human rights abuses in East Timor, the former Portuguese colony that was invaded by Indonesia and then annexed. Last year, a similar, though more strongly worded, resolution was blocked by the United States, Australia and Japan.
In another area of concern among human rights advocates and some members of Congress, Mr. Clinton has yet to say whether his Administration will seek to renew China's favorable trade status without conditions.
Christopher Patten, the Governor of Hong Kong, said after meetings with United States officials this week that he expected human rights conditions to be attached to the renewal of China's trade status.
State Department officials say the Administration will probably push for Congressional acceptance of four treaties that the United States signed under President Carter, but were never officially approved. The treaties are the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the Inter-American Human Rights Declaration, and two accords that ban discrimination based on race and gender.
Officials of human rights groups say they are being taken more seriously by this Administration than by its Republican predecessors.
"There is clearly a signal that has been given at the highest levels of the Administration to get the word out that the nongovernmental human rights organizations are welcome back," said James O'Dea, director of the Washington office of Amnesty International.
"What I note now is that the access is higher and the meetings aren't pro forma," Mr. O'Dea said, comparing the Clinton Administration with the Reagan and Bush Administrations. "It isn't just window dressing."
Some critics note, however, that an emphasis on human rights was also a cornerstone of the foreign policy of Mr. Carter and that he was forced to turn a blind eye to abuses in some countries when not to have done so would have meant a clash with United States strategic interests.

HEADLINE: For Korean Immigrants, America Is Land of Golf

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Shouts of "Gong!" -- Korean for "Fore!" -- echoed across the damp, verdant fairways of the Great Gorge Country Club near McAfee, N.J., as clusters of grocers attacked the course from a half-dozen separate starting tees.
"It's called shotgun play," said Myong Y. Juch, president of the Korean-American Grocers Association of New York. "We can start and finish at the same time and save almost two hours." Although shotgun play is commonly used so all the players in a tournament can start at the same time, the technique seemed particularly fitting to these golfers, who approached the game with aggressive enthusiasm. 
 Thursday marked the group's third tournament, and intermittent rain was no obstacle to the practical, no-nonsense, time-is-money participants. The grocers relaxed with the same directed vigor with which most work 12- or 14-hour days running the stores that have altered the face of New York and other cities.
Little matter that many of the 105 players will never shatter 100, much less par. They scrutinized maps of each hole as if scouting a military operation, lined up their shots like the touring pros they had seen on television, then protested as physics exacted its often cruel course.
An exemplary effort, however, uniformly drew the following comment, "Nice shot."
 
An American Luxury
 Golf's attraction for Koreans lies partly in the fact that it was so out of reach in the old country. Participants recalled that country club memberships cost $50,000 in Seoul, when available at all. Greens fees commonly exceed $100 there, and caddies are mandatory at as much as $50 before tip.
"Some people came over here to play golf," said K. D. Hwang, who lives in New Jersey and owns a store in Manhattan.
In the New York area, some said, they play as often as once a week, sometimes beginning at 5 A.M. Many said they most often play with fellow grocers, discussing such business topics as prices, insurance and taxes.
The day of golf was supported by many of the food and beverage distributors who have come to realize the importance of Korean grocers in the city's economy. Marketing people from Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola, R.J. Reynolds, Apple & Eve fruit juices and several milk companies were among those dropping by to give money for entry fees and convey goodwill.
Indeed, a 30-foot-high inflatable can of Bud Lite commanded a prominent position, while many grocers wore bright yellow raincoats touting Camel cigarettes.
"The Korean grocers are hugely important," declared Phil Birnbaum of Anheuser-Busch.
Of late, political talk has been markedly increasing. One topic is the recent verdict in the Rodney King case in Los Angeles. Just as Korean merchants there feared they might be the victims of rioters if the policemen accused of violating Mr. King's civil rights had been acquitted, New York's Korean grocers heaved sighs of relief. "Some people blame Korean grocers for everything," Mr. Juch said.
 
Political Issues
 The president characterized his members as an increasingly sophisticated group, no longer content to be "buttered up by politicians who tell us how hard we work and how smart our kids are."
He said that every mayoral candidate had met with the grocers' group and that soon each would be presented with a list of specific demands. The list, he said, will include reductions in commercial rent taxes, an easing of the issuance of sanitation tickets and a crackdown on illegal vendors.
In particular, he wants tax abatements on four buildings that the association is buying in Long Island City, Queens, to form a wholesalers' cooperative to sell to retail stores. The buildings are being purchased by the Korean Trade Development Corporation, a Korean Government agency, which in turn will rent the 100,000 square feet of space to the association. Korea hopes to use the co-op as a means to get more Korean exports into Korean groceries.
Mr. Juch emphasized that the heightened movement into politics of his membership as well as the more sophisticated approach to business planning represented by the co-op dramatize the growing sophistication of Koreans in the grocery business here. He said a survey indicated they average 42.5 years of age, have been in the United States for 7.5 years, have been in business 3 years and are considerably more affluent than their predecessors.
"Nowadays, they come with a bunch of money," he said, often through selling their home in Korea for $300,000 or more. "Ten or 15 years ago, you would hear stories of people starting out with $10 or $20, but no more."
Their business acumen is undeniable, say wholesalers and others. The grocers say few stores close, except for retirement or to move into a better location. Peter Spinella, Coca-Cola's director of special markets, agreed, saying, "They drive a hard bargain."
Some of the bargains have been to help improve often tattered relations with people in the poorer communities that many Korean grocers serve. On Tuesday at Hunter College they will join with Coca-Cola to present five black students with $2,000 scholarships. Anheuser-Busch gives $15,000 in scholarships to equal numbers of Korean and black students.
But golf took precedence on Thursday, as rain became sun. "This is comfortable," Sang M. Lee said. "Business is 24 hours sometimes, and this gives you time to yourself."
Mr. Lee's brother, Sang Hyun Lee, who works in the same store at 53d Street and Second Avenue, agreed that golf was his biggest relaxation, then proceeded to demonstrate why. He whacked a nine-iron shot high into the air, then watched it land four feet from the flag. "That's why people come back," he said with a tickled grin. "Just for the one great shot."
They might also come back for the awards. Anheuser-Busch presented 17 trophies, all waist-high and gleaming. Others were given 21 impressive golf bags. The person with the nearest shot to the hole on No. 6 won a round-trip plane ticket to Seoul. Everybody not yet awarded something was asked to raise his hand and presented with gift certificates for Korean food.
One of the trophies was won by Mr. Juch's wife, Chung, one of four women to participate. "If I hadn't invited her, she'd be working at the store today," an ebullient Mr. Juch said in presenting the award. "A lucky lady."

HEADLINE: Shifting List of Prospects To Be Justice

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
President Clinton is expected to announce an appointment to the Supreme Court within the next two or three weeks, White House officials said, although no one has emerged in the two-month search as a front runner.
Mr. Clinton is described by aides as preferring a woman, but several men have been on a list of candidates that has been growing and shrinking almost daily since Associate Justice Byron R. White announced in March that he would be retiring this summer when the Court term ends. Senate aides say it will take six weeks between a nomination and the beginning of hearings, and the White House wants confirmation proceedings to be completed in July, before the Senate leaves Aug. 9 for a monthlong recess. 
 Aides say that Mr. Clinton has eliminated many names while other officials have added others, and by all outward appearances he does not appear to have settled on even a short-list of candidates. The initial list was said to have included dozens of judges, law professors and politicians.
 
Closely Involved President
 Senior lawmakers in Congress say they have not been provided any names, and officials say the President has not spoken to any judge or other candidate about the job. His advisers say they do not know whether he will interview one or several candidates once the list is culled down, or simply select someone who is already familiar enough to him that a meeting would be unnecessary.
By most accounts, the President has played a more involved role in the selection process than any of his recent predecessors, and if there is a single reason why this search has taken significantly longer than previous Supreme Court searches, it is because it has largely been playing out in Mr. Clinton's head.
As a former state Attorney General and professor of constitutional law, he has long expressed a fascination with the Court, and his participation in the search has made it more demanding for the White House staff. He is described by some aides as regularly mulling over dossiers of candidates that include their opinions and writings and ordering his advisers to return with more names. He has also wavered over which constituencies the nomination should appeal to; in particular, the President has been concentrating on female, Hispanic and Jewish candidates.
He and his advisers have said they are looking for a progressive thinker who believes in a constitutional right to abortion and privacy as well as someone who would be able to forge coalitions. As their model, they have pointed to former Associate Justice William J. Brennan.
Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, by contrast, selected six of the nine Justices now on the Court by taking the recommendations of their senior advisers and doing almost no selection work on their own. They would frequently name replacements within days of a Justice's announcement of his retirement.
Unlike his predecessors, who were in office for considerable periods before having to make an appointment, Mr. Clinton was in office for barely two months when Justice White announced his plans. Indeed, Mr. Clinton praised the Justice for giving him so long to conduct a search.
 
Starting From Scratch
 Last month, White House officials told some lawmakers that the President had begun the search from scratch after two leading contenders, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Judith Kaye, the chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals, removed themselves from consideration.
So far, the candidates under the most serious consideration for Justice White's seat have mostly been judges. Officials say that the list has included Shirley S. Abrahamson of the Wisconsin Supreme Court and five Federal appeals court judges: Richard S. Arnold of Little Rock, Ark.; Stephen G. Breyer of Boston; Ruth Bader Ginsburg of Washington; Mary M. Schroeder of Phoenix, and Stephanie K. Seymour of Tulsa, Okla. Another judge who has been mentioned is Jose A. Cabranes of Federal District Court in Connecticut.
Officials emphasized this week that many others whom they would not identify have also been under consideration and it was impossible even to point to possible front runners.
 
Constraints on Choices
 They said that Mr. Clinton had instructed aides to look beyond the courts for possible candidates and include lawmakers and state officials, although in searching for a politician, the White House faces some constraints.
Aides said Mr. Clinton might have been inclined to select a senator like his fellow alumnus from Yale Law School, Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut; or the majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, who was a United States Attorney and a Federal district judge in Maine before he arrived in Washington, or Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, who graduated from Harvard Law School and practiced for seven years after clerking for a Federal appeals judge.
But the Democrats' slim majority in the Senate makes it politically unpalatable to do anything that would erode the party's control of Congress, particularly in light of the recent failure of the Administration's economic stimulus package in the Senate.
Mr. Clinton has not given serious consideration to elevating Attorney General Janet Reno to the Court, an aide said, largely because the Administration does not have the stomach to go through yet another search for a new leader of the Justice Department.
White House aides say the strongest influence over the decision will come from Hillary Rodham Clinton. In addition to her, the search for a new Justice is being conducted by the White House counsel, Bernard W. Nussbaum; his deputy, Vince Foster, and Ronald Klain, an associate White House counsel who used to be a clerk to Justice White and a senior aide to Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Delaware Democrat who heads the Senate Judiciary committee. Bruce Lindsey, director of personnel at the White House, has also been heavily involved.

HEADLINE: U.N. Weighs Plea to North Korea

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 8

 BODY:
The Security Council plans to take up a resolution in the coming week urging North Korea to open two suspected nuclear weapons sites to international inspectors.
The resolution was drafted by the United States and is supported by Britain, France and Russia. China, which has close though not always easy relations with North Korea, is expected to abstain but not to veto the measure. 
 North Korea insists that it has no nuclear weapons program and says it will not submit to regular inspections so long as American troops are stationed in South Korea.
 
Withdrawal From Treaty
 Rather than allow inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency, a United Nations agency, North Korea said in March that it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, as of June 12.
The proposed resolution calls on the Pyongyang Government to reconsider that decision. Western powers fear that North Korea's defection could prompt the departure of other countries that have signed the treaty but are suspected of running clandestine nuclear weapons programs.
Like the Western powers, China is concerned about Pyongyang's potential nuclear capabilities but has previously opposed Security Council initiatives to act on the issue. In the past, Washington has urged that economic sanctions be imposed against North Korea, but the proposed resolution makes no mention of them, diplomats said. Instead, it urges other countries to encourage Pyongyang to cooperate.
At the request of China, State Department officials have met with North Korean diplomats, and further meetings are planned. Some American officials have expressed concern that if Washington increases its reliance on Beijing to put pressure on North Korea, the Clinton Administration will have to ease its stand on China's human rights record and agree to expand trade.

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Carter, at Rice, Urges Help for the Less Fortunate in the World

 BODY:
Former President Jimmy Carter urged more than 1,000 graduates at Rice University in Houston yesterday to use their educational opportunities and their commitment to freedom to help less fortunate people around the world.
Mr. Carter devoted most of his commencement address to global conflicts. So-called ethnic cleansing, he said, is not unique to Bosnia, with racial and religious divisions now fueling more wars than at any other time in history. "Racial, religious, ethnic differences still cause tremendous suffering, deliberately perpetrated by one human being upon another," he said. 
 Mr. Carter, a Democrat from Georgia who was President from 1977 to 1981, told the graduating students that the Carter Center in Atlanta is now monitoring 112 global conflicts, including 32 major wars.
"This century, far beyond any other in history, has been burdened with tragedy, the unanticipated, deliberate murder of people by their own governments," he said.
With the end of the cold war, the United States as the sole superpower has become increasingly responsible for influencing the world, the former President said.
"We can't be the world's policeman -- that's not what I'm talking about," he continued. "But the economic and the political and the military and the cultural influences of the United States permeate the world."
He said it was too early to say how the United States would measure up to the challenge of using its expertise and resources to promote global peace, democracy and economic justice.
"The greatest discrimination in the earth today, including in our own country, is discrimination by the rich against the poor," Mr. Carter said.
After his speech he left for Paraguay to help oversee that country's Presidential election today. The former President has worked as an election observer in Haiti, Panama and several other countries.
Mr. Carter spoke at commencement exercises that were held under sunny skies at the university's academic quadrangle.
Rice awarded bachelors' degrees to 672 undergraduates and masters' degrees to 307 graduate students. The university does not confer honorary degrees.
 
Howard University
 Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, a former Democratic national chairman, was the main speaker at Howard University's commencement exercises yesterday on the university's main campus in Washington.
Mr. Brown told the 2,200 graduates that "we live in times of great challenge, hope and opportunity, times of transition and change," and urged them to "keep the drum beat of activism alive" and "to rouse those who have become too comfortable for the struggle and to reinvigorate those too tired to fight."
The university conferred 1,500 bachelors' degrees and 700 masters' degrees.
Mr. Brown was awarded an honorary doctor of laws degree. Also receiving honorary degrees were Debbie Allen, the writer, choreographer and producer, and Dr. James P. Comer, a child psychiatrist at Yale University.
The late Reginald F. Lewis, former chairman and chief executive of TLC Beatrice International, was posthumously awarded an honorary degree.
 
James Madison University
 Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia delivered the main address yesterday at commencement exercises for 1,745 students at James Madison University. The university's 84th annual commencement was held on the campus in Harrisonburg, Va.
The speech by Mr. Wilder, the first black to be elected Governor, continues a recent tradition at James Madison: each of his two immediate predecessors, Charles S. Robb and Gerald L. Baliles, addressed the university's graduates while serving as Virginia's chief executive.
After Governor Wilder's address, graduates of the university's six colleges and its general-studies program attended smaller ceremonies where they received their diplomas.
 
Indiana University
 At ceremonies marking its 163d annual commencement, Indiana University began conferring undergraduate and graduate degrees on 14,776 students yesterday.
The ceremonies began with the presentation of 8,166 degrees in Memorial Stadium at the main campus in Bloomington. Degrees were presented to 6,116 undergraduate students and 1,984 graduate students.
Commencement ceremonies will continue at the university's eight campuses, beginning today and continuing through the week.
Robert Shaw, a former choral director at the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood, Mass., and a faculty member at the Julliard School of Music, delivered the main address. Mr. Shaw, the conductor laureate of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, received an honorary Doctor of Music degree.
