HEADLINE: Rave at Close of Day? You Betcha

BYLINE: By BETSY ISRAEL

DATELINE: DEER PARK, L.I.

 BODY:
It's 10 P.M. at a Deer Park 7-Eleven, and the rave boys wander in for supplies: five jars of Vicks Vaporub, three asthma inhalers and what seems like the entire contents of the Hostess cupcake stand. Bundled inside Day-Glo raincoats and dangling sock hats, they might be fast-food bandits on a sugar high, turnpike kids who rented "A Clockwork Orange" and have frightened the neighbors ever since.
What they are is the latest group of Long Island boys to play dress-up. Back in the 1970's and 80's, many like them -- out of high school, not quite in college -- put on fishnet tights and drove to see "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" in deepest Uniondale. Now, local boys head for Deer Park, in Suffolk County, and a former gay disco known on Fridays -- rave nights -- as Caffeine. "It's all natural," explains a fountain-haired cashier as the boys head out toward the parental Buick. "Caffeine stands for natural highs. Rave is, like, natural speed, just dancing, no gang stuff. It's like" -- and she pauses, watching a hot dog roll over inside a roaster -- "it's like the 60's." 
 Raves were the youth event of the late 80's. They began in northern England, where thousands of kids would spend whole days outdoors dancing spasmodically to very fast "techno" music. Raves were underground and, some said, political. There was talk of releasing the "primordial energy of the Earth through technology." Mostly there was a lot of the drug Ecstasy, mixed with Gluconate, an energy-inducing drink tasting like Gatorade, and amyl nitrite. The star techno deejays were all American, and in time, raves spread to cities in the United States -- to V.F.W. halls and warehouses; one was even held under a Belt Parkway overpass in Brooklyn. Then, as a boy in a gas mask later explains, "the cops came, like, forever."
Caffeine offers a compromise: primary rave elements (a dark, nondescript warehouse; wall-quaking techno) mixed with standard club features like alcohol and advertising (officially, no drugs, at least not on the premises). Ira Levy, the manager, who at 29 has had much experience with clubs and rave, says, "It's like that bar in the middle of nowhere in 'The Blues Brothers,' and the audience can't believe what's inside."
What's inside, say those on thick lines outside, is "not Long Island." Barbara, 18, of Centereach, a "sort of model" in black Lycra and arm-denting jewelry, says that "here, it's not, like, any one sexuality." Her friend John, who works at King Kullen, pushing items forward on the shelf, "leveling them" so there will seem to be more, likes it "that Caffeine doesn't make you be the same boring person."
Here, the club populations of Long Island unite like warring clans. Before Caffeine, there were the Jewish American princess clubs in JAP locales (the Five Towns, Island Park, various "corporate" points along the North Shore). There were "Guido" places, all those South Shore Italian bars and discos ("Joey joints," says one Merrick girl, referring to that patron saint of Guidos, Joey Buttafuoco). And separate from these were black and Hispanic clubs and the traditional bars-with-a-pool-table.
But at Caffeine, midway between North and South Shores, it's all-island: Ravers and bikers and girls in skirts the length of washcloths out to "par-ty!" toblot out the days spent parked behind some doctor's office window or inside Caldor's. Alex That, 23, of Levittown, a co-owner and promoter, explains the draw: "An underground is a weekend; a club lasts for years."
For local kids, the first purely island-born generation, Caffeine is a piece of the city imported 52 exits out on the Long Island Expressway. "You go in the city, like to Limelight," says a girl with purplish Amy Fisher hair draping an eye, "and they look at you and you're 18 and suddenly it's 19 to get in. You just spent 50 bucks getting there, and where are you?" Caffeine provides remedial clubbing, a kind of suburban club bootcamp for kids who think the city is too far away, too expensive, too tough. It's a safe place, with a "real 60's feel." It's true this feeling is safeguarded by large men with flashlights and headsets. "But it's totally free," says the girl with Amy hair, "compared to boring life."
In Warehouse B, a back room lined with carnival games and a case of scorpions, a techno nostalgia night is under way. "It's for people who love the music," says Mr. That, "and they miss their favorite techno from when we opened, like, in '91." Techno, a speedy synthesized hybrid of hip-hop and mid-80's "house" is a highly disposable pop musical form. ("You play it once," says the star deejay Frankie Bones, "and then some other guy plays it, you gotta throw it out. It'sover, dead, get outta here.")
Mr. That and a high school friend, Kevin Kraft, took over the club, then owned by Mr. Kraft's father, "to help Long Island keep up with the music and to educate people about how to listen, how to get into a rave head." The rave head, or philosophy, dictates nonviolent fashion (ravers often look like swaddled scarecrows) and an aerobic nonalcoholic high. "You do what you gotta do to promote the rave head," Mr. That says. "Without it, you get fights. Undesirables." What he means is "you get Guidos," a term that was once used to describe slick-suited Italian guys and that now covers anyone hinting at a too-macho stance, any guy with a Davy Crockett "do"; a muscly tank top; a Coors bottle defensively covering the Levi's crotch.
"Either he goes, O-U-T, or he gets tuned to rave," said Joe Cruz, the bouncer, who has witnessed Guido rehabilitation firsthand. "I haven't broken up a fight in two years here."
And so tonight, "in celebration of peace," says one deejay, it's 1990. There's a linoleum floor strip for breakdancing. There's a bar crowd, buying alcohol instead of the usual Jolt, an all-sugar, high-caffeine cola. Three young Korean kids move on to the floor, hopping lightly in place near the strip. Two hold beer bottles; one hugs an Sesame Street doll strapped to his chest. "The kid feels good when he's wearing Ernie," explains a 21-year-old man selling T-shirts. "Ernie says: We like our childhood. We like that other people don't try to rip it off our face."
On the main floor, the raving floor, are the hardcore boys smearing Vicks on their faces (it enhances the high) and, at the edges, the "spectators," the ones who have accessories -- a sock hat, a disco whistle -- but not the "total body spirit." All around, dressed in bustiers and tent-size jeans, are the girls, working hard tonight at imitating the boys. They toss out rap-like gestures, a modified air guitar. But it's the boys who form the dense sweaty nucleus, the true raving womb at the center.
"Those girls are wearing, like, underwear," comments a 20-year-old unemployed carpenter wrapped in cellophane and reeking of sweat. (True ravers often rave into the next day. Showering interferes with this.) "The underwear girls don't get that it's not about the display of you."
Girls don't "get it," some say, because they try to bring contact into a dance form about solitary movement -- sex as opposed to masturbation. Others believe girls can't rave because they typically carry leather pouches, cigarette cases, actual purses, while real ravers carry knapsacks filled with gear. One boy has stashed two giant pacifiers, Devil Dogs and 30 glow-in-the-dark necklaces. Another has a thermos of Kool-Aid, Flintstones vitamins and a Ken doll. Someone has brought a box of matzohs. A bustier girl passes a matzoh slice to her friend, who passes it on. They cheer as the matzoh makes its way through the crowd. Kevin Kraft, pointing this out, says: "See? Who knows what they were doing before they came. Now they're doing just what they want."
Outside, on a wood-slatted patio arranged in risers, some girls -- silver moons on their faces, glitter webs in their hair -- are skipping around, crooning about how open and "60's" it all is. It's 35 degrees outside but they are coatless; one is barefoot. Their only concern right now is how commercial an article like this might make Caffeine.
"In the 50's and 60's, people left the hippies, the Grateful Dead all alone," says an angry boy. "That's why they lasted so long. Why do we want people from the city coming out to ruin it? This is our perfect little thing."
Sandra and Laura, who claim to be 18 although they also claim to be Levittown sophomores, look around at this perfect little thing, unimpressed. It is cold. They had thought the scene would be weirder. "But," Laura says, "what are you gonna do? Like, sit behind the high school drinking beers?"
"It's boring," Sandra says, wiggling a stacked slinky of bracelets on each arm. "Here, it's more . . . the 60's."
Except that it could be anytime on Long Island. Change the cars, the slang, the preferred drugs, and you still have local kids dressing up for an event that began "in the city" and moved out -- some gender-bending ritual that is so "totally free compared to boring life" that no one notices it's an expertly staged imitation.
"Who cares?" Sandra says. "It's not like you wanna go out with a raveguy."
"You want someone who takes a shower," Laura says, clarifying. "Maybe from Bensonhurst. Or guys from the city."
"We go to the city all the time," Laura says, looking at Sandra, who tries to recall precisely when. "Like it was not too . . . it was recently," Sandra says.
Laura coughs a giggle away as she says, "Once we went."

LENGTH: 1311 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Plainfield

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
WITH nine districts on the National Register of Historic Places, this Union County city probably has New Jersey's most diverse housing stock.
Stately turretted Queen Annes stand next to Second Empires with mansard roofs and Italianate houses on broad lawns. Most of these large homes were built by turn-of the century businessmen who moved their families to the suburbs and commuted by rail to New York City. 
 The housing stock, which also includes post-World War II Capes, split levels, colonials and ranches, is for sale at bargain prices because of the residual effects of race riots in the late 1960's. Although some neighborhoods, such as the Sleepy Hollow area on the east side of town, with its winding, tree-lined streets and large, custom houses, remain well-manicured, many formerly gracious streets near the center of town, like West Fourth, are blighted, with boarded-up buildings and shards of auto glass on the streets.
Prices range from about $50,000 for a small two-bedroom colonial on a narrow lot to $550,000 for houses with up to eight bedrooms, four baths and four fireplaces on one to three acres on the east side.
"Dollar for dollar, you can't buy what you can buy here anywhere else in the state," said Aaron Campbell, an associate at Century 21 John C. Campbell Realty. "For instance, I just sold a four-bedroom house with a nice fireplace, right near a park, for $136,000."
Mr. Campbell said that he also recently sold a small colonial on McCrea Street on the west side of town for $55,000. Two-family houses near the center of the city go for $90,000 to $125,000.
Most apartment houses are on West Seventh and West Eighth Streets. There are also many apartments in large Victorian homes that have been converted to multifamily dwellings. One-bedroom apartments rent for $500 to $600 a month, with two bedrooms renting for about $100 more and three going for up to $1,000.
One of the residents of the Crescent Hill Historic District is Theodore U. Horger, vice chairman of the Historical Preservation Commission. An engineer at A.T.& T. in nearby Basking Ridge, Mr. Horger owns an 1877 Italianate house and says he enjoys the feeling of living with history and a diverse population.
"My main complaint is the business district," he says. "I would like to see it revitalized."
That district, around Front Street and Park Avenue, has two supermarkets and the usual mix of video stores, banks and small department stores. The largest store in town, Macy's, is boarded up, as are several smaller ones.
Mayor Harold W. Mitchell said he hoped to bring the business district back through a series of incentives, most important of which is the state designation of the area as an Enterprise Zone. This lets store owners collect a 3 percent state sales tax, as opposed to the normal 6 percent. Much of the tax revenue is returned to the city by the state for special capital improvements. Last year, Plainfield used $300,000 of those funds to convert a vacant lot into a downtown park.
"THE city is turning around," said Mayor Mitchell. "We in City Hall have started working with the real estate community, the parents, the schools -- everyone we can who is involved in the system -- to try and make this a better place."
He has also instituted community policing in problem areas and a residency requirement for all municipal employees, a policy that he says made the civil service more stable.
For a small city, Plainfield has a large variety of good, moderately priced restaurants, like Caruso's on South Avenue, with an Italian menu, Freshwaters on Fourth Street, which serves soul food, and Lilly Greenleaves on East Front Street, with an American menu. There are also Jamaican, Colombian and kosher restaurants.
Among the newer residents are Dr. Thomas H. Brown, president of Union County College, and his wife Tressa, a supervisor in the Plainfield Public School District. Two years ago, they moved from Utica, N.Y., after buying a 1914 five-bedroom center-hall colonial on Evergreen Avenue near the city center.
"We just fell in love with the architecture of the city," said Dr. Brown.
Dr. Brown has also contributed toward the renewal of the city by overseeing the revitalization of the Plainfield campus of the college on Church Street, which was shut down in 1990 for a two-year reconstruction. When it reopened last fall, the student body increased from 250 in 1990 to more than 1,000 today.
"We're already seeing a trend near the campus," Dr. Brown said. "Apartment building owners are installing new windows and several new businesses -- a deli, a bakery and others -- have opened to cater to the students."
Although 26 percent of the city's population is white, they make up only 1.5 percent of the 6,700-student Plainfield School District. Superintendent of Schools Dr. Annette Kearney said most of the white school-age children attended private schools in neighboring towns. Dr. Kearney terms this apparent lack of confidence in the system "unfortunate."
She conceded that there were "challenges" facing the school system, including teen-age pregnancies and drugs, that force the faculty to do frequent locker sweeps. However, she said that Plainfield's schools provided a good education and sent 55 percent of their graduates on to higher education; last year a Plainfield High student scored 1540 out of a possible 1600 on the Scholastic Aptitude Tests, which are used by colleges to evaluate potential students.
"OVER the past year," she said, "we saw a slight rise in the number of white students in the schools. Perhaps that's because of the recession and the rising tuition in private schools. We hope that it is the beginning of a trend."
The Plainfield School District has 10 K-6 elementary schools, the largest of which is the 612-student Emerson School on Emerson Street. There are two middle schools, which send graduates on to Plainfield High on Park Avenue, and a special education school and an alternative school with programs to keep students from dropping out.
There are two K-8 private schools, the nonsectarian Wardlaw-Hartridge School and the Roman Catholic Holy Family School.
Plainfield traces its roots to 1684, when Thomas Gordon, a Scot from Perth Amboy, became the first settler to build a bark house, with the help of the Leni Lenape Indians, along what came to be known as Cedar Brook. Front Street was part of an Indian trail that connected the Hudson and Delaware Rivers. Until the early 19th century, when the construction of mills attracted workers, it remained a sparsely populated farming community.
ACCORDING to town histories, the first regular passenger service to New York City was the Swift Shore Line, a combination stagecoach to Elizabeth and steamboat to Manhattan. The growing population attracted the Elizabethtown and Somerville Railroad in 1837 and, in 1849, the Central Railroad of New Jersey established a direct connection to New York City, opening the area to commuters and setting off a development boom.
From 1835 to 1869 the population increased more than 11-fold, from 1,030 to 12,000.
Among Plainfield's many historic buildings on the National Register is Drake House on West Front Street. Built in stages starting in 1746, it now houses the Historical Society of Plainfield and the Drake House Museum, with its collection of period furniture. It is open on Saturdays from 2 to 4 P.M.
City Hall, a 1915 Georgian-style brick building with large stone pilasters, is also on the National Register, as is St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, a Victorian Gothic brick structure on Liberty Street.
In all, the city has 253 acres of parkland. The most widely used park is the 86-acre Cedar Brook Park, off Rose Street, which has two softball diamonds, one baseball diamond, four tennis courts, field hockey and football fields and picnic areas.

HEADLINE: The Inquisition in Mississippi

BYLINE: By Drew Gilpin Faust; Drew Gilpin Faust is an Annenberg professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania. Her most recent book is "Southern Stories: Slaveholders in Peace and War."

 BODY:

TUMULT AND SILENCE AT SECOND CREEK
An Inquiry Into a Civil War
Slave Conspiracy.
By Winthrop D. Jordan.
Illustrated. 391 pp. Baton Rouge:
Louisiana State University Press. $24.95. 
 THIS book, Winthrop D. Jordan tells us in his opening sentence, "is a story, but at the same time it is not." With this paradox, Mr. Jordan characterizes the outcome of more than 20 years of investigation into events that occurred nearly a century and a half ago. "Tumult and Silence at Second Creek: An Inquiry Into a Civil War Slave Conspiracy" is at once an effort to capture the experience of black and white Mississippians confronting the implications of the Civil War for Southern slavery and also -- and perhaps even more fundamentally -- an exploration into the nature of historical inquiry and interpretation.
Mr. Jordan, a professor of history and Afro-American studies at the University of Mississippi, has written a work of historical scholarship that leaves its scaffolding standing and visible, a study in which the process of discovery is at least as important as the result. He not only invites the engaged reader to participate in the struggle to understand the past, but he also includes almost all the available evidence in appendixes.
At the center of both of Mr. Jordan's linked objectives lies a single document, a record, in the handwriting of a white planter named Lemuel Parker Conner, of slave testimony before an extralegal examination committee in Adams County, Mississippi, in September 1861. Happening upon the manuscript in a Louisiana archive in 1971, Mr. Jordan set out to make sense of the tumult it described.
In the spring of 1861, he discovered, slaves in Adams County, "on a group of plantations near Second Creek," began, amid the disruptions of a society at war, to contemplate a plan for seizing their freedom. When fearful whites overheard expressions of rebelliousness, they undertook a formal interrogation of implicated slaves in order to stamp out any sparks of insurrection. As a result of their efforts, more than 27 slaves in and around Natchez, Miss., were hanged.
Yet little has been known about this tragedy, and the fragments of information inscribed in the historical record have for the most part been wrong. The "tumult" of the book's title has been surrounded by a "silence" that originally grew out of the desire of 19th-century Mississippians to prevent white panic over potential insurrections.
Yet the persistence of this silence into our own time, Mr. Jordan believes, has hidden from history an event of considerable significance, a slave conspiracy comparable to episodes, like Nat Turner's 1831 uprising, that have come to play a critical part in our understanding of the African-American past.
To make sense of Conner's document, Mr. Jordan draws upon his deep knowledge of American slavery and race relations. In 1968, he published "White Over Black: American Attitudes Toward the Negro, 1550-1812," a work that swept across centuries and continents -- European, African, American -- in an effort to identify the sources and origins of white racism. It was one of the most influential and acclaimed studies in the outpouring of work by scholars in the late 1960's and early 1970's that transformed our understanding of slavery. But like many other historians of slavery in recent years, Mr. Jordan has shifted, in his new book, from the inclusive breadth of "White Over Black" to the specificities of time and place permitted in a case study. And similarly reflecting more general scholarly trends, his concerns now encompass black attitudes and perspectives as well as white. Indeed, the special value of Conner's transcription, Mr. Jordan maintains, is that it "furnishes more information about the thoughts and aims of a group of rebel slaves than any other single document in American history."
Mr. Jordan's careful re-creation of the Natchez district of Mississippi in 1861 draws on every source he has been able to find in 20 years of searching and presents not just the economy of the cotton plantation South and the social fabric of perhaps the wealthiest slave-owning elite in North America, but the sights, sounds and smells of that time and place. He traces intricate relationships among slaves accused of participation in "the Plan," explores the reputations, family background and political loyalties of their owners, and discerns motivational ideologies in the fragments of slave statements recorded in Conner's hand. In the tense nature of some of the recorded testimony, Mr. Jordan hears "the slash of the whip" and concludes that "the term examine takes on the stench of euphemism for physical brutality." In the slave states, as Mr. Jordan notes, "whipping as a means of obtaining confessions" was not uncommon.
Yet for all the ingenuity of Mr. Jordan's research, for all the imagination and insight he brings to bear on his scanty sources, for all the richness of context in which he is able to place these events, he cannot, as he concedes at the outset, really tell the story of a slave conspiracy at Second Creek. He hopes instead, he says, to offer a "tapestry" or "something of a story."
But despite this open confession of the historian's inability to weave a sequential tale of cause and effect, Mr. Jordan, in some sense, wants to have it both ways, for he never really questions the basic reality of the plot itself. In order to establish the existence of an organized conspiracy, he reasserts the historian's authority he has ostensibly abandoned. Yet, empowered by Mr. Jordan's own offering of his documentary evidence and by his notion of a necessary arbitrariness and a certain relativism in historical interpretation, this reader finds it likely that the tumult at Second Creek was as much the creation of white fears as of actual slave conspiracy. Mr. Jordan does not satisfactorily establish that an organized plot, of the sort contrived by Nat Turner, ever really existed.
There were a few local observers who took such a view of the matter, judging that the slaves' discussions were largely a form of fantasizing about what they might do when the Yankees were victorious and Armageddon brought freedom at last. Mr. Jordan argues that Conner's document represented a verbatim transcription of slave testimony, but it is difficult to imagine that any frightened white Southerner in 1861 would not record at least some of what he expected to hear rather than what was actually said.
And it is impossible not to believe that white men with whips and guns would extract from terrorized slaves what the victims of the lash knew their oppressors wanted them to say. The slaves' testimony about their intentions toward the planters' women is crucial here. Conner's transcription contains several references by those being interrogated to their intention to "ravish" the planters' wives and daughters. "The persistent naming of individual women," Mr. Jordan notes, "is unique among the documents of slave rebellion in the United States."
As Mr. Jordan recognized in "White Over Black" a quarter-century ago, white fear of black sexuality was a fundamental aspect of the psychological and ideological context of North American slavery. But it was founded more in the projection of white anxieties than in any record of black aggressiveness, even during the upheaval of the Civil War.
What then is the meaning of the references in Conner's document? And what does their presence suggest about the significance of the document as a whole? Would slaves have used the term "ravish"? Does the frequent appearance of the word cast some doubt on the manuscript as a verbatim transcript? Does the attention to sexual violence throughout the testimony perhaps suggest that slaves, expecting death no matter what they said, decided at least to reap the pleasure of feeding their masters' worst fears? Was the plot more fantasy than conspiracy?
MR. JORDAN is not convincing when he dismisses the absence of a specific time and date for action by suggesting that African-Americans did not share white obsessions with temporal exactitude. The failure of the rebels to attend to such details supports a contemporary critic of the proceedings who believed that the slaves' conversations addressed the still uncertain Day of Jubilo.
Historians in the 1960's and 1970's quarreled about the existence or nonexistence of rebellions and conspiracies in order to buttress arguments about the essential docility of slaves or about their willing acceptance of their lack of freedom. There can remain little question in 1993 about the commitment of African-Americans in the Civil War South to their own liberation. More than 100,000 ex-slaves risked their lives as soldiers fighting for that freedom, and countless others emancipated themselves by running to Union lines.
The importance of deciding whether the tumult at Second Creek was a black plan or a white panic is not its relevance to these now outdated questions. It is instead to assess the significance of Conner's document and the accuracy of Mr. Jordan's assertion of its value. Does Conner provide a transparent window into the world of the slaves, or is the document a product and an index of white fears and white racism? Has Mr. Jordan gone beyond "White Over Black," beyond the world of the masters into the world of the slaves? Or has he struggled so desperately to overcome the silences surrounding the slave experience that he has misread white constructions of black men for the men themselves?
In keeping with his promises at the outset, Mr. Jordan's book ends not as a story might, with a resolution. It ends with a curious silence -- a description of a pall that hangs over the land today and the banal declaration that the conspirators at Second Creek "lived in particular circumstances and . . . dealt with particular difficulties. In this they shared with other human beings the universal trial of living and dying each and all in their own way." Having been given the sights and smells, even the documents themselves, we as readers are finally left to decide what it all amounted to -- for the participants and their survivors, for the South, for the course of the Civil War, for America.

HEADLINE: No Room for Sentiment on Immigration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your inclusion of Emma Lazarus's "New Colossus" in "Pleas for Asylum Inundate System for Immigration" (front page, April 25), to whose sentiments some Americans might still adhere: the bitter reality is that we are not the same country we were in 1883. 
 At the time of the poem there were still vast areas of undeveloped land as well as seemingly inexhaustible natural resources. As much as we might like to think that our immigration policy then was based on America's magnanimous character, is it not more likely it was our insatiable appetite for cheap labor that drove open-door immigration policies?.
Now that the United States has entered middle age, it is time for us to acknowledge our inability to continue to absorb an endless stream of immigrants. We can no longer base immigration laws on lofty sentiments. Given our economic problems (most notably the protracted unemployment), we've got to make some possibly harsh decisions on immigration.
The World Trade Center bombing highlights another reason not to tolerate a lax immigration system: the unchecked entry of dangerous individuals harboring deadly anti-American agendas.
 
STEVEN A. JENSEN
Brooklyn, April 29, 1993

HEADLINE: Rebuilding Lags in Los Angeles a Year After Riots

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 9

 BODY:
More than a year after the violent disorders that left much of central Los Angeles in ruins, fewer than half the buildings that suffered major damage have been restored. Most of the rest are either shells of crumbling walls or rubble-strewn lots.
Many conflicting forces have combined to slow the rebuilding: lack of money, problems collecting insurance and getting loans, heavy winter rains, bureaucratic delays with permits, compliance with modern seismic and disability codes, opposition to liquor stores, a depressed local economy and, for many owners, sheer fear and weariness. 
 The shop owners who have reopened say business is good, given the lack of competition. But in the area that was hardest hit, South-Central Los Angeles, the rebuilding has been slowest. There are pockets of rejuvenation where new supermarkets and malls have sprung up, now behind high wrought-iron fences to deter looters and vandals. But miles of seedy commercial streets are still pockmarked by year-old rubble, and full-scale rebuilding remains a distant glimmer.
These are some of the findings that emerge from separate building-by-building surveys of damage throughout the city by The New York Times and the Los Angeles Department of Building and Safety, concentrating on the three areas hit hardest by the unrest -- the South-Central section, Koreatown and the adjoining Hispanic Pico-Union area, and Hollywood.
 
1,118 Buildings Checked
 In all, 1,118 buildings were checked, and 513 of them were found to have been repaired. Most of the restoration was to shops looted and burned in the riots, which caused $1 billion in damage. But while nearly half the destruction has been repaired in Koreatown and nearly two-thirds in Hollywood, less than a third has in the largely black and Hispanic South-Central area.
Those who have rebuilt have tended to have deep personal or commercial roots in the neighborhoods, while the large numbers of absentee landlords appear to be waiting for signals of better economic times. In the South-Central area, less property is locally owned, there are both fewer people and fewer resources and banks generally have been less willing to lend there than in Koreatown or Hollywood.
The heartbreak, complexity and hope of Los Angeles's travails are summed up in John Williams. Born in the city, the 67-year-old black businessman has made his life in the South-Central district. He owned two adjacent buildings on South Vermont Avenue near Manchester Avenue. He leased one to a Korean furniture merchant; the other housed Mr. Williams's Universal College of Beauty, a thriving business that employed seven people teaching cosmetology to 100 students.
The rioters made a target of the Korean's store, not the beauty school. But they did not realize that Mr. Williams had his office on a mezzanine above the furniture shop, and all of his records were destroyed in the fire. And so was the school when the flames spread.
A year later, Mr. Williams has managed to rebuild and reopen the school, with $280,000 in insurance money that covered most of the $320,000 cost.
Unlike others, he is not discouraged. "I see no reason to run," he said, standing in the fenced-in lot that was the furniture store, whose Korean owner also wants to reopen. "I am going to run back with something better."
 
More Ambitious Plans
 Mr. Williams says he wants to rebuild the furniture store's building even bigger, with other businesses, including another vocational school. He has approval for a $500,000 loan from the Small Business Administration, but that is not enough.
Mr. Williams is one of the few owners to rebuild in his neighborhood. Just across Vermont Avenue are two vacant blocks, 8400 and 8500, that look like Dresden after the Allies bombed the German city in 1945. The blocks once housed a dozen or so shops, mostly Korean run.
A check of county property records suggests why. Like much of the South-Central section, many of the owners on the blocks are Iranians, Koreans and Chinese who have migrated here in large numbers in the last two decades and live in affluent suburban enclaves. For example, the owner of record of numerous burned-out buildings on Vermont Avenue and other main thoroughfares is Eli Sasson of 626 South Spring Street, an office building in downtown Los Angeles. Mr. Sasson did not return repeated telephone calls for comment on why his properties remain vacant lots.
The survey was conducted by visually checking all the addresses in the city that suffered more than 10 percent damage according to a compilation by the Department of Building and Safety after the riots.
 
Korean Stores Damaged Most
 The results quantified what had been apparent from the first day of riots: the brunt of damage was borne by Korean merchants. Forty-seven percent of the heavily damaged buildings were occupied by Korean merchants, though they were often not the owners. This figure was arrived at by comparing the addresses of heavily damaged buildings to those of looted and burned Korean-owned businesses compiled by the Center for Pacific Rim Studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. Over all, according to the center, three-quarters of the wrecked businesses were run by Koreans.
The study findings conform roughly to a recent survey of damage conducted by the Department of Building and Safety. Rather than addresses, the department counted legal "parcels" of land, which could have more than one building and address. It found that of 1,120 parcels that had some damage, 371 remained leveled, 25 had only braced walls and no construction activity, 104 were under repair, 71 were not severely damaged but remained unrepaired, and 550 had been completely rebuilt.
A spokesman for the department, Nick Delli Quadri, theorized that Koreatown was rebuilding faster because of the "cohesiveness" of that community and the self-financing networks the Koreans maintain, but this access to finance and local ownership is lacking in the impoverished South-Central area.
 
An Overwhelming Task
 Many owners have found the task of rebuilding overwhelming. Max and Frances Fenten, an elderly couple who live in the affluent Beverlywood area, owned a block of four leased stores on South Vermont Avenue that is now nothing but a fenced-in lot.
"We are too old to start again," Mrs. Fenten said in a weary tone, adding they would probably try to sell the lot.
Further south on Vermont, John and Ruby Scott, owned a building they rented to a Korean, who ran a minimarket. The Scotts do not plan to rebuild, just convert the land to a parking lot. Not far away, Church's Fried Chicken, based in San Antonio, does not expect to rebuild the fast-food restaurant that was burned to the ground.
But those owners with the money, political savvy and determination to rebuild have found it profitable. One of the fastest to rebuild in the South-Central area was Denmarst Limited, a family-owned real estate company that had its mall on the northwest corner of Vermont Avenue and Martin Luther King Boulevard burned and looted, with $2.5 million of lost rental income.
Within four months, the company had reopened and even enlarged the mall, which now has 13 shops, all doing good volume because there is so little nearby competition.
"We are committed to South-Central," said Dennis Neeleman, partner with his two brothers, Marc and Steven, in Denmarst. "This is all we know. We had everything down here. It's not like we could just move out to Westwood. Also we had motivated tenants who wanted us to reopen quickly."
But the going has been slower for less well-financed owners, like George Hwang, a 59-year-old Korean immigrant and his wife, Kay. They moved to Los Angeles 23 years ago. Both worked menial jobs for years to save up enough to buy a gas station and then later a six-store mall at West Eighth Street and Vermont Avenue in Koreatown. Rioters burned the mall to the ground, for a loss of more than $1 million.
The two-story mall is 80 percent rebuilt, but will not reopen until September. While his insurer was prompt in paying the claim, Mr. Hwang said he was slowed by the winter rains, contractor problems and city permit problems, and uncertainty about which tenants would return.
Still, the Hwangs are more fortunate than merchants in the South-Central area. Banks have generally been more willing to invest in Koreatown. Also, fewer of the busineses there were liquor stores and were not subject to the same zoning restrictions as the 150 burned South-Central liquor stores. In Los Angeles, each time a liquor store is opened or built a new zoning request must be made.
 
Hollow Insurance Policies
 Many of the Korean merchants found they had hollow insurance policies. Recently about 100 joined in a suit against "nonadmitted" insurers, the many carriers not licensed in California who sold insurance here and have failed to meet millions of dollars in claims. Steve and Alice Kim lost their coin laundry on West Adams Street in South-Central to fire on the first night of rioting. They said it would cost $300,000 to rebuild; but none of their $150,000 insurance with their Texas-based carrier has been paid.
"We are angry at the Government and police, because they didn't protect us," said Mrs. Kim. "We are American citizens. We are paying taxes. How come that kind of insurance company can have a business here?"
Even those businessees whose insurance companies did pay often find other obstacles. For years, Louis Ross ran a small chain of dry cleaners in the South-Central district. Now 77 years old and living in Beverly Hills, he sold the businesses to others about 15 years ago, but kept the property. One of them, on Western Avenue near West 34th Street, was wrecked by rioters. It had both a dry cleaner and a gas station.
His insurance paid promptly, but there is no sign of rebuilding at the lot, behind a chain-link fence. Mr. Ross owns the land free and clear and is eager to rebuild, but is faced with the cost of complying with state and Federal environmental regulations governing gas stations. "I've got an unknown cost of trying to clean up," he said. "This area has always been good for business, but we need a godfather to get it done."
 
Six Months for Approvals
 Miles away in Hollywood, Rob Markley, co-owner of the Atlas Furniture Company on Santa Monica Boulevard has found that his chief enemy in rebuilding is the city itself. He and his father, Les, operated a furniture store, which was looted, and leased four adjoining stores to Korean merchants that were burned. He said that they had their architectural plans to rebuild ready within less than three months of the riots, but that it took six months just to get city approvals.
With only five more minutes needed to complete plan approval, he said, one city inspector refused to work past 5 P.M., causing a two-week delay. Another month was lost in trying to persudae the city there was an alley behind the building, though anyone could drive down it. And just the other day, a building inspector refused to enter the construction site to approve the electrical work because the smell of roofing tar disagreed with him.
Mr. Della Quadri of the Department of Building and Safety defended his agency, saying it had established a "one-stop" permit office for riot victims but that certain hurdles were unavoidable, such a requirements that new construction meet modern seismic and disability standards if the damage was more than 50 percent.
"We are always getting people who say it takes too long," he said. "But there are certain code requirements that have to be met."

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Fighting to Keep Its Tax Breaks for Businesses

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico

 BODY:
Abolish the exemption, the government of Puerto Rico says, and the economy of this Caribbean commonwealth will be crippled for years to come. But the Clinton Administration, intent on raising new revenue to reduce the Federal deficit, is nonetheless moving to revoke a multibillion-dollar tax break for American mainland companies operating here.
At issue is Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code, which gives mainland United States companies an exemption from Federal taxes on income earned in Puerto Rico, whether it comes from operations or interest on local bank deposits. Critics here and in Washington assail the exemption as nothing more than an expensive giveaway. 
 Puerto Rico's new Governor, Dr. Pedro J. Rossello, and business groups contend that eliminating the provision will virtually destroy the island's manufacturing industries, which employs about 165,000. It would also deprive the local government of a big revenue source: a tax of up to 10 percent on profits that mainland companies send home from their Puerto Rican operations. If the Clinton plan is adopted, many in Puerto Rico fear that businesses will leave the island and take their bank deposits with them.
 Rebuffed by the Treasury and the White House, Puerto Rico's leaders have come up with an alternative plan and are taking their case to Congress.
"We recognize that, as American citizens, we Puerto Ricans will have to participate in the President's call to sacrifice," said Daniel Lebron, president of the Puerto Rico Manufacturers' Association, in an interview here. "But we are asking that our sacrifice be proportional to our economic situation and that additional unemployment not be created on an island where 18 percent of the people already are without jobs and the per-capita income is only one-third that of the mainland."
But some Puerto Ricans say they would welcome the elimination of the tax breaks, which, they contend, have long outlived their usefulness. They say that the corporate beneficiaries of the system are exaggerating the impact the changes would have on Puerto Rico's economy and that the companies' vows to abandon the island if Section 936 is abolished are empty threats.
The tax exemption is for corporations only. Individuals on the United States mainland, for example, could not use Section 936 to shelter money by placing it in Puerto Rican banks. United States citizens residing in Puerto Rico pay no Federal income taxes on income derived from Puerto Rican sources.
Section 936 is "nothing but a welfare program for the Fortune 500," said Luis Costas, a tax attorney here who has written extensively on the program. "It's a profit-shifting operation that allows companies based in Puerto Rico to purchase supplies and materials from their corporate headquarters at a much lower than usual rate, while selling the finished product back at the highest price, thus inflating profits."
And Miriam Ramirez de Ferrer, president of Puerto Ricans in Civic Action, a pro-statehood group opposed to the tax-incentive program, asserted: "It has had a long trial and it hasn't worked. Section 936 has cost the United States Treasury billions of dollars, and yet in Puerto Rico we still have 18 percent unemployment and a per capita income of just over $6,000 a year."
During the cold war, a tax-incentive program was the principal instrument used by Washington to build Puerto Rico as a free-market, democratic alternative to Cuba. Supporters of the tax-exemption system argue that as a result of the program, Puerto Rico has the highest standard of living in the Caribbean.
 
 
Credits for Wages
 But the Treasury now wants businesses here to pay taxes on profits and interest income. To ease the burden, it is willing to grant companies income tax credits for workers' wages and credits against a tax on interest income based on investments in plants and equipment. Under the Clinton plan, the Treasury estimated that it would raise $7.3 billion over five years from Puerto Rico.
Among the companies operating in Puerto Rico are Abbott Laboratories, General Electric, Hewlett-Packard, Upjohn and Westinghouse Electric.
A proposal by Puerto Rico's Governor would permit Washington to tax income earned here but would offset that with a 100 percent credit for wages and a partial credit for fringe benefits, local taxes, interest earned on bank deposits and capital investment. Alternatively, the plan would allow for 80 percent of a company's profits to be tax exempt.
The Governor said that his "eminently reasonable" proposal, which has received a cool reception from the White House, would produce $3 billion to $4 billion in revenue for the Treasury Department over five years -- less than the Clinton proposal -- without inflicting unnecessary hardships on Puerto Rico's 3.6 million residents.
 
 
'Numbers Game'
 "What has emerged thus far from the Administration, specifically the Treasury Department, is a numbers game that doesn't take people into account," said Dr. Rossello, a physician who took office in January vowing to lead the island toward statehood.
Of the 975,000 people employed in Puerto Rico, about 110,000, or more than 11 percent, are in manufacturing jobs generated by about 300 companies that enjoy the benefits of Section 936. An additional 55,000 jobs, including many in businesses that supply the tax-exempt companies, make up the rest of the manufacturing sector. Although manufacturing accounts for less than 17 percent of all jobs in Puerto Rico, it generates 40 percent of the island's $34 billion in yearly gross product.
While the Federal Government has provided some form of tax incentive in Puerto Rico since 1921, a tax-exemption policy became the main engine of growth here only in the period after after World War II, when Operation Bootstrap was begun. Proponents of Section 936, which has been in place since 1976, argue that without the measure and its predecessors, Puerto Rico would never have been able to industrialize or to achieve its relatively high standard of living.
 The uncertain outlook for Section 936 has generated considerable alarm and resentment here, dominating headlines and intensifying the debate leading up to a plebiscite on statehood scheduled for November. In March, an estimated 100,000 people marched to protest the changes favored by Washington, and it is not unusual to spot "I Support Section 936" bumper stickers.
Evelyn Berrios was one of those marchers in March. She has worked in tax-exempt factories since 1966, the last 11 years at the Puerto Rico plant of Electro-Biology Inc., a medical instruments company based in Parsippany, N.J., with a plant in the San Juan suburb of Guaynabo. She said any system of incentives that enabled people like her to send two daughters to college and to buy stock in her employer had to be beneficial to Puerto Rico.
 
Drastic Effect Feared
 "We are all very much aware of what is going on and worried that it will affect us drastically," she said. "We don't know what we would do if we lose that. We are willing to sacrifice, but we want to conserve our jobs."
Companies receive as much as $70,000 a year in tax write-offs for each job created under Section 936. Such jobs pay $6.25 an hour on average, excluding fringe benefits, compared with an average wage of more than $12 an hour for manufacturing jobs on the mainland.
Nearly 60 percent of tax benefits -- estimated at $2.7 billion a year -- go to some 60 drug companies that account for 18 percent of the jobs provided by Section 936.
The Clinton proposal strikes especially hard at the drug, electrical equipment and food processing industries that Puerto Rico's government sees as the most promising engines of future industrial growth. Marcos Rodriguez-Ema, president of the Government Economic Development Bank, said his bank concluded that high-tech companies would end up paying an effective tax rate of more than 30 percent under the Clinton proposal -- slightly less than the mainland's tax rate and more than the 20 percent rate under Dr. Rossello's plan.
"That knocks us out of the race" with Mexico to attract mainland companies if the North American Free Trade Agreement passes, the Governor said.
The Clinton Administration plan would also affect some $16 billion in deposits that mainland companies keep in local banks or have reinvested here. That money, large in relation to the size of the Puerto Rican economy, has allowed banks sufficient liquidity to pay low interest rates on deposits, to offer loans at rates slightly lower than on the mainland, to make loans to businesses and to finance the construction of schools, hospitals and roads.
 
 
Taxing Interest on Deposits
 The Administration wants to tax the interest from the deposits, but companies can offset that with an 80 percent credit for the value of their equipment, machinery and facilities here, which total more than $5 billion. The $5 billion in assets would allow for a credit of $4 billion, meaning that the interest earned on $12 billion of the $16 billion in deposits would be taxed.
Officials predicted that the $12 billion in deposits would flee the island; the withdrawal would seriously affect the ability of the commonwealth's government to function. A local "tollgate tax" of up to 10 percent on profits repatriated to the mainland provides the Government with about 12 percent of its total revenue, some $500 million, for which there is currently no substitute.
"It would definitely cause us a gigantic decline," Governor Rossello said of a tax on interest earnings. "It would immediately cost us half a billion dollars a year, a loss that would be reflected in services. If we're already cutting programs because of a budget deficit, and we would have half a billion less, it would mean chaos in Puerto Rico."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We are all very much aware of what is going on and worried that it will affect us drastically," said Evelyn Berrios, who has worked since 1966 in the tax-free Guaynabo, Puerto Rico, plant of Electro-Biology Inc., a medical instruments company based in Parsippany, N.J. (Laura Magruder for The New York Times) (pg. D8)

HEADLINE: Bosnia Move? Not Just Now;
Few Expect a Decision On Use of Force Soon

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Why is it taking so long? Are they just stalling, or what?
The carnage in Bosnia has been horrifying the rest of the world for a year now. Troops from Britain, France and other countries have been there for months under the auspices of the United Nations, doing what little they could to alleviate the suffering. President Clinton has been talking for weeks about new, tougher actions. 
 Yet this weekend in Washington and in the West European capitals, there was still no agreement on what sort of military action should be taken, or when to start. There was no agreement, in fact, on just how much military action could achieve.
To hear the White House tell it, the delay stems largely from European doubts. But the memory of Vietnam, with futile escalation following futile escalation, with bombing campaigns succeeded by pauses succeeded by more bombing and more pauses, has made American officials, military and civilian, look three times before they leap.
 
No Desire to Rush Things
 This time, they vow, they will have an answer to the question that dogged a whole generation of leaders: If this doesn't work, what next? This time, they vow, they will take the country into their confidence before acting.
Call it prudent, call it fainthearted, there is no disposition on the American side to rush things. Few in Washington see much prospect of allied military moves in the Balkans this week.
The Europeans do indeed remain skeptical about taking any military action, though some are ready to set doubts aside in the interest of maintaining good relations with the United States. The British in particular are loath to see President Clinton intervene alone, get his nose bloodied and then turn his back on Europe.
But the West Europeans, who tend to believe in containing problems rather than solving them, have set very limited goals for any military moves. They want to ease the Serbian pressure on Muslim enclaves in central and eastern Bosnia and prevent the fighting from spreading to other countries.
So, pushed to the wall, they favor the use of air power against the Bosnian Serbs' artillery, ammunition dumps and supply routes because that would not widen the war, even though they question how effective it would be. But they favor it only after giving the international peace plan every conceivable chance (including some that seem pretty inconceivable, like a referendum on the plan that the Bosnian Serbs propose to hold next weekend).
 
A List of European Fears
 The Europeans have compiled, furthermore, a formidable list of things to worry about and talk about before agreeing to go forward. Prime Minister Poul N. Rasmussen of Denmark, whose country currently holds the presidency of the European Community for a six-month period, was here last week, discussing some of the pitfalls.
"Without a common enemy in Moscow," he said, "it isn't so easy to coordinate our efforts. Can we get weapons through to the Muslims? If we do, will they be able to fight effectively? What about the peacekeeping troops already there? Will we bring the Croats back into full-scale conflict? Will the war spread to Kosovo and Macedonia? Will the Russians decide to help their Slavic cousins?"
To many American ears, recitals like that sound like excuses for continuing inaction. Not so, the Europeans respond. A ranking European diplomat insisted on Friday, "We will get an agreement, believe it or not, and we will get it within the next week."
President Clinton said much the same thing. But at least in part, this is a case of the wish giving birth to the thought.
 
Europe Has Different Goals
 The Clinton Administration has much broader goals than the Europeans have, and the gap that results has yet to be bridged. Although Mr. Clinton has concluded that there is no real prospect of rolling back Serbian gains with outside military force, he still hopes to influence the underlying political situation. Unwilling to send American troops to tilt the balance on the battlefield, he wants to allow arms to reach the Muslims and use air power mainly to hold off the Bosnian Serbs until deliveries of heavy weapons to their enemies can be completed.
Mr. Clinton could, in theory, undertake that policy on his own. But his advisers think it would be political suicide to try to do so at a time when American voters, fretful about the domestic economy, think Europeans should take the principal role in looking after Europe. Senior figures in Congress who hope to push through a measure of support for the President when the moment comes say they can not do it if he does not already have the Europeans on board.
Mr. Clinton did not take the steps he could have taken while Secretary of State Warren Christopher was making the rounds of the European capitals last week in search of consensus. He did not appeal to the American people on television for support for action in Bosnia; he did not even use his weekly radio speech to do so.
Nor did he announce his strategy publicly and call upon the Europeans, once Mr. Christopher's initial talks had been completed, to follow his lead.
The truth is that almost no one in any of the major capitals is terribly confident that allied arms can make a decisive difference, no matter how they are employed. One of Mr. Clinton's chief advisers spoke the other night about the President's plan as "the least bad thing we could come up with in a situation where we think we have to do something, if we don't want to seem to be condoning genocide."
Lord Owen, the European Community's peace negotiator, said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" today that "you will not solve the problem at 10,000 feet." But it has not been settled by months at the bargaining table, either, and solving it on the battlefields would entail more fighting and more widespread death and destruction.

HEADLINE: Congressmen Urge Action if Iraq Hatched Plot to Assassinate Bush

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Senior Democrats and Republicans in Congress urged the Clinton Administration today to take military action against Iraq if it is shown that its Government plotted to assassinate former President George Bush in Kuwait last month.
"We should retaliate," Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the Foreign Affairs Committee, said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." He added: "We cannot tolerate that kind of an action against a former President of the United States. It's just outrageous." 
 Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said on the same program that a military response "is the only thing that Iraq would understand."
On Saturday, the White House said law enforcement agencies had sent investigators to Kuwait to determine whether Iraq tried to kill Mr. Bush in retaliation for his role in forging the coalition against Baghdad in the Persian Gulf war. Kuwaiti officials have accused 17 people, including 11 Iraqis, of conspiracy to kill Mr. Bush and to conduct "other acts of terrorism, infiltration and robbery." Sixteen of the suspects are in custody in Kuwait.
 
U.S. Waiting for Proof
 Clinton Administration officials have said they have found strong but inconclusive evidence that Iraq directed the assassination plot. But with events in the Balkans preoccupying the White House, officials have signaled that they will not act swiftly and will instead await the conclusions of the investigation.
American officials said this weekend that they had no doubt that the group planned one or more remote-controlled car bomb attacks during Mr. Bush's visit to Kuwait City April 14-16, when he received an award from the Emir in recognition of the American-led military operation that drove the Iraqis from Kuwait in February 1991. But they said that it remained unclear where or when the group intended to move the vehicles to sites near Mr. Bush's route, and that it remained possible that the plot was intended only to disrupt his triumphal tour.
Iraqi officials have ridiculed the accusations. In a statement issued in Amman, Jordan, on Saturday and reported by Reuters, the Iraqi Information Minister, Hamed Youssef al-Hammadi, said, "The sheiks of Kuwait in coordination with American intelligence are plotting another deception to fool American public opinion in order to justify a new aggression on Iraq and tighten the economic siege imposed on it."
Mr. Hammadi said the fact that the accusations had been made by the Kuwaiti Information Minister, Sheik Saud Nasser al-Saud al-Sabah, made it clear that the story was fabricated.
"Sheik Saud al-Sabah is a big liar because it is known that his daughter, Nira, was used by the American intelligence to mislead Congress and American public opinion by concocting the known incubator story before the military aggression on Iraq," Mr. Hammadi said. He was referring to the testimony by Sheik Saud's daughter to Congress while the sheik was Kuwait's Ambassador in Washington about reported atrocities by Iraqis during their occupation of Kuwait. The testimony has since been widely discounted, although it helped to shape American public opinion in favor of Kuwait.
Representative Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip from Georgia, today called upon the military to "drive Saddam Hussein out of power." Asked on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" whether he advocated the assassination of Mr. Hussein or a military invasion, Mr. Gingrich said he was "talking about just simply increasing the pressure."
"I think as a symbol of America and as a human being, President Bush and his family deserve to know that we will not tolerate a government trying to assassinate an American," Mr. Gingrich said.
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, cautioned against taking any action unless the evidence was clear that an assassination plot had been sponsored by the Iraqi Government. "Some action of a definite responsive nature probably needs to be taken if it's absolutely clear, but it isn't, at least in the public sphere, clear that the evidence is overwhelming or without any ambiguity," the Democratic leader said on the CBS program.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Push for a U.N. Police Force of 500 for Haiti

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, May 9

 BODY:
In an attempt to guarantee a peaceful transition to democracy in Haiti, the United States and several allies will sponsor a Security Council vote this week to authorize the quick deployment of a 500-member international police force there, Administration and United Nations officials said today.
On Monday, Foreign Ministers from the Caribbean will meet here with United Nations diplomats who will brief them and seek their support. 
 The Council is expected to approve the measure, officials involved in planning the force said.
 
Rapid Approval Predicted
 "I would think this would move very rapidly," a senior Clinton Administration official said. "The only major obstacle would be a logistical one, pulling people together from a variety of places."
Although the exact composition of the force has not been determined, officials said it was likely to be dominated by French- and Creole-speaking countries, including France, Canada and several Caribbean countries. Officials said Venezuela, which has also been a strong supporter of the idea, might also take part.
President Clinton first spoke last week of the necessity of an international police force to restore the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was overthrown in a violent military coup in September 1991. Since then, senior Administration officials have said that such a force is required in Haiti as diplomatic efforts proceed, because of sharp class divisions, a long history of political violence and a pervasive climate of fear.
The emerging settlement calls for the granting of an amnesty by Father Aristide to his enemies in the army, the resignation of the army command, the formation of a new, broad-based Government, the injection of large amounts of foreign aid and technical support and Father Aristide's early return from exile in Washington.
Officials close to the Haitian diplomacy have said that although no final agreements are in place, the country's military command is expected to support the deployment of the international police force.
 
A First for the U.N.
 United Nations officials said this was the first time the organization had mounted an international police force in a country not engaged in a civil war or international conflict.
Opponents of Father Aristide are concentrated among Haiti's small privileged classes. They have voiced deep fears that the President's supporters, concentrated among the poor, will exact revenge on many who supported the army's overthrow of the populist Roman Catholic leader.
In recent weeks, diplomats involved in negotiating a return to democracy in Haiti have spoken with increasing confidence that with strong international backing, a resolution of Haiti's 19-month political crisis is very near.
"We are optimistic about this thing going forward now," one official said. "That means all the Haitian parties can see their way to an accord that they can agree to."
Father Aristide, concerned about the constitutionality and the political consequences of calling for foreign intervention, has long publicly opposed the use of international force. Asked whether he approved of the police force, as his advisers and diplomats maintain, the Haitian President said on Friday: "I continue to be in touch with the Secretary General. My comments will come at the appropriate time."
If any party opposes the police deployment, officials said, it would be Haiti's de facto civilian Government, which is not recognized abroad and which would be almost immediately replaced under any settlement.
 
Reassuring Current Officials
 "The irony is that we are doing this in large part to reassure the de factos of their safety," one official close to the negotiations said. "But some people will no doubt scream about the violation of sovereignty."
One of the thorniest problems of the negotiations for President Aristide's return has been how to achieve the resignation of most of the army high command without provoking sudden anarchy in the army and in society.
While the prospect of presidential amnesty is meant to reassure commanders who must resign that they will not be prosecuted by the new Government, diplomats have long felt it essential to provide guarantees for ordinary soldiers, many of whom have been involved in violence in the country since the coup and fear reprisals.
The quick deployment of a police force, along with the rapid infusion of economic aid and the subsequent start of many development projects, has been seen by many as a linchpin of stability that would help eliminate the fears of ordinary soldiers.
Once the transition is under way, diplomats said, the army itself will become the subject of extensive reforms. Under the current plans, a professional civilian police force will be created for the first time in the country and the army reduced in size to about 3,000 soldiers from its current 7,000.

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
Treasury's Debt Shift Unlikely to Meet Goal

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
No matter who eventually wins the debate over the wisdom of the Treasury Department's decision last week to make a major shift in its debt- management policy, it does not appear that the savings will tote up to the $16 billion goal the Administration set, regardless of how interest rates move in the future.
The review of the Treasury borrowing practices, for better or worse, was driven by the Administration's promise of a budget savings of $16 billion over the five fiscal years 1994 through 1998. The Senate Budget Committee, in preparing its own budget plan earlier this year, came up with a proposal to meet the Administration's savings goal by shifting some longer-term borrowing with higher interest rates to shorter-term borrowing with lower interest rates. 
 When the Treasury announced its policy shift last week, saying it would give a new emphasis to shorter-term borrowing, some analysts on Wall Street indicated that the savings would be close to that of the Senate Budget Committee figures because the Treasury and Senate plan were similar, although not identical.
 But according to some Government analysts in Washington, the initial reviews of the Treasury plan indicate that only one-third to two-thirds of the $16 billion savings goal will be achieved. "There is no question" the savings will be lower, said one Administration official. "This was not an exercise to maximize the budget savings," the official explained.
The range in the estimates may have more to do with adjustments in budget base lines than with the actual savings achieved, which means the better estimate may be near the bottom of the range. A base line is an assumption of what would have occurred if there had been no change. It also sets a starting point from which to measure savings. It already appears that the Administration may use a budget base line that will give it a higher savings estimate.
According to these analysts, who would discuss the preliminary analysis only on the condition that their names not be used, there are two major differences between the Treasury plan and the Senate Budget Committee proposal, whose $16 billion savings estimate was prepared by the Congressional Budget Office.
One big difference is that the Treasury proposal cuts the annual issuance of 30-year bonds by about 40 percent, while the Senate Budget plan cuts the 30-year auctions by 50 percent. The Treasury, moreover, did not reduce the issuance of five-year notes, while the Senate cut them by 20 percent.
 
Another Difference
 The other difference is that the Treasury is shifting approximately $76 billion of longer-term borrowing ($37 billion from 30-year bonds and $39 billion from 7-year notes, which were eliminated) to 2- and 3-year notes and to Treasury bills, which range from three months to a year. The Senate Budget plan shifted all this longer-term borrowing to Treasury bills, making the interest-rate savings greater.
The savings is the difference between the average rate on the longer-term issues and that on the rates of the shorter maturities, which would be lower under the Senate plan because only bills are included.
The differences between the Senate and Treasury plans could change the projected savings by billions of dollars, officials said, although they would not give specific figures, which are still being worked out. And, as in all budget reviews, the final results can change.
One of the reasons for not shifting all the longer-term borrowing to Treasury bills is that it takes away almost all the Treasury's flexibility in managing the Federal debt. Another factor is that the one-year Treasury bill is a major factor in setting the interest rates on adjustable home mortgages. By not transferring so much of the Government's debt to one-year bills, the Treasury will place less pressure on home mortgage rates -- an end much harder to achieve under the Senate plan.
 
 
Importance of Base Line
 The reason for the wide range in the estimates of savings, officials said, comes from the choice of the base line for calculating the savings.
In one set of Government estimates, the starting point for the annual issuance of 30-year bonds uses as a base line the $9.25 billion quarterly auction in February, which already reflected a $1 billion cut made by the Clinton Administration. But in another Government-estimated base line, the total issuance is based on the higher level in the previous quarterly auction under the Bush Administration, which means the reduction in the size of the auction is larger, so the savings is greater.
The savings estimates, even if they are lower than expected, are easy to lock in -- on paper. All one needs to do is calculate the difference between the interest costs on 30-year bonds (6.84 percent) and the interest costs on 7-year notes (5.54 percent) and the interest costs on Treasury notes and bills with maturities of three years and less that will replace the longer-term borrowing.
A selection of the interest rate assumptions for the next six fiscal years that the Clinton Administration is using shows the three-month bills at 3.1 percent; 3.5 percent; 4.2 percent; 4.7 percent; 4.8 percent and 4.9 percent. The figures for the 30-year bond are 7.3 percent; 6.9 percent; 6.9 percent; 6.8 percent; 6.8 percent and 6.7 percent. The figures are given by fiscal year from 1993, which ends Sept. 30, to fiscal year 1998.
The broader question of the advisability of the debt-management shift disclosed last week will depend on how interest rates perform over time. If, for example, the rate on the shorter-term debt averages less than 6.84 percent (the rate now available on 30-year bonds for 30 years) the Treasury will do well. But who will be checking?
