HEADLINE: As Ratings Stall, Clinton Tries Tune-Up

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
In many of the ways that count, the spirit of the 1992 Clinton campaign is dead.
That spirit, represented by the "War Room" in the Little Rock, Ark., campaign headquarters, was supposed to live on in a World War I-era situation room in the Old Executive Office Building. But the young aides who staffed it -- trained in the art of quick response, coordinated message-making and effective communication that rooted out many a land mine during the campaign -- lack experience with the perils that lurk in real-life threats like a Republican filibuster, debates over aid to Russia or war in the Balkans. 
 "You had a lot more capacity to kind of shape the reality you want," one White House official said wistfully last week of the campaign days.
The Democrats, frozen out of executive branch leadership for 12 years, have discovered that governing is less a political campaign than an exercise in juggling flaming torches.
 
Some Lessons Learned
 Smarting from their early stumbles, Administration officials are determined to learn from their mistakes, turn to the bureaucratic process of nonstop meetings and make better use of the persuasive speech-making skills of the man they see as their best weapon: Bill Clinton.
Having recognized that they made a crucial mistake in trying to win passage of their economic stimulus plan without Republican support, the Clinton team now sees to it that Hillary Rodham Clinton meets with Republicans as well as Democrats when she seeks Congressional support for health-care overhaul proposals.
Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, has taken steps to rein in the operations of the West Wing, hiring a second deputy and coordinating groups that meet three times a week to plot how to win passage of the President's budget.
And Mr. Clinton will take to the road again for three days this week to try his hand at selling his economic program to business people in Cleveland, workers in Chicago and students in New York. At each stop, aides said, he plans to talk about tax fairness and to develop a theme that paints his opponents as protectors of the rich.
"He can focus the debate in a way that no one else can," said Bruce Reed, a domestic policy aide.
 
Too Busy to Chat
 When asked at a news conference on Friday about a significant drop in his approval ratings in recent polls, Mr. Clinton replied: "I haven't been out there as much as I should have been engaging the American people directly since February. I've been doing huge, heavy lifting and long meetings on health care and the economy. That's what I've been working on. And I've been forced to deal with a lot of other issues."
But he also acknowledged the difficulty of keeping connected with the public the way he did during the campaign. "You can't carry on a totally continuous campaign," he said. "It's simply not possible."
One senior Administration official -- none wanted their names attached to any concessions of imperfection -- said: "We have all of these campaign commitments, but we have to translate them into government and governing. That's where the fundamental breakdown occurred."
These are tough learning times at the White House. As senior officials guard their turf, their egos and their access to the President, they face the challenge of executing their chunk of the President's crowded domestic agenda at a time when that agenda could be overshadowed by the potential for American military intervention in Bosnia.
 
Surge of Disapproval
 "The economy, health care, national service, campaign and lobbying reform and welfare reform -- that's what we've been working on," said Mark D. Gearan, the deputy chief of staff who will now oversee long-term planning for politics and policy. "We have to make sure our focus and discipline remains that. Make sure the President's time, activity and efforts reflect the singularity of our focus."
The longer it waits, the harder it gets for the White House to get back on track. A CBS News poll conducted May 4-6 found that 50 percent of Americans disapproved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling the economy, while 38 percent approved. In a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted in late March, only 37 percent disapproved of his economic performance, and 47 percent approved.
Even more damaging, the new CBS News poll shows that the public no longer perceives Mr. Clinton's economic plan as fair. Forty percent say the plan is fair to people like themselves, while 48 percent say it is unfair. In the March survey, 48 percent saw it as fair; 39 percent saw it as unfair.
The CBS News telephone poll of 1,233 adults has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, as did the survey in March.
 
Seeking Clarity in Fuzzy World
 White House officials seem puzzled that they have been driven so far off course in public perception. To them, the goals the President outlined at a post-inauguration staff meeting at Camp David, the Presidential retreat, all look like part of a master plan. To the public, they may seem more like disparate pieces of an overly ambitious and scattered agenda.
Many of the President's advisers look fondly back on the Little Rock days, when the end of an uphill battle was victory. They remember how clear their mission seemed just after the inauguration.
"If that was near perfect coordination in a near perfect context, we now have to have a structure that is tailored toward the best possible coordination in an inherently imperfect context," said one of these advisers.
There has been a singular lack of blame emanating from the West Wing offices of the President's senior staff. Even as the top officials were admitting that their communications had become muddled, there has been no penalty for one of the President's closest aides, George Stephanopoulos, the communications director.
Instead, they have all vowed to learn from the mistakes that it took them weeks to even admit.
"Clearly that's part of the job of the President, and us, in helping him," said Mr. Stephanopoulos. "It's how do you talk about and communicate big things even as you're putting all the pieces together underneath it."
 
Hopes on Health Plan
 White House officials complained that they had not gotten the credit they deserved for their victories and that early defeats enabled "some people who would not know a tough choice if it hit them in the face to go around and suggest that we hadn't done enough."
Administration officials are hoping that when the health-care plan is finally announced next month, its broad sweep and its accompanying public relations pitch will obliterate many of the negative perceptions of provisions that have leaked out.
"We're planting a lot of seeds," said an official involved in the weeks of meetings to define a new image of Presidential policy. "We need to do the best possible job in making the tax issue a tax fairness case, because that is the reality of the President's program."
In the meantime, the White House is culling and assembling bits of good news wherever it can find them. Rahm Emanuel, the White House political director, was cheered by the increased voter turnout in recent special elections in Ohio, Wisconsin and Mississippi. People are engaged, he said.
And it is still early, the officials stress. There is plenty of time to develop a theme that portrays the President's program as the answer to voters' demands and the Republicans' objections as gridlock by filibuster.
"We have to do better in stressing that when we unveil a program that makes it easier for middle class students to pay for college, that's opportunity; that when we reinvent government and consolidate urban programs and bring tax incentives, that the President is fighting for opportunity and for jobs," said one adviser who has a hand in writing the President's speeches. "I don't think the question is changing the playbook so much, as executing the plays better."

HEADLINE: The Changing Definition of Health Insurers

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Even without Federal health-care reform, the nation's $300 billion health insurance industry is on the verge of a transformation.
Many of the nation's 500 or more health insurers are expected to be driven out of the field in the next few years as the industry shifts its business away from traditional insurance and toward the delivery and management of health care. 
 This process would speed up under a health-care plan expected from the Clinton Administration. Analysts predict that such a plan would drive tens or hundreds of thousands of health insurance agents out of their jobs and speed the pace at which Americans are compelled to join health maintenance organizations.
 
Invested in H.M.O.'s
 In the end, they say, the health-care changes would also come as a tremendous boon to the industry's giants: Prudential, Cigna, Aetna, Metropolitan Life and Travelers as well as the nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans. Those companies stand to benefit because they have already invested billions of dollars in health maintenance organizations, a way of controlling costs that is favored by the President's health policy planners.
The impact of such changes on the public is hotly debated. Small companies say that the increased concentration expected to result from the Clinton plans would eventually hurt consumers by centering too much power and business in large companies. The big companies are not as innovative or responsive to the public, the small companies say.
But the five big commercial insurers, which have formed their own lobbying group to support the Administration's approach, dismiss such arguments. They say that many traditional indemnity insurers that have looked to insure only the healthiest customers would hardly be missed.
Whatever happens in Washington, economists, analysts and insurance company leaders say most Americans in the next few years will find themselves changing health insurers or dealing with insurers that have changed vastly.
"The traditional indemnity health insurance industry is biologically extinct," said Alain C. Enthoven, a Stanford economist and one of the architects of the type of health-care change embraced by Mr. Clinton and known as managed competition. "Those changes are already under way. It will just happen faster if managed competition comes into being."
Besides the giants that have committed themselves to becoming operators of H.M.O.'s, the industry is made up of a hodgepodge of companies. They range from relatively large insurers like the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, which insures more than a million people, to tiny operations like the Universe Life Insurance Company of Lewiston, Idaho -- many of whose 50,000 rural customers found their insurance through associations of peanut, soybean and poultry farmers.
As medical costs have spiraled upward, some insurers have invested billions of dollars in H.M.O.'s and other systems designed to control what services are used and what patients are charged.
By last year, 41 million Americans had already enrolled in H.M.O.'s, up from 19 million in 1985, according to the Group Health Association of America, a trade organization of H.M.O.'s. Of all H.M.O.'s, 42 percent are owned by commercial insurance companies or Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
Some H.M.O.'s employ doctors in a clinic or hospital-like buildings. Others run networks of hundreds or thousands of doctors who practice in their private offices. In either case, people joining H.M.O.'s must usually abandon the traditional system of choosing any doctor they want and being reimbursed from health insurance plans.
 
H.M.O.'s Ready to Grow
 Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, a Wall Street research firm, said that even without any new Federal health-care changes, the percentage of Americans with private health insurance who are enrolled in H.M.O.'s would grow from the current 24 percent to 45 percent in the year 2000. The process, he added, would be much faster under managed competition.
"I envision the insurance companies transforming themselves into H.M.O.'s or getting out of the business," Mr. Abramowitz said.
The precise impact on the health insurers would depend on the structure of the health alliances, and there is still much debate over which insurers would survive.
Mr. Abramowitz estimated that 100 of the approximately 500 health insurers in the nation would remain in the business. The majority of the 72 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans and Prudential, Cigna, Metropolitan Life, Aetna and Travelers would have a natural advantage because of the heavy investment they have made in H.M.O.'s and other managed-care systems.
Although health insurers' profit margins would suffer from any form of price controls, Orin Kramer, an analyst who runs Boston Provident Partners, an investment group in Fort Lee, N.J., said the insurers that already had a large foothold in the H.M.O. business would benefit greatly from the Administration's plans to pay for insurance for the 37 million Americans who are now uninsured. In essence, the Government would pay tens of billions of dollars to create a huge new pool of customers for health insurers.
 
Benefit to Big Insurers
 Michael Stocker, the president of Cigna Healthplan Inc., said that if the Clinton plan allowed large employers to choose health insurers outside the health alliances, as expected, that would probably benefit larger insurers, too. Large corporations with operations in many states tend to favor dealing with large insurers that also operate in many locations, Mr. Stocker said, rather than contracting separately with many local insurers in different areas. Small- and medium-sized companies that have not invested in H.M.O.'s would find it difficult to survive.
"The driving issue is whether an insurer has invested in networks that include doctors and hospitals," Mr. Stocker said.
That prospect has caused a schism in the lobbying effort of health insurers. The five giants recently broke off from the Health Insurance Association of America, their longtime trade group in Washington, to form their own organization, the Coalition for Managed Competition, which is closer to Administration thinking on most issues.
On the other side of the spectrum is the Council for Affordable Health Insurers, an organization representing 30 small indemnity insurers that cater to individual customers. It paints a bleak picture of the future if most consumers have to buy their insurance through health alliances.
Its spokesmen argue that managed competition would lead to dominance of the industry by national behemoths unresponsive to consumers. After the shakeout, they say, larger insurers could form an insurance oligopoly.
"Innovative small companies that have fueled competition very well might not be there anymore," said Douglas J. Freeman, the chief executive of Medical Benefits Mutual Life Insurance in Newark, Ohio, an insurer of only about 50,000 customers. "General Motors, if they were not forced by competition to design a new body shape, would still be offering us the Chevette."
Theorists of managed competition, as well as the leaders of the nation's largest health insurance companies, say such an outcome is extremely unlikely. The concentration of business in large companies will be limited, they say, because even companies like Prudential and Cigna lack the capital to underprice or acquire all well-run local enterprises.
In addition, advocates of health-care change argue that the public would be glad to see indemnity insurers that "cherry pick" customers -- or take only the best prospects -- go out of business. For many of these insurers, they say, profits have depended on selecting the most healthy to insure while studiously rejecting those most likely to get sick. Their aim, such critics say, has been to serve least those who need insurance most.
In any case, they say, the health alliances would have to be structured to assure that there are enough companies for competition to exist.
"What you want is enough competition to make sure there is a lot of choice," said William P. Link, executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company. "There will be many, many more than just a few local companies."
Among most health insurers, planning has inevitably turned to finding new niches. Some talk about abandoning customers entirely and processing electronic claims for the insurers that remain. Others believe that significant parts of America will still need traditional insurance plans.
Mr. Freeman of Medical Benefits Mutual Life said his company, which insures residents of Ohio and Indiana, was concentrating on developing networks of physicians in small cities and rural areas. Recent research, including an article in the New England Journal of Medicine in January, suggested that perhaps 30 percent of the nation's residents live in areas where the population is not dense enough for managed competition to exist.
"We are a part of the community in Newark, Ohio, and we feel we can remain a part of the community," Mr. Freeman said. "We are going to change. But I believe we are going to survive."

HEADLINE: Some See Half-Empty Glasses in U.S.-China Pacts

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 9

 BODY:
To hearty congratulations, the United States and China have reached a series of agreements in the last few years aimed at resolving disagreements in areas ranging from trade to human rights. Now those agreements are generating their own disputes about whether China is abiding by its promises.
The latest commotion came late last week with the disclosure of growing evidence that China might have shipped medium-range M-11 missiles to Pakistan. Such shipments would violate China's promise, first made to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in 1991, not to sell such missiles. 
 To some of China's critics, a violation of the missile agreement would fit into a pattern of broken promises. Such critics, including human rights campaigners and some business executives and diplomats, say China has also failed to follow through fully on agreements to allow all dissidents to leave the country, to open its markets and to permit inspections of prison factories.
"The conclusion you have to draw is that the Chinese Government lies a lot," said Robin Munro, a researcher for Asia Watch, a division of Human Rights Watch in New York. "Its credibility is extremely low."
 
China Is Seen as No Different
 Others dispute that assessment, pointing out that disagreements about abiding by agreements are common in relations with Japan and Europe as well. What is special about China, they suggest, is that human rights groups are particularly quick to criticize it.
Indeed, one of the most direct violations of any agreement between two countries recently can be attributed not to double-crossing Communists but to politically ambitious Americans. That was the Bush Administration's decision in the 1992 Presidential campaign to save jobs by selling F-16 fighters to Taiwan -- despite a pledge not to increase military sales to Taiwan.
In any case, it appears that despite grand claims made at the time, the series of Chinese-American agreements in the last few years has not resolved as much as both sides had hoped it would. In what was hailed as a landmark agreement last August, for example, Beijing agreed to let American diplomats inspect prisons in an effort to prevent prison-made goods from reaching the American market.
"It's been a complete flop," Mr. Munro of Asia Watch said of the agreement. "It's utterly toothless."
 
How Many Visits to Prisons?
 The United States Embassy declined to say how many visits had been made under the agreement. But the Chinese Foreign Ministry was more forthcoming. It said that it has allowed three visits to prisons.
"China has all along strictly observed the memorandum of understanding prohibiting trade in prison labor products," the Foreign Ministry said. "The Chinese side has made careful inspection of the relevant factories and found no case of exporting prison labor products to the United States."
In the first inspection, an American diplomat was allowed to visit part of the Gold Horse Diesel Engine Factory last fall in the southwestern Chinese city of Kunming. The diplomat was allowed to see only a part of the factory, which is believed to be run by the Yunnan No. 1 Prison. The Chinese turned down requests to see other parts, and they have not yet permitted a return visit.
In Shanghai, the Chinese permitted a diplomatic visit last year -- before the agreement -- to the Laodong Machinery Factory, which was suspected of using prison labor. But after the visit, evidence emerged that the prison factory in fact was across the street from the site shown by the Chinese. Local officials have not allowed a visit by diplomats to that building.
 
Who Does the Interpreting?
 Still, diplomats say Beijing is not openly flouting the agreement and that cooperation has improved noticeably in the last couple of months. They say that China is simply taking advantage of ambiguities in the agreement and interpreting its obligations narrowly, the kinds of things that countries often do to protect their interests.
Another promise in dispute is China's pledge to Mr. Baker in 1991 to allow Chinese dissidents to leave the country if they are not the subject of legal proceedings. While Beijing has allowed many dissidents to leave, a handful, including Hou Xiaotian, Yu Haocheng and Li Honglin, have still been denied passports.
Among economic agreements, a landmark accord to open China's market to American goods has only been partly put into effect since it was signed in October, American officials say. Likewise, China agreed with the United States in 1989 not to launch international satellites at discount rates. An April report by the office of the United States Trade Representative said that China had been underbidding rivals and that "these low prices have called into question China's compliance with the 1989 agreement."
Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative under President Bush, denied that China had a pattern of breaking its agreements. She noted, for example, that Beijing was generally credited with a solid effort to abide by a pact signed in January 1992 to protect intellectual property. "Every country will not have every date met precisely" in following through on agreements, she said. "But to suggest that there hasn't been dramatic progress is to misconstrue the story."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Home Depot's success has begun to attract naysayers.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado

 BODY:
TOUTED as the stock of the 1990's, Home Depot has rapidly climbed, but some professional investors now wonder if the stock has gotten ahead of itself.
The recent souring of retail stocks has had an impact on Home Depot, as investors tend to herd all retailers together when one falls out of favor. (In this case, that one is Wal-Mart.) But are there soft spots in this retail knight's armor? 
 The company has often been referred to as the Wal-Mart of the home improvement supply business and that comparison, until Wal-Mart's stock started falling, benefited Home Depot. The Atlanta company's string of 27 quarters of record profits, was certainly Wal-Mart-like. Perhaps because Home Depot has been so often compared to Wal-Mart, sobering views are emerging.
"Using any measure, Home Depot is pricey," says Joseph Battipaglia, chief investment strategist of Gruntal & Company. "It is a stock that is trading at three times sales and has a price-to-earnings ratio of 38, based on 1993's anticipated profits. At no point in the 1980's did Wal-Mart ever trade at over one and a half times revenue." Home Depot's stock ended last week up 50 cents a share, to $44.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Last month The Wall Street Journal reported that in March the chairman of Home Depot, Bernard Marcus, sold 5 percent of his company stock, about 550,000 shares, for $35 million. At the time of the article, company officials said the sale did not reflect any concern that Home Depot shares were overpriced, stressing that the chairman still owned 15.1 million shares.
Some analysts have noted Home Depot's dependence on new capital to finance new stores. "Home Depot does not generate sufficient cash to reinvest in the business," Mr. Battipaglia said. "The momentum of growth has been fueled by issuance of high-priced equity. Which leads to another point, and that is the number of outstanding shares has been growing rapidly. This speaks to continuously tapping the financial markets to fund growth. Its illusion of growth reminds me of the Wizard of Oz behind the curtain. It's no miracle."
 The labor force in the hard-hit construction industry was easily tapped by the chain for employees to run its stores. But some professional investors are concerned that with the return of higher-paying construction jobs Home Depot may not be able to retain the experienced trades people who have provided the do-it-yourselfers with building tips and expert advice in making product selections. Michael Murphy, publisher of the Overpriced Stock Service in San Francisco, has maintained for a couple of years that Home Depot is expanding too fast.
"Home Depot has been doing three things that to me do not make sense," Mr. Murphy said. "The first is they are trying to continue to expand at a very rapid rate and it gets harder when you have that many stores. This used to be a fairly regional and tightly managed organization, which is now run to meet Wall Street's expectations."
Mr. Murphy also said that Home Depot opened stores near older stores and cannibalized the old stores' business. The company also opened stores near its toughest competitors, Builders Square, a division of Kmart, and Lowe's.
The stock is widely owned, with a high multiple of 53 times the last 12 months' earnings. "People who own high-priced shares have sky-high expectations, and when they get disappointing sales, the stocks get smashed," Mr. Murphy said. He did acknowledge, however, that as far as Home Depot is concerned, "so far I have been wrong."
James W. Schroeder, an equity analyst for MMS International, noted that store sales were down from historic levels. "Revenues per customer have also come down, but Home Depot is trying to offset the lower customer revenues by tighter controls on inventory, keeping down thefts and things of that nature," he said.
Management, Mr. Schroeder said, is sticking with the notion that it can hold to the course and to some extent is ignoring potential problems.
"If the economy comes back strong, it could cut into the do-it-yourself business, for the alternative could be to simply move to another house," Mr. Schroeder said.

HEADLINE: From Newsreels to Records: A New Home for Sony Music

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
While Sony USA has been conspicuously transforming the former A.T. & T. headquarters on the East Side of Manhattan into its new home, Sony Music has been quietly transforming the former Fox Movietone studios on the West Side into a new video and audio center.
The quiet ends today. 
 That is when the Sony Music Studios open in an industrial red-brick barn on 10th Avenue, between 53d and 54th Streets. Once the home of Fox Movietone newsreels, it was also where "Miracle on 34th Street," "On the Waterfront," "Fail Safe," "Shaft," "The Exorcist," "Sophie's Choice" and "Kramer vs. Kramer" were filmed, as well as television series like "I Spy" and "The Adams Chronicles."
At the heart of the complex, which Sony has completely rebuilt, to the tune of perhaps $40 million, is a 75-by-100-foot sound stage, with a 40-foot-high ceiling. This is where Sony will make many of the 220 music videos it produces every year.
Nearby are a smaller sound stage, a recording studio where 7 or 8 musicians can perform, 16 audio recording production rooms, 4 video editing rooms, a television control room, 2 rehearsal rooms, 4 songwriters' offices and an audio and video library and archive.
"Every phase that happens in the career of an artist can be handled and catered to," said Thomas D. Mottola, the president of Sony Music.
The studios will be available only to artists under contract to Sony, a roster that includes Michael Jackson, Billy Joel, Bruce Springsteen and Barbra Streisand.
Mr. Mottola would not disclose the cost of the project. He said it did not involve any economic incentives or tax abatements from New York City.
Mayor David N. Dinkins is scheduled to attend the opening tonight, when the main stage will resemble a West Side streetscape.
There are few traces of the past at the studios except for the sheer volume of the main stage itself, a handsomely paneled elevator cab and holes in the fourth-floor ceiling where chimneys used to extend from the nitrate-film storage vaults.
For 20 years, the studios were owned by Camera Mart, an equipment rental company, and leased to movie and television producers.
But Al Smith, a vice president of Sony Music, said: "It was getting to be a ghost of a building. There weren't many productions shot here." The last movie to be filmed there, he said, was "Billy Bathgate," released in 1991. Thirty-year-old equipment still filled the building after Sony acquired it, Mr. Smith said.
"If anything, we've built a more creative facility," he said. There will be about 80 full-time employees at the complex. When the studios and production rooms are booked up, there might be a few hundred people working there, Mr. Smith said.
Alan Suna, the chief executive officer of Silvercup Studios in Long Island City, Queens, said he had received inquiries from producers who might have gone to the Camera Mart stages in previous years.
Of the Sony project, he said: "Our view is that the entertainment industry hasn't lost anything. In fact, it's a reopening, a rebirth of a facility."

HEADLINE: In Managed Competition, Insurance Agents at Risk

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
One part of the health insurance industry that could receive a body blow under managed competition is the nation's 250,000 agents and brokers.
Today, they act as intermediaries between the employers and individuals who buy health insurance and the companies that sell it. But if the new health alliances can bargain on behalf of most consumers and gather information from insurers, consumers should be able to make choices on their own, theorists of managed competition say. 
 David E. Hebert, counsel to the Association of Health Insurance Agents in Washington, said that if the President's health-care proposal required most consumers to buy their insurance exclusively through the health alliances, many, if not a majority, of health insurance agents could be unemployed. The Administration should plan for such dislocations, he said, just as the Defense Department must consider the loss of jobs from arms industry cutbacks.
Anxiety about that prospect is particularly pointed at small businesses like that of Joel A. Shapiro, whose firm, Bartmon, Shapiro & Associates on West 57th Street in Manhattan, sells life and health insurance. Mr. Shapiro, who over the last 20 years has built up a business with nearly $1 million a year in revenues, employs 10 people and does business from airy offices that afford a majestic view of Central Park.
Mr. Shapiro said that if the description of health-care change that he has read is adopted, he would be forced to drop half his workers.
"I have been having trouble sleeping lately," Mr. Shapiro said. "I imagine it will be like watching them cut the heart out of a person."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Troubled New York City And a Note of Optimism

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
IN 1987, a stubbornly optimistic mayoral commission issued its forecast for the millennium under a title that evoked high hopes: "New York Ascendant." Less than four months later, the stock market crashed.
With the millennium now six years closer, another city commission has just published its own generally rosy vision of the future, but with a decidedly more sober name. "Shaping the City's Future" is the less judgmental title of the New York City Planning Commission's first strategic agenda, as required by the revised City Charter. The commission's report on planning and zoning doubles as a broadly delineated gauge against which the courage and the imagination of municipal candidates can be measured. 
 First, the report provides thought-provoking perspective: in 1989, the rate of housing construction hit a 13-year high; the quality of waterways surrounding the city in 1990 was the highest recorded since monitoring began in 1909.
Since 1960, the city lost more than two-thirds of its factory workers; more than 1 in 4 of the 3.3 million people employed in the city work for government or in the fields of health, education and social services; nearly half of the city's households have access to a car -- up 28 percent since 1980. Women make up 47 percent of the city's labor force (and, among those working women, 12 percent have children younger than age 6); median household income, adjusted for inflation, declined in only three of the city's community districts during the 1980's -- all of them in the South Bronx; while the poverty rate declined slightly between 1979 and 1989, the number of poor working-age adults rose; 47 percent of households spend more than 30 percent of their monthly income in rent.
Also, the ratio between the number of New Yorkers who are college graduates and the number of higher-skilled jobs reversed over the last two decades: in 1970, city residents held 200,000 more management and professional jobs than college degrees; in 1990, the number of New Yorkers with college degrees surpassed the number of employed managers and professionals by 125,000.
Those figures may suggest a statistical portrait of Dorian Gray in reverse. New York's inanimate stone and glass skyscape is frequently renewed while its flesh-and-blood inhabitants seem to age somewhat less gracefully. But the real picture is more complex. For example, immigrants represent a vital influx of raw material with which the city can, once again, re-invent itself.
The stock market crashed in 1987. The city did not. But New York's resiliency is again facing a profound test. This year's mayoral campaign is a good time to confront the questions and demand answers. The City Planning Commission's "discussion document," often vaguely but sometimes boldly, provides grist for both.
It recommends a major overhaul of the zoning guidelines that have governed development for three decades -- though not scrapping them altogether because that would be too time-consuming and politically wrenching.
Among the proposed changes: recycle older Manhattan office buildings for housing; allow bakeries, electronics assemblers and other light industry on local commercial streets; let supermarkets and large retail stores open in underused industrial zones and permit housing in industrial sections of the West Side and of downtown Flushing, and re-evaluate liberal rules that routinely allow health, education and child-care centers in residential and commercial neighborhoods since their missions have expanded markedly.
Employment in export industries that provide service and information to the nation and to the world exceeds the number of jobs in local-market industries. Commercial transportation used to flow west from the city, sending goods to the rest of the country. Now it generally comes east, delivering goods to New York City, the nation's largest market, and to Long Island, the ninth largest.
The report proposes concentrating more suburban jobs in compact centers and improving mass transportation to those centers. That might discourage even more automobile traffic and accommodate New York City residents who work in the suburbs -- a category that grew by one-third during the last decade.
It also proposes discouraging entry of private cars into Manhattan south of 60th Street by imposing tolls, at least during certain times of day, on all bridges and tunnels or requiring special permits for vehicles entering Manhattan; reviving the Second Avenue Subway (one mile of tunnel and three stations were built and abandoned); extending the Flushing Line to New Jersey; building an express bus terminal in lower Manhattan; allowing commercial vans on the Belt and Grand Central Parkways; constructing a twin span at the Goethals Bridge on Staten Island; widening the Van Wyck Expressway, and reviewing the limits that had been imposed on new parking lots and garages in Manhattan because automobile use has increased regardless.
"Perhaps unreasonable public confidence in a better future has been replaced by an often unjustified sense of gloom," the City Planning Commission says, comparing its vision with the one advanced in 1987 by the Commission on the Year 2000. Or, as Dr. Seuss might have said of grown-up city like New York:
You're in pretty good shape . . .
For the shape that you're in.

HEADLINE: THE WHITE HOUSE STRUGGLES TO SAVE ENERGY TAX PLAN

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has altered major facets of its proposed energy tax in response to political pressures and is now struggling to rescue the tax against a horde of lobbyists straining to pick it apart.
Some of Washington's most potent industry groups -- the National Association of Manufacturers, the American Petroleum Institute and the American Farm Bureau -- have vowed to kill the tax altogether, while dozens of other lobbies are mounting a major effort to amend the Administration's proposals. 
 Although some lobbyists say they have a good chance to kill the tax outright, Administration officials and many members of Congress predict it will survive -- even if substantially reworked.
 
 
Broad-Based Tax
 It should be no surprise that the energy tax faces so much opposition: it is a new type of tax, it would touch all Americans and industries, and it would raise a lot of money. The tax -- based on the heat content of fuels as measured in B.T.U.'s, or British thermal units -- would cost a family of four earning $40,000 about $200 a year, according to Administration officials.
Aluminum producers want an exemption from paying the tax on the huge amounts of electricity they use, the trucking industry wants its diesel fuel exempted and farmers are resisting a tax on the fuel they use.
"There's a lot of grass-roots lobbying about this because it touches so many people," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which acts on tax legislation. "I would expect more changes in it because it has so many moving parts."
 
 
Political Heat
 Lobbying groups have been emboldened to seek changes in the proposal -- the most significant new tax in the President's economic package -- because the Administration has already made so many major concessions on the tax in response to searing political heat. Since President Clinton proposed the tax on Feb. 17, it has probably been altered more than any of his other tax proposals.
Originally, the White House had hoped to generate $22 billion from the energy tax. Administration officials say that the exemptions already agreed to would reduce the tax revenue by a few hundred million dollars, although some environmentalists say the revenue erosion is much more than that.
As a result of farm state lobbying, the Administration now proposes to exempt ethanol, a fuel made from corn. Responding to steel industry pressures, the Administration has proposed exempting coal used for making steel. And to protect domestic airlines from foreign competition, the Administration has bowed to industry pleas to exempt fuel used for international flights. Seeing all these concessions, other industries are shouting "me, too!"
If the lobbyists succeed in truncating or killing the tax, it would be a major setback for the Administration, which has already seen the Senate block its stimulus package, and which appears to face almost certain defeat on its plan for an investment tax credit.
The President embraced the energy tax -- which would add 5 to 10 percent to the price of oil, gas and electricity -- because it is expected to encourage conservation and reduce pollution. But any environmental benefits from the tax seem largely forgotten as lobbyists line up to eviscerate it.
"The energy tax is important to help us get the deficit down," said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen.
The tax could face its biggest test in the Senate Finance Committee, where the Democrats, many from oil or farm states, have an 11-to-9 edge. That means the Administration may be forced to make concessions to individual Democratic senators to keep them on board.
 
 
Impact in North Dakota
 Take Kent Conrad, a committee Democrat from North Dakota. He points to studies showing that the tax would cost $1,200 a year for a typical North Dakota farm family, whose income averages $17,600.
"My view of the B.T.U. tax is we're better off without it," he said. "In terms of my constituency, it hits agriculture very hard. I can foresee a possibility where I'd vote for it, but that would be assuming it included broad exemptions for agriculture."
Senator Conrad merely wants what many of his colleagues have already won. Responding to pressures from Senator Moynihan, from the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, and from others, the Administration has exempted home heating oil from the proposal to tax oil products at a higher rate than coal or natural gas, a provision intended to reduce the nation's dependence on oil imports. Many homes in the Northeast are heated by oil.
 
 
Changes Cited
 Secretary Bentsen described at a recent Senate Finance Committee hearing how the Administration had changed its energy tax proposals. He noted that the Administration moved to exempt ethanol after Senators Conrad and Thomas A. Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat, voiced their concerns. Then he noted that Democratic Senators John Breaux of Louisiana and David Boren of Oklahoma were unhappy with a proposal to tax natural gas at the wellhead. Gas companies feared that fixed-price contracts might prevent them from passing on the cost, so the Treasury proposed that the tax be collected once the gas leaves the pipeline.
Similarly, coal was originally to be taxed at the mine, but many mining companies complained that it would be hard to measure the B.T.U. content of their coal and hard to pass the cost of the tax through because of fixed-price contracts. Now the Administration proposes that the tax be collected from utilities and industries that use coal.
Environmentalists and electrical utilities are at loggerheads over the industry's effort to move the collection point from the utility, as the Administration has proposed, to the consumer.
 
 
Not Eager for Hearings
 Electric companies are concerned that if the tax is collected from utilities, they might need to go through regulatory hearings before passing the tax onto consumers. Utilities are not eager for such hearings, fearing that rate commissions might seize the opportunity to push electric prices down, because lower interest rates have cut the capital costs of many utilities.
Environmentalists say it is important to keep utilities as the collection point because that will increase their incentive to use cleaner, more efficient fuels. Environmentalists fear that the House Ways and Means Committee will approve the utility-backed proposal -- unless the Administrations fights hard against it -- because several committee members are close to their local utilities.
Another big fight involves the aluminum industry, which is intensely jealous that the steel industry has won an exemption for its coal. Aluminum producers have mounted perhaps the largest pressure campaign in the hope of exempting the electricity they use. Turning ore into pure aluminum requires great amounts of electricity, and industry lobbyists say the tax will cost aluminum makers $170 million a year.
Coal and coke used to make steel are exempted because some carbon from these fuels goes into the steel itself. They are thus considered feedstocks, rather than fuels. Similarly, petroleum products that go into plastics are exempt, while those used for fuel are not.
Representative Michael Kopetski, an Oregon Democrat, is pressing the Administration to exempt the aluminum industry's electricity from the tax, saying it could drive two Oregon aluminum plants out of business, costing the state more than 1,500 jobs.
 In a recent hearing, Secretary Bentsen was hanging tough -- and sounded surprisingly like a chemistry professor in explaining why electricity used to make aluminum was not a feedstock and did not deserve an exemption.
"In making petrochemicals, the atoms of the feedstock hydrocarbons become the atoms of the polymers and other products," he said. Contrary to claims advanced by aluminum industry officials, he said, "electricity does not contribute net electrons of the reaction; it contributes the energy that causes the chemical reaction to occur."

HEADLINE: Higher Salaries for Teachers?

 BODY:
Encouraged by state fact-finders who recommended that the New York City teachers' union get slightly higher salary increases than most other city unions, the teachers want more than slightly more. Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, points to ambiguous language in the fact-finders' report that suggests her union should get an 8.5 percent increase over 39 months -- instead of the 8.25 percent other unions got -- plus "an appropriate payment of additional money as may be made available" by the state.
The 8.5 percent is defensible; the city has traditionally paid teachers a bit more than other municipal workers in recognition of their role in educating the next generation. But the city's finances aren't strong enough to justify an even larger increase just now. 
 While Albany gave the city an additional $145 million in education aid this year, it didn't earmark that money for teachers' salaries. The Legislature allocated $27 million for building new schools, $18 million for school grants, and the remaining $100 million for operating aid, which the Board of Education wants to use to plug harmful holes in its budget.
Why not give the teachers part of the $100 million? The idea is tempting. But the city is still suffering from an economic slide; indeed, the Mayor's proposed budget cuts $150 million from the school system. But though there is clearly little money for additional raises, Ms. Feldman argues that New York City schoolteachers earn 23 percent less than those in surrounding communities; that teachers lured by those higher salaries are leaving, and that low salaries are hurting recruitment and forcing the hiring of uncertified teachers. Those arguments are unpersuasive.
Although city teachers earn less than those in the suburbs, they earn more than those in other large cities. School officials say they hire uncertified teachers largely because of a teacher shortage in specialized areas. And there is evidence that most teachers who quit aren't going to the suburbs, where, in fact, there aren't that many jobs.
Many teachers leave to go into other professions, or because of poor conditions in the city schools. Teachers do not want to work in decrepit, unsafe schools, teaching overcrowded classes. Spending money to improve those conditions might well encourage more teachers to stay in the system than would a slightly higher salary.
If teachers want raises higher than the 8.5 percent recommended by the fact-finders, they can earn them by giving up some benefits. For instance, if they gave up paid sabbaticals, worked longer days and agreed to cover occasionally for absent teachers without additional compensation, the money saved could go to higher salaries.
With a limited amount of money to spend, the city must make difficult choices. The schools come first, teachers' salaries second.

HEADLINE: U.S. Intervention in Bosnia Has Only Negatives;
Moral Leadership Calls

 BODY:
To the Editor:
My former professor Zbigniew Brzezinski speaks eloquently to what millions of my generation must be thinking (" 'Never Again' -- Except for Bosnia," Op-Ed, April 22). Those of us born after World War II grew up in a near-barrage of accounts of the horrors of Hitler's Nazis and the Holocaust. Reminders were deemed necessary if the world was to insure such horrors never occurred again. 
 Like Mr. Brzezinski, I have noted the dark irony on recent front pages: reports of the opening of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum printed alongside coverage of the carnage in Bosnia.
The lesson of the Holocaust is that our "national interest" must encompass something beyond economic or political concerns. We are a nation of human beings, and the brutality in Bosnia represents a fundamental threat to people everywhere. As former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain noted last week, even if it could be argued that Bosnia is not in our sphere of interest, it must be in our sphere of conscience.
That it would be appropriate for Europe to intervene in Bosnia is without question. But Europe has proved that a truly united European Community is a pipe dream.
The credibility and legitimacy of America's influence in the world derives not just from its ability but from its willingness. The United States must act because no one else will. Extraordinary responsibilities, as well as privileges, attend our country's status as world leader.
If we don't respond, convincing ourselves that the risks are too high, the time isn't right or that acting is not in our interest, what will become of our moral leadership in the world? And what will the Holocaust museum be but a monument to our self-righteousness?
 
JOHN R. DEARIE
New York, May 5, 1993

HEADLINE: What Are We Going To Do About Crime?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Even more important than health care reform is the issue of crime in this once great country. It is absolutely urgent that politicians face this issue immediately. Crime is causing the financial destruction of the inner cities of the United States. 
 I own a large industrial complex in the East Williamsburg section of Brooklyn; the area's high crime rate makes leasing industrial space to businesses impossible. We are constantly harassed by hookers, drug addicts and the common thief.
Just last week the siamese pipe that is necessary for the fire department to operate our sprinkler system was stolen. It was stolen because it was made of brass and is easily resalable by a drug addict. Because of the configuration of the building it is impossible to hide the pipe. I fully expect that within 30 days this $800 brass pipe will again be stolen.
It is unreasonable to expect new businesses to want to come into the inner cities because of the high crime rate. It does not matter that inner-city rents are so low businesses could probably operate profitablely even during these difficult economic times. Businesses cannot get employees to come to work in the inner cities. So, what are we going to do about the crime issue?
 
ROY W. GUTTMAN
Brooklyn, April 30, 1993

HEADLINE: China Now the Big Spender on Gold

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
China has become the largest buyer of gold, ending the United States' 25-year reign and giving gold's price a buoyancy it has not had in a decade.
Last year, the Chinese bought more than 350 metric tons of gold, much of it in the form of chuk kam, or pure gold jewelry, according to the annual report on the gold market by Gold Fields Mineral Services of London. Its figures are the most closely watched in the market, and this year provided some of the first concrete data on Chinese gold purchases. 
 Philip Klapwijk, an author of the report, said the Chinese buying did not outstrip that of the United States by much, but he could not provide comparable figures because Gold Fields has not completed its consumption analyses for 1992. Total world demand last year was 3,480 metric tons, up 12 percent.
 
Abundantly Disposable Income
 There have been several spurs to China's buying. With the expansion of the economy, the Chinese now have more cash, but relatively few outlets for spending it. The threat of Chinese inflation -- gold is a classic inflation hedge -- and a drop in the value of the Chinese currency, the yuan, added to the buying, according to Gold Fields.
Speculation about Chinese buying has helped the price of gold rally. Since March, its price has jumped 9.6 percent, to a nine-month high of $358.30 last week, from an eight-year low of $326.90. The price of gold on the Commodity Exchange here in New York closed yesterday at $357.20 an ounce, down 20 cents.
The potential for continued buying in China has produced predictions of further increases from gold analysts. When these analysts gather now, their talk turns to how China, the world's most populous nation, could be the consumer of millions and millions of ounces of gold as its economy opens and develops. By contrast, the United States market is a mature one, where fewer of the traditional reasons for buying gold apply.
 
Balance to Other Selling
 China's buying has spurred prices another way. The Government there, according to the report, appears to have purchased a large portion of the 12.9 million ounces of gold sold by the Dutch central bank at the end of 1992. In a year when total central bank net sales were the largest since 1968, this buying helped relieve some of the downward pressure on prices, which fell 5 percent in 1992.
Also keeping prices from dropping further was the strong worldwide demand for gold jewelry, which rose 329 metric tons last year, the third-largest increase in 25 years.
The data on Chinese buying are still secret, and Government figures do not disclose very much. But the authors of the study say that the estimate of Chinese purchases, at more than 350 metric tons, is a conservative figure.
By comparison, in 1991, the latest such data available in detail, the United States accounted for 259 tons, and India, which was No. 2, 207 tons. Italy, the largest maker of jewelry by a wide margin, was the No. 3 gold consumer, with a total just over 165 tons. This includes jewelry, bars and coins.
China's movement to the top of the list reflects in part an effort to integrate the gold production and consumption of Communist countries, and formerly Communist ones like the old Soviet Union, into the global data that Gold Fields has been collecting and analyzing for 25 years.
At the same time, the distribution of these figures helps lift the price of gold by increasing expectations that the bottom of the decade-old bear market may have been reached. The supply and demand forces that have brought gold prices down may now be reversing themselves, according to the data.
 
 
Much Greater Demand
 Such a possible shift is evident from the global figures that include the Communist and formerly Communist countries. According to this data, the gap between fundamental supply, which includes mine production and gold scrap, and fundamental demand -- fabrication and bar-hoarding -- is widening. In 1990, basic demand outpaced basic supply by 187 tons. By the end of 1992, this had greatly widened, to 725 tons.
"The underlying supply-and-demand fundamentals are becoming more positive," said Mr. Klapwijk, who is a senior metals analyst at Gold Fields.
Early this year the price of gold failed to rally, and the fact that it did not, despite the improving fundamentals, shows the effect that swing factors, in this case central bank selling, can have. Last year, net gold sales of central banks reached 599 metric tons. The threat of more sales this year helped keep a lid on the price early in 1993.
 
Cyclical Performance
 In an interview here before the formal presentation of the Gold Fields report yesterday, Mr. Klapwijk would not predict what would happen with central bank gold sales for all of 1993. But in the past, large net selling in one year has been followed by little or no selling the next.
What this means for the price of gold is hard to predict, according to Mr. Klapwijk, who acknowledged that the Gold Fields report has a more optimistic tone than others in the last several years.
China's buying could slacken if its Government decides to fight rising inflation with an austerity program, as occurred in 1988. And central banks could keep on selling. But if the supply-and-demand fundamentals hold out in favor of gold, prices of $380 an ounce by the end of the year have a better base of support than in past years.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Shifting Demand for Gold" shows worldwide net official purchases and worldwide demand for gold jewelry, in metric tons, since 1983. (Source: Gold Fields Mineral Service)

HEADLINE: Jackson Heights Streets Familiar to Drug Cartels

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
Colombia is a continent away from Queens, but Carlos Zamora felt no surprise yesterday when he heard that leaders of the Cali cocaine cartel had been accused of killing his friend, Manuel de Dios Unanue. Seated three barstools from where Mr. de Dios was shot to death, Mr. Zamora sadly stated the obvious: the cartel is a strong and brutal presence in Jackson Heights.
"These people got no brains," said Mr. Zamora, a 50-year-old insurance agent, as he sipped white wine in the Meson Asturias restaurant where Mr. de Dios died with two bullets to his head in March 1992. "They just kill whoever they think they've got to kill." 
 Law-enforcement officials say Jackson Heights and Elmhurst are the center of cocaine importation and distribution for the northeastern United States. But the tightly structured drug organizations operate well out of view; street crime is not high, because there is no big money in muggings.
This is the world that Mr. de Dios chronicled in El Diario-La Prensa and in his own crime magazines, and it is the world that killed him, the authorities say.
 
Laundering Drug Profits
 Hundreds of millions, maybe billions of dollars in cash and cocaine flow in and around Jackson Heights, according to state and Federal law-enforcement officials. Along Roosevelt Avenue, a small but visible service economy bubbles amid travel agencies and check-cashers that, while seemingly unremarkable, are believed to launder hundreds of millions of dollars of drug profits each year.
Neighborhood advocates complain that the Cali cartel, and to a lesser degree the Medellin cartel, casts an unfair shadow on most of the 30,000 Colombian immigrants there. But law-enforcement officials say that is why the cartels chose Jackson Heights, because the dealers can blend into the vibrant, diverse and rapidly changing neighborhood.
"This is their base of operations -- this is the sea they can swim in," Thomas F. Sheehan, a Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent, said in a recent interview before two people were indicted in Mr. de Dios's death. "They are not immigrants. They are here to plunder."
 
Business and Crime
 Colombians are the largest Hispanic group in Queens, according to the city Planning Department. Most of the immigrants are legitimate workers or entrepreneurs who opened restaurants, clothing stores and real estate agencies.
But when cocaine came in vogue in the early 1980's, many other businesses opened that the authorities say are less innocuous. These enterprises fascinated Mr. de Dios as he wrote about the connection between crime and legitimate business.
"He had many friends and many enemies," said Nestor Campas, a 56-year-old Colombian who owns a clothing store next to the brick office building on 79th Street off Roosevelt Avenue where Mr. de Dios based his crime magazines.
The cartels themselves are elusive organizations in which members are strung through the city, moving and guarding cash and cocaine in so-called "stash houses" and "safe houses." Over the last few years, the authorities have made scores of raids, which they say have resulted in the movement of some high-level drug activity from Jackson Heights to quieter places like Long Island.
In 1991, the New York Drug Enforcement Task Force, made up of Federal, state and local authorities, arrested 38 members of a Cali cartel group in New York City. Many had ties to Jackson Heights, the authorities said.
 
'One-Stop Shopping'
 Although cartel members themselves -- and their bases of operation -- shift constantly, the authorities say that the cartel presence is clear in Jackson Heights because of the businesses that have sprung up to support them.
There are now some 200 travel agencies, check-cashers and international telephone services, many of which the authorities say launder hundreds of millions of dollars to South America and Europe. No one knows the exact numbers, but the Drug Enforcement Administration estimates that 90 percent of its money laundering cases in the New York area trace back to Jackson Heights.
And there is even what might be called "one-stop shopping" for high-level drug dealers: In 1991, the owners of a real estate office on Roosevelt Avenue were arrested after the authorities said they rented beepers, cellular phones and apartments for members of a cartel, and even arranged to handle their bills and rent payments.
"All these places, the majority of them, launder money," Ivan A. Hoyos, a 26-year-old telephone worker, said yesterday, echoing a common belief in the neighborhood and among law-enforcement officials. Referring to Mr. de Dios, he said, "He dealt with all of them."
Mr. de Dios's involvement in the neighborhood, exploring the cartels and their business relationships, ran so deep that many felt his death was almost inevitable, if not by the hands of the cartels then by someone else.
"Everybody was expecting this because of his books and his magazines," said Francisco Talamonte, a 31-year-old restaurant worker, as he sat in a small trash-strewn park off Roosevelt Avenue now named Manuel de Dios Unanue Triangle. "Everybody would say, 'One of these days, they are going to kill him.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Authorities say that the articles Mr. de Dios wrote chronicling cocaine importation in Jackson Heights and Elmhurst are probably what led to his death. (El Diario-La Prensa)

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Figures Revised Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Consumers increased their debts by a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.5 percent in March and borrowed much more during previous months than had been estimated earlier, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
Consumer installment credit grew by $3.44 billion, to $752.2 billion, in March, according to the Fed's report. It was the eighth straight monthly increase. 
 The Fed also said that consumer credit rose a sharply revised 7.4 percent in February, rather than 1.9 percent as estimated earlier, and 5.0 percent in January, rather than 1.6 percent.
The consumer-credit report contained revisions going back to January 1989, including more up-to-date data and newly calculations of seasonal factors.
Before the release of today's figures, the Fed had reported that consumers resumed borrowing after the recession, when many had reduced their debts though at a slow pace.
Consumer-installment credit includes all household debt not secured by real estate; it does not include home-equity loans or mortgages.
 
Hint of Spending Patterns
 Consumer-credit figures can be an indication of consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
In today's consumer-credit data, a lack of growth in personal income was apparent in the use of revolving credit. It increased 9 percent at a seasonally adjusted annual rate after shooting up a revised 13.8 percent in February and 10.1 percent in January. The Fed had said earlier that the increase was 11.4 percent in February and 7.3 percent in January.
But the rise in automobile credit slowed to 1.4 percent in March from a revised 11.5 percent surge a month earlier. The original February estimate had been a gain of 4.8 percent. Auto loans dropped 5.4 percent in January.
Other kinds of consumer credit rose 6.2 percent after falling a revised 4.5 percent in February, less than the 12.6 percent decline in last month's estimate. This category -- which includes loans for education, vacations, boats and mobile homes -- had increased 11.3 percent in January.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Consumer Borrowing" tracks monthly net change in total consumer installment credit outstanding since October 1991. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: Though Still in Effect, Arabs' Economic Boycott of Israel Weakens

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 10

 BODY:
Step by step, Government officials and business leaders here say, the decades-old Arab economic boycott of Israel has weakened to a point that many international companies now believe they can safely ignore it.
But the officials caution that while down, the boycott is far from out, and that it continues to scare away foreign businesses skittish about offending Arab countries, especially the oil-producing nations of the Persian Gulf. 
 Israelis were heartened by recent news reports that Kuwait and Saudi Arabia had told the United States that as partial repayment for the American rescue in the Persian Gulf war they would stop two forms of the blacklist: a secondary boycott affecting American companies that trade with Israel and a tertiary boycott of concerns doing business with the blacklisted companies.
 
Primary Boycott Remains
 No change was announced in the primary boycott, which prohibits Arab countries and companies from commercial dealings with Israelis and which was created by the newly formed Arab League in 1946, two years before the state of Israel was. Egypt, headquarters of the Arab League, dropped its own boycott laws after signing a peace treaty with Israel in 1979, although trade between the countries remains small.
Among other encouraging signs for Israelis were new antiboycott regulations that went into effect last week in Germany. More than a week ago, on the heels of a Japanese Government denunciation of the boycott, the heads of major Japanese trading companies came to Israel. While the visit produced no new contracts, the mere fact that it had taken place was considered significant, given Japan's faithful adherence to the boycott over the years.
Beyond that, Israeli officials and American Jewish groups are looking to the Clinton Administration to exert new vigor in efforts to kill the boycott once and for all.
Although American companies have been prohibited for 16 years by Federal law from observing the Arab blacklist, enforcement has often been spotty. That was underlined in late March when Baxter International Inc., the world's largest medical supplies concern, agreed to pay civil and criminal fines of $6.5 million for having tried to get around the antiboycott law.
 
The Largest Penalties
 The penalties against the Chicago-based company were by far the largest imposed under the statute. While some experts viewed the action as a sign that the new Administration might prove to be tougher on this score than its predecessors, others argued that the case had shown that even big companies could still be cowed into going along with blacklist rules.
Still, many Israelis say that momentum is now with them.
"I believe that the Arab boycott is on a losing trend," said Micha Harish, the Minister of Industry and Trade. Dan Gillerman, president of the Federation of Israel Chambers of Commerce, says that many companies -- including giants like Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Hilton Hotels and Toyota -- have discovered that they can set up shop in Israel without harming their interests in the Arab world.
"In many cases, the fear of the boycott turned out to be stronger than the boycott itself," Mr. Gillerman said. "Companies that never spoke to us, that would never answer an Israeli fax, are now coming here."
His organization estimates that the blacklist has reduced Israeli exports and foreign investment in Israel by 10 percent a year. "At the end of the day, I don't think Israel was devastated," he said. Nonetheless, the federation calculates that at that annual percentage, the country has lost more than $40 billion in exports and investments over the last 45 years.
Even in the recently improved climate, thousands of companies remain on the blacklist kept by the Damascus-based Central Office for the Boycott of Israel; they include hundreds of companies added in the last few years. And while Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have signaled that they are ready to ease up on American companies, they have made no such gesture toward Europeans and Asians.
In fact, several European companies were recently added to the roster, including CSA, the national airline of the Czech Republic. The carrier had been "transporting Jewish settlers to Palestine," an official in Damascus said.
Japanese businesses say that they, too, still feel Arab pressure even though their Government has begun calling for an end to the boycott and major auto companies like Toyota and Honda, once reluctant, have entered the Israeli market. Masaya Miyoshi, president of the Keidanren, the dominant Japanese business organization, said in Jerusalem recently that it could take years before large numbers of Japanese felt confident enough in this region's stability to tell the Arabs no.
Harry Wall, head of the Israel office of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said that unless the gulf countries declared unambiguously that the rules had changed, many small companies would continue to feel intimidated.
"The atmosphere is better, and the Middle East peace process has definitely had an impact," Mr. Wall said. "But until the Arab leadership stands up and says that in the spirit of the peace process we're dropping the blacklist, I can't say there's been progress."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ECOLOGIST NAMED FOR A U.N. AGENCY

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 10

 BODY:
In a move seen as likely to rankle many third-world governments, President Clinton has nominated a specialist on the environment as the new administrator of the United Nations Development Program.
The nominee, James Gustave Speth, is president of the World Resources Institute, an environmental research center in Washington. Clinton Administration officials confirmed today that he had been nominated to succeed William H. Draper 3d, who said last week that he would step down on July 15. Mr. Draper has been administrator since 1986, and his second four-year term was scheduled to end next year. 
 The Development Program administers and coordinates most of the United Nations' technical assistance programs around the world. They include programs in economic development, health, education, environmental protection and the status of women. Under Mr. Draper, the agency's programs grew in value from $890 million in 1985 to $1.5 billion in 1992. Traditionally, the agency's administrator has been an American.
 
Priorities Criticized
 Mr. Draper, a former president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank, was seen as favoring economic development over environmental concerns, a reputation he and his supporters contest.
Mr. Speth, a professor of law at Georgetown University, is a former chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, and he served on a White House strategy commission on dealing with toxic substances, in the Carter Administration. He was also a member of President Clinton's transition team dealing with natural resources.
Delegates here from some developing nations were said to be less than enthusiastic about Mr. Speth because of his background in environmental issues. In the third world, development and environmental protection are often seen as incompatible.
Mr. Speth was a major contributor to "Global Biodiversity Strategy," a blueprint for the Earth Summit, the United Nations-sponsored international ecological conference held in Rio de Janeiro last June.
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, is said to be ready to endorse Mr. Speth next month and to present his name to the General Assembly for formal approval. Under United Nations rules, he selects a candidate with the advice of the Development Program's governing council, a 48-nation body, which traditionally accepts the recommendation of the United States Government.

HEADLINE: A War on Global Corruption

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 10

 BODY:
Alarmed by a sharp increase in bribery over the last decade, a group of senior government, business and development-agency officials met here recently to establish a coalition against corruption in global business transactions.
The coalition, called Transparency International, is being modeled on Amnesty International, the human rights advocacy group. It will concentrate on battling what officials termed "grand corruption" in development programs and trade. 
 About 70 executives, aid experts and senior government officials attended the inaugural sessions here, including Robert S. McNamara, the former World Bank president and American Secretary of Defense. Its 30-member advisory council includes Oscar Arias Sanchez, Nobel laureate and former President of Costa Rica, and Andrew Young, chief American delegate to the United Nations in the late 70's. Initial financing is being provided by the German Foundation for International Development.
The experts said that corruption in international aid and commerce had risen sharply, with the average rates for bribes paid to acquire large contracts in developing countries rising in the 1980's from about 5 percent of a deal's total value to about 15 percent.
Anti-corruption measures like international competitive bidding or pre-shipment inspection of goods are, at the same time, being increasingly circumvented by tacit agreement of buyers and sellers, the coalition said.
