HEADLINE: Trade-Pact Opposition Eases a Bit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
After intense pressure from the White House, some leading Congressional critics of the North American Free Trade Agreement are toning down their oratory. A few of them are even saying they might support the pact after all.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said in an interview late today that he was urging Democrats to avoid taking positions now on the pact, which would eliminate trade barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States. He said lawmakers should give the Clinton Administration time to complete its negotiations with Canada and Mexico on three side agreements. 
 The side agreements will cover labor and environmental issues and the surges of imports that might follow the lowering of tariffs. They are scheduled to be completed by mid-July. The Clinton Administration is counting on concessions in the side agreements to win over some Democratic opponents of the pact.
 
Looking for 'Real Teeth'
 Mr. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, said the free-trade pact could pass Congress if the side agreements have "real teeth," as the Administration has promised. He described the pact itself as "a reasonable and good thing for the United States, Mexico and Canada to do."
Mr. Gephardt is scheduled to give his views on trade in greater detail in a speech here on Tuesday sponsored by the Economic Strategy Institute, a research group that has been critical of the pact.
Representative Sander M. Levin, a Michigan Democrat who has long been one of the most visible and influential Congressional critics of free trade, sent his colleagues a letter on Friday urging them not to take any position on the pact until the Administration concludes negotiations on the side agreements.
 
Possible Conditional Support
 Mr. Levin said in an interview today that he might support the pact if those agreements included a long list of changes intended to provide additional protections for American workers against lower-wage competition from Mexico.
The new stances by two of the best-known Congressional critics of free trade upset some members of Congress who remain opposed to the agreement. "I don't think this is the time for us to let the debate wallow; it's time for us to sharpen the debate," said Representative Marcy Kaptur, a six-term Ohio Democrat. "We can't be back-benchers on this one."
Representative Sherrod Brown, a freshman Ohio Democrat who has organized freshman opposition to the pact, said, "It seems to me now is the time to really scuttle the agreement."
President George Bush signed the agreement on Dec. 17, but it can go into force only if a simple majority of each house of Congress votes for legislation putting its provisions into law. Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said last week that the Administration planned to introduce this legislation at the beginning or end of August, so that it could be passed before Congress adjourned for the year. The agreement is scheduled to take effect on Jan. 1.
 
Intense Lobbying
 In interviews today, lawmakers gave several reasons for the pact's brightening prospects and the new reluctance of leading Democrats to criticize it. One reason is an Administration lobbying blitz after Leon Panetta, the budget director, said three weeks ago that the pact did not have enough votes to pass in its current form. Another is a compromise struck by six environmental groups 11 days ago to support the pact if a side agreement on the environment included certain provisions. If there was solidarity against the pact by the environmental movement and labor, Congressional approval would be difficult, said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who heads a Congressional group of the pact's backers.
A third reason is a decision by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council last week to continue pressing for broad side agreements and changes in the basic pact. Some union leaders have been calling for a national campaign to kill the agreement, but they were turned back by the national leadership, said Democrats with close ties to organized labor.
 
'Common Sense' Cited
 The council's decision "has some impact," Mr. Levin said. "In a sense, it's common sense: first decide what's in it."
Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican who has led support for the pact, said that among members of Congress, "There is a shift, and I trace it back to the Panetta comments, which really shook up the White House."
On Thursday, President Clinton strongly urged Congressional approval of the pact, while Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has defied opposition from organized labor to give two speeches in the last two weeks in favor of the agreement.
Administration lobbying has focused on the House, in which Democrats hold a larger majority, because purely local concerns about trade tend to be more pronounced and organized labor tends to have more influence there. Lawmakers and Administration officials say the agreement is more popular in the Senate.
 
Concern About Bureaucracy
 House and Senate Republicans have warned the Administration against pursuing ambitious side agreements of the sort sought by Mr. Levin and Mr. Gephardt. They contend that the North American labor and environmental commissions now being negotiated could turn into new bureaucracies on labor and environmental issues.
House and Senate Republican leaders have warned the Administration that it risks losing their support if the side agreements go too far.
The Administration lobbying effort has been unusually pugnacious. For example, it has included publicly and private appeals to anti-Japanese sentiment in Congress, something that the Bush Administration tried to avoid.
"If we fail to approve the Nafta, we won't get its benefits," Mr. Kantor told the Senate Commerce Committee last week. "In fact, it could go backward, and frankly, open up opportunities for the Japanese or other countries to come in and take advantage of what we will not take advantage of."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Castro Sofa Concern Sold By Family

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers

 BODY:
The Castro Convertibles Corporation of New Hyde Park, L.I., a family-owned company started in 1931 by Bernard and Teresa Castro, has been bought by Krause's Sofa Factory of Brea, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.
Michael W. Gibbons, the president and chief executive of Krause's, a unit of the Worth Corporation, said yesterday that his company had bought Castro's Long Island manufacturing plant, 18 Castro showrooms throughout the East Coast and the Castro corporate name and patents. The New Hyde Park plant, which employs more than 50 people, will close by summer, according to Krause's officials. 
 Mr. Gibbons said Krause's may some day open a new plant on the East Coast to serve a planned expansion of up to 100 stores under the Castro name. He said no specific sites had been considered for the plant, but he did not rule out reopening in the Ocala, Fla., area, where the company had a manufacturing plant until last year. Bernard Castro died in 1991, but Mrs. Castro lives in Ocala.
 
East Coast Expansion
 Krause's manufactures custom upholstered furniture and has 68 plants throughout the western United States. Mr. Gibbons said the purchase of Castro would allow Krause's to expand into the East Coast.
In 1991, Worth had a $1 million loss on sales of $79 million; for 1992, the company was expected to report sales in excess of $100 million.
Castro, a private company, recently retrenched. From 1990 to 1992, the company cut back from 45 showrooms to 18. Last October, the company said sales had declined 30 percent because of the recession. At that time, it closed the Ocala plant, putting 100 people out of work, and shifted production to New York.
Castro's president and chief executive, Bernadette Castro, the daughter of Bernard Castro, said in New York yesterday that she would remain with Krause's for 18 months to assist in the transition.
"It was a hard decision but something we discussed for several years with various sets of investors," Ms. Castro said.
She said the family made "no money" on the company's sale but was able to keep its extensive land holdings in Florida and New York. The family owns more than 4,000 acres of land in Marion County, Fla., in the central part of the state.
"Krause's will take us nationwide," Ms. Castro said. "Even though they will not use our name on the West Coast, they will expand our name greatly on the East Coast."

HEADLINE: Big Board Stocks Finish 6.09 Points Higher

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market staked out higher ground throughout most of the session yesterday, but fell back in the last half-hour, closing up only modestly.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed by as much high as 31 points before closing up 6.09 points at 3,443.28. All other major indexes were up, also modestly, in moderate trading. 
 The vicissitude of the market was especially difficult for analysts to puzzle out yesterday, having come after several recent sessions in which the Dow hugged a narrow trading range. Early in the day, some analysts said that the surge was partly due to a wave of buying in certain stocks by short-sellers, who had committed in earlier sessions to selling shares they did not own.
Short-selling means selling borrowed stock before it is actually purchased; the borrowed stock must eventually be bought and interest paid to the stockbroker for what, in effect, is a loan. Thus, according to the short-seller argument, the winners yesterday were the familiar big losers of previous trading days: stocks like Philip Morris, Merck and Eastman Kodak, all of which were up moderately yesterday.
But short-sellers often zero in on difficult-to-sell stocks, and the sheer volume in individual issues yesterday seemed to undermine the short-seller argument: 1.3 million shares for Kodak, 2 million shares for Merck and 6.87 million shares for Philip Morris.
 The alternative explanations for the market's strength were a firming of bond prices and even a delay in a United States decision on military intervention in Bosnia.
"The fact of the matter is," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist and portfolio manager for the Dreyfus Corporation, "this is a market characterized by halting rallies and halting sell-offs."
 
 
Bullish and Bearish Factors
 The reason is there is an abundance of both bullish and bearish factors, Mr. Hoey said, with neither side prevailing. On the bearish side are stock valuations that are high, or as Mr. Hoey put it, "fully stretched," as well as an increasing supply of new stock issues. On the bullish side are low short-term interest rates and a river of money spilling into mutual funds, he said.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index was up 0.35 point, to 245.03, and volume was 235.6 million shares, higher than Friday's volume of 223.5 million shares when the Dow closed down 4.7 points. Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners by 10 to 8.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed up 0.49 point, to 442.80, and the Nasdaq composite index, dominated by high-technology and smaller capitalization stocks, closed up 1.38 points at 682.82. The American Stock Exchange market value index closed up 0.63 point at 426.69.
The Dow was lifted by Goodyear Tire, up 1 3/4, to 38 5/8, and Philip Morris, up 1 3/4, to 52 3/4. Philip Morris was the most active stock on any exchange.
The Dow Jones transportation average, after vaulting 17 points, was down 1.61 points at the end of the day, to 1,569.87. It was dragged lower by Consolidated Railroad, or Conrail, down 7/8, to 51 3/4, and Delta Air Lines, down 1 1/8, to 56, on no discernible news.
 
 
Biggest Decliner
 The biggest percentage decliner on the Big Board was the Discount Corporation of New York, a dealer in United States Government securities. It was down 1/2, or 8.3 percent, to 5 1/2, also on no discernible news.
The biggest percentage gainer on the New York Stock Exchange was Parker & Parsley Petroleum, an oil explorer and refiner, up 3 1/8, or 14.4 percent, to 24 7/8, on news that it planned to buy $466 million in oil and gas limited partnerships.
Also notable was Gtech Holdings, which rose 1 5/8, to 37 1/2, on news that the New York Supreme Court affirmed a Gtech contract with the New York State Lottery. The court rejected a competitor's legal challenge to the award of the contract. Gtech manufacturers computerized equipment for making lottery bets.

HEADLINE: An East Coast Express? Maybe, in New Rail Plan

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARWICK, R.I., May 10

 BODY:
With faith that three-hour train trips from New York to Boston will be commonplace in a few years, about 100 rail experts gathered here to sketch out the next step: an advanced rail network that would extend over much of eastern North America.
Amtrak hopes to begin work next spring on electrifying the railroad north of New Haven to South Station in Boston, continuing a project that stopped 80 years ago. 
 The result, with a half-billion dollars of new trains that could take advantage of the electrification, would be to cut the trip time by an hour, and increase the railroad's slice of the passenger traffic it shares with the airlines to 60 percent from 15 percent, according to Amtrak. Separately, Maine and the the Federal Government have put up money to run trains from North Station in Boston to Portland.
At a meeting here today, organized by the Northeast Corridor Initiative, a nonprofit group based in Providence, participants proposed a system that would put New York State at the hub of a European-style high-speed rail network. Northeast Corridor service, which now runs on a modern system from Washington through New York to New Haven, and then continues to Boston with a sometimes slow, sometimes unreliable diesel, would continue on through Maine to the Maritime Provinces of Canada.
The route from New York City to Albany would be improved, along with the tracks from there to Montreal and to Buffalo. From Buffalo, the high-speed route would continue across Ontario to Detroit.
 
Looking Beyond the Border
 The rail route from Boston to Albany -- a 120-mile trip that now takes four and a half hours -- would also be modernized. The goal is to build a system that is faster than cars, especially on congested highways, and that compares favorably with planes on trips of a few hundred miles.
All that is needed, said Edward Burke, vice-chairman of the Initiative, is for the railroads to be recognized as the solution to the problems of road congestion, air pollution and high energy use. The technology, he said, is relatively easy.
"In 1921 when Franklin Roosevelt was stricken with polio in Campobello, they brought him through Eastport, Maine, to Washington in eight hours by train," said Mr. Burke, possibly with some hyperbole. But referring to the way the rail system has withered, he said, "Try doing that today."
Underscoring the reality of the transportation market, the day-long session was held at the Johnson & Wales Airport Hotel, across the parking lot from the Providence airport.
 
Federal Support Proposed
 The group announced the formation of a Canadian affiliate to push the plan from north of the border. It will be headed by Remi Bujold, the former Minister of Economic Development in Canada. Serving as co-chairman will be Richard M. Flynn, chairman of the New York Power Authority, and John Buchanan, a member of the Canadian Senate and a former premier of Nova Scotia.
Mr. Flynn and others at the conference said they were encouraged by the Federal Department of Transportation's proposal, made last month, to spend $1.3 billion over five years to encourage high-speed rail. The money could be used to match state spending, said James T. McQueen, associate administrator for railroad development of the Federal Railroad Administration, and if properly leveraged, "makes for a very good start." The money could be used for small public investments in large private projects, he said.
The Amtrak project, for which Congress has already appropriated $447 million, depends in part on an environmental impact statement now being prepared. One unresolved issue is whether electrifying the line would create electromagnetic fields along the right of way that would become a health hazard. The railroad is already installing concrete ties and better rails, and a signal system that can handle trains at 150 miles an hour.
But the ideas face formidable obstacles. For example, the Providence & Worcester Railroad, which handles freight on the Northeast Corridor from New Haven to the Rhode Island-Massachusetts border, is afraid that overhead power lines will be too low to allow triple-decker new car carriers, or containers stacked two high. Worse, very fast passenger trains may prove incompatible with 30-mile-an-hour freight trains, requiring a third track to be built in some areas, but the poles for the overhead power lines may go where the third track would have to be.

HEADLINE: $7.2 Million Grant Persuades Dun & Bradstreet to Move

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In what Connecticut officials hailed as a victory for their economic development campaign, Dun & Bradstreet, the financial information company, said yesterday that it had accepted a $7.2 million grant from Hartford and would move its headquarters staff of 300 people from midtown Manhattan to Wilton, Conn.
The money comes without any strings, and it is one of the largest outright grants Connecticut has ever given to a company. 
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who announced the relocation, said it was the result of 18 months of negotiations and reflected a new determination to attract business to Connecticut.
"This is a reaffirmation that the state is moving to rebuild its pro-business reputation," Mr. Weicker said. "We are competing."
 
Little Choice
 In fact, Connecticut had little choice. Dun & Bradstreet approached the state saying it was considering moving its existing operations in Wilton, Conn., to Westchester County or elsewhere. With the Connecticut economy still struggling to bounce back from the recession, state officials were eager to respond.
Dun & Bradstreet's decision, however, is not a repudiation of New York City. Although it is moving its top executives, it will retain 3,000 other workers in Manhattan.
Still, New York City officials said they had tried to persuade Dun & Bradstreet not to move its headquarters. The company, whose name has been all but synonymous with big business in Manhattan for more than 100 year, now has its headquarters on Park Avenue and 48th Street.
But at City Hall, officials said Dun & Bradstreet's departure, while a blow to New York's ego, would have little or no impact on its economy. The officials said New York City had not offered financial incentives to the company to stay, in part because such a small part of the company's Manhattan operations were at stake.
"This was not an economic issue," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, who negotiated with Dun & Bradstreet. "We don't like to lose any company, but New York has more corporate headquarters than any other city, and our franchise is not in jeopardy."
 
Deep Ties to Wall Street
 Dun & Bradstreet, which describes itself as the world's largest business information company, is an amalgam of subsidiaries with deep ties to Wall Street and corporations around the world.
Its major subsidiaries include Moody's Investors Service, the bond rating agency; an information services company that provides credit analysis of businesses; the A. C. Nielsen Company, which analyzes sales of consumer goods and television audiences, and a market research company that specializes in pharmaceuticals.
One advantage of moving to Wilton, an affluent suburban town in Fairfield County, is that the company owns and has only partially occupied the building that is to become its headquarters. It said it acquired the building in 1979, and in recent years has had 273 employees of its A. C. Nielsen subsidiary assigned to it.
Reid H. Gearhart, a Dun & Bradstreet spokesman, said yesterday that "several locations" were considered in addition to the Wilton site, but he declined to elaborate.
Initially, Dun & Bradstreet threatened to vacate the Wilton building and move its employees elsewhere. Later in the negotiations, Mr. Gearhart said, the company approached Connecticut with a proposal to use the Wilton building as its headquarters, but with financial support from the state.
The company said it would use the $7.2 million to renovate the building and to provide training for about 50 new employees to be hired there, mostly clerical workers. It plans to relocate its Nielsen workers elsewhere in Connecticut.
Joseph J. McGee, the state's Economic Development Commissioner, said Connecticut would recoup its grant money in less than three years through the income taxes to be paid by the Dun & Bradstreet headquarters workers, many of whom command high salaries.
 
'Highly Unusual Makeup'
 Mr. Weisbrod said New York's difficulties in persuading the company to retain its Park Avenue headquarters in Manhattan were complicated by what he called the "highly unusual makeup of Dun & Bradstreet."
"This is more or less a holding company," he said, in which senior headquarters staff members travel frequently to manage the affairs of businesses around the world.
"Unlike other financial powerhouses in New York, this is not a top management organization that needs to be in an urban center," he said.
Another benefit of relocating to Wilton is that many top Dun & Bradstreet executives live in the nearby suburbs.
In Harford, Mr. McGee said 42 of the 300 executives who will relocate their offices to Wilton already live in Fairfield County.
Dun & Bradstreet said 200 of its headquarters staff members would move to Wilton in September, with the rest moving there by the end of 1994.
The Manhattan space occupied by Dun & Bradstreet's corporate headquarters will be filled by a company division, Nielsen Media Research, whose current lease expires next year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Rise

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose yesterday as traders and investors awaited the beginning today of quarterly auctions of $35 billion in 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
The three days of auctions start with $16 billion of three-year notes this afternoon. The auctions and new reports on inflation in April will help to determine the direction of the bond market. 
 David Ader, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the 3/8-point increase in the price of the 30-year bond was partly a result of too much selling on Friday. Yesterday, he said, many traders decided to reduce their exposure to an adverse market move by buying back bonds.
Although dealers often sell ahead of a Treasury auction to try to get prices lower and make the new securities cheaper, Mr. Ader argued that many dealers were afraid of selling too many bonds ahead of an auction when trading remained in a narrow range.
 
Fear of Exposure
 He said that with basic economic developments generally supportive of bonds and with a lot of cash still waiting to be invested, dealers did not want to be exposed at the lower end of a trading range, since prices could rally and push yields down again.
Mr. Ader said he mainly saw buying by institutions and other investors yesterday in shorter Treasury maturities, like the three- and five-year notes. But he said the price of the 30-year bond probably rose the most yesterday because it fell the most on Friday.
Many traders say they believe that the rally that pushed the yield on the 30-year bond to a 16-year low of 6.72 percent in early March is over. But the employment data on Friday, which reported a smaller-than-expected 119,000 increase in nonfarm payroll jobs in April, shows that economic growth is still sluggish. As such, inflation is not expected to be a threat for some time. In addition, the slow growth makes it unlikely that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates any time soon.
With another round of low inflation reports expected this week, investors and traders will be getting the kind of news that would keep yields close to their recent lows.
 
Producer Prices Tomorrow
 The Labor Department will issue the April Producer Price Index tomorrow, the day of the 10-year auction, and the Consumer Price Index on Thursday, the day of the 30-year bond auction.
At the same time, the Clinton Administration's problems in Congress are beginning to worry some investors, who are now much less confident that the President can win approval of the spending cuts and tax increases that are needed to bring down the budget deficit. Combined with the uncertainty about the President's health-care proposal, the President's performance, which had helped the bond rally earlier in the year, is now putting some upward pressure on interest rates.
In trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond rose 12/32 , to 104, as the yield dropped to 6.81 percent, from 6.84 percent on Friday. Earlier in the day, the market regained almost all the ground lost in the selloff on Friday. But by the end of the day, some of those gains had been erased.
The price of the 10-year note was up 5/32 , to yield 5.87 percent, down from 5.90 percent. The price of the three-year note was unchanged at a yield of 4.13 percent.
 
When-Issued Market
 In the when-issued, or pre-auction, market, the yield on the 30-year bond was also at 6.81 percent, down from 6.85 percent Friday. The yield on the 10-year note was down to 5.88 percent from 5.91 percent. For this auction, the Treasury is reopening the current 7.125 percent 30-year bond and the 6.25 percent 10-year note and issuing additional securities with these coupons in an effort to ease a sharp shortage that could make it easier to manipulate the market.
For the three-year note, which will be a new issue, the yield in the when-issued market was at 4.26 percent yesterday, up from 4.24 percent Friday.
At the regular weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rate on the three-month bill was 2.89 percent while the average on the six-month bill was 2.99 percent. Both discount rates were one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, higher than the rates at last week's auction.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Widespread Rally in Dollar Is Aided by Selloff in Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar soared against the British pound and other leading currencies yesterday in a powerful rally that seemed to shake the American currency from its recent doldrums.
The broad advance, while largely technically driven, gave a bullish tone to the dollar after weeks of decline. Strengthening the dollar was a selloff in the pound, which lost nearly 4 cents in value amid growing concerns about the stability of the Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major. 
 Traders said the dollar's rally had its roots in trading late last week, when the dollar did not sink below a recent psychological bottom against the German mark and began to climb.
 
Loss of Confidence
 That encouraged traders to buy the dollar. It broke 1.5920 German marks in early New York trading, proceeded to crack the 1.6-mark level and settled at 1.6075 marks. That was sharply higher than late Friday's 1.58375 marks.
Much of the dollar buying was by sellers of pounds who are losing confidence in Britain's economic recovery. In addition, speculation mounted yesterday that the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, would be replaced after the Government's poor showing in elections last week.
"People were positioned for a lower dollar, and it looks as though they're wrong," said John Nelson, director of foreign exchange at Barclays Bank. "Everything is revolving around liquidation of sterling positions."
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5354, from $1.5730 late on Friday. The pound fetched $1.5340 in New York, sharply lower than late Friday's $1.5720.
The pound's weak tone spread to other European currencies, particularly the mark and the Swiss franc, amid uncertainty about the European economic union and the economy of Germany.
"The fact that those currencies are weakest reinforces that the dollar is beginning a new leg up," said Marc Chandler, a market strategist for IDEA. "These are more than just corrective upticks. There's a generalized stronger dollar tone."
The dollar rally also hurt the Japanese yen. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 110.27 yen, up 0.30 from Friday. In New York, the dollar traded at 111.78 yen late yesterday afternoon, up from late Friday's 110.30.

HEADLINE: East Europe's Low Wages Luring Manufacturers From West Europe

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GYOR, Hungary

 BODY:
Needing a factory to build a new generation of engines, Audi, the German car maker, spent years considering sites in Spain, France, Austria and eastern Germany, among others.
It finally made a choice that is becoming increasingly common among Western manufacturers: Eastern Europe. In particular, Audi and many other manufacturers have picked this Hungarian region 30 miles from the Austrian border to take advantage of sharply lower labor costs and access to Western markets. 
 Although some Eastern European economic officials have complained that investment and purchases by the West have been less than they had hoped, there is no quarrel with the fact that nearly $8 billion has been invested in Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic since the fall of Communism. One reason is that wages and social welfare taxes are usually less than half those in the West -- and sometimes as little as a tenth.
That is making Eastern Europe appear to Western industry the same way that Mexico looks to companies in the United States. Just as American companies have shifted labor-intensive production south of the border, Western manufacturers are starting to migrate east, leaving in their wake concern about job losses and a protectionist backlash.
 
Best of Both Worlds
 Big names like Volkswagen, Thomson and General Electric are part of the trend as well as hundreds of smaller concerns. Audi's decision, for example, will ultimately create 1,000 new jobs here and will cost its engine factories in Germany roughly the same number.
At first, the investments were in joint ventures with state-owned companies that were being privatized. Then came entirely new factories. But for the most part the initial investments were intended as an entry into Eastern markets rather than as a way to shift work to the East.
But stiffening competition in almost every industry has manufacturers searching for the least expensive places to make their products. And Eastern Europe offers the best of both worlds: markets with growth potential and low-cost factory sites to make products for Western Europe or anywhere else.
"We are bound to see production moving away to areas where production costs are lower," Horst Krenzler, a European Community official, told a panel of the European Parliament in April. "And it is a problem we are going to have to grapple with for the next 10 to 15 years,"
At a time when much of the European Community is in recession and unemployment and trade tensions are high and rising, labor unions in the West are watching the trend with dismay, anger and some resignation.
"The decision to start producing engines in Hungary was a blow for us, and involved very hard negotiations," said Hans Joachim Werner, a spokesman for the Audi Workers Council in Germany. "It is a question of numbers, after all, and the management's arithmetic was very convincing. Wages there run about two to three Deutsche marks an hour and it is up to 10 times that here."
Audi found that producing in Gyor would be a third less expensive than in eastern Germany, the other finalist for the new plant, said Tamas Bognor, Audi's director of marketing in Hungary. Labor costs are expected to be about half what they would be in Germany, he said.
To win approval for its plan from Audi employee representatives,, Audi had to guarantee that it would funnel a third of the savings to worker retraining and other benefits for employees at its main plant in Bavaria. It also persuaded its workers that low-cost production of components might be the only way for the auto maker to survive in the intensely competitive business.
Workers in steel, textiles, agriculture and other industries have taken a harder line. They are putting pressure on their governments to protect their jobs, even if it means erecting or bolstering trade barriers with Eastern Europe.
Officially, the European Community says that it will continue to liberalize its trade agreements and eventually offer community membership to nations in the East. But it could become harder to maintain that position, community officials say, if jobs continue to migrate eastward.
 
Vastly Lower Costs
 "We see the first signs in textiles and steel, but it is something that is going to become much more acute when we bear in mind that wage costs are lower in the area by a factor of more than 1 to 10," said Mr. Krenzler, who is the community's director general for external relations.
For all the upheaval it is causing in the West, the trend is helping the economies of the East. The region around Gyor has become one of the most popular sites in the old Soviet bloc for Western investment because of its easy access to Austria and Germany. Its regional government and economic development officials spend considerable time in the West touting the area's attributes and have struck deals of one kind or another with more than 700 foreign companies.
Hungary's unemployment rate is 13 percent, but in Gyor-Moson-Sopron County it is 8 percent. The streets of Gyor are bustling, new stores are opening and in a sure sign of economic development, Gyor has a McDonald's.
"The export possibilities are very good from here to both Eastern and Western Europe; we have a highly qualified work force and low operating and wage costs," said Gabor Botos, the president of the county council. "This is attracting jobs."
But manufacturing here can be problematic. Western executives say it is easy to underestimate the expense of modernizing plants or building new ones. Joint ventures and wholly owned plants can absorb tremendous amounts of management time, they say. And lower wages do not by themselves guarantee operating efficiency.
General Electric, whose 1990 investment in the Tungsram light bulb factory in Hungary was one of the pioneering joint ventures in the East, has generated nothing but losses. Last month G.E. injected $195 million into the venture to keep it afloat, raising its total investment to more than $500 million. The company is expected to lose money again this year amid intense competition, high overhead and the effect on exports of a currency considered overvalued by many Western manufacturers.
 
Hard to Beat, Despite Problems
 Still, the labor cost advantage available in Hungary and elsewhere in the East remains a lure, especially for German companies like Audi.
According to a report last year by Morgan Stanley International, average labor costs in 1991 in western Germany were $22.49 an hour, compared with $15.34 in France, $15.27 in the United States, $13.41 in Britain and $13.23 in Japan. In eastern Germany, where workers have been pressing for parity with the West, labor costs were $14.56. But in Hungary they were $1.38 an hour, and in Poland, $1.
"Germany's cost structure is an enormous burden," said Nigel Gault, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill in London. "We're seeing throughout German manufacturing industries a rethinking of where to locate production facilities, and they are deciding in some cases that they cannot afford to produce in Germany anymore. They are deciding that one of the places they want to produce in the future is Eastern Europe."
But wages are rising in Eastern Europe, particularly for Western companies that are paying for the most motivated and skilled workers. Ganz-Hunslet RT, a British-Austrian-Hungarian joint venture in Budapest that exports railway cars, has average labor costs of about $6 an hour including wages and social welfare costs, said Stephen F. Kostyal, the managing director. But that compares with $12 to $15 an hour in Britain, he said.
 
Well-Educated Work Force
 Moreover, workers in most Eastern European nations tend to be as well educated and trainable as their counterparts in the West, executives said.
Thomson Polkolor, a joint venture outside of Warsaw that is 51 percent owned by Thomson, the French consumer electronics company, exports more than three-quarters of its production of television picture tubes, mostly to Western Europe. But the plant has become competitive on a worldwide basis only after considerable investment and effort by Thomson, which paid $35 million for its majority stake. The plant had been closed before Thomson came in, and when production was restarted, as much as a third of the tubes it produced could not pass quality tests.
Thomson brought new technology, retrained workers and reorganized management. Now, said Stanley Urban, the chief financial officer, the rejection rate is down to as low as half a percent, in line with Thomson's best factories around the world.
The company is sufficiently happy with the joint venture's results that it is spending $65 million to upgrade the plant's technology further. However, Mr. Urban said the plant could not compete in the long run on its labor cost advantage alone.
"Labor rates at present are lower than they are in Western Europe but the rate of increase is pretty steep," Mr. Urban said. "We're not looking for a bargain off the backs of our employees. We believe we pay them fairly."

HEADLINE: G.A.O. Sees Softening of Bank Rules

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Congressional auditors chastised Federal bank regulators today for preparing standards that they called "a serious weakening" of the rules Congress intended to prevent management abuses from leading to bank failures.
The banking act Congress passed in 1991 "needs to be fully implemented by meaningful regulations to avoid the costly mistakes of the past," Charles A. Bowsher, the head of the General Accounting Office, said in a letter to the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. 
 The F.D.I.C. is expected to vote on Tuesday on new standards for internal management practices to be followed by banks it regulates, including requirements for annual independent audits, internal controls on lending and the use of audit committees. But the agency, judging by discussions at its recent public meetings, is likely to issue a rule that sets broad guidelines rather than specific strictures and that exempts all but the largest banks from the rule's effects.
The F.D.I.C.'s action appears to reflect a broad decision by regulators, with the blessing of the Clinton Administration, to emphasize giving banks more leeway so that they will lend more freely and help to stimulate the economy.
 
 
A Gentle Touch?
 Experts said that banking regulators, in issuing a stream of rules called for by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Improvement Act of 1991, have been adopting a gentle touch that has pleased the industry but dismayed some advocates of tougher regulation.
A month ago, for instance, the Federal Reserve Board proposed rules to carry out another section of the law, and it, too, chose to write broad guidelines rather than precise prescriptions. At issue was a section of the law calling for each Federal banking agency to set standards regarding operations, management, asset quality and other banking practices -- details so arcane that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, calls these "the micromanagement provisions" of the law.
Banking analysts consider the regulators' soft touch in putting the law into effect a big victory for the banking industry, which generally viewed the law's passage as a defeat.
Karen Shaw, president of the Institute for Strategy Development, a banking consultancy, said the rules promulgated by Federal agencies since the law was passed were not as harsh as had been predicted.

HEADLINE: Penelope Gilliatt, 61, Film Critic And Writer for The New Yorker

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
Penelope Gilliatt, a writer of fiction, journalism and screenplays, and a longtime film critic for The New Yorker, died on Sunday at her home in London. She was 61.
She had been in poor health for some time. 
 Ms. Gilliatt (pronounced with a hard G) was best known for the film criticism she wrote from 1968 to 1979 for The New Yorker, where she shared reviewing duties with Pauline Kael, and for her screenplay for "Sunday, Bloody Sunday," a 1971 film starring Glenda Jackson and Peter Finch.
Her short stories were marked by precision, compression and a gift for conveying a dramatic situation through dialogue. Anthony Burgess, reviewing her short-story collection "Nobody's Business" for The New York Times Book Review in 1971, wrote: "She is intelligent, economical, poignant, highly contemporary. She is also innovative."
Ms. Gilliatt, whose maiden name was Penelope Conner, was born in London. Her father, a barrister and later a judge, worked as a director of the BBC. After attending Queen's College, a private school, she came to the United States to enter Bennington College in Vermont on a scholarship. She dropped out during her first year. "I thought I should get on with life, and I'd run out of money," she later said in a newspaper interview.
 
A Contest Winner
 A brief period working for the Institute of Pacific Relations in New York ended when she won a short-story contest sponsored by British Vogue. She returned to London to join the magazine's staff, eventually becoming its features editor. She also contributed freelance articles to The Spectator and New Statesman.
From 1961 to 1967, Ms. Gilliatt served as film critic and, for one year, drama critic of The Observer in London. In 1968 she joined The New Yorker, where, in addition to reviewing film, she contributed many short stories and profiles.
Her first novel, "One by One" (1965), about a menage a trois, contained the seeds of her screenplay for "Sunday, Bloody Sunday," about a London couple, a man and a woman, in love with the same man. The screenplay, which was widely praised for its sensitive, literate treatment of a potentially exploitative subject, was nominated for an Academy Award. The National Society of Film Critics named it the best screenplay of the year, and the New York film critics, in a tie vote, named her co-winner for best screenplay with Larry McMurtry, for "The Last Picture Show.
Ms. Gilliatt left The New Yorker in 1979 on an extended leave of absence after writing a profile on the novelist Graham Greene whose accuracy was challenged by Greene. A novelist, Michael Mewshaw, also complained to the magazine that material in the article had been taken, without credit, from an artcile he had written on Greene for The Nation. At the time, Ms. Gilliatt said that Mr. Greene's charges were a subtle form of practical joke. She continued to contribute short stories to the magazine and in recent years wrote profiles of John Cleese and Jonathan Miller.
 
Known for Her Stories
 Although Ms. Gilliatt wrote five novels, including "A State of Change" (1968) and "The Cutting Edge" (1979), she was best known for her stories, collected in "Come Back if It Doesn't Get Better" (1969), "Nobody's Business" (1972), "Splendid Lives" (1978), "Quotations From Other Lives" (1982) and "They Sleep Without Dreaming" (1985).
Ms. Gilliatt's New Yorker film criticism and profiles were collected in "Unholy Fools" (1973) and "Three-Quarter Face" (1980). Her last book was "To Wit: Skin and Bones of Comedy" (1990), a collection of essays.
Both her marriages, to Roger Gilliatt, a neurosurgeon, and the playwright John Osborne ended in divorce.
She is survived by a sister, Angela Conner of London, and a daughter, Nolan Osborne Parker of East Sussex.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
New TV Deal a Slight to Fans and Players Alike

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
In concocting an unprecedented television deal with two networks, major league club owners have sent messages to their fans and their players. They have told their fans that not all their post-season games are worth watching, and they have told the players that the partnership they have proposed isn't worth the paper it would be written on.
To the fans, the owners have said, look, we have had a maximum of 21 post-season games and you have been able to watch, if you have so desired, all 21 of them. Now we want to increase the maximum number of post-season games to 41, but we want to decrease the number you can watch to 19. 
 That would be the effect of the regionalization of baseball's playoffs. The first, or new round of divisional playoffs, would consist of four series with a maximum of five games each, adding a potential 20 games to the 14 games of the league championship series and seven of the World Series.
But the new round of games would be televised regionally, as would the league championship series, meaning fans could see only one series of the first round and one of the two league championship series. Forget the staggered starts of games six and seven of the latter series as a way of seeing additional games. That gimmick could turn out to be meaningless, depending on the length of the two games.
"What is the equivalent of the A.F.C. and N.F.C. championship games is being televised so that you can't see both," Eugene Orza, a Players Association lawyer, remarked yesterday.
Regionalizing post-season games falls into the category of how more is less. By creating it, the owners are demeaning their sport. But they have long done that. For years, they have undermined the product they sell by complaining about greedy players and their salaries. If General Motors and Ford executives followed a similar approach in talking about their products, everybody in America would be buying foreign-made cars.
The television deal also represents a self-fulfilling prophecy. For a couple of years, owners have been talking about how their television money would be reduced drastically, giving networks no reason to offer more than rock-bottom prices. It was a major part of the owners' doom-and-gloom approach in an effort to show that players' salaries were too high.
Some management people apparently wanted to emphasize that the two-network deal represented a major economic hit, but other officials said w that would only continue the doom-and-gloom approach.
Nothing positive between the clubs and the players has emerged from the deal. The owners, who want the players to accept a salary cap, have talked of forming a partnership with the players, but their relationship suffered a setback yesterday.
Players Association and management officials disputed what management had told the union before the deal was announced Saturday.
"I informed them of the outline of the deal without mentioning which networks were involved," Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, said, discussing a meeting the two sides had last Thursday. "I told them everything I was told about the deal at that point, how it was structured, the fact there was no guarantee."
Donald Fehr, the union head, and Orza disputed the suggestion that they were informed of all of the important details. Furthermore, they said they did not know before the announcement that the deal had been completed.
"If he told us everything he knew about the deal, he didn't know anything," Orza said. "Nothing was said about such things as regionalization and the way post-season games would be televised. It came as a complete shock to me that they would do this deal without getting back to us and getting our input. It's clear they don't want our input. They'd rather be partners with the networks."
The owners will meet Thursday in Chicago to discuss the television deal. Bud Selig, the man in charge in the absence of a commissioner, said he wasn't certain if they would vote on the deal. But the owners might want to ask a question about what might have been.
A baseball lawyer familiar with at least some aspects of the negotiations said that earlier in the talks CBS had offered about $130 million for the same setup they have had for four years. Superstation TBS, he said, offered $40 million to $45 million for an extra round of playoffs. With those offers, the owners could have had perhaps $175 million to divide, two-thirds of the average of $265 million CBS has paid under the expiring contract.
Under the joint venture with NBC and ABC, if they sold $250 million in advertising, which some television people consider a long reach, baseball would net $158 million.
Reducing the gross by 15 percent in agency fees, the net becomes $212.5million. Baseball will get 87.5 percent of the first $160 million in net sales, which is $140 million; $10 million of the next $30 million and 80 percent of everything beyond $190 million. Subtract its $10 million in start-up costs, and baseball would net $158 million.
In this deal, baseball carries all of the risk. In what could have been, it would have carried no risk.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CLASHES CLOUD U.S. POLICY ON BOSNIA;
End to Sanctions Sought

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 10

 BODY:
The President of the Yugoslav federation, Dobrica Cosic, will soon ask the United Nations to ease economic sanctions against his country in response to its recent decision to halt most supplies to the Serbian nationalist forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina, a senior Yugoslav official said today.
The aide, Dragoslav Rancic, also said that Yugoslavia would accept the deployment of foreign observers along its border with Bosnia to verify that supply lines have been cut. But he said such observers should also be deployed along Bosnia's border with Croatia, across which military aid for Croatian and Muslim forces now flows freely. 
 In a dramatic turnaround, the Governments of Serbia and its parent state, Yugoslavia, announced on Thursday that they would no longer allow any supplies other than food and medicine to be shipped to their longtime clients in Bosnia. They acted hours after a Bosnian Serb assembly rejected a peace plan.
 
Inspection of Vehicles
 Yugoslav soldiers along the border have received orders to inspect all vehicles seeking to cross into Bosnia and to turn back any that are carrying unauthorized supplies.
A vice-president of the self-proclaimed Bosnian Serb Republic, Biljana Plavsic, telephoned a Belgrade television station today to complain that she had been turned back at the border. She said Yugoslav border police had shown her a notice ordering them not to admit the Bosnian Serb president, Radovan Karadzic, or other officials. But she said she had managed to slip across.
 
A Deepening Isolation
 Banning Bosnian Serb leaders from entering Yugoslavia would increase their already considerable isolation.
"We are very sorry about that decision of Yugoslavia," Mr. Karadzic said today from his headquarters in Pale. "We know that they are being squeezed and blackmailed, but still it's too strong a measure."
Foreign diplomats in Belgrade were uncertain today whether the new restrictions on movement between Bosnia and Yugoslavia were genuine.
"There are indications that this is a serious step," said one diplomat. "Had they taken it a year ago, we might not be where we are now, and there might have been 100,000 less victims."
Asked if the United Nations might ease sanctions, the diplomat replied, "I think you're getting ahead of the game. We have to see what the follow-through is."

HEADLINE: 2 BUSINESS GROUPS ATTACK TAX PLAN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Two major business lobbying groups attacked important aspects of President Clinton's tax proposals today, arguing that the plan would weaken the economy and make the tax code less fair.
One group, the United States Chamber of Commerce, lined up against a Clinton plan to tax energy and to increase the corporate income-tax rate to 36 percent from 34 percent. The White House has said the measures would raise $100 billion in the next five to six years. 
 Separately, a group of 300 major corporations and trade associations known as the Tax Reform Action Coalition said it strongly opposed Mr. Clinton's move to increase the top rates for individual and corporate taxes. The group was an important force behind Congress's decision in 1986 to overhaul the income-tax laws, lowering most rates and eliminating an array of shelters and loopholes.
It is unclear how the opposition will affect Mr. Clinton's plan. The two groups join a number of others, including the National Association of Manufacturers, that have come out against parts of the Administration proposal. The tax plan will have its first serious Congressional review this week, when the House Ways and Means Committee meets in private to draft the proposal into legislation.
The Chamber of Commerce has come under attack from conservatives, in Congress and from in its own ranks, who complain that the chamber has not been tough enough on President Clinton. The chamber adopted a "wait and see" position on Mr. Clinton's proposals when they were made public in February, rather than declaring its immediate opposition to tax increases.
Chamber officials insisted that the announcement today was not meant to regain the confidence of conservatives but rather reflected rising disenchantment with the President's policies among the 215,000 businesses represented by the organization.
Meeting with reporters today, the president of the chamber, Richard L. Lesher, said the energy tax would slow economic growth and fuel inflation by raising the costs of producing and shipping manufactured goods. Because imported products would not be similarly taxed, foreign competitors would gain an economic advantage over American goods here and abroad, the chamber's economists contended.
Members of the Tax Reform Action Coalition registered their opposition to income-tax increases in a letter to Mr. Clinton on Thursday. In the letter, made public today, they argued that the increases undid the fundamental compact of the 1986 tax law: the idea that the income tax should be both lower and cover businesses and individuals who had escaped taxation through using loopholes.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Hopes Are as Big as Texas in Senate Race

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, May 10

 BODY:
When Lloyd Bentsen announced late last year that he would quit the Senate to become Treasury Secretary, Texas Democrats spent a few convulsive weeks sorting out whom Gov. Ann W. Richards should name to replace him. Still, at least one thing seemed likely: whoever was chosen would spend a long time in the seat, which has been held by Democrats since Reconstruction.
But then came the special election for the seat on May 1 when the State Treasurer, Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Republican, stunned nearly everyone by placing first in an open field of 24. That left Governor Richards's choice, Bob Krueger, who placed second, as the clear underdog in the June runoff. 
 With the unexpected emergence of Ms. Hutchison, Texas could be on the verge of having two Republican Senators for the first time in modern history.
And President Clinton could be on the verge of having to cope with a major political headache: a Democratic loss in a race that Texas Republicans say they will gleefully cast as a referendum on his Presidency. A loss would also mean erosion of the 57-to-43 edge that Democrats now hold in the Senate.
 
An Assist From Dole
 Republicans in the Senate have already banded together to block the President's multibillion-dollar plan to stimulate the economy. Picking up the Texas seat would embolden the Republicans and their Senate leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, who campaigned over the weekend for Ms. Hutchison.
All told, Republican candidates in the special election won 58 percent of the vote even though the state's Democratic leadership was united behind Mr. Krueger; some of his advisers had even speculated that he might just capture 50 percent and avoid a runoff.
Ms. Hutchison finished first, though by just a few hundred votes from more than the two million cast. She won despite a bruising attack from two Republican Congressmen who repeatedly brought up accusations that she had once pummeled a staff aide with a notebook, pinched others and ordered employees to perform personal chores for her on state time.
Ms. Hutchison denied the accusations, which were leveled by the daughter of former Gov. John B. Connally, Sharon Ammann, who said she was on the receiving end of the notebook assault because she took too long to look up a telephone number that Ms. Hutchison wanted. Both women have said they took polygraph tests that showed they were telling the truth.
 
A Commanding Position
 In the open election Ms. Hutchison weathered the charges, though perhaps only because they were pushed out of the spotlight by the April 19 fire that consumed the Branch Davidian compound near Waco and left 72 people dead.
In any event, many Texas political consultants say Ms. Hutchison is in a commanding position for the runoff, which the Governor has set for June 5.
Part of the reason is Mr. Krueger himself, a former English professor and Elizabethan scholar at Duke University who served in the House of Representatives in the late 1970's but lost two previous campaigns for the Senate. Governor Richards turned to him only after several better-known figures, including former Mayor Henry G. Cisneros of San Antonio, took themselves out of contention. Mr. Cisneros later joined the Clinton Cabinet as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
Even some of Mr. Krueger's allies say the new Senator suffers from a sanctimonious bearing, lackluster campaigning skills and -- perhaps most damaging in a state where people like their politicians to be bold and colorful -- an image as a bland moderate. A Democratic rival once said Mr. Krueger would "run over his own mother to get to the middle of the road."
Still, the Senator has tried to put the best face on the situation, insisting that he likes to run as an underdog.
 
Going on the Offensive
 In the rich tradition of Senate runoffs here, which includes Lyndon B. Johnson's controversial 87-vote victory over Coke Stevenson in 1948 -- the victory that earned him the nickname Landslide Lyndon -- two things are virtually certain: anything can happen, and the race will turn nasty before it is over.
Mr. Krueger wasted no time going on the offensive against Ms. Hutchison, telling reporters the day after the first round of voting that "the people of Texas over the next five weeks will clearly want to assess her integrity."
He promised to make an issue of an investment services contract awarded by Ms. Hutchison's office to Goldman Sachs & Company, one of whose partners is a major supporter of hers. She says the contract, for which she suspended bidding, saved the taxpayers money.
Mr. Krueger, a consistent supporter of abortion rights, also criticizes Ms. Hutchison for what he calls her "multiple choice" position on the issue. She says she favors a woman's right to choose an abortion, but she has also said that states should be entitled to impose restrictions on abortion.
So far, Ms. Hutchison has tried to take the high road. "I talked about my dream for America, and he talked about how negative and how tough this campaign was going to be and how he was going to trash me from one end of this state to the other," she said of Mr. Krueger.
 
No Senatorial Courtesy
 But even if Ms. Hutchison keeps the gloves on, she will get plenty of help from fellow Republicans in attacking the interim Senator. Even before she made it into the runoff, the Republican National Committee was running negative radio advertisements about Mr. Krueger. And Texas's other Senator, Phil Gramm, a Republican, has abandoned all pretense of senatorial courtesy for his Texas colleague, ridiculing what he called Mr. Krueger's "stunningly poor showing" on May 1.
Although no statewide polling data have been made public since the election, a survey of 829 voters by the Mason-Dixon Poll, conducted a few days before the election, included a question about a matchup between Ms. Hutchison and Mr. Krueger. She got 47 percent to his 40 percent, with 13 percent undecided.
For Ms. Hutchison, a victory in the runoff would surely catapult her to national attention. And for the Republicans, it would mark an important step in the party's effort to put more Republican women in office. Four women were elected to the Senate last fall, but all were Democrats. (The only female Republican Senator is Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas.) And only 12 of the 47 women elected to the House were Republicans.
In the May 1 election, the 49-year-old Ms. Hutchison won 593,479 votes while Mr. Krueger, 57, received 592,982. Thus, each of the two front-runners won about 29 percent of the vote.
But given the relative unity among Democrats and Ms. Hutchison's intraparty challenge from Representatives Joe L. Barton and Jack Fields, the results were widely interpreted in Texas as a triumph for Ms. Hutchison and an embarrassment for Mr. Krueger. Mr. Barton and Mr. Fields placed third and fourth, respectively, with about 14 percent each.
Democrats have tried to play down the results, with some claiming that the Senate race was skewed by a large number of anti-tax Texans who turned out to vote against a statewide school-finance proposition that would have shifted some education revenue from wealthy school districts to poor ones.
"What she did, in effect, was surf a tax-revolt wave," George C. Shipley, a consultant to Mr. Krueger, said of Ms. Hutchison.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CLOSING OF CONAGRA PLANT TO IDLE 600 WORKERS

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Conagra Frozen Foods plant in Turlock, Calif., will close in July, leaving about 600 people out of work, the company announced yesterday. The plant, which processes frozen dinners and entrees under the Banquet and Healthy Choice Labels, is a victim of overcapacity, a Conagra vice president, Gil Mulhere, said. 
 The plant, a leading employer in Turlock for 37 years, is operating at less capacity than the seven other plants that make up its division, he said. Its production would be shifted to plants in Missouri, Arkansas, Iowa and Virginia.

HEADLINE: A Useless Filibuster

 BODY:
Sixty votes. That's what it takes to break a Senate filibuster and speed a measure to a floor vote, where only a majority is required for passage. Sixty is the magic number this week as the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, tries yet again to win passage of the "motor-voter" bill -- an overdue political reform designed to make it easier for Americans to vote.
The measure, vetoed by President Bush, would require states to let people register to vote when they obtain or renew a driver's license. It would also require states to permit registration by mail. 
 For want of one vote in March -- there were 59 votes for cloture -- the bill's backers swallowed damaging G.O.P. amendments removing the requirement that states make registration available at public assistance, disability and unemployment offices. The face-saving compromise that has emerged from a House-Senate conference committee mandates registration at welfare and disability offices but makes it optional at unemployment offices. It also adds safeguards against coercion.
Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota, one of a handful of moderate Republicans who voted for the measure last year but not in March, when the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, made it a test of party loyalty, now says he'll vote for the bill.
That should be sufficient to give Mr. Mitchell the 60 votes he needs. Mr. Dole knows that, but he may still put the Democrats through the paces, tossing up the usual arguments about the bill's costs and its potential for fraud. But where's the evidence? The states that already register voters at motor vehicle offices report no increase in cheating.
Mr. Dole's opposition rests not on fear of fraud but fear that the new registrants will vote Democratic. This time, with some luck, democracy of the small "d" variety will prevail.

HEADLINE: Record Store of Near Future: Computers Replace the Racks

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Computer technology has turned its hungry gaze on a pair of well-known institutions: the record store and the video shop.
A vision of the future of entertainment retailing, announced yesterday by I.B.M. and Blockbuster Entertainment, could do away with sprawling stores, aisles and aisles of offerings, and back rooms full of inventory -- be it the latest Michael Jackson recordings, Arnold Schwarzenegger video releases or Nintendo games. 
 In a few years, even a small-town record shop might offer all the titles of the biggest big-city megastore -- not on hand, but summoned from the digital files of big computers thousands of miles away, traveling as electronic impulses to machines in the store that copy recordings or movies on blank CD's or videocassettes.
I.B.M. and the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation announced a partnership yesterday to jointly pursue this vision. The computer giant and the entertainment retailer will work on developing the new distribution technology for use in-house by Blockbuster, which has nearly 3,500 video and music stores. The technology would also be sold to other retailers.
The concept, analysts say, has several advantages over current methods for putting recorded entertainment into consumers' hands, eyes and ears. For retailers, it could eliminate the costs of shipping and inventory, and avoid the loss of business when popular offerings are out of stock.
 
Vastly Expanded Choices
 "It could well change the economics of retailing for record stores and video rental shops," said Tom Adams, an analyst for Paul Kagan & Associates, a research firm in Carmel, Calif.
For consumers, the concept promises almost unlimited availability and diversity. "If a 7-year-old comes in on a Friday night and wants the latest hot video game, the chances are high now that it's sold out," said David Lundeen, vice president of Blockbuster's technology unit. "But with this system, it's never sold out -- you can get another one electronically in a couple of minutes."
Despite its promise, the new technology faces some formidable obstacles. The company formed by the International Business Machines Corporation and Blockbuster to run the system, Fairway Technology Associates, must negotiate with record companies, movie studies and game makers for the rights to sell their wares.
Sony Music, for one, gave the I.B.M.-Blockbuster venture a chilly reception. In a brief statement yesterday afternoon, Sony said it was not supporting the new system, indicating concerns about electronic distribution of its recordings.
"Commercial copying is illegal, and it's not clear to Sony Music what benefit consumers would derive from in-store copying," the company said, though it added that it was confident that I.B.M. and Blockbuster "would not engage in commercial piracy."
Limited previous efforts to market recordings electronically have not had notable success, encountering resistance from consumers, who seemed to prefer retailing's sizzle to cold technological efficiency.
 
A Note of Skepticism
 "Electronic distribution hasn't worked yet," noted Richard Shaffer of Technologic Partners, a consultant in New York. "Consumers don't just want the music. They want the liner notes, the nice picture of Michael Jackson, all that."
In 1988, Tower Records/Video made room in its big record stores for an outside vendor, the Personics Corporation of Menlo, Calif., whose computerized kiosks enabled consumers to make their own customized audio cassette tapes. The systems were popular for a while, but customers eventually lost interest. Personics wound up in bankruptcy court in 1991.
"In the end, its kiosks were just sitting around, unused," said Robert Delanoy, vice president of retail record sales for Tower.
Personics, Mr. Delanoy said, had trouble getting licensing rights from record companies, and thus had a limited selection. And most customers preferred to just buy tapes rather than compile their own.
For his part, Mr. Delanoy is skeptical about the I.B.M.-Blockbuster effort. "We're going to keep on doing this the old-fashioned way -- just sell 'em," he said.
 
Backers See Advantages
 Yet I.B.M. and Blockbuster are convinced they have a more advanced system, more marketing muscle and better timing. "This is a distribution channel with compelling advantages for retailers, content suppliers and consumers," said Robert Carberry, president of Fireworks Partners, the I.B.M. unit handling the partnership with Blockbuster.
The new system, which should be available in the first half of next year, will involve a kiosk in the store, where consumers will order selections by touching a computer screen. The first offerings will be audio compact disks and video games, with videocassettes offered later.
Working models of the system copy CD albums in about six minutes. Color laser printers in the kiosk will reproduce the jacket pictures and liner notes -- with a quality that company officials say is indistinguishable from factory production.
At the outset, the price of the electronically distributed CD's will be the same as those from the factory. But that could eventually change, since $3 to $4 of the cost of a $15 CD now goes for transportation.
Unlike the early system tried at Tower Record stores, the I.B.M.-Blockbuster venture will offer only the same CD albums that the record companies market. It will not give consumers the option of making their own album by picking and choosing songs , for instance.
 
Maybe Easing Some Fears
 That restriction, I.B.M. and Blockbuster officials say, should simplify the task of counting the number of times a recording is transmitted from a central computer bank to stores, presumably allaying record companies' fears about piracy. And it would simplify the task of paying record companies a fee each time a recording is reproduced.
Officials with the venture say they have held talks with some record companies, game makers and movie studios, and many of them are intrigued. A big Japanese video game producer, for instance, is said to be quite interested. In its statement, Sony said it had not been contacted by either I.B.M. or Blockbuster.


GRAPHIC: I.B.M. and Blockbuster Entertainment intend to develop computerized retail booths were customers can have their choices from a vast library of digitally recorded music, video games, computer software or nearly any kind of digital information manufactured to order in minutes. Here is how the technology might work for music recorded on compact disks.
 
1. Participating record companies put their recordings in digital form into a master computer library called a regional server.
 
2. Booths installed at retail stores have permanent high-speed data links to the regional server.
 
3. A customer in a booth slips a credit card through a swipe card reader. The computer built in to the booth checks the store's data base for information about the customer's past purchases and displays a menu of choices tailored to the customer.
 
4. The customer navigates through menus and makes selections by touching the screen. Video clips and sample cuts can be played to help the customer choose an album.
 
5. The computer in the booth signals the regional server to transmit the customer's selection and charge the cost to the customer's credit card.
 
6. The selection is transmitted to the booth, where it is recorded on a blank CD, while labels and packaging are printed by a color printer. The manufacturing process takes at least six minutes.
 
7. While the customer waits, the booth computer may offer related merchandise like concert tickets or posters, or show video clips.
 
8. When the CD and its packaging are ready, they appear in the booth for the customer to take.
 
(Source: International Business Machines) (pg. D13)

HEADLINE: SERBIA'S PRESIDENT CALLS FOR MEETING OF HIS COUNTRYMEN

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Wednesday, May 12

 BODY:
In a move apparently intended to override the rejection of an international peace plan by Bosnian Serb leaders, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia demanded on Tuesday that the leaders cancel their proposed referendum on the plan.
He called on them to come to Belgrade on Friday for an extraordinary gathering of legislators from all of the Serbian-populated regions in the Balkans. 
 Early this morning, the Yugoslav press agency reported that the Bosnian Serbs had rejected Mr. Milosevic's invitation and said they would go ahead with the referendum. Because the Milosevic proposal was endorsed by virtually all of the key leaders of the various Serbian republics, it appears that the Bosnian Serbs have placed themselves in virtually complete political and military isolation.
 
Unclear if Session Will Proceed
 It is unclear whether Mr. Milosevic will go ahead with the meeting without the Bosnian Serbs, bringing together members of the Serbian, Montenegrin and federal Yugoslav Parliaments, and representatives of the self-declared Serbian Krajina Republic in Croatia.
Even if the Bosnian Serbs' assembly would have voted once more against the peace plan at the proposed gathering, their votes would have been overwhelmed by those of the other legislatures, which are expected to support the plan with great majorities.
The Bosnian Serbs' referendum, scheduled for Saturday and Sunday, is expected to result in a vote against the plan, which was drafted by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen. The Bosnian Serb leaders said today that they would consider attending a pan-Serbian meeting, but only after the referendum.
 
'Of Utmost Importance'
 "The decision on the Vance-Owen peace plan is of utmost importance not only for the Serbian people in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also for Serbia, Montenegro, the Serbian Krajina Republic and the Serbian people as a whole," Mr. Milosevic told the Yugoslav press agency. "Support for the Vance-Owen plan is the same as support for peace, and this fact can be overlooked only by those who are not motivated by the interests of Serbia and its people."
Because of Serbia's previous support for its brethern in Bosnia, the United Nations has imposed sharp economic sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro, and Mr. Milosevic's actions against the Bosnian Serbs are in part meant to encourage the United Nations to lift the embargo. But Western diplomats here are becoming increasingly convinced that genuine resentment now exists between the Bosnian Serbs and the leaders in Serbia.
As soon as the peace plan is approved, Mr. Milosevic asserted, "tensions will ease, the standard of living will rise and citizens will be relieved of uncertainty and the fear of war."
"Serbia must now start thinking of itself," he said.
 
Milosevic's Campaign for Plan
 Mr. Milosevic's statements and his proposal for the joint parliamentary session on Friday were the latest steps in his intensifying campaign to win approval of the peace plan and bring an end to the embargo.
At a session in the Bosnian town of Pale last week, the Bosnian Serb assembly rejected Mr. Milosevic's plea to endorse the Vance-Owen plan, which would divide their war-torn land into 10 semiautonomous provinces. They voted instead to hold a referendum on the plan, but neither Mr. Milosevic nor foreign diplomats here considered that an acceptable alternative.
Since then, Mr. Milosevic has been steadily increasing pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to reverse their decision. Only hours after the vote in Pale, the Governments of Serbia and Yugoslavia announced that they were cutting all military and logistical aid to the Bosnian Serbs. Later they reportedly banned Bosnian Serb leaders from entering Yugoslav territory.
In recent days, Mr. Milosevic's campaign has intensified, with bitter attacks against Bosnian Serb leaders in the Government-controlled press. Only a week ago, these leaders were being portrayed here as heroic fighters who were making great sacrifices to defend the Serbian nation. Now they are depicted as reckless adventurists who live in luxury while their people suffer.
One of the principal targets of this new campaign has been the president of the self-proclaimed Bosnian Serb republic, Radovan Karadzic. A television broadcast today reported that Dr. Karadzic was a heavy gambler who had run up the equivalent of $200,000 in debts at a Belgrade casino. Newspaper reports have alleged that his daughter lives in a luxurious villa she received as a gift from a Serbian-American millionaire, and that his son recently sought to push wounded soldiers off a relief flight to make room for his dog.
Another newspaper story said that one of Dr. Karadzic's vice presidents, Biljana Plavsic, had bought a luxury apartment in Belgrade despite having no known source of income.
"The whole Bosnian Serb leadership, and by extension the referendum they have called, is being vilified and ridiculed," a European diplomat said. "The goal is to convince people that there is no point in fighting or suffering for people like that. Milosevic is making a U-turn in order to get the peace plan approved, which he now believes is essential if he is to stay in power. This is a very interesting moment."
A senior Yugoslav official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Milosevic was determined at all costs to win approval of the Vance-Owen plan.
"The reason is simple," he said. "We are exhausted."
