U.S. Watches Supply Flow
 Special to The New York Times
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Administration officials said today that it was too early to tell whether Serbia was carrying out President Milosevic's pledge to choke off the flow of material and equipment to Serbs in Bosnia.
Initial intelligence reports indicate that truck traffic -- including some oil tankers and military transport vehicles -- continues across the principal bridges that link Bosnia to Serbia.
But officials said that while American spy satellites could produce detailed photos of roads in the Balkans, it was difficult to detect from above whether a given truck was stocked with bread or mortar rounds.
Although the Bosnian Serbs have stockpiled ammunition, they depend on Serbia for fuel and spare parts. Janez Jansa, the Defense Minister of Slovenia, said recently that the war would begin to wind down in weeks if Mr. Milosevic really turned off the logistical pipeline to the Bosnian Serbs.


GRAPHIC: Bosnian Croat forces in MOSTAR battled Muslim-led government troops for control of the west bank of the Neretva River in their quest for a "Greater Croatia."
Chart: "Balkan Update"
At the United Nations, BOSNIA formally requested withdrawal of peacekeepers and workers from Bosnia yesterday in the hope that a Security Council arms embargo would be lifted. The Council is unlikely to agree.
Yugoslav leaders in BELGRADE appealed to Bosnian Serbs to join a vote of all Serbian lawmakers in the former Yugoslavia on a peace plan for Bosnia. But the Bosnian Serbs rebuffed the plan, which would undermine their own referendum. The plan was expected to fail the referendum but would have a chance of passing in a pan-Serbian vote.
Clinton Administration officials traveling with the President in Illinois said the he is considering sending troops to the former Yugoslav republic of MACEDONIA to bolster peacekeeping forces.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: Compromise on Military Gay Ban Gaining Support Among Senators

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Senior Senate Democrats and Republicans are beginning to coalesce around a proposal that would end the military's efforts at unmasking homosexuals but would continue to bar gay men and women from serving if they are open about their sexuality.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, summarizes the policy as, "Don't ask, don't tell." It would mean that the military would not ask new recruits about their sexual orientation or conduct investigations meant to ferret out homosexuals. 
 But it would also impose a strict code of conduct that would address such questions as harassment, holding hands on base and same-sex dancing.
 
Opposed by Clinton
 The Clinton Administration and gay-rights groups oppose the plan, which would essentially make permanent an interim Defense Department policy worked out by President Clinton and Senator Nunn in January. The temporary plan stopped the practice of asking recruits their sexual orientation, but it still allows the armed services to place declared homosexuals in a special-reserve status until Mr. Clinton issues a new policy.
The proposal, which still lacks specific details, today received the endorsement of the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf war, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. "Open homosexuality is the problem," the retired general told a hearing of the Armed Services Committee.
General Schwarzkopf told senators that allowing declared gay men and lesbians to serve in the armed forces would result in disheartened troops. Testifying in his familiar booming voice, General Schwarzkopf likened such demoralized soldiers to the Iraqis "who sat in the deserts of Kuwait" when allied forces rolled through.
 
Supported by Sailors
 The compromise, enthusiastically received by scores of Navy sailors whom senators interviewed at the Norfolk Navy Base on Monday, has suddenly gained momentum. Senators John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, and Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, today lent their support to the proposal.
"What this says is that people can't identify themselves as being gay and stay in the military," said one Pentagon official. "It contradicts the President's commitment and his order to the military to draft a policy that lifts the ban."
Defense Secretary Les Aspin must present a draft executive order to Mr. Clinton by July 15. The Pentagon has two groups -- about 50 military officers and the Rand Corporation -- studying how to carry out the directive. Senior aides to Mr. Aspin say they will begin consulting with advocacy groups, military leaders and lawmakers in early June.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the other military service chiefs would almost certainly support the compromise since it would codify the interim policy they have already approved.
Thomas B. Stoddard, coordinator of the Campaign for Military Service, a gay-rights group, said Senator Nunn's proposal would not end discrimination against gay service members.
 
'A Lawyer's Tinkering'?
 " 'Don't ask, don't tell' is a lawyer's tinkering with a policy that must be rooted out in its entirely if equal protection of the law means anything," said Mr. Stoddard.
It is unclear how deep support for the compromise runs in the Senate Armed Services Committee, which has been holding hearings on whether homosexuals should be allowed to join the military since late March. Senator Nunn and the panel's ranking Republican, Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, both favor the plan.
A spokesman for Senator Dan Coats, one of the ban's strongest proponents, said the Indiana Republican has sensed a shift toward the compromise but is waiting to hear more testimony.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, strongly oppose the compromise. "Members of the armed forces, like any other Americans, should be judged by their ability, not by the prejudice of others," said Mr. Kennedy's spokeswoman, Pamela Hughes.
 
Senate Backing Predicted
 One senior Senate aide said, "We haven't done any kind of a head count, but my feeling is that the compromise would get a heck of lot more votes than Clinton's position."
Supporters of the compromise acknowledged that defining homosexual behavior posed a brier patch of hypothetical situations to untangle. A spirited exchange between General Schwarzkopf and Senator Levin illustrated the point.
Seated alongside two Marine Corps officers and a senior Navy enlisted officer at the witness table, General Schwarzkopf summarized: "Don't ask the question, but don't tolerate any homosexual activity or behavior in the organization."
When Senator Levin asked if reading a magazine that catered to homosexuals constituted homosexual activity, General Schwarzkopf said, "No."
 
A Barracks Scenario
 But then General Schwarzkopf added that if a soldier was reading the magazine "in the barracks on a continuous basis to the point where it caused all those around you to be concerned about your sexual orientation and it started to cause polarization within your outfit," the offending service member should be removed.
Several gay people, some on active duty and others who have left the service, testified at the Senate hearing and took issue with General Schwarzkopf and Senator Nunn's compromise.
"As long as there's a regulation out there, someone will have the power to use that threat against me," said Margarethe Cammermeyer, a former colonel and chief nurse in the Washington State National Guard. She was discharged last year for acknowledging that she is a lesbian.
 
A Father's Discovery
 The hearing's most emotional moment was provided by a Marine colonel, Fred Peck, who became familiar to Americans as the military spokesman for the multinational operation in Somalia.
Colonel Peck, who returned last week from five months in Somalia, told senators that if the military ends its ban on openly gay members he would tell his sons to stay out -- especially the one who is homosexual. Colonel Peck said he would fear for the life of his 24-year-old son, Scott, an aspiring journalist at the University of Maryland.
"I love him as much as I do any of my sons," said Colonel Peck, who later told reporters he learned of his son's sexual orientation just five days ago.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Passes the Hat Among Supporters at Ellis I.

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Trying to cash in on a strong showing against his Democratic challengers in several recent polls, Mayor David N. Dinkins was joined by 750 supporters on Ellis Island last night for an elegant salute to his mayoralty and a passing-of-the-hat that his campaign hoped would net $1 million.
The Mayor chose the unusual site for the fund-raiser to emphasize a theme that no doubt will figure prominently in his re-election campaign: inclusion. Both the location and the evening's program were intended to reinforce Mr. Dinkins's image as a healer, a political leader capable of bringing together New Yorkers of diverse ethnic, racial and religious backgrounds. 
 But the selection of Ellis Island also raised anew a two-year-old dispute over a quotation attributed to the Mayor in a profile in Vanity Fair magazine in January 1991. Mr. Dinkins, the magazine said, told his friend, Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, that he had declined to attend the formal opening of the renovated immigrant reception center on Ellis Island.
"Ellis Island is for the people who came over on the ships! My people came over in chains," the magazine said Mr. Dinkins had told Mr. Rangel as they marched an an African-American Day Parade.
"I don't want any part of those people from the ships today," it quoted the Mayor as saying. "Today, I am coming home."
 
'All in the Same Boat Now'
 Mr. Dinkins said yesterday at a news conference at City Hall that he had been misquoted. The Mayor insisted, as he has before, that he never made the remarks attributed to him.
"That's not what I said," Mr. Dinkins said. "I don't talk that way. You have heard me. When I talk about Ellis Island and immigrants in general, I have a set thing.
"I say always, because I very deeply believe it, I say that some of us, our ancestors may have come on the Mayflower, and others of us our ancestors were here to greet the Mayflower. Still others came on ships seeking freedom from oppression, as our Haitian brothers and sisters do this very day. Some others came on ships seeking freedom of religion. My ancestors came in the hold of slave ships and in chains.
"But the significant thing is, irrespective of the ships on which our ancestors may have come, we're all in the same boat now."
Mr. Dinkins did not attend the opening ceremonies at Ellis Island, having chosen instead to march in the African-American Day Parade, the Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said late yesterday.
Mr. Dinkins's campaign tried last night to reinforce the theme of inclusiveness in the fund-raiser. For example, invitations showed the torch of the Statue of Liberty raised to a globe surrounded by this slogan: "We are one world. We are one people."
The Mayor, standing against the glittering backdrop of the Manhattan skyline across the bay, predicted that he would be re-elected in the fall.
"We will prove again that the values and ideals that made our city a mecca for immigrants from every continent are still powerful and compelling," Mr. Dinkins said. "We will prove again that New Yorkers share our vision of New York as a city of economic strength and economic opportunity for all. A city of toughness and decency. A city with big dreams and a bigger heart."
"With your help," he continued, "we will in September and November of 1993 -- not just for a candidate, but for our enduring ideals and our best hopes."
The Dinkins campaign hoped to raise $1 million from last night's event, said Leah C. Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Dinkins campaign, including those who attended, paying $1,000 a ticket, and others who could not attend but made donations.
Among the celebrities who spoke at the dinner were Mary Tyler Moore, the salsa musician Willie Colon and Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, the widow of Arthur Ashe.
Mr. Dinkins's chief rivals, Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney, held their own fund-raisers two weeks ago. Mr. Giuliani raised about $1 million for his Republican campaign at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, while Mr. Stein took in several hundred thousand dollars at a party at the St. Regis Hotel for his challenge to Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic primary.
It is not possible to say exactly how much each campaign has raised, because the last reporting date was in January and the next is not until July. In January, Mr. Stein had raised the most money, $4.7 million, compared with $3 million for Mr. Dinkins and $2.25 million for Mr. Giuliani, but Mr. Stein has also had the highest expenses. The three major candidates all had roughly comparable amounts on hand -- around $2 million -- after factoring in the matching city funds for which Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Dinkins are eligible.
The most recent poll on the mayoral race, released on Monday by Quinnipiac College in Connecticut, showed Mr. Dinkins ahead of Mr. Stein, 43 percent to 17 percent. Herman Badillo, the former Bronx Borough President, trailed with 9 percent of those surveyed and Roy Innis, the head of the Congress of Racial Equality, had 6 percent. The survey of 1,001 registered city voters had a margin of error of 3.1 percentage points.
The Quinnipiac poll also showed the Mayor and Mr. Giuliani in a statistical tie. The survey showed Mr. Dinkins with 43 percent of those surveyed, Mr. Giuliani with 40 percent and 17 percent undecided. Because of the margin of error, the results represent a dead heat.
In a related development, George J. Marlin, a municipal bond expert who has never run for office before, formally announced that he was seeking the Conservative Party nomination for Mayor. Mr. Marlin, who is challenging Mr. Giuliani for the nomination, called both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Dinkins failed liberals.
When the remark was repeated to the Mayor by a reporter, Mr. Dinkins laughed heartily. "It's going to be an interesting campaign with him in it," the Mayor said.

HEADLINE: The Economics of Wait and See

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
As economic growth has slowed in the last few months, business executives have exhibited signs of nervousness. Many have scaled back expansion plans, put hiring on the back burner and held down capital spending.
The uncertainty in Washington is clearly one reason for the hesitation. But even as executives keep one eye on Congress and another on the White House, many say their caution comes as much from their own modest order books and economic forecasts as from the political outlook. This wariness comes at a stage in the business cycle when attitudes normally turn more ebullient and is likely to help turn predictions for only moderate growth into reality. 
 "We quite frankly are waiting to see," said Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores. "We are trying to understand where it's all going. We're just not seeing a lot of activity. We have to be conservative. There's a sense of uneasiness about the future."
Gerry Saylor, chief economist at Deere & Company, the largest farm equipment company in the world, blamed "uncertainty over policy" for part of the reluctance of business to expand. But, he added, "70 percent is explainable by the slow recovery."
Even though most forecasts called for slower growth this year than at the end of 1992, unexpectedly sluggish activity in many economic sectors -- from industrial production to retail spending -- clearly is taking its own toll on business plans. In March, for example, when the forecasting firm Cahners Economics asked 400 business executives in its monthly poll what was holding back their expansion plans, more than two-thirds blamed sluggish economic prospects for their caution.
It is a theme voiced by executives in many industries.
"We were hoping that the economy would have firmed up more by now than it has," said James Treadway, president of Seattle-based Westin Hotels and Resorts, North America.
Mr. Treadway noted that the lodging industry was still slowly digging "out of the hole we found ourselves in after the gulf war." Instead of building new hotels, he said, Westin was aggressively taking over management of its properties from others.
 
Dissatisfaction With Clinton
 To be sure, the Washington scene is also making many executives uneasy. To some executives, the defeat of the Administration's economic stimulus package signaled that other Clinton programs to help the economy -- including strengthening the infrastructure and developing new technologies -- face rough sailing, and that, too, helped cool nascent business enthusiasm.
"The Clinton Administration has been extraordinarily ineffective in getting the pork through," said T. J. Rodgers, the chief executive officer of the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation. He said the "broad pragmatic middle" of the business community is saying to itself, "the pork's in jeopardy; the taxes aren't."
"The political side reinforces the economic side," said Kermit Baker, chief economist at Cahners Economics. "If the economy were healthier, we'd see a different reaction to some of the plans being proposed in Washington."
The economic and political uncertainties are affecting growth plans in many different ways.
"It's not a great market in which to raise capital," said J. J. Finkelstein, the president and chief executive of Cryomedical Services Inc., a five-year-old biomedical company in Rockville, Md. "We had to fund our launch from within. It hasn't really stopped us, it's just given us less of a cushion. It's kept us lean."
Health-care companies are particularly handicapped now, Mr. Finkelstein said. "It's difficult for medical companies to make decisions when they don't know where they'll be tomorrow. At the meetings I attend in my industry, the single most common question and discussion is where health-care reform will come out."
Of course, to the extent that prospects brighten and the economy starts looking better, that, too, feeds on itself.
"Once business thinks prospects are brighter, they start investing," said George Hatsopoulos, chief executive of Thermoelectron, a Waltham, Mass., high-technology company. "The moment that they invest, employment grows, the thing snowballs. This has not happened. We never got to the point of sustained optimism in the business community."
For now, however, even as executives see some improvement -- and can make the case for yet more -- they are being very careful not to let costs rise.
The Hechinger Corporation, for example, a home improvement and hardware store chain with 122 stores, is still planning to add 10 new stores this year. At the same time, however, John Hechinger Jr., the chief executive, talks of seeking ways to cut costs.
"We'll continue to focus sharp control in the area of overhead -- the back office or back room. We'll concentrate aggressive energy in reducing expenses and infrastructure, even payroll -- and instead, invest capital at the point of contact with customers," he said.
At the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, there also are prospects for growth -- but also for belt tightening.
"There is certainly a substantial pent-up demand for housing in this country," said James C. Van Meter, chief financial officer at the Atlanta-based forest products company. "But people are not inclined to want to make the commitment that's required to purchase a new home when they're worried about jobs."
"While we haven't seen a large spike in demand, we are prepared for the normal construction season," he said, but added: "Our managers try to keep the head count as low as consistent with prudent operations."
 
Damp Entrepreneurial Spirt
 Even entrepreneurs are sounding conservative. "We're not hiring ahead of the curve," said Jean Villanueva, a corporate vice president America On-Line Inc. a Vienna, Va., company that sells data to computer users.
The Navistar International Corporation, a Chicago-based truck manufacturer, said the company was not planning to expand its head count despite its expecting truck sales to be up solidly this year.
"Companies are still very willing to make investments where there are good payoffs," said Mr. Saylor of Deere. But most of those investments, he said, were designed to bolster productivity, or output per machine or per worker, rather than total production.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Lends Support To the Free-Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The House majority leader today broadly endorsed the Clinton Administration's trade policies toward Mexico and Japan, while calling for legislation later this year to extend the use of trade sanctions in labor and environmental disputes.
The endorsement from Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the most prominent advocate in Congress of a more confrontational trade policy, has political effects. It is aimed at protecting the Administration from criticism by labor and some environmental groups who argue that Clinton trade policy is not tough enough. 
 The proposed legislation would provide cover for lawmakers who want to vote for the North American Free Trade Agreement, in the face of arguments from these critics that the pact fails to address inequities inherent in low Mexican wages and lax enforcement of environmental controls.
Mr. Gephardt also endorsed the Administration's request for an extension until December of the President's authority to negotiate a 112-nation global trade agreement -- within the Uruguay Round of tariff talks -- and submit it to Congress with no amendments allowed.
Extension here of "fast track" authority requires approval by both houses of Congress. Mr. Gephardt's comments improve the odds of its emerging from Congress unaltered.
The legislation that the majority leader proposed today would have a limited effect on Mexico or Canada, the two countries with which the Bush Administration negotiated the North American accord. It would authorize the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, to impose sanctions on countries that failed to enforce their labor and environmental laws. The North American pact would limit the application of such measures to Mexico and Canada.
Sanctions concerning labor and environmental issues would be possible against Mexico or Canada if such provisions are included in side agreements being negotiated for the North American pact. Administration officials are debating this week whether to include these sanctions.
Mr. Gephardt avoided taking a position today on whether trade sanctions should be included in the side agreements, though unions and some environmental groups have called for this. He said he would wait to see what the Administration was able to negotiate with Canada and Mexico.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
A Return to Profits for Equitable

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
The Equitable reported yesterday its first profitable quarter since 1989 -- the latest chapter in the turnaround story of an insurance giant that faced insolvency as recently as two years ago.
After-tax earnings for the first quarter of this year totaled $31.8 million, the company said, compared with a loss of $18.6 million for the corresponding period in 1992. 
 The good news for the company came 10 months after the Equitable Companies went public and received $1 billion in capital from Groupe Axa, the third-largest insurance company in France. Since going public in July at $9 a share, the stock has risen as high as $22. The stock closed yesterday at $21.75, up 62.5 cents.
 
Luck and Skill Helped
 "The improved profitability for the quarter reflects the continuation of significant positive trends in our core businesses," said Richard H. Jenrette, the Equitable's chairman and chief executive. "The company's investment services segment had another outstanding performance, and Equitable's insurance segments continued to show substantial improvement."
The company has benefited from both luck and skillful management by Mr. Jenrette, analysts said yesterday. It was luck that the company went public just before a stock and bond market rally that not only improved its investment portfolio but also bolstered profits in its financial services units, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and the Alliance Capital Management Corporation.
But the analysts also cautioned that the company's stock price, buoyed by excitement in all financial services stocks, may have run ahead of Equitable's recovery.
"It is a good company and it is a survivor," said Dan Murray, an analyst with Argus Research in New York. "But considering the quality of their assets -- they have a tremendous amount of underperforming real estate -- I think the price has gotten ahead of itself."
Two years ago, Equitable appeared to be a classic story of 1980's failure. Then a mutual insurer owned by its policyholders, the company tried to lure investors with hot new products that paid high interest rates. Equitable's Guaranteed Investment Contracts paid up to 18 percent yearly and were backed by junk bonds and real estate. But junk bonds and real estate plummeted in value, and many analysts said that Equitable was at risk of insolvency.
In 1990, the company installed Mr. Jenrette, who cut costs and assets and who reached an agreement with Axa to give the French company a 49 percent stake in Equitable in exchange for capital. Equitable raised $450 million in its initial public offering of common stock and an additional $800 million from an issue of convertible preferred stock.
In its announcement yesterday, the Equitable said its pretax earnings for the first quarter totaled $48.3 million, up from $9.4 million one year earlier.
After-tax operating income from insurance operations totaled $21 million in the first quarter, compared with $4.8 million for the quarter last year. Both numbers exclude disability income losses and investment transaction gains and losses.
The Equitable's investment business generated after-tax earnings of $46.4 million for the first quarter of 1993, down from $49.3 million in the corresponding period of 1992. The company reported a loss on its disability income business of $31.6 million, compared with a loss of $4.5 million a year earlier. The company is trying to shed that business.
The company's overall after-tax earnings of $31.8 million included investment gains outside of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette of $7.3 million and restructuring charges of $3.9 million. The loss in the first quarter of 1992 included investment losses and one-time charges of $46 million.
But analysts said the company remained dependent on its investment services operations, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and Alliance Capital Management, which have benefited greatly from rallies in stocks and bonds. The Equitable's problem commercial mortgages totaled $299.1 million at the end of March, down from $388.4 million.
Shelly Harris, a director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the Wall Street rating agency, said that because real estate problems were expected to continue, Equitable's life insurance operation must raise more capital and increase sales to meet investors' expectations.
Although the company's agents have largely remained loyal to Equitable, Ms. Harris said, the premiums generated in 1992 were below that of 1990.
"They have a new generation of insurance products," Ms. Harris said. "The field force has got to get out there and sell them."

HEADLINE: Sharply and Loudly, G.O.P. Rivals Debate

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHIPPANY, N.J., May 11

 BODY:
The three major candidates for the New Jersey Republican gubernatorial nomination participated in their first televised debate tonight, getting little chance to differentiate themselves from their rivals but giving voters across the state a barb-filled, free-wheeling 90-minute preview of the final weeks of the campaign.
The clash began with the opening question, on the controversial $2.8 billion tax increase that Gov. Jim Florio pushed through three years ago. The three -- Christine Todd Whitman, Jim Wallwork and Cary Edwards -- alternately cut one another other off or tried to shout one another down. 
 "Cary, you keep putting words in my mouth," Mrs. Whitman said at one point. "You've done that about 15 times."
With the primary four weeks from tonight, the campaign has turned into the backbiting race that party leaders had dreaded, as Mr. Edwards and Mr. Wallwork work feverishly to close the advantage in the polls each acknowledges that Mrs. Whitman has.
That turned the debate in a ballroom at the Birchwood Manor here into open season on Mrs. Whitman, who responded in kind.
The event was televised live over New Jersey Network, the state-supported public television network, which was co-sponsor of the debate along with the State Chamber of Commerce. It was the first of two mandatory and televised debates involving candidates who receive public campaign financing.
 
Florio Tax Increase
 One of the few points that the Republicans agreed on tonight was dislike of the Florio tax increase, one of the most contentious issues in New Jersey political history.
Mr. Florio has said he was forced to raise taxes after following the Republican administration of Thomas H. Kean and finding the state was nearly broke. But the Republicans here tonight blamed the increase for stagnating the state's economy and contributing to the 9.1 percent unemployment figure announced last week. Still, they quarreled over just what to do about the taxes.
Mr. Edwards proposed that the rollback should begin with the budget now under discussion for the 1994 fiscal year that begins on July 1.
Mrs. Whitman said her goal would be to repeal the Florio taxes.
 
Stinging Exchanges
 The debate guidelines, as announced before the debate by the moderator, Michael Aron, a political reporter for NJN, allowed the candidates to break into the others' comments.
That made for some stinging exchanges.
When Mr. Edwards said he would demand an elected auditor to help his shape his decision on budget cuts, Mr. Wallwork interjected that he would accomplish it with the gubernatorial line-item veto powers.
Mr. Wallwork was not able to expand on that thought before Mrs. Whitman pounced. "That is a traditional kind of response to the problems we have, add another layer of government," said Mrs. Whitman in response to Mr. Edwards. "We have all the tools we need right now, Cary, to do it."
"You don't know what you're talking about," Mr. Edwards shot back.
When the question of crime arose, Mrs. Whitman cut off the anticipated attack on her from Mr. Edwards, a former State Attorney General who has accused her of being soft on crime, by launching a surprise attack on his own record.
"If you look at the time when he was the chief law enforcement officer of the State of New Jersey, crime went up 9 percent," she said. That set off such a vigorous side argument that Mr. Wallwork had to play the mediator, laughing boisterously and patting Mr. Edwards on the knee to calm him down.
Just hours before the debate, Mr. Wallwork unveiled a new one-minute radio advertisement assailing Mrs. Whitman.
 
Accusations of Contradictions
 "While Whitman's campaign continues to stumble over bad, liberal economic policy, hidden tax returns and illegal alien scandals, Jim Wallwork's campaign is surging," said the radio spot, which is to begin airing this week.
Mr. Edwards also announced a $50,000 radio ad campaign on New Jersey, Philadelphia and New York City stations that attacks Mrs. Whitman.
"The radio ad campaign focuses on Christine Todd Whitman's hypocrisy, contradictions and flip-flops," said Jeffrey T. Michaels, campaign manager for Mr. Edwards.
"Her contradictions are not infrequent, isolated occurrences," Mr. Michaels said. "They have defined her entire candidacy. There are simply too many questions about her credibility for Republicans to trust her with the nomination for governor."
 
Whitman Confident of Lead
 Mrs. Whitman has at least a double-digit lead over either Mr. Wallwork, a businessman, and Mr. Edwards, a lawyer, according to their polls.
Confident of her lead, Mrs. Whitman's campaign has refused to respond to the barbs tossed out by her opponents as they try to sway the bloc of undecided, mostly conservative Republicans who are likely to control the outcome of the June 8 primary.
Instead, she has spent the four months since making her official announcement speaking to Republican groups, generally avoiding reporters and issuing policy papers on subjects from education to crime.
Republican leaders fear that if the primary season turns into a slugfest, their eventual nominee will head out damaged to do battle with the unpopular but still politically tough Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat who is seeking a second term.

HEADLINE: FIRST LADY SPEAKS TO WEST VIRGINIANS

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., May 11

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a preview of the health-care campaign on television tonight, assuring West Virginians with an array of health-insurance problems that their concerns would be met when the Clinton Administration unveiled its proposals next month.
In a statewide town meeting conducted by satellite, Mrs. Clinton and one of the state's Democratic Senators, John D. Rockefeller 4th, quizzed a series of carefully selected West Virginians who typified the problems of the uninsured, of small businesses struggling to afford insurance and of hospitals and other providers trying to give care without reimbursement. 
 The theme that ran throughout the one-hour program, which was broadcast statewide and in parts of Pennsylvania and Kentucky, was that a crisis exists in the status quo and what Mrs. Clinton described as the "cost of doing nothing, of throwing up our hands and saying, Gosh, I don't think we can tackle something that complex."
 
No Mention of Taxes
 Mrs. Clinton, chairwoman of the task force on health care, did not address the costs of the changes believed to be favored by her planners, nor the various tax increases that are expected to be necessary. None of the West Virginians selected to appear, who ranged from an injured coal-industry worker to the head of the state Chamber of Commerce, touched these issues. The session was opened by Senator Rockefeller, long active on health care, and organized by West Virginia University, on whose campus it was held.
Despite the lack of fireworks, the session did give a glimpse of Mrs. Clinton's early sales pitch for a plan still in development. When the head of a small business talked of the difficulties in providing health insurance for his workers, Mrs. Clinton launched into an impassioned explanation of the complicated concept at the heart of the Clinton plan, the health-insurance purchasing cooperative.
"You'll be part of great big pools to buy insurance, and you'll get all the breaks and all the discounts that the big guys are entitled to," Mrs. Clinton told the businessman. "And people will not be denied insurance coverage because of their age or their pre-existing conditions. They'll be eligible for reasonably priced insurance because they're Americans."
At another point, Mrs. Clinton vowed that the Clinton plan would "streamline reimbursement, eliminate all these forms." And she also promised that the Administration would "measure everything we propose against the standard, what does it mean for patient care."
 
A State of Hard Times
 For all the choreography, there were several poignant moments that captured the toll of rising health-care costs in a state where unemployment stands at more than 11 percent, highest in the nation. Vicki McClung, whose husband is unemployed, talked of the worries of raising four children without health insurance and how she yearned to be able to give her children good preventive care.
"The way it stands right now, the ones on welfare are the ones who get to go and get their kids checked," she said.

HEADLINE: Panel Eases Employers' Tax on Domestic Workers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The House Ways and Means Committee today kicked off the prickly task of writing President Clinton's economic program into law by giving some taxpayers a break: it voted to raise sharply, to $1,750 a year, the $50-a-quarter threshold that an employer can pay a domestic worker before becoming liable for Social Security taxes.
That was a belated bow to Zoe Baird, the Connecticut lawyer whom Mr. Clinton dropped as his choice for Attorney General after it was found that she had failed to pay taxes on the earnings of her chauffeur and nanny. The Internal Revenue Service says the changes approved today, if enacted, would benefit far more than the rich, affecting three million or more Americans who hire cooks, maids, sitters, gardeners and other household help. 
 It was, nevertheless, a thimbleful of sugar in what promises to be an ocean of medicine. By the time the panel finishes drafting Mr. Clinton's program into bill form, probably late this week, it will almost certainly have approved plans for some $300 billion in new or higher taxes on income, energy and business earnings
The domestic-worker rule, and the approval later of plans to spend more on child welfare, were the notable achievements of a day spent mostly on rote work and political labors.
 
'Supportive of the President'
 The panel's chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, spent most of the afternoon with his committee's 23 Democrats, lining up support for the more dicey tax measures that he must steer past the Republican minority later in the week. The 14 Republicans, who will have virtually no say in the outcome, spent the afternoon plotting ways to frustrate him.
After the Democrats had met for several hours, Mr. Rostenkowski said, "To an individual, they want to be supportive of the President."
Other Democrats said that the essence of the Clinton tax plan -- higher tax rates on the wealthy, a new tax on fuel, taxes on more of the Social Security benefits of middle- and upper-income retirees and a big expansion of tax credits for the working poor -- would be approved. But they said some changes would be made on the edges.
The biggest debates, they said, were over how to reallocate the $30 billion that Mr. Clinton originally wanted for an investment tax credit to business and how to devise the fuel tax proposal in a way that would generate the most political support.
 
Corporate Tax Rate Question
 Mr. Rostenkowski said he would like to keep the corporate tax rate at no higher than 35 percent, but was not certain that could be accomplished. The rate is now 34 percent, and Mr. Clinton wants it raised to 36 percent.
Although the panel is working mostly on tax-code changes, lawmakers devoted most of their time today to a grab-bag of economic and trade issues that are also in the bill. Among the actions the panel took were these:
*It approved an Administration initiative to reduce the flood of children into foster homes by spending more to counsel troubled families and end child neglect and abuse. The $1.5 billion program is offset in part by $1.3 billion in spending cuts in other programs.
*It agreed to postpone for a year the effective date of a law passed under President Ronald Reagan that would require states to find jobs or job training for tens of thousands of married welfare recipients. The Clinton Administration had asked for a two-year postponement, contending that the welfare rolls would be pared more effectively if programs concentrated on finding jobs for single mothers.
*It adopted an amendment by Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, that would extend through 1998 a trial program in New York State that tries to keep families off welfare by increasing child-support collections.
 
Simplifying the Process
 The action today on domestic workers, if enacted, promises to vastly simplify the process of paying all taxes, state and Federal, on the household help now employed by at least three million American families.
The current law requires employers to pay Social Security taxes on any domestic worker who is paid more than $50 in a three-month period, a figure that has not been adjusted since the law was passed in 1950. Critics say that under the law as it stands, millions of taxpayers should file quarterly returns to cover taxes on teen-agers who mow their lawns or baby-sit.
The Internal Revenue Service says that 733,000 employers do file such quarterly returns on their household workers, but that about 2.2 million other employers are ignoring the law.
The changes adopted by the Ways and Means Committee, on a voice vote, raise the $50-a-quarter threshold to $1,750 a year this year and $1,800 in 1994, with adjustments for inflation thereafter. Employers paying less than that would not be required to pay any Social Security taxes on their workers.
The $1,750 figure, aides said, roughly accounts for the effect of inflation in the 43 years since the law was passed. In a gesture to employers who have avoided the tax and are either caught or decide to make amends, the committee voted to apply the threshold retroactively, adjusted for inflation, back to 1950.
While the changes benefit employers, they are potentially less helpful to the domestic workers themselves, who could find it harder to gain eligibility for Social Security or could see their retirement benefits reduced.
Under the law, workers receive credit for three months worked every time they earn $560, up to four times a year. The law requires at least 40 such quarters over a life's work before a worker can become eligible for retirement or disability benefits.
Under the new reporting requirements, the I.R.S. estimates, 16 percent of the nation's domestics would lose at least one quarter of earnings credit because they fall beneath the new reporting threshold.
Other amendments adopted today could wipe out much of the paperwork for employers, who now must pay Social Security and state and Federal unemployment taxes each quarter.
The changes would permit employers to pay Social Security obligations on household help each April 15, as part of their annual 1040 tax filing, and to avoid paying a lump sum by having the taxes deducted from their paychecks. It would allow the same arrangement for paying Federal unemployment taxes, which are required for any domestic earning more than $1,000 a quarter.

HEADLINE: Dow, in Closing Surge, Ends 25.47 Higher

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In a reversal of Monday's trading, the stock market languished in near-torpor for most of yesterday's session but surged strongly in the last half- hour.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had climbed as much as 26 points late in the day, closed up 25.47 points, to 3,468.75. All other major indexes were up in relatively moderate trading. 
 Yesterday's Treasury auction of $16 billion in three-year notes -- the first of three big Treasury sales this week -- provided investors with an excuse to take a wait-and-see attitude, analysts said, and accounted for the relatively tranquil trading in the morning and early afternoon.
But when results of the sales after 1 P.M. showed interest rates at the auction were at the expected low range, traders were encouraged to look again at stocks for investments. Computerized buy programs helped accelerate the stock rally in the last few minutes of the session.
The two remaining Treasury auctions, for longer-term securities, are considered more significant by analysts for their possible effect on the stock market.
Gold prices, closely watched in recent days, drifted upward yesterday but most gold stocks were down or up only modestly. Newmont Mining, which helped spark investor interest in gold last month, closed down 1/8, to 47 3/4. A Financial Times report said that Sir James Goldsmith had sold a 9.5 percent stake.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index closed up 0.85 point, to 245.88, and trading volume totaled 221.6 million shares, compared with 235.6 million shares Monday. Winning stocks on the Big Board outnumbered decliners, 1,053 to 856.
The Standard & Poor's 500 was up 1.56 point, to 444.36 and the Nasdaq composite index was up 0.24 point, to 683.06. The American Stock Exchange market value index was up 0.56 point, to 427.25.
For the most part, stock watchers saw nothing new in the market's activity yesterday. Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers Inc. said, "It's striking that we've had a long string of relatively high-volume, 200-million-plus shares a day, and no real price movement for much of the session for each of those days."
He added, "The market is basically waiting for some breakout -- the economy catching fire, which would spark a major rally, or interest rates dropping sharply, which would scare the market because that would mean the economy was dropping sharply, too."
The Dow Jones transportation average, volatile for weeks now, closed up 0.61 point, to 1,570.48. The average was lifted by Federal Express , up 1 1/8, to 49 1/8, on no discernible news, and Consolidated Railroad, up 7/8, to 52 3/8, on upbeat analyst comments on the rail industry.
The Dow was mainly lifted by seven stocks that gained 1 point or more. These stocks lifted the blue-chip index by nearly 19 points of the 25-point rise. The stocks were led by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and J .P. Morgan. 3M was up 1 7/8, to 114 1/8, on upbeat comments by the chairman at the annual meeting. J. P. Morgan was up 1 1/4, to 68 3/8, on no discernible news.
The two most active stocks on the Big Board were tobacco stocks. The industry leader Philip Morris was down 1 1/4, to 51 1/2, and No. 2 RJR Nabisco was up 1/4, to 6, on news of price increases for some Philip Morris deep-discount cigarettes. Analysts say the price changes indicated no backing away from an expected price war.
Also noteworthy were the semiconductor stocks, which declined, especially Intel, which was down 3 points, to 99 1/2. An industry group reported that demand for semiconductors eased in April.

HEADLINE: U.S. SET TO CHANGE ABORTION POLICIES

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 11

 BODY:
Declaring that it wanted to help lead a new global effort to address the issue of overpopulation, the Clinton Administration said today that efforts to stabilize world population growth must concentrate on providing more opportunities and rights for women, including abortions.
In a speech to a United Nations committee that is planning a major conference on population in Cairo next year, Timothy E. Wirth, the State Department Counselor, said the Administration intended to reverse policies on population growth that had been adopted under Presidents Reagan and Bush. 
 Under the two Republican Presidents the United States refused to finance international population programs that provided women with counseling on abortion. In addition, in Mr. Reagan's term, the United States took the position that population growth was a "neutral phenomenon" -- neither harmful nor beneficial to the environment -- and that the important issue was economic development.
 
A Question of Choice
 In a previous United Nations population conference held in 1974 in Bucharest, Romania, and in 1984 in Mexico City, the issue of abortion was played down. Some population experts say that out of deference to Catholic countries and some Muslim nations, they do not expect next year's gathering to approve a strongly worded statement asserting a woman's right to an abortion. Still Mr. Wirth said the United States would push for it.
"The U.S. Government would be remiss if it did not develop recommendations and guidance with regard to abortion," Mr. Wirth said. "Our position is to support reproductive choice, including access to safe abortion."
Population experts say about 125,000 women die each year -- about one-fourth of all maternal deaths -- as a result of improperly performed abortions. Almost all of these deaths occur in developing countries.
In outlining Administration policy for the first time in a forum devoted to population issues, Mr. Wirth made clear how dramatic a change the Clinton Administration was making in the area of population stabilization.
 
President 'Deeply Committed'
 "President Clinton is deeply committed to moving population to the forefront of America's international priorities," Mr. Wirth said. "He understands the cost of excessive population growth to the health of women, to the natural environment and to our hopes for alleviating poverty. He believes that America cannot stand aside as the world confronts one of the largest challenges of this century and the next."
Mr. Wirth also put the Clinton Administration on record endorsing other ideas in the population and development field that were anathama to the Reagan and Bush Administrations, like agreeing with developing countries that that Western nations should limit their consumption.
For the first time, Mr. Wirth officially confirmed that the Administration would resume financing for the United Nations Population Fund. Congress cut off funds to the organization after reports that it financed family planning efforts in China that entailed coercive abortions and forced sterilization.
The American official did not say how much the Administration would seek for the United Nations Population Fund, though he did mention that the Administration has asked for a $100 million increase for population programs in the Federal budget for the year ending Sept. 30, 1994.
 
A Tumultuous Response
 Mr. Wirth's speech received a tumultuous response from some of the delegations, and from many of the representatives of non-governmental organizations -- women's groups, and environmental and population specialists -- who listened from the gallery as he addressed the delegations to the Preparatory Committee. "As one of those who had to struggle within the old U.S. policy it is like a breath of fresh air," Fred Sai of Ghana, chairman of the Preparatory Committee, said.
But anti-abortion groups, denounced the Administration's reversal of American policy. "It's outrageous, in a word," said Representative Chris Smith, a New Jersey Republican who heads the Congressional Pro-Life Caucus. "The U.N. Population Plan of Action of 1984 that was adopted in Mexico City made it very clear that abortion was not to be construed as a method of family planning."
 
Public Financing Weighed
 Published reports have said Mr. Clinton is considering public financing of abortions as part of his health care package. The Administration has overturned the Reagan Administration's policy that barred United States funds from international population groups involved in providing women with information on abortions.
Archbishop Renato R. Martino, the head of the delegation from the Vatican, declined to comment on the American delegate's speech.
The representatives of the nongovernmental organizations who generally occupy the liberal end of the political spectrum and who opposed the Reagan-Bush policies, erupted into applause at the end of Mr. Wirth's address, a marked contrast to the polite silence that often greeted the remarks by delegates from other countries.
After the speech some women in the gallery punched their fists into the air, and some wept.

HEADLINE: Business Schools Hit Hard Times Amid Doubt Over Value of M.B.A.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
After two decades of growth so robust that they could just sit back and welcome waves of students year after year, the nation's business schools have hit hard times as more students wonder whether an M.B.A. is worth the time and expense.
Over the 1980's, the number of masters' degrees in business administration awarded at the nation's 680 business schools grew about 15 percent. Then came the recession and the much-publicized shrinking of corporate payrolls. 
 Since 1990, the number of M.B.A.'s has slipped about 3 percent, to 75,000, and no one expects an increase anytime soon. The number of students taking the Graduate Management Admission Test, the standard business-school entrance exam, has fallen even more sharply -- 6 percent from 1991 to 1992, with a steeper decline expected this year.
"There's a growing realization that an M.B.A. is not a ticket to the gravy train," said Charles Hickman, director of projects and services for the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business in St. Louis, which accredits graduate schools of business. "Having said that, I'm not ready to write the obituary for M.B.A.'s. But the good times are over."
 
Growth at Other Schools
 The fortunes of business schools contrast sharply with those of other graduate and professional schools. Although current figures have not yet been compiled, experts who track enrollment patterns say more students are staying in school to wait out the aftereffects of the recession. Among the major fields of study, only law schools are showing a similar decline in enrollment, although not as pronounced as business schools'.
The signs of shrinking interest are everywhere, from Stanford to the University of Texas to Gannon University in Erie, Pa. Of a dozen business schools sampled, only Harvard's showed a substantial increase in applications, to 5,930 for the 1993-94 academic year from 5,714 this year.
At Duke University, the admissions office says it expects applications to drop this year to 2,100 or 2,200, off from last year's total of 2,300. At the University of Texas, applications slipped by 17 this year, remaining in the low 3,000 range. And at the University of Michigan, applications have tumbled to 2,700 this spring from 2,899 a year ago.
Business schools are trying an array of new tactics to counter this trend. Texas, for example, established a 24-hour toll-free telephone line this year for prospective students. At Kent State University in Ohio, the business school hired a marketing firm for the first time to produce a glossy brochure promoting its business school.
 
Reaching Out to People
 "This is unheard of," said Richard E. Brown, assistant dean for graduate education at Kent State's Graduate School of Management. "Used to be, we'd sit around and let the good students come in. Now you have to identify niches and let people know what you can do for them."
And Mr. Hickman, of the business school accreditation organization, warns that those who fail to adjust to leaner times could find themselves out of business. "It's not going to happen this year," he said. "But it won't take too many years of seeing reductions of 10 percent or so before we begin to see some schools close."
It was not always this way. For years, the "B-school" could do little wrong, as colleges and universities watched applications and enrollments in business schools increase at a healthy clip.
Even small players like Gannon University established M.B.A. programs 20 years ago to reap the rich harvest of tuition dollars. The number of M.B.A. programs surged to its current level of 680, almost double the 389 institutions offering M.B.A.'s in 1974.
 
Wall Street Wealth Cited
 The Wall Street boom in the 1980's only quickened the growth. The halcyon years of American business lured students like Jeff McGee, who attended Dartmouth College's business school from 1987 to 1989, when the nation's business climate began to sour.
"There was so much wealth on Wall Street in the 80's, it just sucked people in," said Mr. McGee, 32, who now works in finance for a New York City consumer products concern. "It's been a rough couple of years, but I think for me it's really beginning to kick in. My credentials really helped."
Now students like Tracy Ott, a 24-year-old marketing consultant in New York City, are posing questions that a decade ago would have sounded like heresy.
"There is a question of whether going to business school is a good investment," said Ms. Ott, who is deciding whether to go full time to New York University's business school, where she is now a part-time student. "The big question I have is, are M.B.A.'s really teaching what students need for the 90's?"
By and large, the answer is yes -- but only because corporations are demanding better trained students from business schools, which are scrambling to reconfigure curriculums from general business courses to more specialties and electives. But the updating of curriculums also reflects an effort by schools to distinguish themselves from competitors.
The University of South Carolina, for example, has transformed its business school into one of the top three in the nation in international business, Mr. Hickman said.
The same can be said for the University of Tennessee, whose business school has carved out a niche in the area of personnel management. And as demand for an M.B.A. wanes, even universities like Harvard and Columbia are beginning to realize that they cannot passively trade on their names anymore.
Harvard, for example, is recruiting more aggressively in Miami and San Juan, P.R., to increase its Hispanic enrollment. At Columbia, recruiting swings now include trips to Hong Kong and cities in Japan. The curriculum has been revamped to emphasize international affairs, and the school now admits students three times a year to its program. Blurring the traditional academic year, which few other major business schools have done, has helped encourage more applications.
"In today's marketplace, you have to have a sense of focus and you have to have unique advantages," said Ethan Hanabury, the assistant dean of admissions at Columbia's business school. "We're trying to put our best foot forward."
Colleges and universities that do not have Ivy League appeal go to even greater lengths to attract students to their business schools.
At Kent State, business school officials and students wrote letters and telephoned Julie Valentine two years ago in an effort to persuade her to attend the university. Ms. Valentine, now 24, had just completed her undergraduate degree at Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C., when she applied to and was accepted by Kent State, Rutgers University and Clark Atlanta University.
Kent State's personal touch ultimately won.
"Kent was much more aggressive than the other institutions," said Ms. Valentine, who is completing an M.B.A. in finance. "Whenever I called, they recognized my name and they knew who I was. They'd say: 'Oh, Julie, hi. How are you?' They remembered little things about me, and that didn't stop once I arrived."
 
Geared to Local Workers
 For business schools at little-known institutions like Gannon, the future looks more foreboding. The program is entirely part time, and enrollment is heavily geared to local workers whose companies pay tuition.
The university now has 900 students in its business school, down from the 1,000 a decade ago. But Betty Jo Licata, the business school dean, sounding as optimistic as other business school deans, says she is not worried about national trends.
"Unlike Harvard or Northwestern, we serve local interests," she said, adding that layoffs at local companies affect enrollment significantly. "I'm more concerned about our local economy."
Like many places in the United States, the economy has not been purring in Erie. So Gannon expanded its recruiting trips this year, not to foreign cities or even to major American cities, but to a company just three blocks from its campus.
"Instead of expecting people to come to us," Dean Licata said, "we're going to them."
At a cost of $7,000 to $10,000 a year in tuition alone for a typical two-year M.B.A. program at a state university like Texas, to nearly $20,000 in tuition at institutions like Harvard, the cost has remained relatively stable despite the heated competition for students, business school officials at colleges and universities say.
But the return on that investment seems to be diminishing. Business school placement offices say their job is getting much tougher. In a meeting last summer of job placement officials at the 40 largest M.B.A. programs, most officials said job offers and salaries in the $50,000-a-year range to students who graduate from the programs were holding steady.
But Mr. Hickman, of the business school accreditation group, said: "It is apparent that the rules for career services and placement are changing. Schools and graduates are going to have to work a lot harder to place students."

HEADLINE: Factory Raid Nets 45 Arrests and a Million T-Shirts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
As part of a drive against illegal street vending, the Dinkins administration announced yesterday that the police had arrested 45 people and seized more than a million imitation designer T-shirts from manufacturing operations housed in a Manhattan building.
Police officials said they believed it was the largest such T-shirt counterfeiting operation in the city. 
 Yesterday's action was the latest move in an effort by City Hall to pacify small-business owners, who have complained bitterly about the proliferation of street vendors who operate illegally. The presence of an estimated 10,000 illegal vendors in the city has become a heated political and economic issue, as some major streets have become congested with street merchants.
At a City Hall news conference, Mayor David N. Dinkins made the announcement while standing next to a large table filled with colorful, illegally manufactured T-shirts bearing the logos of companies like Champion, Nike and Guess and sports teams like the New York Knicks. Standing with Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and Wallace Ford, Commissioner of the city's Department of Business Services, the Mayor said the city would step up its efforts against illegally produced goods.
"We had envisioned from the outset that our enforcement efforts under this program would include measures directed against the organized illegal suppliers of street vendors," Mr. Dinkins said. "Selling illegal merchandise on our city's streets cannot be sanctioned and will not be tolerated."
Yesterday's arrests and confiscation involved an operation on four floors of a commercial building at 1165 Broadway, at West 27th Street, police officials said. The Mayor said the action came after a monthlong investigation. Search warrants were issued by a State Supreme Court Judge, and another judge signed an order of attachment for the operation, the first step in forfeiture proceedings.
The five-story building housed 38 manufacturers of the shirts operating in close quarters, police inspectors said. They added that the operations employed about 100 workers.
 
'Target Wholesalers'
 Police officials said they had confiscated two tractor-trailer loads of clothing manufactured at the Broadway operation that illegally used trademarked labels. But they said they had not assessed the street value of the merchandise.
"We will continue to target wholesalers of counterfeit merchandise in order to protect consumers," Mr. Dinkins said, adding that he intended to send a message to vendors that "our city's business environment does not include the sale of illegal merchandise."
The police said that only managers had been arrested, not laborers. The managers were charged with possession of and offering for sale counterfeit goods with a value in excess of $1,000.
Just a month ago Mr. Dinkins said the city would intensify its efforts to crack down on illegal vendors by assigning 36 additional police officers to the 46-member peddler enforcement unit and by deploying 31 more city inspectors. The Mayor's efforts come in an election year in which Mr. Dinkins has undertaken several initiatives aimed at gaining the support of small business owners.
Mr. Ford, who along with Commissioner Kelly heads the Mayor's month-old Vendor Policy Group, estimated that illegal vendors deprive the city of about $300 million annually in sales taxes.

Detectives Robert Baymert, left, and John Huvane examined some of the confiscated items. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Hartford, The Budget Is Passed And Signed

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 11

 BODY:
The Connecticut General Assembly, after stumbling last week in its effort to pass a budget a month ahead of the deadline, gave final approval today to an $8.58 billion spending plan for the year that begins July 1.
The budget, which was immediately signed into law by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., restores most of the cuts in welfare and other social programs that Mr. Weicker proposed earlier this year, and does so without major tax increases, because existing taxes are generating more revenue than expected. 
 "It's a good budget," Mr. Weicker said in a brief signing ceremony in his office just after 5 P.M. He then bent down to sign the document and said, "Done."
"And it's daylight out," said House Speaker Thomas D. Ritter, a Hartford Democrat.
 
Democrats' Muted Joy
 For the Democrats, who control both chambers of the General Assembly, however, the joy at avoiding the last-day-of-the-session frenzy was clearly muted. Leaders had hoped to have the budget wrapped up last week, a month before the June 9 adjournment, only to see the momentum halted in the Senate when state labor union leaders objected to a provision that would have eliminated automatic pay raises for many state employees.
The Senate amended the offending article, voting to phase out the automatic raises beginning next Jan. 1, and it was that amended budget that the House passed today on a largely party-line vote, 87 to 62.
But the give-and-take with the unions, in addition to stalling the budget, gave the Republicans a target that could not be resisted: Labor had said jump, the Republicans said over and over again in the three-and-a-half-hour debate, and the Democrats had responded, How high?
 
'I'm Embarrassed'
 "I'm embarrassed, everyone should be embarrassed," said Representative Andrew McCall Norton, a Colchester Republican. "The public sees a General Assembly that seems to be in control of a special interest."
"The word I've heard is unconscionable," said Representative Claudia Powers, a Republican from Greenwich.
Democrats, in response, noted that the labor unions were unhappy with the compromise worked out in the Senate and were lobbying today to try to scuttle the budget in the House. The Republicans, in voting no on the budget, were thus the real supporters of labor's position, the Democrats said.
"I'm not embarrassed," said Representative Michael J. Jarjura, a Democrat from Waterbury. "I'm shocked and dismayed at what I hear coming from the other side of the aisle."
 
Little Pain, Some Gain
 People in both parties said that the major reason for an early finish for the budget was that it did not involve great pain or sacrifice. Mr. Weicker said in February that balancing the budget this year, as the recession continued, would mean $180 million in new and higher taxes and deep spending cuts for things like welfare and medical prescription subsidies for the elderly.
Governor Weicker suggested, for example, that any person on general-assistance welfare considered employable by state examiners be evicted from the program, which would have thrown an estimated 22,000 people off the welfare rolls on July 1. The new budget maintains Mr. Weicker's two-tier system of employable and nonemployable needy and cuts the benefits of the employables from the current $314 a month to $300. But no one will be excluded.
Mr. Weicker had also proposed creating an assets test in giving prescription aid to the elderly, narrowing the program to the poor, a proposal that provoked howls from advocates for the aged. Almost all the proposed $14 million in cuts proposed by the Governor were restored, with no questions about assets.
 
The New 2-Year Plan
 The budget was the first one prepared under a rolling two-year budget law passed last year. It provides for a $9 billion budget for the year that begins July 1, 1994, but the goal is mainly to provide a spending and tax target for the next legislative session, since the 1994 budget will have to be passed all over again as part of next year's two-year plan.
Republicans, who proposed spending cuts of $161 million in an amendment on the floor -- an amendment rejected on a party-line vote -- tweaked the Democrats one last time in the final moments of the debate. If the budget had been passed on its original timetable last week, they said, the Democrats would have passed the earliest budget in recent memory. The delay, however, keeps that distinction with the Republicans, who passed a budget on May 9, 1985, when they were in the majority, said the House minority leader, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol.

HEADLINE: Traffic Alert

 BODY:
Because of President Clinton's visit to New York City today, the city's Transportation Department is urging motorists not to drive into Manhattan between 2 and 9 P.M.
The President will fly into Newark International Airport and will arrive in lower Manhattan at 2 P.M. 
 His motorcade will proceed to Cooper Union, at 5 Astor Place, where he is to give an economic address.
Major delays are expected along his route and on surrounding local streets, and drivers are advised to avoid the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, though the authorities did not provide details of the route for security reasons.
The President is to leave Cooper Union about 4 P.M., heading north to Lincoln Center. He will leave Lincoln Center some time after 9 P.M., heading downtown.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
U.N. of Pit Crews Revs For Old Brooklyn Poly

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
REMEMBER the 1969 Mets, Harry S. Truman in 1948, David? Well, slingshot, longshot and underdog fans, meet the car racing team from Brooklyn Polytechnic University.
Brooklyn Polytechnic is a no-frills school. It does not have dormitories or a gymnasium and few of the 4,000 students seem to know that the school's nickname is the Blue Jays. The students, many of them foreign born or the children of immigrants, come to the downtown Brooklyn buildings, study hard, become engineers and get good jobs. There is not much rah-rah. 
 But now, Brooklyn Poly has a student-built, scaled-down Formula One racing car ready to compete against entries from better-heeled schools in the Society of Automotive Engineers competition to be held near Detroit at the end of May. Building such a car is an expensive and time-consuming undertaking, and for Brooklyn Poly it has been a little like having the Dead End Kids preparing for a fox hunt.
"You have to realize that Brooklyn Polytechnical is a very tough school," said Minh Duong, a 19-year-old sophomore who is the elected president of the car building group. "Nobody lives on campus. All of us commute. Most of us have to work at jobs in addition to our course work."
"There's not much room for social life," Mr. Duong said. "For the last year this has been our social life," he said, gesturing to the 10-foot-long tubular car in the center of a basement workshop. "Many nights we've slept here."
As Mr. Duong spoke, Andres Matias, also 19, was taking off the car's front wheels. "We have to do it so that we can get it through the doors into the parking lot," said Mr. Matias, who was to be the first driver on the first test run. Meanwhile, the car's other builders were drifting in: James Wong, who was originally from Malaysia; Miguel Pires from Portugal; Meijiao Sara Chen from China. Mr. Matias was born and finished high school in Puerto Rico while Mr. Duong came to New York 11 years ago from Vietnam along with his parents, two older sisters and a younger brother. Of the basic core group only Stacy Genovese from Howard Beach has a car of her own.
"We've had people from all over working together," said Mr. Matias, "Pakistan, the Caribbean, the Middle East. We've had men, women, about 40 people altogether, though only about 15 worked on it regularly."
Four of the students were struggling to wiggle the 400-pound car past the door frames. Dominick Rivera, a powerful sophomore, was holding up the front end as Mark Rodrigues angled the back through the opening. Then they wheeled it onto an elevator and down to a loading dock. There, in an efficient application of the physics of simple machines, they hooked the car onto a hydraulic crane and lowered it from the four-foot ledge.
"Our idea is to drive it in a way that will break things," said Mr. Matias.
"We want to anticipate what could go wrong," said Mr. Duong, adding that a year ago, when Brooklyn Polytechnical sent its first car to the competition, the team was left crushed by a faulty drive train.
"We had done real well in the first two days of technical inspections and tests," said Mr. Duong, who was there as a freshman. "We were up there holding our own with Cornell and R.P.I. -- but then, just before the key 70-mile time trials, the drive train broke. We didn't have spare parts or money to buy anything, and anyway it was a Sunday and everything was closed. It was pretty sad, but all we could do is watch the others."
This year, he predicted, will be different, largely because the group has received $25,000 from Roger Penske, the sponsor of a professional racing team who heads companies selling automotive products. The contribution more than doubled the meager funds that the students managed to come up with last year, though it reportedly still left them with less to work with than most of the competing schools. When a single racing tire costs $500 and it takes $6,000 to transport the car and its builders to Detroit for three days, even the new, more generous budget required careful economizing.
Now Mr. Matias, dressed in fireproof driver's suit and helmet, strapped himself into the car. He hit the ignition and the 600-cubic-centimeter Yamaha engine roared. Mr. Rodrigues tinkered with the carburetor until he got the right pitch. Mr. Matias put the car into the first of six forward gears. And then a cable on the clutch pedal snapped.
Mr. Duong used baling wire for temporary repairs. For the next four hours the students kept the engine going while they tinkered and gauged performance. They never got out of first gear. They spotted a tiny crack on the critical drive train that would have to be welded. No one seemed alarmed.
"No problem -- we'll be ready in Detroit," said Mr. Duong, hinting at an upset victory for Brooklyn Poly, poly as in polyglot.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Good Demand at Treasury Auction

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury's quarterly auction got off to a respectable start yesterday with the sale of $16 billion in three-year notes.
Traders said there was good demand at the auction, with buying by retail and institutional investors as well as bond dealers. Yields at the auction averaged 4.27 percent on the notes, the lowest since three-year notes were first regularly issued in 1978. 
 But some traders said they were still unsure about the outlook for the two other auctions this week, $10.75 billion of 10-year notes today and $8.25 billion of 30-year bonds tomorrow. And the inflation data to be released today and tomorrow could hold some surprises that would make these auctions more difficult.
 
 
Little Room for a Rally
 With the two auctions still overhanging the market and the inflation data to come, there was little room for a rally after the auction results came out in the early afternoon. So in late trading, prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed on the day. The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 104 with the yield at 6.81 percent.
In the when-issued, or pre-auction, market, the yield on the 10-year note for sale today was 5.88 percent, unchanged from Monday and the yield on the 30-year bond to be sold Thursday was also unchanged at 6.81 percent.
Daniel Callahan, the managing director in charge of Government trading at Paine Webber, said he expected the 10-year note auction to go well. He said that apparently many dealers had already sold 10-year notes to customers in anticipation of the sale and therefore would bid to get the new securities at the auction.
He also said the Treasury's decision last week to eliminate the 7-year note would send some buyers to the 10-year note as an alternative.
But he said the Government's reports on the Producer Price Index today and the Consumer Price index tomorrow would set the tone for the 30-year bond auction.
 
 
Surprises Possible
 Michael H. Strauss, the chief economist at Yamaichi International, said there could be some surprises in the inflation data, especially in the producer price report, that could cause trouble for the 10-year note and the 30-year bond auctions.
He said many analysts were expecting the inflation increase for April to be low because of price-cutting in the tobacco industry. But he said the tobacco price war could have less effect on inflation than the bond market expected.
He also suggested that inflation in April could be higher than expected as a result of higher food prices because of the bad weather in March and a jump in natural gas prices. He is forecasting a three-tenths to four-tenths of one percentage point increase in producer prices.
But he said that if the full effect of higher natural gas prices was reflected, the increase could be six-tenths of one percentage point. Such an increase would be disturbing to traders and investors, who have come to expect low and steady inflation.
The consensus forecast for the Producer Price Index among a broad group of economists is an increase of two-tenths of a percentage point, according to Bloomberg Business News.
Mr. Strauss is predicting that the Consumer Price Index will rise by about three-tenths of one percentage point, which is also higher than the consensus outlook for this index, which is two-tenths of one percentage point.
Along with the consumer prices report tomorrow, the Government will release the April report on retail sales, which fell 1 percent in March. If retail sales post a strong rebound, then any unexpected inflation increase will be even more worrisome for the bond market because a growing economy makes traders worry about rising prices.
At the three-year note auction yesterday, the signs that it went well included the performance after the auction was over. In late trading in the when-issued market, the yield on the new three-year note, which has a coupon of 4.25 percent, was at 4.24 percent, down from the average of 4.27 percent at the auction. This means there was good buying later in the day.
Mr. Callahan of Paine Webber said there was good demand for several reasons. One is that there are many portfolio managers with plenty of cash to invest. Another is that the three-year note with a yield of 4.24 percent is a safe place to put money at a time when the outlook for the economy and the future of President Clinton's economic program is mixed.
"Anyone who is confused would be happy to get a 4.25 percent yield until the picture is less cloudy," he said. The 10-year note and the 30-year bond are less attractive because their longer maturities makes their prices more volatile and more vulnerable to a quick shift in market sentiment.
Following are the results of yesterday's three-year note auction:
