HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Lower on Report Of Weak U.S. Retail Sales

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar slipped in thin trading yesterday after a private report showed weakness in American retail sales, dimming traders' hopes for upbeat news about the economy.
Gold prices edged up slightly in New York after slipping overseas. Gold for current delivery rose 10 cents, to $356.70 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. 
 A report by the Johnson Redbook Service said adjusted retail sales rose just three-tenths of 1 percent in the first week of May. That was far below the 1.2 percent rise that economists expect for April in a Government report scheduled for tomorrow.
 "The report was quite a big blow and is causing a bit of a panic," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at the NBD Bank.
 
 
Southeast Asian Buying
 Dealers were also disappointed at the dollar's stubborn refusal to move higher despite early rumors of speculative buying by a Southeast Asian central bank and other accounts.
 "The more the dollar doesn't go up, the more traders figure it should go down," Mr. Glowacki said. "The market has to move for traders to make money."
 The British pound rallied on a 300 million purchase in the Far East, dealers said. A 22 percent rise in British housing construction in the first quarter also improved sterling's outlook.
 The pound rose to $1.5421 in New York, from $1.5320 late Monday. Earlier in London, the pound traded at $1.5420, up from $1.5340 Monday. Meanwhile, the dollar fell to 1.6065 German marks in New York, from 1.6088 marks Monday.
The dollar also lost ground against the Japanese yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 111.34 yen in late dealings, down from 111.78 yen Monday. It closed in Tokyo at 111.35 yen, up from 110.27 yen late Monday.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Moody's Gives Junk Rating To $4.6 Billion of Delta Debt

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The rating on about $4.6 billion of long-term debt of Delta Air Lines was lowered to junk bond status yesterday by Moody's Investors Service Inc., which is concerned about the operating performance and cash flow of the No. 3 domestic airline.
"While Delta's proportionate share of international revenue to total revenues is not as large as other U.S. competitors," Moody's said, "Delta's international activities are heavily reliant on flying to Europe." 
 Moody's noted that the airline's European operations accounted for about 75 percent of its international business, which represented about 25 percent of the carrier's systemwide revenue.
The agency said it expected Delta's short-term profitability to suffer because of the weak economy in much of Europe. That will be especially true in Germany, where the airline's costly hub in Frankfurt is likely to have lower revenues over the intermediate term, though it has excellent long-term potential, Moody's added.
The rating agency lowered Delta's senior unsecured debt and industrial revenue bond rating to Ba-1 from Baa-3.
In March, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, another big debt rating agency, lowered to junk level the rating on $21.4 billion of debt owed by Delta; the UAL Corporation, owner of United Airlines, and the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines.
Over all, the long-term profitability of Delta heavily depends on the completion of big cost savings and fewer fare wars, Moody's said. But in Moody's view, both will be difficult in light of the continuing negotiations with the pilots' union and the highly competitive atmosphere among domestic and foreign airlines.

HEADLINE: 7 Deadly Sins of Living Linked To Illness as Well as Mortality

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
As if he were a medieval artist depicting the depravity of the seven deadly sins, Dr. Lester Breslow, a California public health specialist, has created a solemn portrait of self-destruction. The weapons are seven unwholesome habits he first identified more than a quarter-century ago.
By following the fates of nearly 7,000 adults living in California's Alameda County over three decades, he proved that the more of these poor health habits people practiced in 1965, the greater their chances were of dying within 10 years. 
 And now his latest study shows that even fewer people than thought escape the ravages of their health "sins." In a study conducted with his son Norman, a statistician at the University of Washington in Seattle, Dr. Breslow has shown that the unhealthy habits portend not only early death for many but chronic and costly disabilities for those who survive.
 
Predictors of Early Death
 Two of the poor health practices, as Dr. Breslow calls them, obesity and physical inactivity, are reminiscent of the ancient sins of gluttony and sloth. The others include both the predictable -- smoking and drinking too much alcohol, and the surprising -- sleeping too much or too little, eating between meals and skipping breakfast. Based on studies he and others did in the 1960's, Dr. Breslow singled out these seven things as likely to predict an early death.
His first Alameda County report revealed in 1972 that in combination these poor health practices could double a person's chance of dying prematurely. Now, in his latest paper, published in a recent issue of the journal Preventive Medicine, Dr. Breslow reports that even when the practices do not lead to an early death, they increase the risk that a person will suffer one or more physical or medical limitations that can degrade the later years of life.
Their study found that those Californians whose lives in 1965 were characterized by six or seven of the poor health practices were twice as likely to be disabled 10 or more years later as were their neighbors with no more than two of these habits.
Even without taking age or initial health status into account, among those with no poor health habits or just one, 12.2 percent were disabled, and for those with two or three poor health habits, 14.1 percent were disabled. In contrast, 18.7 percent of those with four or more poor health habits were disabled.
Dr. Jonathan Fielding, chairman of the board of the nonprofit California Wellness Foundation and chief health-policy planner for Johnson & Johnson, said Dr. Breslow's newest study was "critically important" at a time when the nation is trying to revamp its approach to health care.
"The results really say that how you live determines how long you will live without your state of health interfering with the things you want to do or forcing you to make changes in your life to accommodate your health problems," he said in a telephone interview.
 
Priorities Are Questioned
 The Breslows' findings underscore a theme that public health specialists have been promoting for decades to a nation that has listened with less than half an ear: preventive health practices are important not only in decreasing premature deaths but also in reducing costly debilitating illnesses. Dr. Breslow fears that current efforts to overhaul the health-care system put the cart before the horse by focusing on crisis medicine.
"It's a gross mistake to call what is being attempted now by the Clinton Administration health-care reform," Dr. Breslow said in a recent interview. "It is medical-care reform. To reform health care, we have to address how health can be maintained apart from medical services.
"There are indications that the Clinton Administration is aware of this, but the issue is not yet being tackled as an integral part of the reform effort."
Dr. Fielding said economic incentives for companies, health maintenance organizations and individuals would be needed to goad them into fostering and practicing preventive medicine.
Dr. Breslow, a professor emeritus at the School of Public Health of the University of California at Los Angeles, is perhaps his own best advertisement for the merits of disease prevention. Noting that he has avoided all seven of the poor health practices for most of his life, the 78-year-old researcher, who retired in 1980, said he worked "only eight days a week." He also swims, continues to eat sensibly and maintains a normal weight.
"With people of the United States now living typically into their 70's and 80's, the personal and social importance of maintaining health into the later years is mounting," the Breslows wrote. "People are increasingly concerned about how to avoid disability during their longer lives."
 
A Disturbing Trend
 But are people concerned enough to make changes in the living habits that undermine their chances of continued good health? And can young people be enticed to lead "cleaner" lives when the wages of their health sins may not be exacted until decades later?
According to the latest survey of American health practices, the decades-long trend toward healthier living habits has taken a turn for the worse. In December, Louis Harris & Associates polled 1,251 randomly selected adults in a survey by telephone conducted for Baxter International, a Michigan producer of health-care products and services. The survey included many of the same questions the Harris poll takers have been asking every year for a decade.
The 1992 survey showed that compared with the findings in 1991 or, say, 1983, more Americans were overweight and they were eating less carefully, exercising less and getting less sleep. Last year, 66 percent of Americans were found to be overweight, up from 63 percent in 1991 and 58 percent in 1983. Only 33 percent said they exercised vigorously three or more times a week, down from 37 percent the year before. Fewer of those questioned were "trying hard" to eat less cholesterol, fat and sodium and to eat more fiber than in 1991.
And, as an indication that their lives had become more stressful, last year only 50 percent of respondents said they got as much as seven to eight hours of sleep a night, down from 64 percent in 1983.
"These survey results represent disturbing trends in the nation's health behaviors," concluded Dr. James S. Todd, executive director of the American Medical Association, a traditionally conservative organization that has belatedly jumped on the preventive-medicine bandwagon.
But for some of the health practices Dr. Breslow has been studying, the survey findings were encouraging. Cigarette smoking, the nation's single most damaging and costly habit in terms of health, was practiced by only 24 percent of adult Americans, and 70 percent of them said they wanted to quit. In the 1960's, when Dr. Breslow began the Alameda study, half of Americans smoked regularly.
The survey also found a rise in the number of people who said they drank alcohol either moderately or not at all and a decline in the number who said they consumed more than three drinks on any given day.
In questioning Alameda County residents about how much they slept or whether they ate breakfast or ate between meals, Dr. Breslow said he did not mean to suggest that sleeping too much or too little, snacking and skipping breakfast were deadly habits in themselves on a par with smoking or excessive drinking. Rather, he said, "I believe these poor health practices are indicative of a chaotic life style" and that people who follow them are likely to pay inadequate attention to their overall well-being.
 
Unexpected Findings
 As the years passed, to the surprise of nearly all Dr. Breslow's colleagues, the study showed that snackers, breakfast skippers and people who slept more or less than seven to eight hours a night were more likely to die prematurely or to suffer life-limiting disabilities.
"Regularity in one's living habits seems to be important to health and longevity," Dr. Breslow said. He also urged health-care policy planners to recognize that "people do not choose their health habits in a vacuum; rather, they are strongly influenced by their social environment."
"We have to address the environmental and social influences on people's health practices, influences like cigarette advertising and the ease with which teenagers can buy cigarettes," he said.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Bonuses Planned For U.S. Medalists

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
The United States Olympic Committee is planning to offer bonuses of $15,000, and possibly more, to most American athletes who win gold medals at the next winter and summer Olympic Games.
The plan was formulated by the Athletes Support Committee and is due to be approved at the U.S.O.C. board of directors meetings on June 5 and 6. According to the four-year, $7.6 million plan, silver medalists will receive $10,000, bronze medalists $7,500, and fourth-place finishers $5,000. 
 In addition, American athletes will receive up to $5,000 for winning major international competitions, such as world championships, in non-Olympic years.
"For some, this will strictly be a reward," said Carol Brown, chairman of the support committee. "For others, who have borrowed money for their training efforts, they will have a chance at reimbursement against the loans they have."
The new bonuses are based on projections that American athletes will win 19 medals (6 gold, 6 silver and 7 bronze) at the 1994 Winter Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway, and 184 medals (90 gold, 41 silver, and 53 bronze) at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.
If, as the Olympics approach, it appears that these projections are too optimistic, the U.S.O.C. might increase the bonuses for each medal, Brown said.
The Athletes Support Committee has until the June meetings to come up with a special plan regarding athletes who earn large salaries within their own sport. The U.S.O.C. is wary of the perception that rich tennis or basketball players will receive bonus money, and the support committee has recommended that the bonuses for these players should go to the national governing body of the respective sports for youth development.
"National Basketball Association players have given more to our organization than we've ever given them," said Harvey Schiller, executive director of the U.S.O.C. Schiller, who calls the new bonuses "an extension" of the existing support system called Operation Gold, said that Magic Johnson recently donated a $10,000 international award that he received to youth development in basketball.
Several track-and-field stars have been calling for a similar, separate prize-money system for the world championships from the International Amateur Athletic Federation.
"Nobody's going to get rich here," Brown said. "But our athletes need more support than in the past. This system is easy to administer, it's objective, and it's incentive-based."

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Where's the Pork?

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
To Bill Clinton
Re: The Economy
Well, Mr. President, it's time to go back to the future. 
 Good idea, reconnecting with just plain folks in Ohio and Illinois over the last few days. But you've got to go farther than that to get back to where you once belonged.
Go back to the days before Secret Service agents stuck to you like pilot fish to a shark, before you sat in the back seat of a car you didn't drive, before your life was filled with Rhodes scholars and movie stars.
Go back to the supermarket. Push a cart around and take a look at the difference between how those people you talked to in the Midwest are running their economies and the way they think you're running ours, a difference that has caused a rift between you and them.
Go back to February, when you managed with some eloquence to convince them that they had to join you in busting the deficit and that it would require pain all around.
They knew what that was like because they've done deficit-busting themselves. Times aren't what they were, and after putting the bread, the milk, the chicken and the toilet paper in the cart they know the sad truth: There is no more room, wallet-wise, for the Sara Lee cheesecake, the peaches and the dearer cuts of meat. The steaks, the veal and the pork.
You won so many of those people over with your economic speech. You persuaded them to be part of doing the right thing for the future.
But not the whole thing.
They've watched you go shopping for 100 days now and they haven't seen you make those hard choices. Instead they've figured out that taxes are going to pay for this deficit reduction. Instead you've used your political capital on a stimulus package, full of a nice this and a pleasant that, the equivalent of those coupons that save you a quarter on a new cereal you wouldn't normally buy.
There was a catch to your share-the-pain scenario, and now you're caught in it. You had to decide on broad and significant spending cuts. You had to ditch Federal departments and consolidate like crazy in grossly inflated bureaucracies.
You had to make another eloquent speech and show the public how you intended to spread the sacrifice around, to Democratic and Republican pet programs alike. When your people talked about $2 in cuts for every $1 in new taxes, it sounded fair. When the ratio became 1 to 1, you lost half your credibility.
You had to throw the pork out of the shopping cart. Some of that would surely make people mad. But at least when you went on trips like the one you took this week, you'd have something substantive to say. Grousing about Washington lobbyists gets old real fast. You don't want to start sounding like your predecessor on his peevish days.
People say the problem is that you've lost your focus, that you've got too many things on your mind. You don't get enough credit for having a mind big enough to have too many things on. After all, Ronald Reagan knew as much about public policy as he did about method acting. Other people focused for him.
You've done the right thing on social policy issues. You signed the family leave bill and overturned the gag rule and the ban on fetal tissue research. Your caution on gay men and lesbians in the military has had a bright side; it has fomented a national discussion on the issue of sexual orientation and shown many people how little they know.
Bosnia must be much on your mind. But you can't make the mistake that George Bush made during the gulf war, when the domestic agenda went to hell in the shadow of foreign affairs.
I don't know what happened to that sign in your campaign headquarters about the economy, stupid, but when you next speak to the American people it should be framed on your desk.
It's not easy when you compare your wallet with your wish list and don't bring home the bacon, but millions of Americans have learned how and you can, too. Think about what it's like when you get to the checkout and you don't have enough money to pay for what you've bought. You put back the things you don't absolutely positively need. Maybe that sounds simplistic. But it's how the people who employ you live day to day. And maybe simplistic, or at least simple, is what you're missing right now.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Station Rebirth Will Aid Region

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 2 article on Amtrak's proposal to move New York's Pennsylvania Station to the General Post Office building across the street fully investigates important esthetic issues. But it does not discuss other considerations, which should be seen as equally significant. 
The proposal offers a bold, creative solution to the problems that have beset the station and its users. It makes excellent use of a confluence of opportunities that are unlikely to appear again soon.
The Regional Plan Association has long advocated the development of a new station that could provide access to a comprehensive regional transportation network, and we are delighted by the proposal, which we see as a first step toward improving access to the heart of the region.
But plans should not stop here. There needs to be a second phase of development that would allow for the creation of additional train capacity to and through Pennsylvania Station to centers throughout the region. Under the Amtrak proposal, it would be difficult for New Jersey Transit or the Long Island Railroad to increase passenger service beyond their current levels.
Moreover, new and much needed services, such as a regional rail system connecting mass transit and commuter lines, could not be accommodated within this proposal.
Pennsylvania Station is one of the most important ports of entry in the region, serving many times the number of passengers as the airports serve. As such, it is the nexus of much of the region's physical and economic infrastructure.
The demolition of the original station signaled the start of 30 years of economic and civic decline. Its rebirth presents an opportunity for a turning point, a symbol of renewed confidence in the region's future.
We hope that the opportunity can be realized to the fullest extent possible.
 
H. CLAUDE SHOSTAL
President
Regional Plan Association
New York, May 3, 1993

HEADLINE: East Harlem Schools Have Success Story Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read "Our Students, Still at Risk" (Op-Ed, May 3), about New York City's Community School District 4 and its system of choice with dismay. 
 I am the principal of a "traditional" elementary school in East Harlem, Public School 171. Eighty percent of my students come from the neighborhood, which is beset with drugs, crime, unemployment, poverty and single parenthood. The student body, 536 students, is 98 percent minority; 67 percent receive free breakfast and lunch, which they eat in a 93-year-old school building.
Despite the odds against them, my students rank first in District 4 in standardized reading scores, with 53.9 percent reading at or above grade level. Almost 77 percent perform above grade level in math and also rank first in the district.
Public School 171 and its dedicated teachers are not rewarded for doing well. There are no dollars, it seems, for excellent schools, only for the unsuccessful. District public relations focus on "alternative" schools with "thematic" approaches.
I invite those interested in effective education to call me, see our school and see what else is going on in East Harlem.
 
LORRAINE MANN SKEEN
Principal
Patrick Henry Preparatory School
New York, May 4, 1993

HEADLINE: Right to Challenge Borrowing Is Upheld

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 11

 BODY:
The New York State Court of Appeals ruled today that citizens have the right to challenge state borrowing done without voter approval, reversing its earlier position and opening the door to a flurry of lawsuits.
The decision is a potential problem for the state, although the extent of the problem depends on further court decisions. The State Constitution says the state has to have the approval of voters for taxpayer-supported debt, though the reality is that most borrowing is conducted by public authorities outside voter scrutiny. Courts have upheld this in the past, but today's decision opened the way to a new wave of challenges. 
 While the court gave voters the standing to bring those challenges, it left unresolved how these would fare.
 
A 5-to-1 Decision
 In its 5-to-1 decision, the state's highest court refused to take up the issue of whether state practices, like allowing quasi-governmental authorities to borrow money to balance the state budget, are legal. That question should be put off until a later time, the court said, as it affirmed the public's right to scrutinize government action.
"Public indebtedness is viewed skeptically by the people of New York and must be tightly circumscribed by the people themselves and not entrusted finally even to their own representatives," said Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa, writing for the majority.
This was the second decision in two weeks calling into question longtime governmental practices. Last week the court ruled the Legislature could not call back bills from the Governor just to avoid a possible veto.
While state officials said they were relieved that their budget schemes had not been struck down, legislative aides and lawyers familiar with state borrowing practices said the judge almost seemed to be inviting new lawsuits. Previously, state courts had held citizens had no standing to sue.
"We're extremely concerned aobut this, particularly in light of our $6 billion transportation bonding deal in the past budget," one legislative aide said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "It seems to us that the court is sending a pretty clear message."
Michael E. Katzenstein, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in public-authorities law, said the decision could open the door to scrutiny of borrowing practices he said had become "more and more abusive and less tasteful." He added: "You're going to have private litigants challenging state financing, which could be disruptive to the state. The court has said there has to be a way to review state actions where the executives and officers of the state would not be expected to seek review themselves."
The decision was a victory for Robert L. Schulz of Glens Falls, N.Y., who has devoted recent years to challenging the way the state spends its money. Mr. Schulz, a retired engineer who represents himself in court, has argued that as money grows tighter, the state's mechanisms for closing its budget gaps become shadier, falling increasingly beyond voter scrutiny.
"We are now free to take our case against runaway spending by self-serving and thoughtless governmental powers to the judiciary, where these cases rightfully belong," Mr. Schulz said in a statement.
Most of the state's borrowing is done by authorities that float bonds on their own and pay the debt service through legislative appropriations. The last two major bond issues put before the voters, an $800 million economic development proposal and a $1.9 billion environmental proposal, were defeated at the polls. In the last four years the state has borrowed $6.6 billion in nonvoter-approved debt. the state's total debt is expected to reach $27 billion within a year.
Mr. Schulz has brought a number of lawsuits against the state. In this case, he had challenged its 1990 scheme to allow the Urban Development Corporation to borrow $230 million to "buy" a state prison and a stretch of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, money which was then used to close the state budget gap.
 
Filed Too Late
 Judge Bellacosa ruled that Mr. Schulz had filed his lawsuit too late to generate a decision on the merits of the plan. But he said Mr. Schulz, and others like him, had every right to sue. "We cannot allow that right to become a dead letter, a mere set of hollow words," he said.
A second challenge by Mr. Schulz, which questioned the state's formation of a quasi-governmental borrowing authority called the Local Government Assistance Corporation, was not considered by the court on the ground that no constitutional issue was at stake.
While some expressed worry privately, state officials portrayed the decision as a win for their side, saying that it would have no immediate impact the state budget.
"This decision doesn't impugn the merits of the state's current borrowing practices," said John Clarkson, a spokesman for the State Budget Division. "The ruling may provide voters such as Mr. Schulz with a broader ability to sue, but we're not concerned about that because we're confident that our borrowing practices are constituitonal and we'll prevail in any court challenge."
But Marvin G. Nailor, a spokesman for H. Carl McCall, the new State Comptroller, said he was not so sure. "Any type of borrowing that bypasses the voters and has questionable payback arrangements certainly invites a lawsuit and the possiblity of success, particularly now that the plaintiff has standing to sue," he said.
The ruling was signed by Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye and Judges Richard D. Simons, Vito J. Titone, and Stewart F. Hancock.
In a dissenting opinion, Judge George Bundy Smith said the court should have addressed whether the borrowing schemes were legal, rather than reserving such a decision until a later case.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 13, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a New York State Court of Appeals decision to let private citizens challenge the state's borrowing practices omitted the context for a comment by a lawyer, Michael E. Katzenstein. He referred specifically to a complicated state plan in 1990, under which a public authority borrowed money to buy a state prison, when he said, "Obviously, the plaintiffs' view in this case is that the one-shots, like the prison bond case, have become more and more abusive and less tasteful."

HEADLINE: Recession? Why Worry?

BYLINE: By John Kenneth Galbraith; John Kenneth Galbraith is professor emeritus of economics at Harvard.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Reputable economic attitudes hold that the economic norm is high, if not quite full, employment and a reliable rate of expansion in economic output. Recessions are an aberrant departure from that norm. Correction must come. The question after nearly three years is whether this is so. Or is it possible that the economy has settled into an underemployment equilibrium of small or negligible growth?
There is no great novelty in this suggestion. It happened in the Great Depression: there were 10 years of stagnation that ended not because of any internal dynamic but from the massive spending for the war. And one mildly esoteric branch of economic thought has long allowed for the possibility of an enduring underemployment equilibrium, of stability with high unemployment, of low or negligible economic growth. 
 One must, however, challenge all accepted attitudes on the next point. It is that recession is uniformly adverse in its effect and thus by everyone deplored. A great many people and an even higher proportion of those who have political voice and vote, though perhaps not a majority, find a recession quite comfortable, and certainly more so than the measures that do anything effective about it. This, however, no one dreams of saying.
Economists and all approved economic doctrine have made high employment and economic growth a sacred good. With this no one can openly disagree.
There are the many who live in recession with a wholly secure livelihood and with a lessened fear of price increases, of inflation. They are in no real danger of loss or diminution of income. Present here are the more secure parts of the modern corporate bureaucracy. Its members see their brethren being shed. (The corporate elite is never fired or sacked; in the interest of efficiency, in is only shed.) However, those who are truly influential have no fear. They, always in the interest of efficiency, are the ones who do the shedding.
Similarly secure are many in the professions, professors, needless to say, some public servants, lawyers, doctors and media stars. Also very important is the modern large rentier class. And many who live on Social Security or pensions.
For all these, recessions mean stable or even falling prices and no serious reduction of income. Relatively secure also are those Kansas farmers, constituents of Senator Bob Dole, whose prices are guaranteed by the Government, whose expenses and labor costs are now stable.
Also, in an economy where services are increasingly important, a recession means a more willing and pliant labor supply, an underclass more available for the unpleasant toil that makes life for the rest of us more agreeable. And for employers.
A recession in modern times is also for many far more attractive than remedial action against it.
The possible positive lines of action against recession are three: taxes can be reduced to enhance the flow of consumer and investment spending, or so it is hoped; interest rates can be lowered to enhance investment spending and consumer purchases of houses, automobiles, refrigerators and electronics, or so it is also hoped; the Government can undertake direct, forthright job creation. This is the holy trinity. Prayer and repetitive prediction of recovery apart, there are no other lines of action.
Tax reduction has its proponents, notably among those who pay the taxes. Unfortunately, its relation to recovery is theoretical. There is the difficult question as to whether the revenues released will be spent or invested; they may be held as cash or unused bank balances. And tax reduction would increase the deficit, concern with which has now reached near paranoiac proportions. Again, better the recession.
Next, there is monetary policy: the reduction of interest rates by the Federal Reserve. This is believed to have a peculiar magic. It calls for no big bureaucratic effort, carries no threat of taxes -- and a special intelligence is taken to characterize those who are associated occupationally with money.
But monetary policy works against recession by reducing interest rates and therewith rentier income. This is by no means welcomed by those who enjoy such income. They are not without political influence. Any talk of an easier monetary policy automatically brings grave and urgent warnings of the danger of inflation. This, too, is a threat to those on stable incomes.
Additionally, there is the sad fact that in a recession monetary policy doesn't work. The elasticity of the response to reduced interest rates is then very low. People and firms spend and invest, or fail to do so, pretty much as before.
Finally, there is direct Government expenditure and employment. For those resting comfortably in recession, this is the worst of all. It could raise prices, risk inflation. Much worse, it promises higher taxes at some time yet to come.
President Clinton proposed a very modest economic expansion program; we have seen what happened. As the recession continues, I hope he will come back to this policy with force. That is not, however, my point here. I have a lesser plea; it concerns our awkward secret, our forbidden truth.
We pride ourselves in being plain-spoken, free from cant and certainly from any pathological self-delusion. Given a fact, we face it. Let us now face the fact that for many a recession is a tolerable, even pleasant thing. And let us say so. This will not be popular. There could be indignant denial. That is often the response to unwelcome truth.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: A PRICE RISE FANS INFLATION CONCERN

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
An unexpected surge in wholesale prices last month, the latest of a string of higher price reports, left many economists and investors wondering whether the inflation genie was starting to slip out of the bottle.
Producer prices leaped six-tenths of a percent in April, the Labor Department reported yesterday. That jump -- the biggest in two and a half years and significantly larger than most forecasters expected -- unsettled everyone from bond investors to homeowners who had not gotten around to refinancing their mortgages and worried that an uptick in inflation could push interest rates higher.
 
4.7% Annual Rate
 Although bad weather was partly to blame and the monthly rate probably exaggerates the average increases over a longer stretch of time, the spurt suggested that the sanguine inflation forecasts of the Federal Reserve and the Clinton Administration, of 2.5 to 3 percent for the year, could ultimately prove a shade too rosy. 
 The Producer Price Index has now risen at an annual rate of 4.7 percent so far this year, well above the 1.6 percent increase for 1992. The index measures price changes of all goods produced in the United States -- everything from computers to celery -- and is based on a monthly survey mailed to 87,000 factories and farms. Since it covers only about 30 percent of economic activity, a rise in the index does not translate into an equal increase in inflation generally.
To some economists, the most eye-catching number in the report was the underlying or "core" inflation rate -- the index stripped of volatile food and energy prices. This core number has risen at a 3.4 percent annual rate so far this year, noticeably faster than last year's 2 percent, though merely a fraction of the 12.8 percent increase in 1979, during the high inflation years.
Administration economists called the numbers disappointing, but, like many analysts, said they were waiting to see today's Consumer Price Index, a broader measure that includes services as well as goods. Most economic forecasters have predicted a moderate rise of two-tenths or three-tenths of a percent -- in line with what they had expected for producer prices. Although consumer prices generally move roughly in parallel with producer prices, they do not necessarily match each other month by month.
 
High Vegetable Prices
 Several special one-time events, including bad weather that pushed up vegetable prices, made things look worse than they probably were.. But the fact that analysts were unpleasantly surprised for several months in a row made many reluctant to dismiss the report as yet another fluke.
"You can keep saying this is an exception and that's an exception but pretty soon things add up to a trend," said Tom Tibbetts, who is in charge of the producer price survey at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The accumulation of special factors makes it look like inflation is a little warmer this year than last year."
Even if the poorer performance continues, however, a modest increase in the inflation rate is not expected to alter the political battle that is shaping up over Alan Greenspan's steady-as-she-goes monetary policy.
Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, said that he and fellow Democrats planned to keep pressing the Federal Reserve to push interest rates lower -- even if inflation does worsen a bit.
"We have already pushed the Fed, and continue to keep up the pressure," he said. "The first thing the Fed should not do is panic and use these numbers to tighten.
"At best, they ought to consider loosening to spur more economic growth. They ought to put up a sign over the Fed saying 'It's not inflation, stupid.' "
But Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, said the Fed should not back off. "They need to be vigilant," he said. "My Democratic colleagues want to use fiscal policy to aggravate the economic situation. Then they want to say to the Fed essentially, 'You guys have to pull our car out of ditch.' There's no way that monetary policy can undo the harmful effects of bad fiscal policy."
Investors initially reacted to the report yesterday morning by selling bonds and stocks and driving up gold prices, partly because the report dashed hopes of easing by the Fed to bolster the weak economy.
"Inflation is starting to come back a little," said Brian Keyser, an economist at CRT Government Securities. "If the Fed doesn't step on it later this year, we could have a real problem in 1994."
Bad weather can be blamed for more than a third of the leap in the producer price index last month. Thanks to wet weather in the West and cold in Florida, fruit and vegetable prices zoomed at one of the fastest rates on record, by 44.7 percent, as heavy rains washed away crops in the fields. Those price are likely to fall again within a couple of months.
 
No 'Catastrophe' Seen
 "This isn't a catastrophe," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Center for Economic Forecasting at Georgia State University, and one of the few forecasters who saw the spurt in producer prices coming. "We get six different crops a year and within two months we'll get the East Coast crop."
Another jolt came from tobacco prices, which rose about 8 percent in the last year. But smokers of Marlboros or Camels or other popular brands are expecting price cuts. Philip Morris, for example, announced on April 2 that it was cutting the price of Marlboros by 40 cents a pack, but the average price of wholesale cigarettes did not start to fall until May and is apt to keep declining in June. R. J. Reynolds is also making cuts.
A factor likely to weigh against inflation is lingering unemployment, which holds down wage gains. Unit labor costs have been rising very slowly, thanks to rapid productivity gains. And factories still have lots of spare capacity.
But there were also signs in yesterday's report that businesses, which have not been very successful at raising prices in the weak economy of the last few years, are trying again to increase profit margins, especially since virtually all of the improvements in profitability so far have come from cost cutting.

HEADLINE: Clinton Supports Creating Fund Designated Solely to Cut Deficit

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
Responding to accusations by Ross Perot and Republicans that he is just another tax-and-spend Democrat, President Clinton yesterday endorsed a proposal to require that all the money raised by tax increases in his new budget be used solely to reduce the Federal deficit.
Locking new tax revenues and savings from some of his proposed budget cuts into what he termed a "trust fund" would guarantee that the sacrifices the budget demands of the voters would go toward their stated purpose, Mr. Clinton said. 
 The new taxes that would be required to pay for Mr. Clinton's health-care and welfare proposals, expected in the coming few months but not included in this budget, would not be covered by the deficit-reduction measure he talked about yesterday.
The President's position would not change the substance of his budget, now being considered by Congress. Aides to Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the fund idea is primarily a political gesture to underscore their commitment to attack the deficit. Details on how the fund might work have yet to be worked out.
"Credibility is difficult to come by in Washington today," Mr. Clinton said in a speech to community and business leaders at Cooper Union in Manhattan. "After 12 years of rising deficits and Americans' feeling deceived about the issue, I don't blame the people of this country for being distrustful about what they hear from Washington when it comes to bringing down this deficit."
With a "deficit-reduction trust fund," added Mr. Clinton, "the American people know that it has to go to deficit reduction."
Mr. Clinton was welcomed at Cooper Union by a host of New York Democrats, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
 
Cutbacks in Military
 Mr. Clinton said the new spending programs in his budget would be offset by cuts in discretionary spending, particularly military programs.
On Capitol Hill, the trust fund idea was denounced as a gimmick by Republicans and cautiously supported by Democrats. Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the head of the Budget Committee, called it a "laudable goal" that was already covered by budget law.
Administration officials said the proposed legal handcuffs on spending would apply to the taxes and cutbacks in the budget that takes effect Oct. 1. That budget, for fiscal 1994, is part of a five-year program of tax increases and spending cuts designed by the Clinton Administration to trim the deficit, now roughly $320 billion a year, in half.
If the economy went into deep recession and the Administration wanted to engage in deficit spending to spur growth, it could pass a special supplemental bill to do that at any time.
 
No 'Gimmick,' Schumer Says
 "This does not change the current budget numbers," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who has been leading the drive for this deficit-reducing trust fund in Congress. "But it is not a gimmick either. There is a problem of credibility. The public does not believe we will really cut the deficit when we say we will, and this puts our feet to the fire."
"Everywhere I went in my district people said, 'We are willing to tighten our belt, but we don't believe you,' " Mr. Schumer went on. "The popular view was that we would raise the taxes and then spend it on pork. And this will not allow that to happen."
A total of $496 billion in extra taxes, cuts in spending and savings from lower interest payments are expected to be realized over the next five years, Administration officials said. They broke that down as $101.9 billion in savings from cuts in military and civilian spending (the amount left over after Mr. Clinton pays for his $135 billion in new programs over the next five years); $50.3 billion in reduced interest payments on the debt; $103.2 billion from cuts in entitlement programs, and $240.7 billion in additional tax revenues.
Congress would have to approve the trust fund proposal as an amendment to the fiscal 1994 budget bill now under consideration.
White House officials had been talking with Mr. Schumer about this idea for the past few weeks. They suddenly called him at 10 A.M. yesterday to say that they were going to get behind his idea and that he should get on a plane to New York to be on hand when Mr. Clinton discussed it at the Cooper Union yesterday afternoon.
Administration officials said they decided to appropriate the idea to blunt efforts by Mr. Perot and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, to undercut the President's $1.5 trillion budget, the same way they did his economic-stimulus package, by presenting it as just more deficit spending.
A prime reason the stimulus package failed was because it called for more deficit spending without offsetting budget cuts -- a move opposed not only by Mr. Perot and the Republicans, but by many conservative Democrats.
Clinton Administration officials acknowledged that they had misgauged the public's desire for real deficit reduction, before any new spending. For the past few weeks, conservative Democrats have been bombarding the White House with reports from the home front that voters are ready to sacrifice and tighten their belts.
"This is our way of telling people, 'You don't have to worry, all your sacrifices will go into deficit reduction,' " said Gene Sperling, an economic adviser to the President.
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the Republicans' designated spokesman on budget issues, called the proposal "a transparent attempt to mislead the American people."
"This President has a long-established pattern of behavior in his four months in office: when something goes south, he changes the subject," Mr. Gramm said. The trust fund, he argued, was an attempt to divert public attention from the size and scope of his tax plans.
Senator Sasser said the budget law already contained guarantees that tax increases be used only for deficit reduction, and that any spending increases be offset by spending cuts.
 
An Economist's Opinion
 But an economist who is a former Congressional budget expert gave the idea some support. "I wouldn't go so far as to use the term gimmick," said this budget expert. "It is a kind of political device, and it might be a useful political device, to increase the discipline in budgeting. It is unlikely to do much harm, and might do some good."
During the campaign, President George Bush suggested that taxpayers be allowed to dedicate a portion of the tax payments to reducing the deficit, an idea criticized at the time by the Democrats.
The latest idea for a defict-paying trust fund was hatched in conversations in the House between Mr. Schumer and fellow Democrats, Bill Brewster of Oklahoma, Chet Edwards of Texas, Jane Harman of California and Robert Wise of West Virginia. It has also been under discussion in the Senate by Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey.
Mr. Schumer said he and his colleagues concluded that if they could find a way to guarantee that all tax increases go to reduce the deficit it would resonate with the public and make passage of the Clinton budget that much easier.
Mr. Clinton has used the trust fund approach before, during his last term as Governor of Arkansas. As he was trying to convince a reluctant public to accept tax increases so he could raise money for schools, Mr. Clinton promised that every dollar raised would be placed in a special account, and no money would be taken from that account unless it went to the schools.
The idea had been used before in Arkansas, early in this century. But it fell out of favor when certain government agencies began enriching themselves with special-purpose taxes. When the Clinton Administration revived the idea in Arkansas in 1991, it proved quite popular, and the new taxes were approved.

HEADLINE: Report Calls Simple Test Effective In Reducing Colon Cancer Deaths

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
After decades of debate and inconclusive findings, a major new study has shown that a yearly test can significantly reduce deaths from colorectal cancer, the second leading cause of cancer deaths among Americans.
In the 13-year study, those in a group randomly chosen to undergo annual tests for blood in their stools experienced 33 percent fewer deaths from cancers of the colon and rectum than did those in a similar group who were not offered the test. 
 The study, using 46,551 Minnesota residents, showed that the screening test could detect many colorectal cancers at an early stage, when they are curable. At this stage, symptoms of cancer typically have not yet appeared.
The test also turned up many adenomatous polyps, lesions in the bowel that are considered precancerous.
 
'Astounding Result'
 The life-saving benefit was found even though only 46 percent of the screened group took all 11 of the offered tests.
One drawback to the findings, however, is that because fecal blood can be caused by benign conditions, people with positive results on the screening test have to undergo costly follow-up exams to determine whether they actually have cancer.
The study, longer and larger than any before it, is being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.
"We think this is quite an astounding result in terms of its impact on this disease," the director of the study, Dr. Jack S. Mandel, said yesterday in an interview.
The findings suggest that if all Americans over age 50 took the test every year, more than a quarter of a million lives would be saved over the next 13 years, based on current incidence and death rates from colorectal cancer. The American Cancer Society estimates that 152,000 new cases of this cancer will be diagnosed this year, and 57,000 Americans, a vast majority of them over 50, will die of the disease, which ranks behind lung cancer as a cause of death among Americans.
Dr. Sidney J. Winawer, chief of the gastroenterology and nutrition service at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, said in an interview that according to the findings, 1 in 10 people who are not considered at high risk for colon cancer will have a positive stool test, "and in this group you'll find 92 percent of the colon cancers."
Dr. Winawer, who wrote an editorial praising the new study, said it showed "for the first time a significant decline in the death rate as a result of testing for fecal occult blood."
The cancer society currently recommends that people over age 50 should get the test, which costs only $20 to $40, once a year.
But the encouraging results, while vindicating the cancer society's assertion that the simple test for fecal occult, or hidden, blood can save lives, is likely to prompt further debate over the question, Can a health-care system in economic straits afford the millions of expensive follow-up tests that would be needed to determine which of the nearly 10 percent of people with positive results on the screening test actually have cancer or premalignant polyps?
In the new study, by Dr. Mandel and his colleagues at the University of Minnesota School of Public Health, only one in three people whose screening tests showed blood in the stool were subsequently found to have cancer or precancerous polyps. But all those with positive test results had to undergo a costly colonoscopy, a procedure in which a flexible scope is used to examine the entire five feet of the lower bowel.
When performed in a doctor's office, a colonoscopy typically costs $700 to $900. But hospitals, where some colonoscopies are performed, may charge two to three times those prices.
If all 60 million Americans over 50 had a fecal occult blood test each year, the new study suggests that about six million of them would need the costly follow-up tests.
"There is a real problem with translating these results into public policy," said Dr. Douglas B. McGill, a gastroenterologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., whose study published two months ago declared the stool test to be ineffective as a screening tool. "Given the considerable costs of follow-up exams, it has to be determined whether screening for occult blood is worth it."
Dr. McGill noted that only 2.2 percent of those with positive results on the stool tests were ultimately found to have cancer, which means that 97.8 percent were subjected to the costly follow-up exams only to be found free of actual disease.
Over the 13 years of the study, 38 percent of the participants had positive results on one or more stool tests and had to undergo one or more colonoscopies. Dr. McGill predicted that just doing that many colonoscopies on a random group of people, without testing first for occult blood, would result in a decline in cancer deaths similar to what Dr. Mandel and his colleagues found.
One advantage to colonoscopy is that possible cancerous lesions can be biopsied, and premalignant polyps can be removed during the same procedure. In the new study, nearly 30 percent of those with blood in their stool were subsequently found to have polyps that could become cancerous years later. By removing those polyps, future cancers can be prevented.
The screening test for fecal occult blood, developed in the late 1960's, is familiar to many Americans who have routine health checkups. It involves test cards impregnated with a substance called guaiac. The cards are smeared with tiny stool samples from three consecutive bowel movements, then mailed to a physician or laboratory for analysis. If blood is present in any of the samples, the test is considered positive.
However, many factors, including various foods, like meat, aspirin-like drugs and vitamin C, and the presence of bleeding hemorrhoids, can produce false positive results on the stool test.
In the new study, a drop of water was added to the smears that had dried in transit, which quadrupled the ability of the test to detect hidden blood. This increased sensitivity may partly explain the encouraging results from the Minnesota study when previous studies, including those done at the Mayo Clinic on dry stool samples, failed to show a life-saving benefit from the screening test.

HEADLINE: Coverage Cited by Groups Opposing Sale of Post to Murdoch

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Civil rights groups and minority businessmen seeking to block Rupert Murdoch's proposed purchase of The New York Post have argued in filings with the Federal Government that the move would perpetuate poor coverage of the city's black and Hispanic communities.
They told the Federal Communication Commissions that allowing Mr. Murdoch to own both a local television station and The Post would stifle competition. They also accused Mr. Murdoch and all of the city's daily newspapers of discrimination in both hiring and promotion practices and coverage of minority issues. Mr. Murdoch owns WNYW-TV, Channel 5, which is part of the Fox network. 
 William Reyner Jr., Mr. Murdoch's lawyer, said, "We're not really surprised by the filings. They're making the kind of arguments you would expect in this proceeding."
At least one civil rights group, the Congress of Racial Equality, supports Mr. Murdoch's request for a waiver from a Federal rule that prohibits anyone from owning both a television or radio station and a daily newspaper in the same city. The rule, which forced him to sell The Post when he bought WNYW-TV, has never been waived, although many newspaper companies own radio or television stations in the same city because the stations were started or purchased before it went into effect.
Other supporters warned that without the waiver, The Post would die because Mr. Murdoch would be unable to buy the paper and there were no other credible bidders.
In a filing with the F.C.C., the Metropolitan Council of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Branches said that "diversification at the highest levels of media influence -- involving a television network, TV Guide, a VHF-TV station and a daily newspaper in the nation's largest city -- could not be more relevant to the competitive environment in the New York media."
"Regrettably, the New York media, including The Post and WNYW-TV, have not served the largest black community outside the continent of Africa," said papers filed by Laura D. Blackburne, general counsel of the New York State Conference of Branches of the N.A.A.C.P. She also represented The Amsterdam News and its publisher, Wilbert A. Tatum.
Similarly, the Caucus for Media Diversity, an ad hoc group that represents the National Hispanic Media Coalition, among other groups, said that "New York City's four white corporate-owned newspapers presently provide little diversity of news and editorial coverage from the perspective of minority groups and others that constitute the bulk of the city's population."
Mr. Murdoch's petition also was opposed by the National Black Media Coalition and the Committee to Eliminate Media Offensive to the African People, which charged that "Murdoch's station and The New York Post appear to discriminate against African American employees." The newspaper and the station "do not employ African Americans in managerial or executive positions and actively attack and denigrate leaders and members of the African American community."
 
A Supporter
 But the chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, Roy Innis, wrote, "Should The Post go out of business, an often eloquent voice of dissent compared to the majority of the media will be lost."
One law firm that opposed Mr. Murdoch did not disclose its client, either in its filings or in responding to a telephone request for the information. Fleischman & Walsh, a Washington firm that specializes in cable-television law, said that if Mr. Murdoch received a waiver, "The result would not be an increase in media diversity, but would actually be a decrease in both the diversity of media voices and in economic competition among the mass media."
The F.C.C. filing showed that Mr. Murdoch had a number of supporters, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Murdoch also won the support of the Democratic and Republican leaders of New York's City Council, Peter F. Vallone, Speaker and Majority Leader, and Alfred C. Cerrulo 3d.

HEADLINE: For Clinton, Barricades But Few Hands to Shake

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Maybe it was the police presence that made Cooper Square look like an occupied country. Maybe it was the prospect of waiting in the hot sun for three hours. Or maybe, it was simply that spectacle-weary New Yorkers would just as soon have watched the whole thing on television.
Whatever the reason, the crowd greeting President Clinton when he stepped out of Cooper Union after delivering his economics address yesterday afternoon was surprisingly small by Presidential -- or New York -- standards. At many places along the metal barricades, in fact, onlookers stood less than one deep as they waited for the chance to shake hands with Mr. Clinton. 
 "Why isn't there more of a crowd?" asked Ellie McCully, as she stood with her son, Cameron, and a group of other parents who had brought their children to the event after a class at a nearby gymnasium. "When the Pope came to town, every street was packed with people -- and there was torrential rain."
Security for the event, the President's first stop on his first visit to New York since his inauguration, was intense. Three hours before Mr. Clinton's arrival, a police bomb squad was called to inspect a black metal box that had been found hanging from a fence outside the building, a police spokesman, Officer Scott Bloch, said. The box was found to contain some bricks, he said.
 
'Too Cool' for This?
 Rows and rows of police barricades lined the streets around Cooper Union, from Astor Place to Second Avenue. Police sharpshooters patrolled the rooftops, Secret Service agents strolled with their fingers on their earphones and police officers on foot patrol were everywhere.
The only thing missing was the civilians.
"Maybe people on the Lower East Side are too cool for this," said Carl Hultberg, recycling coordinator for New York University, as he leaned on a barricade on Cooper Square, waiting for a glimpse of the President.
Aside from the speech, the President's day, in many ways, had a not-for-the-masses quality. His only other scheduled event, a Democratic National Committee fund-raiser at Lincoln Center, where tickets went for up to $2,500 each, was closed to the media and public.
Under a white tent in Damrosch Park, "everybody who's anybody" mingled, including various local union presidents, county Democratic leaders and Mayor David N. Dinkins, who strolled around the crowd, said Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, a big Clinton supporter who stayed just long enough to be kissed by the President.
During the event, the table talk was so distracting that at one point, the Mayor gave up trying to address the audience, said Gordon Davis, a former city parks commissioner, who was among the guests. The Mayor, in turn, was admonished by the actress Whoopi Goldberg for speaking on his cellular phone while she was addressing the crowd, Mr. Davis said.
Because Mr. Clinton's main appearance was in the East Village, away from midtown traffic, disruptions were minimal for much of the day, although the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was closed from South Street to the Triborough Bridge from about 4:30 to 5 P.M., officials said.
"It may be coincidental that the President chose a location in the East Village rather than in midtown," said Samuel I. Schwartz, a former deputy commissioner of transportation who helped arrange several Presidential visits during the 1980's. "But that means less of a dramatic effect on traffic at the busiest places."
There was congestion of another sort -- call it politicianlock -- inside the Great Hall at Cooper Union, a college of art and architecture, where Mr. Clinton delivered his speech to an audience of about 900, including a bevy of admiring New York Democrats. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor Dinkins and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan paid tribute to the President in their introductions, and the President returned the favor in his remarks, which were broadcast by loudspeaker into Cooper Square.
The speech, in which he endorsed a proposal to require that the money raised by tax increases in his new budget and saved by spending cuts be used to reduce the Federal deficit, drew raves from many politicians.
"He was superb," said Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Congresswoman and Democratic Vice Presidential candidate. "He was energetic. He was funny. It was just very impressive: really talking about the responsibility of Government."
 
Hand-Shaking and Sweating
 But on the street outside the Great Hall, most of those who had waited for the better part of the afternoon to see the President were not as impressed with his words as with his presence. For the opportunity to shake Mr. Clinton's hand, they had to walk through metal detectors and wait in a fenced-off area.
About 4:30 P.M. the President emerged beaming from the Cooper Union building. He was jacketless, his blue shirt drenched in perspiration, as he plunged into the crowd with Mayor Dinkins in tow. For the next 15 minutes, he shook virtually every hand in the crowd, which, despite its size, seemed to represent a snapshot of the face of New York City in mid-spring: nannies with babies, college students, Japanese tourists.
"Nice eyes," said Karah Woodward, after shaking Mr. Clinton's hand. "Beautiful blue eyes."
Her friend, Amy Kates, who works with her at a management-consulting firm on East Ninth Street, added, "The air-conditioning must not be working in there."
Many in the crowd hypothesized that Mr. Clinton's choice of the East Village was a sign that he was more attuned to the concerns of average people than his predecessors.
"This is one of the hippest places in New York," said Larry Florman, a clerk at the Carl Fischer music store across the street from the Cooper Union. "If anybody says a President is coming downtown, it's usually Wall Street."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Producer Price Rise Jars Treasury Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
There was a rude awakening for the Treasury market yesterday: The April jump in producer price inflation was much higher than expected and signaled that there is less hope now for a new rally based on declining inflation.
The metaphorical slap in the face pushed prices lower, with the 30-year bond down 19/32 point and the yield up to 6.85 percent, from 6.81 percent Tuesday. The prices of two-year to five-year notes fell much less, however, because inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments, has less impact on shorter-term securities. 
 The selling, which came in the morning, might have actually helped the Treasury's auction of $10.76 billion of 10-year notes because the price of that issue also fell ahead of the 1 P.M. bidding deadline, making it more attractive to dealers.
In the end, the 10-year auction went fairly well, with an average yield of 5.96 percent, the lowest since the Treasury began regular auctions in 1978. But that was not enough to lift the cloud created by the inflation report or to offset concerns about today's $8.25 billion auction of 30-year bonds. That auction could be undermined by the hangover of yesterday's inflation report and the release of the Consumer Price Index today. The April report on retail sales could also give traders headaches on the final day of the Treasury's quarterly auction series.
The bad news for traders and investors was in the six-tenths of one percentage point increase in the Producer Price Index for finished goods. Some analysts dismissed the April increase as an aberration, in part because of the weather-induced 44.7 percent increase in the prices of fresh and dried vegetables.
Some traders said if the figures had been taken as a new sign of rising inflation and not just an aberration, the selloff would have been steeper.
But this is the third out of the first four months of the year that the index has been higher than expectations because of aberrations and "these aberrations are adding up to a higher P.P.I. number," Michael H. Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International, said. "Bond investors should take a look at it."
If future reports make it clearer that inflation will be higher this year, there will be more upward pressure on interest rates. The C.P.I. rose 3 percent last year. But those who think it will be higher this year say the increase will be small.
Traders were able to dismiss the jump in food prices. But they had trouble with the more than 1 percent increase, after seasonal adjustment, in the price of passenger cars. "The car prices are real to me," one trader said.
"When the market was rallying earlier this year, people expected that the rate of inflation would be lower," Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said. "I think the market has realized that inflation won't be lower, but I do not think that it has realized that it will be higher."
However, some traders and forecasters, including those at Merrill Lynch, still expect inflation to decline, despite yesterday's report.
 
 
Four Themes
 Inflation is one of the four themes that have been influencing trading recently. And because traders can quickly turn from positive to negative, the bond market has been locked in a narrow trading range for two months.
The others are the pace of economic growth, President Clinton's handling of the economy and the deficit, and technical factors, which include the strong demand for Treasury securities because portfolio managers still have a lot of cash to invest.
The inflation theme had been a worry but was put to rest temporarily by the small increases in the producer and consumer price indexes in March. That confidence was unsettled a bit yesterday.
On growth, the data have been relatively positive for the market as it shows that the economy continues to appear to be moving ahead at a slow pace that would not put any upward pressure on prices. But this could change later in the year.
 
 
Deficit Doubts
 The recent setbacks to President Clinton on his economic program have raised some doubts about the outlook for significant deficit reduction, although it was his promise of such reduction that fueled the rally earlier this year.
The fate of today's 30-year bond auction is likely to hinge on the C.P.I. report and retail sales reports for April. A jump of two-tenths of one percentage point in the C.P.I. and a 1.2 percent rise in retail sales, which are the consensus forecasts, would settle inflationary jitters and help the auction. Stronger inflation and stronger sales would cause trouble.
The success of yesterday's 10-year note auction was reflected in trading afterward, when the yield in the when-issued market fell to 5.92 percent, from the 5.96 average at the auction.
The 10-year notes are the same as the 6.25 percent issue that was originally sold in February and matures in February 2003. The Treasury reopened the issue because there was a severe shortage of the notes available for trading, which left open the possibility that the issue could be manipulated.
The reopening policy was set after the Treasury bidding scandal at Salomon Brothers in 1991. The 30-year bond sale will also be a reopening of the 7.125 percent issue sold in February and maturing in 2023.

HEADLINE: Ethiopians Return, Glad to Help Build a New Land

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia

 BODY:
After two decades of Marxist rule and civil war that have left the economy in ruins, a handful of Ethiopians have returned here from exile to help build a new government in a nation that has never had a democratic tradition.
It is proving to be an enormous, painful task. With eight months left before the transitional Government must step down after national elections, it is still unclear whether Ethiopia -- which has finally achieved peace and with it some stability -- can avoid falling back into ethnically fueled civil war. 
 Nebiyu Samuel, who was a broker in Los Angeles, came to visit in 1991 after 19 years in exile. When he was invited by the leading guerrilla group to take part in a national conference to establish a transitional government, he decided to stay permanently. He gave up his job and left his family behind.
A year and a half later, as the head of a political party, he earns the equivalent of $150 a month. He says he leaves his office many days overcome by frustration and futility and deeply lonely for his wife and child. Yet he has no intention of giving up. As a former businessman, he says, he knows the necessity of planning for the future.
Andreas Eshete is in his mid-40's like Mr. Samuel. His world is one of ideas. A political philosopher who has taught at Brown University and the University of California at Berkeley, he too has returned permanently after 20 years in exile -- but not as part of the Government.
He works for Inter-Africa Group, a private organization that wants to act as an impartial contributor to building government here. His aim is to restore intellectual and political life and, most important, the freedom of debate.
Mr. Eshete is helping organize a symposium on building a constitution, analyzing the problems Ethiopia's transitional Government is having and studying the new constitutions of Eastern Europe to glean the good and discard the bad from what those governments have learned.
 
The Idealist
 Another Ethiopian who has returned is Netsannet Asfaw. Seventeen years ago she left her infant daughter in her mother's care in Addis Ababa and joined the Tigrean People's Liberation Front to fight a war against the Government in northern Ethiopia. She did not see her daughter for 10 years, traveling from the bush, where she fought with weapons to overthrow the Government, to England and the United States, where she fought with words.
Ms. Asfaw also returned to Addis Ababa in 1991, after the fall of the Marxist Government, and joined the governing party, the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Defense Front, as press secretary to President Meles Zenawi. Her intensity and air of simplicity mirror the almost puritanical zeal of the front, a grass-roots movement that she says is intent on uprooting poverty and bringing Ethiopia into the 21st century.
Some Western analysts have said democracy in Ethiopia is an experiment likely to fail. But these three returnees have a stubborn faith that Ethiopia will survive. Mixing Western theories with Ethiopian traditions, they have brought with them varied experiences and new thoughts and energy to find ways to bridge the gap between the skeleton of a Marxist state and a new government, as yet undefined.
"I'm trying to be a realist," said Mr. Samuel, whose party, the Ethiopian Democratic Coalition, advocates multiparty democracy, a free-market economy and a limited role for government. "Sometimes I find myself in a dilemma. Is the ideal of democracy too Westernized? Is it too unnatural for Africa?
"But the bottom line is that the commitment to democracy is the only alternative. But democracy is a process, not a one-shot deal. I am here because it is the most crucial period in my country's history. There is a lot of work to be done and a lot of ugly things to confront."
Many Ethiopians say that compared with the situation two years ago, any change will be progress. A pawn of the cold war, Ethiopia was one of the United States' main African allies in the 1950's and 1960's under Emperor Haile Selassie. It entered the Soviet camp in 1977 under the Marxist rule of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam and remained there until the revolutions in Eastern Europe brought about the collapse of Ethiopia's overseas alliances.
It remains a deeply traumatized country. For two decades, civil war against the Mengistu Government killed and wounded hundreds of thousands of people. A decade ago famine killed one million more. When in May 1991 the guerrillas led by the People's Front overthrew Colonel Mengistu and established a transitional Government, the country was in economic and political disarray, an entire generation lost to war.
Since then, the front-led Government of President Meles, who was chosen head of state in July 1991 at a conference of Ethiopian parties and whose term runs until national elections are held next January, has been promised $650 million in aid through next year by Western donors. And it has embarked on an ambitious program to rebuild its destroyed infrastructure.
The currency is being devalued and the bureaucracy slimmed down, half a million soldiers have been demobilized and farm prices have been freed. The rains have been the best in years and harvests have been good.
In an effort to create a federal system and to placate minorities, the Government has advocated self-determination for the country's ethnic groups and is pushing for the regionalization of power away from the capital.
 
Poverty, and Hope
 Addis Ababa, like the rest of Ethiopia, emanates an air of uncertainty, of a land torn between poverty and a tentative future. Even the symbols of the past Government have been left behind in limbo. Most of the hammers and sickles have been pulled down, but the red stars and the huge revolutionary arches and squares remain.
Shantytowns are huddled near the wide avenues, with their 1970's Soviet-style crumbling concrete high rises, and beggars comb the streets. Yet business is slowly coming to life in Addis Ababa, even though foreign investors are still only tentatively exploring the market. The Italian clothing chain Benetton has opened a store, and chic restaurants and discos are thriving.
But the plight of the Ethiopian economy may be the greatest threat to a sustainable democratic transition. The problems remain staggering. Unemployment is more than 40 percent, wages are miserably low, and ethnically and politically the country of about 53 million is deeply divided.
Most of the members of the People's Front are Tigreans from the north, and the main opposition groups are formed by the Oromos, based in the east, and the Amharas, who are spread throoughout the country. The enmity was underscored last fall when the Oromo Liberation Front, the largest opposition group, pulled out of the Government and accused the People's Front of rigging the regional elections last June. Since then it has threatened secession.
In the midst of this uncertainty, the Government is trying to create a constitution. It has formed a constitutional committee with an 11-member executive committee that meets twice weekly. Formally, the constitution will have to be revised by a constituent assembly elected in the coming national vote.
The constitution is seen as the tool that will legitimize any future government, the first step in building domestic and international confidence and the only alternative to reverting to civil war for solving problems. It must address problems as diverse as the limits of power (at present a de facto one-party rule), language differences and the relationship between church and state. The traditionally powerful Coptic Christian Church was muzzled by the former Government.
Some of the biggest challenges facing Ethiopia have been pushed into the constitutional realm. The most heated and critical issue is property rights, Mr. Eshete said. In a country that is more than 85 percent agricultural, where land has been owned by the Government for decades, the Government has said the constitution will describe how private ownership will be achieved.
"It is going to be a very painful transition," Mr. Eshete said. "This must be an exercise on the debate over the future visions of Ethiopia. It is the first time here that constitution-making may be a meaningful effort. Confidence has to be built, and citizens have to be convinced to become involved."
Through his party, Mr. Samuel hopes at least to introduce new ideas, in particular a push for a multiparty system.
"Ethiopia is in a very precarious situation," he said. "People argue that what they want is bread and butter, not promises of democracy. They say, rather than giving us democracy, give us discipline."
Ms. Asfaw said: "We have achieved peace, but the greatest challenge is development. Even if you have five years, it won't be perfect. If we fail, we start again."

Although the streets of Addis Ababa are crowded with beggars and refugees, business is slowly coming to life in the city. (Fiona McDougall for The New York Times)
