HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
U.N. Steps Said to Dry Up Serbs' Cash

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
A looming cash shortage brought on by the latest United Nations sanctions is a major element in the sudden push by Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, for peace in Bosnia, Administration officials say.
The new sanctions, which took effect on April 26, have seriously disrupted the intricate network of banks and front companies Serbia relies on to evade the year-old Western embargo, the officials said. 
 Administration officials said that one of the most significant setbacks for the Serbs unfolded last month in Cyprus, when banking authorities responding to the new sanctions seized as much as $500 million in Yugoslav assets.
 
Pledge to Cut Supplies
 Just days later, Mr. Milosevic publicly appealed to the Bosnian Serbs to accept an international peace plan that they had twice rejected. American officials viewed the apparent dispute as one over tactics, not goals. But when the Bosnian Serbs' Parliament ignored Mr. Milosevic and rejected the plan for a third time, he vowed to choke off the flow of material and equipment to the Bosnian Serbs' army, a force that he helped to create.
Administration officials said it was still too early to tell whether Serbia was carrying out Mr. Milosevic's pledge, but they said it was significant that Yugoslavia was offering to accept international monitors on its border in exchange for lifting the sanctions.
"The party's over," said one Administration official. "Cash is short for them. How much these guys have stashed away for a rainy day over the last year and a half, we can't be completely sure. But we know the rainy day is here."
The Serbs began the hostilities with an estimated $5 billion, the officials said. About $1.8 billion was frozen overseas by the first sanctions, and more than $1 billion in foreign deposits is believed to have been seized in recent weeks, they said. Several American officials estimate that Serbia's available "hard" currency -- dollars, German marks or British pounds -- is now below $1 billion. A recent article in the Belgrade weekly Vreme claimed reserves had fallen as low as $268 million.
 
A Chinese Refuge?
 Although the latest sanctions have substantially limited where Serbia can do business, Government officials said that China has emerged as one refuge for Serbian capital.
The officials said Russian companies were also continuing to do business with Serbia, defying the United Nations restrictions and throwing Mr. Milosevic a tenuous lifeline. In the years before the breakup of the old Yugoslav federation, the Soviet Union was its largest trading partner, and the breakup of the Soviet Union left Moscow with a debt to Serbia of several billion dollars that Belgrade has presumably called in.
The first round of United Nations sanctions against the rump Yugoslavia, which includes Serbia and Montenegro, were imposed last year. Though the sanctions were somewhat leaky, they and the war combined to send inflation soaring and led to a jobless rate of more than 50 percent.
Mr. Milosevic, a former banker, kept essential items flowing into Serbia through a web of more than 100 companies in Europe, Cyprus and the Far East. A provision of the United Nations sanctions permitted overseas branches of private Yugoslav companies to continue operations, providing the Serbs with badly needed cash. The overseas companies also played a role in such crucial covert efforts as fuel smuggling, officials said.
 
Seizure of All Assets
 The United Nations sanctions imposed last month took direct aim at the overseas companies, requiring member nations to freeze all Yugoslav assets. Rules were also tightened to eliminate the other chief means of sanctions-busting, under which goods labelled for transshipment through Yugoslavia were actually delivered in the country.
The sanctions gave new impetus to American demands that other countries detain the 23 Yugoslav tankers and freighters still sailing around the world. Administration officials said the bulk of the vessels now sail under Maltese flags, and in recent months, at least four have called on ports in China.
Cyprus, twice visited by American delegations, was among the first to take action against the overseas Yugoslav companies.
Michael E. Sherifis, Cyprus's Ambassador in Washington, said in an interview that under the new sanctions his country seized the assets of three Yugoslav banks and 53 companies totaling $450 to $500 million. While precise figures are not yet available, Administration an officials estimate that European nations tightened the squeeze further by freezing several hundred million dollars controlled by Serbian companies.
What one official characterized as a "chess game" between the Serbs and the sanctions enforcers continues. In recent months, officials said, "bag men" working for Mr. Milosevic have stashed millions of dollars of cash in bank vaults abroad. With the overseas transactions of Serbian-linked companies frozen, the Serbian Government has also begun hiding some of its assets in the private accounts of Serbs living overseas.
Evidence that sanctions have had an effect in Serbia can be seen in a proposal now being floated by Greece, Serbia's main ally in the region. The Greeks have said if the West was prepared to lift the United Nations sanctions, Serbia might accept international observers on its borders to monitor the enforcement of its cutoff of supplies to Bosnia. A senior Yugoslav official this week publicly proposed such an approach in an interview.
 
Tighter Than Iraqi Sanctions
 American officials said the sanctions against Serbia are now the strongest ever put into effect, and are much tighter than those currently in place against Iraq.
A C.I.A. study earlier this year said that sanctions alone were unlikely to stop the fighting in Bosnia in the immediate future, in part because Serbs there are already well supplied. But American officials and military experts in the region believe that a tight blockade by Mr. Milosevic against the Bosnian Serbs would help quell the conflict because they depend on Yugoslavia for fuel and spare parts.

HEADLINE: Rostenkowski Urges Clinton To Seek Support 'Out There'

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
As he struggled to forge the tax legislation that is the core of President Clinton's economic program, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, suggested today that the President needed to generate more enthusiasm in the country for his plan if he hoped to get it enacted.
"The Administration, never having written a tax bill, doesn't understand that you have to get supporters out there, not exclusively in the House of Representatives or the Senate," Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, told reporters after meeting for hours with the other Democrats on his committee. 
 He continued: "You've got to get some people out there suggesting to the American people that this is good for the country and that large corporations and small businesses see in this bill an attractiveness for them to spend more money to create jobs. I'm trying to convince them that's important, and I think that on some ears the suggestions have fallen favorably."
 
His Experience Speaking
 Mr. Rostenkowski, who bears responsibility for getting the President's economic program started in Congress, spoke like an experienced sergeant pleading with his young commander for reinforcements. "It's very difficult to pass tax legislation," he declared.
In New York today, Mr. Clinton endorsed a proposal that would require that money raised by tax increases and saved by spending cuts be used to reduce the deficit.
Earlier this week Mr. Clinton traveled to Cleveland and Chicago to promote the economic package. Along with some other Chicago politicians, Mr. Rostenkowski had dinner with him Monday night.
These were Mr. Clinton's first trips out of Washington to promote his economic plan since his emergency spending bill was killed last month by a Senate filibuster, his popularity ratings began to drop and he conceded that his Presidency at the outset had lacked sufficient focus. It was not clear whether Mr. Rostenkowski was criticizing the trips this week as uninspiring or applauding them and asking for more.
In an interview this morning on WFAN radio in New York, Mr. Clinton said that some changes were being made by Congress to make his program better and that they "don't in any way undermine the fundamental principles of the tax program and the spending cuts program I laid out."
 
Crucial Committee Review
 The Ways and Means Committee is especially important because it gets first crack at writing tax measures, and Mr. Rostenkowski controls his committee the way a masterful conductor directs an orchestra.
No one doubts that the committee will approve a tax bill containing the main elements of the Clinton proposal: higher income tax rates for wealthy people and corporations, a new tax on fuel, taxes on a larger proportion of the Social Security benefits of upper- and middle-income retirees and more generous tax credits for the working poor.
And since tax measures are voted on by the House under rules that restrict amendments, the committee's work is likely to be adopted when it reaches the floor. But Mr. Rostenkowski is taking no chances, and he is working with the Administration to make changes around the edges that will make difficult votes easier to cast.
He said today that his goal was to structure a bill that could win support of a majority of representatives, but he may also have his eye on the Senate, where the Democratic majority is less solid than in the House and where the prospects for approval of the President's plan are less favorable.
 
Powerless Republicans
 Mr. Rostenkowski spent most of today with the other 23 Democrats on his committee around a conference table in his office on the second floor of the Capitol. The committee itself, which is required by the budget resolution approved last month to produce a tax bill by the end of this week, never met but is scheduled to convene Thursday morning.
The 14 Republicans on the panel are basically powerless when it comes to tax legislation. They said in advance that they would vote against any measure to raise taxes, so Mr. Rostenkowski has excluded them and concentrated on drafting a measure that can win solid support from the Democrats on his committee. That means the real work has gone on in his private meeting with the other Democrats.
A politician from head to toe, Mr. Rostenkowski would never ask colleagues to cast votes that would seriously jeopardize their standing at home. On the other hand, he says his job is to persuade others that they must sometimes abandon parochial interests for the good of the President and the country.
"I tell them Clinton's our President, and we ought to do everything we can to support him," Mr. Rostenkowski said.
 
Forcing Their Hands
 An associate who has watched Mr. Rostenkowski manipulate legislation for years said his strategy was to push committee votes up against the weekend deadline to force the hand of the other lawmakers. "Part of the dynamic for him," the associate said, "is to have them hit the wall -- to say if we don't throw some of our constituent interests overboard now, the whole thing is going to crash."
The main issues under discussion today seemed to be how to allocate the fuel tax in a way that would win the most possible political support and how to arrange corporate taxes to encourage investment.
Mr. Rostenkowski said his preference was to set the corporate tax rate no higher than 35 percent, although he said he was not sure he had a consensus on the committee for that view. The rate is now 34 percent, and the Administration wants to raise it to 36 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Federated Net Aided By Controls

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The first-quarter results issued yesterday by Federated Department Stores Inc. demonstrated that attention to cost control could mitigate the impact of high markdowns and weak sales.
Federated's divisions, which consist of Abraham & Straus, Bloomingdale's, Burdines, Rich's and five other regional department store chains, were forced to take greater markdowns than planned in the quarter because severe weather and slowing sales threatened to clog inventories. But the company still managed a whopping 83.7 percent increase in profits before an extraordinary charge related to debt reduction, even though sales in stores open at least one year were less than planned. 
 The ability to clamp down on expenses has become the factor distinguishing winning retailers from the also-rans in the first quarter, when bad weather in most regions and increasing concerns about the economy slowed sales momentum.
Taking the special charge into account, Federated's net income in the first quarter increased 53.7 percent, to $18.2 million, from $11.8 million in the corresponding period last year. But sales inched up just 1.2 percent, to $1.59 billion from $1.57 billion.
 
Drop in Share Earnings
 Quarterly earnings per share fell to 14 cents from 15 cents because of a huge increase in the number of shares outstanding, which rose to about 126 million, from 80 million last year, because the company had its initial public offering in last year's second quarter.
Federated's stock climbed 87.5 cents yesterday, to $21.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
Comparatively, the company had few markdowns in the first quarter of last year, so it was up against a strong performance, analysts said.
"That this year, with markdowns and disappointing business, they have been able to do this shows a sign that they are tightening their belts," said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associate Inc., a retail consulting firm. "With that kind of streamlining, I think this company has a dynamic growth pattern ahead."
But Federated's executives were cautious about the future, even though the company said sales had picked up this month.
"Although there are encouraging signs that sales are improving with the warmer weather in early May, we are continuing to view the remainder of 1993 with caution, reflecting consumer uncertainties about the economy and the impact of future tax and health-care funding proposals coming out of Washington," said Allen I. Questrom, Federated's chairman and chief executive.
Kimberly Walin, a retail analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said that even if sales did not pick up dramatically, changes in the company's distribution processes and centralization of accounts payable functions should help Federated continue to pare its costs.

HEADLINE: House Panel Backs Clinton Student-Loan Plan

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
The House Education and Labor Committee today approved President Clinton's proposal to allow needy students to borrow directly from the Federal Government to pay for college.
In a voice vote, the panel resisted lobbying by the banking industry and agreed to replace the current guaranteed student-loan program, which is highly profitable for private banks. But the new direct lending approach still faces strong opposition in the House, and even higher hurdles in the Senate. 
 Proponents argue that replacing the program would each year save the Federal Government $2 billion paid to lenders for defaulted loans and other costs, and that this would translate into lower interest rates for student borrowers. They also say the new program would free students and their parents from the confusing paperwork required by the banks.
"We are shifting from an entitlement to banks to an entitlement for students," said Representative Robert E. Andrews, a New Jersey Democrat who is a leading proponent of the overhaul.
But some Republican opponents argue that the new loan arrangement could become an administrative burden for the Education Department, creating a new and expensive bureaucracy. Representative Steve Gunderson, Republican of Wisconsin, predicted that the Government would have to borrow $20 billion to create the program. He urged that a more modest pilot project be adopted.
 
'Smoke and Mirrors'
 "This is the kind of smoke and mirrors that attracts support for Ross Perot," Mr. Gunderson said.
Under the current system, the Government guarantees the loans extended by private lenders, and reimburses money that is defaulted. The Government also pays the private lenders interest on loans while students are still in school, at a rate of 3.1 percent above the 91-day Treasury bill rate.
The banks make more profits from student loans than they do from mortgages or automobile loans, President Clinton has said.
Under the Clinton proposal, the Government would provide colleges with the money to lend to students. Colleges that did not want to approve or collect the loans could contract such work out to private companies.
Bankers' groups have been lobbying vigorously against the legislation, arguing that private industry can serve the students more efficiently than the Government. Donald G. Ogilvie, executive vice president of the American Bankers Association, said, "We expect this plan to be just another failure in the Government's long history of taking over private enterprises."
In a visit to Illinois on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton depicted his plan as a matter of shaking up the Washington establishment. He took aim at the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, which buys student loans from banks, collects monthly payments and sells bonds secured by the loans to investors. Mr. Clinton accused Sallie Mae of hiring "seven of the most powerful lobbyists in Washington to try to stop this process from changing."
 
Resistance in Senate
 "There are a lot of people in Washington who want to keep the status quo," Mr. Clinton said.
A leading Democratic Senate strategist that Mr. Clinton would eventually be able to marshal enough support to enact the program. But there is resistance from a broad coalition of Senators. Some, like Senator Claiborne Pell, a Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Education, caution that the Government should first try a pilot project. Many Republicans are skeptical of taking a banking service from the private sector. And other Senators are sensitive to the argument from bank lobbyists that their states will lose banking jobs.
The student loan plan is part of a catch-all bill reconciling spending and taxes with deficit-reduction goals set by the Administration. The House Budget Committee requested that the panel make savings of $5.8 billion over five years, and the education committee believes that the new lending plan will save $4.3 billion.

HEADLINE: Shellshocked Island Has Had Enough of the Navy

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIEQUES, P.R.

 BODY:
When the Pentagon recently announced its list of 165 military bases to be completely or partly closed, people here were angry and disappointed. Despite their best efforts, the Navy "weapons training facility" that occupies two-thirds of this small island just east of Puerto Rico was not placed on the list.
While communities throughout the United States are fighting to persuade the Base Closure and Realignment Commission not to close local military bases, nothing would please the 8,000 residents of Vieques (pronounced vee-ECK-es) more than to be rid of the military presence here. 
 Since the 1940's, the Atlantic Fleet has been bombing and shelling the island and the waters around it as part of military training exercises conducted from Roosevelt Roads Naval Station just across the straits, and the local people want it to stop.
 
'A Beautiful Place'
 "We're in bad shape here," said Luis Antonio Medina, president of the local fishermen's association. "This is a beautiful place, and a lot of things could be developed here, but we have nothing because the Navy has taken everything that is worth anything. It's an injustice that we have been fighting for a long time without success, but now we think our time has come."
Mr. Medina and other community leaders complained that the Navy, by taking over the area in World War II, had closed more than 22,000 acres to settlement or construction of hotels or factories. By its action, they said, the Navy forced thousands of Vieques natives to move to New York, San Juan or the Virgin Islands. Those who remain, they said, are prevented from farming in fields their families once owned, or have had their favorite fishing grounds closed for security reasons or destroyed by errant shells.
"The Navy presence here signifies an ecological disaster," said Robert Rabin, director of the local museum and the island's historian. "Many of the bombs miss their mark and fall into the water, damaging reefs and wildlife."
Because of the military restrictions, only the middle third of Vieques is inhabited. The western side is a weapons storage depot, and the eastern end is used to carry out amphibious landing and parachuting exercises as well as what the Navy delicately calls "ordnance delivery from aircraft and surface ships."
Mr. Rabin said that several people had been maimed over the years from picking up unexploded hand grenades and ammunition and that a drone aircraft crashed in a school yard in the early 1970's. There were no injuries in that incident.
 
Sorties and Explosions
 The latest round of exercises, called "Ocean Venture 93" and involving 20,500 American troops plus British, Dutch and French forces, began on April 20 and will continue through May 24. Throughout the day, the tropical calm and stillness is disrupted by the sound of jet sorties and bomb explosions that reverberate throughout the island. Residents say napalm is also being dropped.
A Navy spokeswoman, Lieut. Beth Jones, said that while some Marine Corps units had used napalm in the past, it was her understanding that none was being used in the current exercise.
Rafael Rivera Castano, a retired professor of medicine who is the son of a former mayor of Vieques, said local people had for years been told that the military exercises here were a bulwark against Communism. Now, he said, with the Soviet bloc having disintegrated, "Cuba no longer a threat, the Sandinistas out of power in Nicaragua and Noriega gone from Panama, that argument is no longer convincing."
In a recent statement explaining its position, the Navy said that the thousands of square miles of uncongested air space and ocean around Vieques are the only areas in which the Atlantic Fleet operates that can "allow all warfare components to train together in a realistic, integrated scenario." All exercises, the statement added, "are carried out according to strict safety regulations" with an eye to "preserving the environment on Vieques."
The arguments of Vieques residents have not been received with much sympathy in San Juan, either. The last thing the commonwealth's pro-statehood government can afford is to lose another pillar of the economy. Congress appears likely to revoke a tax break for American companies operating in Puerto Rico that has created more than 100,000 jobs, and fears are growing about competition with Mexico if the North American Free Trade Agreement is signed.
Originally built to counter a Nazi threat in the Caribbean and the Atlantic, Roosevelt Roads Naval Station currently employs about 3,000 civilians and pumps more than $200 million into the Puerto Rican economy each year in the form of salaries, construction work and purchases of supplies and services. But only a minuscule amount of that spending reaches Vieques.
Since Hurricane Hugo blew through here in 1989, more than $100 million has been spent to repair and modernize the base, and 90 percent of the $70 million in contracts to be let this year are likely to go to Puerto Rican companies.
 
'Colony of a Colony'
 On Vieques, however, the Puerto Rican Government's stance merely reinforces feelings that the island is, as the saying here goes, "the colony of a colony," largely ignored or forgotten. "When the San Juan television stations give the weather on the news, they don't even show Vieques on the map," said Jenny Benitez, a local businesswoman.
A delegation drawn from members of the Committee to Rescue and Develop Vieques, the leading opposition to the base, is scheduled to go to Washington in mid-May to urge Congress and Clinton Administration officials to add Vieques to the final base-closing list to be announced this summer. Although the group would like to see all Navy land returned as soon as possible, their immediate focus is the western third of the island.
"They only use that land to store bombs that could just as easily be put on Pineros," a small, uninhabited island just off Roosevelt Roads, said Ismael Guadalupe, a schoolteacher and committee leader who has led opposition to the Navy's presence since the 1970's. "That is the most viable and practical solution."
Should those lobbying efforts fail, Mr. Guadalupe said, "We'd have to think about a court case."
But, he added: "At the moment, we have faith. Our fingers are crossed."

HEADLINE: G.E. Deal Will Help Save GPA

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 12

 BODY:
GPA Group P.L.C. said late today that it had reached a deal under which the General Electric Company will help the giant aircraft-leasing company avert financial collapse. As part of the deal, G.E. would acquire 45 planes from GPA for $1.35 billion.
GPA said the deal could lead to G.E. owning as much as 80 percent of the Irish company. 
 General Electric already has a plane-leasing operation and is one of the two largest builders of jet engines, along with Pratt & Whitney. Should it exercise its option under the deal to acquire control of GPA, General Electric would become an even more powerful force in the aircraft industry.
 
Should Placate Creditors
 The late-night announcement of the deal by the two companies came after weeks of intensive negotiations and should ease the immediate fears of the banks and bondholders that are owed $5.5 billion by GPA, as well as aircraft builders like the Boeing Company. GPA is among the world's largest buyers of commercial jetliners.
Although executives involved in the negotiations said GPA had not yet overcome all of its troubles, they said there were signs that the deal with General Electric's GE Capital subsidiary, based in Stamford, Conn., would lead the banks and existing shareholders to provide $250 million in additional financing. That money would be crucial to GPA's efforts to avoid defaulting on bond payments of $220 million due over the next six weeks.
GPA, which is based in Shannon, Ireland, is to hold a previously scheduled meeting with bondholders in New York on Thursday. In its statement tonight, GPA said that if it could complete a deal for the additional financing and win approval from its banks, it expected to make all the bond payments.
 
Stock Offering Failed
 The deal, which must be approved by GPA's private shareholders, would effectively end the company's efforts to remain independent after a dizzying yearlong plunge that began when an ambitious $1 billion public stock offering failed last summer and had to be canceled.
GPA has since had to cancel billions of dollars in aircraft orders, hurting the order books of manufacturers like Boeing, while scrambling to raise cash for debt payments. It sought fruitlessly over the last several months to piece together a deal with its banks and shareholders.
"We are pleased with this agreement with GE Capital, a company that understands our business and is committed to the aircraft industry," said Tony Ryan, GPA's founder and chairman. "If agreed, the closer long-term association we are discussing will create a powerful global alliance which will lead the aircraft leasing and financing industry."
The companies said they were discussing making GPA in effect a subsidiary of GE Capital, with GPA's current management staying on to manage GPA's leasing business. They said they expect to complete those negotiations within a few days.
Under the deal, GPA would retain an unspecified equity interest in the 45 plans that it would sell to GE Capital for $1.35 billion. Meanwhile, GE Capital would help GPA sell additional jetliners and their leases to investors, with a goal of raising another $2 billion, the companies said.
GPA has historically used such sales to investors to raise cash for further aircraft purchases. The company is the primary supplier of leased planes to airlines, and it owns 460 aircraft, which are on lease to 113 airlines in 52 countries.
In return, GE Capital would be granted an option to acquire an equity interest in GPA of at least 65 percent, with the percentage perhaps going as high as 80 percent. The companies declined to disclose the price at which G.E. would be able to buy the stake. GPA had sought to sell its shares for $20 a share in its aborted public offering last year, but recently has been unable to raise additional equity from current shareholders at $1 a share.
 
New Bank Loans Possible
 Executives involved in the negotiations said GPA's 138 bank lenders, led by Citibank, had indicated that they were willing to lend an additional $100 million to the company. Existing shareholders, which are primarily financial institutions and airlines around the world, have also indicated they are willing to provide another $150 million to the company in the form of convertible preferred shares, the executives said.
But the executives stressed that there was no guarantee that deals would be completed with the banks and the shareholders, who have been negotiating with GPA for months.
G.E. had owned a 22 percent stake in GPA in the early 1980's and tried unsuccessfuly at the time to buy the entire company before selling its stake at a substantial profit.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher As European Rates Decline

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday after European interest rates dropped while American rates showed signs of remaining firm.
"The rate cuts in Europe helped push the dollar higher today," said Paul Farrell, chief dealer at Chase Manhattan. Lower interest rates make investments in a country less attractive, diminishing demand for its currency. 
 The dollar began to rise in European trading after Germany's central bank lowered important money market rates. Central banks in Austria, Belgium and the Netherlands followed by lowering official lending rates.
The dollar was also helped by the Government's report that producer prices rose an unexpected six-tenths of a percent in April, the biggest gain in two and a half years. The prospect that inflation may be accelerating makes it unlikely the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates, which would undermine the dollar.
"After today's report, there's little chance that the Fed will ease rates," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan in New York.
Signs that some European central banks sold dollars for German marks capped the dollar's gains yesterday, traders said. The Bundesbank and others were said to be buying marks in preparation for a defense of the Spanish peseta, which has stumbled recently.
European central banks will need marks to sell for pesetas should the Spanish currency threaten to tumble out of the European Community's exchange rate mechanism, said John Nelson, chief dealer at Barclays Bank in New York.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.611 German marks, from 1.608 marks on Tuesday. The dollar was also quoted at 111.55 Japanese yen, up from 111.34 on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, the British pound fell to $1.5350, from $1.5412 late on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why the energy tax has turned into a political hard sell.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT was meant to be simple -- messy to administer, perhaps, but simple to sell to Congress. But now President Clinton's proposed levy on energy is in political trouble, and for reasons that apparently have a lot to do with the Administration's haste to raise maximum revenue with minimum political pain.
The President may yet be able to build a winning political coalition for the levy. But tinkering will not save Mr. Clinton from the interest group collision he hoped to avoid. 
 The reasoning behind the proposal, pieced together by analysts sympathetic to the Administration, went something like this:
Tens of billions of dollars would be needed to meet the President's budget goals, and there were limits to how much more could, or should, be squeezed from income taxes. Energy, by contrast, would make a fecund cash cow. And since overall consumption would not change much in response to modest price increases, producers would not squawk because they would be able to pass the tax through to users the way retailers pass on general sales taxes.
Besides, there would be brownie points to score with environmentalists, who never met a tax on fossil fuels they did not like. An energy levy might even take some wind out of Ross Perot's sails, since he favored a stiff gasoline tax.
The most neutral energy tax is one on the heat content of fuels -- a B.T.U. tax. But the tax really need not be neutral, the reasoning went, because coal and oil do more environmental damage per B.T.U emitted. The surcharge on coal did not survive: Coal was already scheduled to take a hit under the Clear Air Act of 1990, and coal-state Democrats served notice they would not sit still for another. But the surcharge on oil did, doubling the proposed tax per barrel. All told, the Administration estimated, the typical family would pay a mere $300 a year more to save the future from the debt sins of the fathers.
So what went wrong? Technical glitches, such as a loophole that would have given foreign oil refiners a cost advantage over domestic competitors, were easily plugged. And a few interest group objections, including the prohibition on listing the tax as a separate line on utility bills, were easily accommodated. But there was no comparable repair for the Administration's misconception that the tax would be spread so thin that no one would bother to make a Federal case of it.
Actually, gasoline does fit the Administration's model. Since the price of gasoline per B.T.U. is very high, the tax amounts to just 7 percent of the cost at the pump. And since there are no ready substitutes, consumers would no doubt hunker down and pay.
But the heavy heating oil used in industrial boilers is a different story. The price per B.T.U. is relatively low, so the tax amounts to a quarter of the current price. And unlike gasoline, heavy heating oil competes in the marketplace directly with natural gas and coal.
Indeed, notes Philip Verleger of the Institute for International Economics, many utilities routinely switch from fuel to fuel to save their customers a few pennies a month. And since the B.T.U. tax would add just 5 percent to the price of natural gas, heating oil producers would have to eat most of the cost to stay in the game. "It's a tax on heavy oil from California, Mexico and Venezuela," said Mr. Verleger -- one that ironically "works to the advantage of light oil producers including Libya and Algeria."
Or consider farmers, whose fuel-hungry machines make it possible for a single family to cultivate thousands of acres of grain. They could not pass through the extra tax to buyers because grain prices are set by world markets. Nor could long-haul truck drivers, who must compete for freight with far more energy-efficient railroads. Thus, even if the President muscles the bill through the House, he will face determined special interests in the more hostile Senate.
The easiest way out, says Larry Goldstein of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, would be to drop the surcharge on oil, perhaps recapturing the revenue with a higher rate on all fuels. That would disarm the interests most at risk from the tax on oil products.
A better way, Mr. Goldstein argues, would be to recognize the B.T.U. tax for what it is: a flawed method for raising a lot of money in a hurry. He would pass an energy levy now, with the proviso that within two years it be folded into a broad-based tax on consumption -- something on the order of a national sales tax or value-added tax.
Such a tax is probably in the works anyway, he notes, since the Administration will have to find $50 billion to $100 billion a year as a reliable source of revenue to cover the cost of national health insurance. The politics of the switch, of adding a percentage point or two to the consumption tax in order to jettison the B.T.U. tax would, at worst, be a wash.

HEADLINE: 'I Love Tourism': 3 States Try To Resume Luring Visitors

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 12

 BODY:
Fifteen years after New York tourism officials imprinted the phrase "I Love New York" on the nation's collective consciousness and "New Jersey and You" seemed so perfect together, efforts to promote the metropolitan region as a travel destination are emerging from their darkest hour.
New York and New Jersey, which had television promotion campaigns throughout the 1980's, went off the air in the early 1990's because of state budget cuts. Connecticut has not had an active statewide travel promotion for seven years, an eternity in building the kind of recognition that marketers say is needed to influence decisions on where to take a vacation. 
 But this spring, all three states are preparing to re-enter the tourist marketing fray. Connecticut has begun a $3 million television and print campaign -- its biggest ever -- with the eager phrase, "We're full of surprises!" aimed at weekend travelers from New York and New Jersey. New York, bolstered by a doubling of its promotion budget this year, is preparing a television campaign on its tried and true "I <heart> NY" theme for later this month. New Jersey officials hope to resume marketing out of state this summer with new money proposed by Gov. Jim Florio.
"It was about obliterated," said Stuart Schulman, an associate professor of travel and tourism at Kingsborough Community College in New York, who helped create the "I Love New York" campaign in the 1970's, then watched the effort dwindle. "Somehow the connection has been re-established that tourism is not fluff."
But much has changed, and in the patterns of tourism, since the heady days when everyone from Frank Sinatra to Thomas H. Kean and Susan St. James was pitching various corners of the Northeast. Even with the new resources, the efforts are a pallid reflection of past efforts. The $7 million committed to the "I Love New York," campaign this year, for example, is more than twice as much as the state spent last year. Just four years ago, however, the marketing budget was $15 million.
Across much of the region, the tourism and travel industry itself stagnated as the states were retrenching, but travel experts say the causes are more complex than the lack of a good sales pitch. Fewer business conventions and tighter corporate purse strings for business travelers, higher hotel taxes and limited household budgets in the recession all contributed, they say.
In New York State, traditionally the nation's No. 3 tourist destination after California and Florida, 40,000 travel industry jobs were lost in 1991, 8,000 in New York City alone, according to the state. Tourist visits and hotel occupancy rates have fallen in a wide swath through Westchester County and in northern New Jersey, which had thrived for years on corporate meetings located conveniently near golf courses.
 
Eras Come and Go
 Eras have come and gone as well. "Better Yet, Connecticut," for example, gave way to "Classic Connecticut," while "New Jersey's Got It!" begat "New Jersey and You," which begat "New Jersey, You Should See Us Now," the state's current slogan. Foreign tourists, lured by favorable exchange rates and falling political barriers, have become a bigger factor than ever.
Perhaps most important, tourism experts say, more and more Americans no longer take the kind of extended summer vacations they did even 10 or 15 years ago, instead taking short, often spontaneous trips, closer to home, often planned around a specific event or activity.
"Ten or 15 years ago, two weeks was the standard," said Ed Dombroskas, executive director of the tourism division at the Connecticut Department of Economic Development. "Five years ago, it went to a week. It's now three to four days. In the past few years, the economy has pressurized us all. We need more breaks."
But if shorter, closer-to-home vacations are the wave of the future, the next question for marketers is, What do these travelers want: relaxation or excitement? Leafy bucolic getaways or mini-adventures? And do vacationers, upon packing up the mini-van, really want "surprises," as Connecticut promises? Holiday Inn, to cite a contrary example, based its advertising for years on the opposite tack, promising travelers they would find "no surprises."
How short will the vacation of the future become if the trend toward abbreviation continues? In New Jersey, for instance, the number of tourist visits actually increased in 1992, rising to 136 million in 1992 from 127 million in the previous year. But a majority of the new visitors were what are known as "drive-throughs," who came for the day, then kept on going or went home. The number of such one-day visits rose from 110 million to 115 million, according to figures from the State Department of Commerce and Economic Development.
"Our overnight market is decreasing," said Eugene Dilbeck, the State Director of Travel and Tourism.
 
The Casino Factor
 In Connecticut, by contrast, travel experts say that tourism is increasing as perhaps never before, largely because of the Foxwoods Casino, which opened last year on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Reservation in Ledyard. The casino has drawn an average of 12,000 gamblers a day since it opened in February 1992, making it, almost overnight, the biggest tourist attraction in the state.
Travel and tourism was Connecticut's ninth largest employer in 1990, according to the most recent figures from Travel Industry Association of America, a trade group. In New Jersey, by contrast, travel was the third largest employer, while in New York, it was the second largest. In 37 states, it was the first, second, or third largest employer, according to the travel association.
"Connecticut is seen by many people as the thing you have to do to get from New York to Boston," said Lalia Rach, dean of the school of hotel, restaurant and tourism administration at the University of New Haven. "I don't think there is a well-defined image in the minds of consumers." Professor Rach praised the state's new commitment, especially the new dedicated fund for tourism promotion, using a $1-a-day tax on rental cars. But she said she thought more of the campaign should be broadcast within the state.
"You have to change the minds of the locals," she said. "Connecticut doesn't see itself as a destination."
Economic realities may change that. In the area around the casino, more than 1,000 hotel rooms are expected to be built by the end of this year, a 33 percent increase from the current 3,200 rooms. Casino officials say that about 50 percent of their customers are from out of state, mostly from Massachusetts and Rhode Island, but with about 15 percent from New York and New Jersey.
The tribe has also committed $1 million a year to a marketing campaign to push the New London County area, including television ads that began in the New York market last year. A new series of television spots for the casino and the region is to begin on New York stations this weekend.
In New York City, travel industry officials say they have been weakened by a 5 percent state tax imposed in 1990 on hotel rooms costing more than $100 a night. The tax has pushed the total hotel tax in the city, where almost every room costs more than $100, to 21.25 percent, the highest in the nation, and ignited a revolt among many tour operators and convention organizers.
Mayflower Tours of Downers Grove, Ill., for example, which brings about 25 tours a year to New York City, now uses hotels in New Jersey, partly because of the tax, the company's president, John Stachnik, said.
 
'Usurious' Tax
 The Professional Convention Management Association, a trade group for convention operators, formally recommended last year that its 3,100 members avoid New York until the tax is lifted. A spokesman for the organization, Roy B. Evans, said his members conduct about 125,000 meetings a year around the country, booking an average of 27 million room-nights a year.
"As long as that tax is at such a usurious level, we will not bring our meeting to New York," Mr. Evans said.
While New York State is taking to the airwaves again, its commercials will not focus solely on New York City, as they have in the past. Officials say that even with new money in the budget, there is not enough for a statewide campaign and a separate city campaign.
What will not change is the slogan. "I Love New York," they say, is here to stay.
The fact that "I Love New York" has endured, even as New Jersey and Connecticut have adopted new slogans, shows that New York may have stumbled on a deeper truth, beyond slogans, said Professor Donald E. Hawkins, director of the International Institute of Tourism Studies at George Washington University.
"I would call that the essence of authenticity," he said.

LENGTH: 342 words

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
New York Refinancing Correctional Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Strong investor demand and low interest rates continue to encourage bond refundings, in which proceeds are used to pay off bonds sold when rates were higher.
Taking advantage of the opportunity yesterday was the New York State Urban Development Corporation, which priced $670 million of correctional facilities revenue bonds through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. 
 Part of the financing was $523.6 million in correctional facilities revenue bonds, called the 1993 refunding series, initially priced to yield a maximum 6.04 percent for a bond due in 2015. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 5 percent in 1999 to 5.60 percent in 2004.
Among the bonds to be refunded with the proceeds of the offering are securities with interest rates of 7.50 percent to 8.125 percent.
Other long maturities in yesterday's offering were priced to yield 5.875 percent in 2007, 5.60 percent in 2012, 6.02 percent in 2013 and 5.65 percent in 2018.
Underwriters noted that the bond due in 2012 is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and that the bond due in 2018 is insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation. The insurance gives those securities a triple-A rating by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. All other maturities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.
The offering priced yesterday included $41.71 million in capital appreciation bonds. These securities pay no interest, but if held to maturity will yield 6.20 percent for issues due in 2008 to 2010.
 
Second Portion
 The second part of the refinancing was $105 million of correctional capital facilities revenue bonds, which were priced to yield a maximum 6.05 percent for a maturity in 2018. The shorter-maturity serial bonds were priced to yield from 3.25 percent in 1994 to 5.60 percent in 2004.
Long maturites in 2007 and 2013 were priced to yield 5.875 percent and 6.02 percent, respectively, with capital appreciation bonds due in 2008 through 2010 yielding 6.20 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Price of Gold Surges $4.50 On Prospects for Inflation

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Prices of precious and industrial metals surged yesterday after the Government reported that inflation on the producer level had risen six-tenths of 1 percent in April, its largest increase in two and a half years.
"Inflation is always a plus for gold and silver in particular, as well as for industrial metals," said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst at Prudential Securities. 
 Gold for June delivery jumped $4.50, to $361.80 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. July silver futures gained 11.9 cents, to $4.392 an ounce.
Analysts said yesterday's rally was also fueled by concerns that the surging Asian demand for gold would outstrip supplies. June gold futures have climbed $23.60 an ounce, or about 7 percent, in the last month.
"I think this would have happened without the increase in the P.P.I.," said Ian McDonald, vice president of the precious metals division at Credit Suisse in New York. "The writing was on the wall. There's a supply shortage at a time when interest rates are low and the stock market is floundering."
 
Copper in Rebound
 Copper futures, meanwhile, rebounded from the five-and-a-half- year lows set last week, on concern about coming labor negotiations at copper mines in Chile, the world's largest producer.
"There's the feeling the market bottomed out last week, just at the upper range of production costs, which is about 77 cents a pound for most of the major producers," Ms. Raptopoulos said.
July copper closed at 82.25 cents a pound, up 2.65 cents, at the Comex.
On other commodity markets, orange juice surged for the third straight session while energy futures slumped.
Orange juice for July delivery climbed to its highest price since October, settling at 105.60 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange, up 2.90 cents. Analysts said there was speculation that Brazilian orange juice processors would produce less juice and raise the prices of their exports.
Oil futures fell after reports that American refineries processed more crude oil last week. Crude oil for June delivery closed 14 cents lower at $20.20 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil for June delivery finished 0.77 cent lower at 55.14 cents a gallon and unleaded gasoline for June delivery finished 0.51 cent lower at 60.63 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Taxable and Tax-Free Funds Have Lower Yields in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were down in the latest week. Analysts said there appeared to be little chance that money market fund yields would rise or fall sharply soon.
IBC's Money Fund Report said yesterday that its latest survey showed tax-exempt money fund yields were down in the week ended Tuesday after a sharp rise the previous week. Yields were off an average 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, as investors moved $918 million into tax-free money funds, bringing total assets to $99.6 billion. 
 Money managers moved to lower the average days left to maturity of securities held in portfolios to 48, from 49.
IBC/Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt money market fund fell 5 basis points, to 1.96 percent, and the average seven-day simple yield fell a similar amount to 1.94 percent. Analysts said that over the last 30 days, the compounded yield was averaging 1.99 percent and the simple yield about 1.97 percent.
Yields may also be down because of continuing demand by investors for tax-exempt investments as a hedge against future tax increases. Such demand has put a premium on new issues, raising prices and lowering yields.
Without state and local taxes, the taxable-bond equivalent yield for the average seven-day yield was about 2.72 percent for investors in the 28 percent bracket and about 2.84 percent for those in the 31 percent bracket.
Among the tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, the Money Fund Report said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund was on top for the third consecutive week, continuing to be one of the better performers this year. The fund had a yield of 2.61 percent, down 3 basis points from the previous week.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for the Money Fund Report, said he did not see yields making any significant moves soon and that they would continued to bounce in a narrow range.
"Yesterday's disappointing Producer Price Index number was nowhere as ominous as it looked if you looked at it closely," Mr. Frank said. "While once more appearing that the Fed was going to move toward lowering short-term rates, this recent inflation news puts a damper on that speculation."
 
Taxable Funds
 For the week ended yesterday, the assets of taxable money market funds rose $3.7 billion, to $491.3 billion, with institutional funds accounting for $3.2 billion of the inflow, to a total $177.4 billion.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios was unchanged at 63 for the third consecutive week.
IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield on a taxable fund was down 3 basis points, to 2.62 percent, with the seven-day simple yield down the same amount, to 2.59 percent. The compounded average yield over 30 days was 2.65 percent, while the simple yield was 2.62 percent.
The top general-purpose fund in the most recent week and in the last month was the Dreyfus Basic Money Market fund, which reported a return of 3.44 percent, down a basis point from the previous week.
Meanwhile, banks, which compete directly with money market funds for investor cash, were offering a yield of 2.54 percent, or two basis points lower than in the previous week.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
As the Shelter World Turns

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
I AM looking at a 23-year-old shingled house by a pond in suburban Chicago, contemplating the meaning of zing. It is the presence of zing, "in all its colorful forms," Traditional Home magazine says, that makes this house such a joy to behold.
You would not have found the word zing in HG, a magazine that has long served as an urbane arbiter of taste. But throughout their history, home magazines have been a Rorschach test of American values. If the announcement of HG's closing and the rise of magazines like Traditional Home are any indication, Americans have grown weary of visual repartee. Forget cutting edge. They want zing. 
 Shelter magazines have grown up with America. Though they may seem fluffy (see "Soft Spots: Handmade pillows to cushion life's bumps" in Martha Stewart Living), they have historically reflected broad cultural shifts that transcend ad pages and other publishing concerns. In the early 1980's, the retooling of House and Garden, rechristened HG, and Metropolitan Home heralded the era of the Masters of the Universe a la "Bonfire of the Vanities."
Today, magazines like Traditional Home, which shun chrome and look to suburban Chicago and Tulsa, Okla., for inspiration, seem to reflect the generational shift in values symbolized by the 1992 Presidential election.
If Architectural Digest is like Nancy Reagan's gaze, cool and remote, the Traditional Homes of the world try to be as accessible as Bill Clinton's bear hugs. They feel our pain. They are Little Rock, not Santa Barbara or Kennebunkport. "Style isn't selling anymore," said Martha Stewart, ruminating on the crop of voyeuristic "dream books" that defined the 1980's. "The idea of looking has had its time."
The emphasis on traditional design and how-to stories about real people -- what House Beautiful's editor in chief, Louis Oliver Gropp, calls "the new realism" -- is in a sense a return to the shelter magazines of old, which taught women how to produce the perfect setting for the perfect American family. To John Mack Carter, the head of magazine development for the Hearst Corporation, the roll-up-your-sleeves orientation of today's magazines has resulted in the triumph of "the thumb print" over the coffee table.
The earliest shelter magazines, born in the 1880's, tried to ask, "What is home?" rather than, "What can I buy for it?" "People thought houses conveyed values," said Mary Corbin Sies, a historian at the University of Maryland. Houses were vehicles for the American democratic ideal.
Shelter magazines were also esthetic bibles and social instructors. Caroline Seebohm, who has written a biography of Conde Nast, says House and Garden was meant to do for interiors what Conde Nast had done with fashion: help the socially insecure, including the wives of railroad barons "who had huge houses on Fifth Avenue and didn't know what to do with them."
Home magazines' fortunes have always waxed and waned with the economy, foundering during World War I, for example, and booming after World War II. A 1955 edition of House and Garden was dedicated to "the over 1,600,000 young couples" who would marry that year and decorate their first home, aided by the magazine's yearly color proclamations.
The early 1980's were clearly a Zen moment for shelter magazines. In 1969, the Meredith Corporation issued a one-shot special-interest publication tailored to the post-collegiate bricks-and-boards crowd called Apartment Ideas: the Magazine of Better Apartment Living. In 1974, the magazine became Apartment Life. Apartment Life profiled bearded men in dashiki shirts playing the flute while building bookcases and sensitive-looking couples eating quiche together in bed.
In 1981, the magazine switched its name to Metropolitan Home and became a grown-up sophisticate enraptured with design. Like House and Garden, which also switched focus in that period, Met Home went off in pursuit of what William F. Bondlow Jr., House and Garden's publisher at the time, called the "movers and groovers." The groovers were equipped with discretionary income, education, a lust for the good life. The objects of their desire filled the dreamiest dream book of them all, Architectural Digest.
In the mid to late 80's, ad pages of high-end shelter magazines were as pumped up as their readers' biceps. Since the late 1980's, says William Kerr, executive vice president of Meredith, there has been "an equally great collapse."
Met Home fell prey to lackluster circulation growth and a standstill in the furniture industry, Mr. Kerr said. Meredith, based in Des Moines, recently sold Met Home to Hachette Publications, which owns two other shelter magazines, Elle Decor and Home, and has made Met Home a bimonthly.
But the reincarnated Met Home has lost the zeal and graphic punch of those heady days -- when innovative work by architects and designers was fueled by the economy and each month offered an endless, exhausting array of design trends.
Mr. Kerr thinks that high-style design magazines may have had their day. "Like Andy Warhol's 15 minutes, 'design' and 'style' were a hot subject five or six years ago, just as today 'family' is a hot subject," he said. "Home and family are a more enduring phenomenon."
Dorothy Kalins, Met Home's longtime editor in chief, observed: "We were breaking new ground, but maybe aging baby boomers don't want 'new' in their lives. They're putting their 2-year-olds to bed instead of shopping for Philippe Starck lamps."
Like voters rejecting trickle-down economics, shelter readers may have become fed up with a dream that was unattainable. As Barbara Caplan, a director of Yankelovich Partners, a market research concern that advises shelter magazines, said, "The new status is feeling good about yourself, feeling comfortable, realizing that all that stuff didn't bring happiness."
Ms. Kalins thinks readers still want shelter magazines. "Every life stage, whether it's having a baby or getting a divorce, demands a physical change in living space," she said.
Or as Eckart L. Guthe, Conde Nast's vice president for corporate research, put it, "The nostalgia quotient is up, and people are looking for things that are safe, with everlasting beauty, which are not banged around by fads."
Enter the new-old shelter magazine, designed to be "family friendly" in Mr. Kerr's words, a trend some are calling de-decorating. Under the editorship of Mr. Gropp, House Beautiful, has combined its how-to tradition with a breezy, unpreachy writing style. In recent issues, it has addressed the subject of environmentally sensitive architecture as well as propped rooms of Baker Furniture. Country Living, also published by Hearst, veers more toward Bed & Breakfast Adorable, with silhouetted roosters on the chandeliers.
Country Home, published by Meredith, deals in elegant nostalgia. Its three-and-a-half-year-old sister, Traditional Home (circulation already 675,000), is more upscale, geared to affluent suburban readers who want comfortable squishy sofas.
Perhaps the most heralded new arrival has been Martha Stewart Living, a bimonthly published by Time Publishing Inc. Ventures. It is a hybrid, a classy how-to magazine. Ms. Stewart's regular appearances on the "Today" show have helped establish a circulation of 725,000, fanned by the Martha wanna-be factor.
Ms. Stewart wants her readers to read the magazine the way they would a cookbook. The thinking is that although they can't afford a Peter Marino house, they want to stencil their walls as he does (an approach that melds "inspiration" with "information," said the publisher, Eric G. Thorkilsen). Of course, working parents may not have time to stencil, but the fantasy is there.
"Reagan took us through glitz and glamour," said Jean LemMon, who last week became editor in chief of Better Homes and Gardens (the largest, with a circulation of 7.6 million) after a seven-year stint at Country Home. "Now unemployment is high, jobs aren't secure. It means we're going to have to find ways to enjoy life that don't cost a lot of money -- puttering around the house or inviting friends over for a chili supper."
Chili suppers are not part of the picture at Architectural Digest, the imperious queen of shelter magazines. In its pages, which have changed little in recent years, decorators are stars and real people are nowhere to be found. But like the British royal family, even Architectural Digest, which has wafted over the scene like Glinda's bubble, may have to let the commoners in, taking in the occasionally quirky, like the English magazine World of Interiors, and perhaps a bit of irony.
The magazines exist in a moment in which Kaki Hockersmith, a little-known decorator from Little Rock, is redesigning the private quarters of the White House. "It's a sensible time," said John Mack Carter. "Rather than dreaming, people want things that work. They want knobs that work, houses that work."
In other words, the mandate for shelter magazines is not unlike the one given to Bill Clinton and the economy, with the same expectations and sense of frustration. It's the slipcovers, stupid.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:
Action movies deliver thrills on screen, and as Hollywood has discovered, they also make for a star-studded breed of interactive video game. Thanks to the multi-media compact disk, called CD-ROM, the Arnold Schwarzeneggers and Sylvester Stallones can jump into the contest, too.
"Real characters are better to interact with than those little green guys," said Peter Dille of Sony Imagesoft, which produces video games for the corporation that owns the Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star studios and Columbia Tri-Star Home Video. 
 The green characters are a reference to the video-game craze that came and went in the early 1980's. These days Mr. Dille's company and others like Sega and Electronic Arts, the world's largest interactive software producer, are developing advanced games with sound and graphics that one day might approximate the movies themselves.
Last year Sony released a game based on "Hook," with players advancing from level to level on a quest with Peter Pan. In the future there will be Sony games spun off from "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " and two coming films from Tri-Star and Columbia, "Cliffhanger," with Mr. Stallone, and "The Last Action Hero," with Mr. Schwarzenegger.
The 16-bit games, which can process more information on their wider data path, can be played on a Sega Genesis machine that has an attachment for reading the large-capacity compact disks, the CD-ROM. Like other video games, the new ones involve quests or missions that progress from one level of difficulty to the next. As with the old games, the object is to win, but CD-ROM games offer players more varied situations and options. The goal is a greater degree of reality and a higher level of entertainment.
"Games are fast and have a lot of moving characters," said Ellen Beth Van Buskirk of Sega, which will issue a game this summer tied to "Jurassic Park," the Steven Spielberg film that opens June 11. For games on disk, clips from the films can be used, but the action is less than full motion. Stars might appear to offer pointers or take part in some other way.
The aura of the film business has overtaken the game industry. Sega, for example, has built a $10 million studio in Redwood City, Calif., where film-trained graphics artists and technicians make all kinds of games, from sports to movie-related. For its movie games, Sega seeks ties with Hollywood. "We want to get in on the front end, see what kind of footage we can get," Ms. Van Buskirk said.
At Sony and other studios' own game divisions, the game makers have the advantage of being in the studio already. "We have early access to scripts and sets," Mr. Dille said.
In the planning stages are more powerful 32-bit games to be played on a new machine promised by 3DO of San Mateo, Calif. "The use of those extra 16 bits is to make the audio and video sound and look more like television than an interactive video game," said Stewart Bonn of Electronic Arts. In 32-bit games, he added, players might also be able to control the plot line.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
A River Runs Through It
1992. Columbia Tri-Star. $94.95. Laser disk, $39.95. 123 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.
 Robert Redford's reverent version of Norman Maclean's memoir about family and male ritual on the trout streams of Montana can follow the book only so far. With its handsome tableaux and sturdy characterizations, the film contributes a seriousness of purpose. Craig Sheffer is the scholarly and passive Maclean, with Brad Pitt as his livelier brother and Tom Skerritt as their stiff, austere father. An uncanny director of actors, Mr. Redford is able to convey the distances between men. But, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times, the film remains "more a homage to its source material than a work of comparable emotion or breadth."
 
Glengarry Glen Ross
1992. LIVE. $94.98. Laser disk, $34.95. 100 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
 It's crunch time in a Chicago real estate office where the most productive salesman will win a Cadillac Eldorado and the least successful will find himself on unemployment. Directed adeptly by James Foley, David Mamet's adaptation of his 1984 Broadway play ups the level of psychic desperation. With expanses of Florida scrub land to peddle in the kitchens of the unsuspecting, the smooth Ricky Roma (Al Pacino), the highest-powered of the sales crew, is off and running. The rest (Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin and Jonathan Pryce) are a sweaty bunch in a time of tight money and waffling clients. Using Mr. Mamet's gift for language. Mr. Foley delivers a "living film that preserves the claustrophobic nature of the original stage work" (Canby).
 
Ted and Venus
1991. Columbia Tri-Star. $89.95. Closed captioned. R.
 Ted (Bud Cort), a dissipated drifter, falls for Linda (Kim Adams), a pretty social worker he spies on the beach in Venice, Calif. With a courting technique that veers from dopey humor to obscene phone calls, Ted doesn't get very far. Still, Mr. Cort's film has an interesting cast (with Jim Brolin as a hard-drinking hipster and Gena Rowlands as Linda's mother) and "a vivid sense of the numerology, yoga classes and dulcimer lessons that color California beach life, circa 1974" (Janet Maslin).
 
Zentropa
1992. Touchstone. $94.95. Laser disk, $39.99. 112 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
 After the war a German-American pacifist (Jean-Marc Barr) goes to post-Nazi Germany to help out in the restoration. There he takes a job at a giant railway terminal called Zentropa and finds himself in a futuristic nightmare in which stony-faced crowds wander a bleak landscape. With this as its platform, Lars von Trier's film devotes itself to high-flown allusions to celebrated film technique, "becoming a sarcastic comic meditation about cinematic myth-making and the relationships between Hollywood, Europe and World War II" (Stephen Holden).
 
FROM YEARS PAST
 
The Feature Films
On the Best-Seller List
Of the 40 titles now on Billboard's best-seller list, 9 are feature films (the others falling into the animated, workout, music and Playboy and Penthouse categories). At No. 5 on the list, "Dances With Wolves" is the highest-ranking film. Here are the others.
THE MARK OF ZORRO (No. 17). Tyrone Power, Linda Darnell and Basil Rathbone star in Rouben Mamoulian's swashbuckler. 1940. Fox. $19.98. 93 minutes. No rating.

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks in Puerto Rico

 BODY:
Only infrequently, and then fitfully, do mainland Americans pay much attention to their offshore ward Puerto Rico. Many islanders now fear their vulnerable economy will be devastated by a Clinton Administration deficit reduction proposal. These fears could well be overblown, but 3.5 million Puerto Ricans are owed a better demonstration that Treasury Department mandarins have responsibly done their homework.
President Clinton has endorsed, and Congress is weighing, a Treasury proposal to amend Section 936 of the tax code that gives U.S. companies an exemption from Federal taxes on income earned in Puerto Rico. This tax break, which extends to interest on local bank deposits, is seen in Washington as an excessive giveaway whose prudent trimming can yield $7 billion over five years. 
 Treasury is doing its job in taking aim at all such long-encrusted tax breaks. But grievously, it has failed to spell out potential damage to an island where unemployment is 18 percent, or more than twice the mainland rate. Hence the outcry in Puerto Rico.
And thus the need for thorough hearings by the House Ways and Means Committee, as urged by Representative Charles Rangel of New York.
Puerto Ricans say that 110,000 islanders are employed by businesses benefiting from Section 936, or 70 percent of all manufacturing jobs. Treasury retorts that the chief beneficiaries have been capital-intensive pharmaceutical companies; it proposes a far less costly tax incentive related directly to payrolls. But Puerto Ricans insist that this would mean the loss of high-skill jobs and the flight of pharmaceuticals, either to Mexico or to Asian competitors.
One unanswered question is how much of this offshore wealth is recouped by parent companies on the mainland, without tangible benefit to islanders. Another is why Puerto Rico has not outgrown its dependence on a tax crutch. And a third is whether Section 936 has provided too generous a relocation subsidy to mainland companies.
These matters call for sensible responses. Amending Section 936 need not be devastating if more narrowly targeted incentives are formulated. But care is surely in order to prevent wanton damage to islanders, who for all their progress average an annual income of $6,200, or half that of Mississippi, the poorest of the 50 states.
Finally, a measure of extra fairness is owed to a territory acquired as war booty in 1898. Puerto Rico's inhabitants became citizens through conquest, not choice. A careful Ways and Means Committee hearing is the minimally decent obligation owed by a negligent landlord.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Kurdish Example

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Remember those gut-wrenching pictures two years ago of Kurdish villagers fleeing the wrath of the defeated Saddam Hussein, tearfully abandoning their homes, children freezing in the snow?
The nation's horror at the sight of that first televised exodus drove George Bush into doing what his advisers warned against: intervening in the complex internal affairs of Iraq, with all its ancient ethnic hatreds and vengeful savagery. U.S. air cover sealed off most of the Kurdish portion of northern Iraq, creating a haven for the targets of genocide. 
 Let's see how our intervention, so ardently derided by geo-pragmatists as prelude to some awful national "dismemberment," is working out.
Kurdish tribes and clans have stopped bickering and elected a parliament, forming a united front with Iraqi Shiites and Sunnis against Saddam.
Cooperating with Turkey to the north, where 10 million Kurds live, Pesh Merga fighters behind Massoud Barzani successfully took on the Marxist terrorist Kurds. This helps remove Turkish fears of a territorial threat from an autonomous region that might turn into an independent country called Kurdistan.
With about $50 million in U.S. farm equipment and seed grain, the nascent democracy has begun to feed and shelter its four million people. Two universities have been opened.
But the Kurds in the mountains are by no means out of the woods. Saddam has canceled the currency, sealed off crossing points and raised the price of produce to pull the food out of the Kurdish area. Life is hard; the freed Kurds need help; but they are no longer being wiped out.
Quietly, two weeks ago, a delegation of Kurds, Sunnis and Shiites including Massoud Barzani came to Washington. Accustomed to being shunted off to a third assistant nobody in the Bush Administration, they were received by Vice President Gore, Secretary of State Christopher and national security adviser Lake.
"We accept their verbal assurances," Mr. Barzani tells me, that the troubling Clinton desire to "depersonalize" the conflict with Saddam means only that any successor regime will be expected to comply fully with the cease-fire terms; that there is no chance for normalization with Saddam or a similar dictator; and that the U.S. seeks a democratic alternative to the present regime. (I'd like to see that in writing, but the "memcon" recording the policy is needlessly classified.)
Beyond the continuance of our air cover, what do the Kurds need to stay free and develop their nation? No U.S. troops. Only emergency economic aid of $150 million this year; and what they don't talk about publicly, antitank and antiaircraft weapons in case Saddam attacks and the world is afflicted with Bosnianitis.
And they need a way to get oil out of their ground. Although oil-rich Kirkuk, which will one day be the capital of Kurdistan, is still under Saddam's occupation, both Taqtaq and Zakho in Kurdish control cry out for mobile refineries. If State will get the U.N. to permit the needed suspension of the Iraqi sanctions, and will prevail on Turkey to allow overland transportation, the Kurds are confident financing can be found to begin making their region self-sufficient.
The soft-spoken Barzani, 46, son of the legendary Mullah Mustafa and father of eight, is not pushy; he observes the taboo about talking of independence; but on the urgent need for economic and diplomatic aid, even after all the top-level meetings in Washington, "I have no answers for my people."
The Kurds deserve answers. They are no longer ignored: Ray Bonner's on-the-scene reporting in The New Yorker, and Graham Fuller's analysis in the current Foreign Affairs, underscore the value of democratic movements in the Middle East. (Only the U.S. Army War College, Maj. Gen. William Stofft commanding, refuses to correct its infamous monograph that cast doubt on reports of the poison-gassing of the Kurds.)
The Kurdish view of Bosnia? "The West should act decisively to stop the war criminals," says Barzani, whose people were saved by the West from a war criminal. "And why don't the Arabs help? Not just because the people being killed are Muslims, but because they are human beings." He shakes his head. "If we had the force, we would use it against the Serbs."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Why Has New York City Just Recognized Small Businesses?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I found your May 3 report that New York City is looking to small businesses to provide jobs right on target. Though the Department of Business Services classifies 98 percent of all companies in New York as small shops, the city has fewer small businesses than in 1969. 
 In the 1980's, small businesses accounted for 75 percent of job growth nationwide; in this city, however, that figure was only 22 percent. Even more troublesome, small businesses grew by 4 percent in New York City in the 80's, compared with 24 percent across the country.
The vast majority of burdensome laws, regulations, taxes and conditions under which small-business owners operate these days explains why so many companies have flocked out of the metropolitan area.
That the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins is only now attempting to exploit New York City's potential as an incubator of new businesses and small businesses speaks volumes about government's misguided priorities.
 
JOSEPH J. PREVITE
President
Queens Chamber of Commerce
Long Island City, Queens, May 5, 1993

HEADLINE: Why Has New York City Just Recognized Small Businesses?;
A Role in Exports

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is to be hoped that those responsible for the new initiatives to alleviate small-business burdens in New York City (news article, May 3) will integrate their efforts with the New York State export finance program, formed just over a year ago by the State's Department of Economic Development and the private New York Business Development Corporation. 
 According to the Department of Commerce, New York State exports in 1992 were valued at $22.6 billion, supporting some 429,000 full-time job equivalents. The Bureau of Census reports that in many fields, small businesses export more per employee than larger companies. Small-business growth can reduce unemployment and increase tax revenues.
Export finance is essential if small businesses are to expand sales overseas, where payment is usually received weeks, even months, after shipment. The New York export finance program can help smaller companies get financing before and after shipment, without which exporters cannot compete in world markets.
Exporters abroad are supported by government financing. The United States company that limits its sales to the domestic market may soon find that market also lost to foreign competition.
 
ALBERT H. HAMILTON
Senior Associate
First Washington Associates
Arlington, Va., May 4, 1993
