HEADLINE: Trenton Names Auditor to Rule Newark Schools

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 13

 BODY:
The State Education Commissioner moved today to take fiscal control of the troubled Newark school system by appointing a special auditor to oversee its business and financial operations, with veto power over school board spending greater than $20,000.
The announcement by the Commissioner, Dr. Mary Lee Fitzgerald, came as she released a detailed report that she says documents chronic failings in the school system, a system that spends more per pupil than most poor urban areas in New Jersey and even many affluent suburban districts. 
 Newark's critics have said the system does not make good use of the money it has, but district officials say education spending alone cannot solve the problems of troubled urban children. Saying she was acting because of the report's conclusions, Dr. Fitzgerald ordered a review that could lead to a state takeover of the Newark system within the next year.
Even as Newark school officials charged at their own news briefing that the timing of today's actions was politically motivated, Superintendent Eugene C. Campbell said the district would cooperate fully with the auditor general, and he said the system welcomed state advice or assistance.
In announcing her decision, Dr. Fitzgerald received the personal support of Gov. Jim Florio, who attended the Commissioner's news conference at the Department of Education.
The Governor was clearly signaling that the state was serious about watching how the Newark schools use the $354 million in aid that pours in from Trenton each year. The appointment of the auditor today suggested that the state did not want to wait for another report before beginning to address long-term problems of substandard student achievement, high truancy, poor maintenance and spending on administrative and support staff that has turned the system into what some officials have described as a patronage mill.
 
'A Jobs Market'
 Dr. Elena Scambio, an assistant education commissioner who served as the first state-appointed superintendent in the Jersey City takeover, said a member of the external review panel put it best: "Newark is a jobs market disguised as a school system."
Amid local school officials' accusations that the government was grandstanding in a gubernatorial election year, Mr. Campbell offered a token of the district's good faith, sketching the broad outline of a plan to improve security and building maintenance, raise academic performance and provide more after-school programs. But he reiterated Newark school officials' complaint: that there is never enough money or help to deal with the problems of poor urban children. Including Federal, state and local money, the district's annual budget is $535 million.
Mayor Sharpe James, who has long opposed the nine-member elected Board of Education, called today for a coalition of groups to take corrective action. He urged members of his administration, the City Council, the school board, clergy and other community leaders to end fiscal abuse and political interference. He has refused to say explicitly whether he would accept a state takeover, asserting instead that he favors any proposal that can improve the schools.
 
3-Month Survey
 The conclusions of the report released today, a three-month-long survey of the system by a committee of 50 outside experts in education, business and management, also formed the basis for Dr. Fitzgerald's decision to order one final management review, which could serve as the blueprint for a takeover.
The review, called a comprehensive compliance investigation, will seek to determine the causes of problems identified in the report.
As part of the review process, Dr. Fitzgerald named Rebecca A. Doggett, director of the Office of Business and Job Opportunity for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to serve as auditor general. Such an office has existed since 1975, but today Dr. Fitzgerald said she would widen its scope and strength.
She also appointed Dr. Joseph Cappello, business administrator of the Clifton, N.J., school district, as assistant auditor general. Three other auditors will join their staff within the week, all working out of board headquarters in Newark.
Eventually, 12 officials from the Department of Education will form an evaluation team, and the state will seeks bids from professional consultants and auditing firms to conduct an independent management review of the system.
 
2 Previous Takeovers
 Should the state eventually intervene, it would dismiss the district's top administrators, including the superintendent and the elected nine-member school board, and replace them with state appointees for at least five years.
A state takeover of the Newark district -- with 50,000 students, the state's largest -- would be the third in New Jersey since legislation authorizing takeovers was adopted in 1988. The state's second- and third-largest districts, Jersey City and Paterson, were taken over in 1989 and 1991, respectively.
Since then budget constraints delayed Trenton's efforts to focus on the state's largest district.
But last fall the state reviewed a 1987 report evaluating how Newark had addressed problems identified in a 1984 assessment. An updated report from a review panel appointed last December reached the Commissioner in mid-April.
The report released today documents failings in finance, management, buildings and educational programs in an urban district whose problems, the report said, are similar to those of every large urban school district: declining population, declining job base, an exodus of middle- and high-income residents and a rise in family and child poverty.
 
Panel Finds Link
 As a result the school district has become one of the few repositories for jobs and power in Newark. William H. Tremayne, senior vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company and co-chairman of the external review panel, said the committee repeatedly identified a strength-sapping link between jobs, money and education.
There was often more money available for those who were failing, he said, than those who were achieving. The reason, Mr. Tremayne said, was that more Government funds are customarily available for remedial programs, and more funds mean more jobs. As a result, he said, "overall aspiration levels were based too low."
"Too many programs seem to have been created and expanded to chase monies available from other levels of government," the report said, "without thought as to whether it is in the best interest of the children. Therefore, we seen an overemphasis on running basic skills programs, rather than on getting children successfully out of them."
The report identified 225 areas in need of improvement, Mr. Tremayne said. The panel found numerous bookkeeping inefficiencies that led to late financial reports and poor inventory accounting. It found that no interest was received on payroll or construction accounts, that no written cash-flow or cash-management plan exists and that no investment reports are given to the board.
In one instance, the report found that $536,000 is budgeted as the annual contribution to the unemployment trust fund but that the fund does not need the money because contributions and interest far exceed claims.
The panel's subcommittee on buildings found that 92 percent of the schools had ceilings, walls or floors with holes, sags, damage or other hazards. And while maintenance projects are enormously costly, particularly since 70 percent of the buildings were built before 1950 (30 percent before 1890), tens of millions of dollars already budgeted and on hand have never been spent.
The panel also took issue with hiring practices. The study pointed out that Hispanic residents, who account for 26 percent of the system's enrollment, are not similarly represented among the system's employees.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Power Built on Poverty: One Man's Odyssey

SERIES: The Baron Of the Bronx: First of two articles.

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZwith MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
Through a network of nonprofit organizations, Ramon S. Velez has long dominated the antipoverty programs of the most downtrodden part of the South Bronx, America's symbol of urban poverty and powerlessness.
In no small part because of his social-service work, he is also a millionaire. 
 Mr. Velez holds no public office; aside from a few years on the City Council, he has been a notably unsuccessful candidate. But for a quarter-century, he has reigned as the political baron of the South Bronx. He has practically written the book on how to seize power and use it in an impoverished neighborhood, how to pull the interlocking levers of social services, politics and personal gain.
 
Interlocking Relationships
 Mr. Velez's nonprofit empire, for instance, operates an alcoholism clinic and a health center. Yet his personal ventures include a one-man consulting firm that landed a $150,000 contract to promote Puerto Rican rum, and a development company that leases space to the health center for a rent that Federal officials have called excessive.
And as scores of photos and warm letters that cover his office wall attest, he has put his political clout behind an eclectic gallery of candidates -- from Jimmy Carter to Ronald Reagan to Jesse Jackson, from John V. Lindsay to Abraham D. Beame to Edward I. Koch.
Mr. Velez's interlocking business relationships and political pirouettes, glued together by a network of allies and relatives that amounts to a patronage system, have made him a perennial target of investigations, not to mention questions about whether his self-interest supersedes his commitment to the poor. In several cases over the years, government reports and audits have faulted programs run by him or his allies for inferior service, high costs or not serving enough people. As a result, several programs had funds cut off.
Mr. Velez considers it a point of pride that, despite what he estimates have been a hundred investigations of his finances and programs, none has led to indictments. Indeed, he has managed to accomplish a feat that has eluded almost all of his cohorts in the battle for antipoverty money and community power: at the age of 60, with controversy flaring at every side, he has survived and prospered.
 
Political Cunning and Muscle
 How Mr. Velez has accomplished this, to the point where next month he will proudly stride down Fifth Avenue before a million and a half people at the head of the Puerto Rican Day Parade, is a story of political cunning and muscle -- and, some contend, bare-knuckle bullying. It is a testament to how well he understood the potential for turning his community organizations, originally financed as 60's antipoverty pilot programs, into a political and economic force.
Time and again, his ability to switch political allegiances has resulted in continued contracts and funds for his antipoverty programs. In turn, he has used those programs as a source of campaign workers and as conduits for lucrative consulting and business contracts with companies he and his allies own. On Election Day, his machine can turn out a few thousand votes for the right candidate.
Today, Mr. Velez points to an operation that, through himself, his family and his close associates, provides social services to thousands of people daily.
"Look to the 70's and those who got millions," he said recently, crossing his wrists in the manner of a prisoner in handcuffs. "A lot are in jail or dead; the only one who is here is me.
"The others disappeared because they didn't plan. They saw it as something transitory, not permanent. I saw it as something permanent and effective for people in human services and politics."
 
A Penchant for Profit
Private Enterprise Mixes With Public
But while Mr. Velez says this reflects his persistence, organizing, and commitment to the poor, others see something else.
They point to such things as Mr. Velez's personal wealth. According to a financial statement prepared in 1988, he owned more than a dozen properties, including numerous condominiums in San Juan's upscale Condado district, another parcel in Puerto Rico where he planned to build luxury housing, and farmland in upstate New York. He had also amassed more than $1 million in pensions and annuities and claimed an annual gross income of $290,897, much of it from his private businesses that had dealings with related nonprofit groups.
"Maybe he doesn't break the law, maybe he bends it," said the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, whose relations with Mr. Velez have often been stormy. "Maybe it's flexible in his hands."
The Velez empire extends in many directions:
*Mr. Velez's flagship nonprofit corporation, the Hunts Point Multi-Service Center, Inc., spawned a series of organizations and programs that by his estimate have attracted $300 million in government funds over a quarter-century for programs involving health care, housing, drug treatment, day care, and services for the elderly. Today, the center has an annual budget of nearly $11 million and employs 250 people.
*The nonprofit South Bronx Community Management Corporation, which Mr. Velez once headed and which is now run by his son, Ramon Jr., manages 56 government-subsidized apartment buildings with 135 employees and an annual budget of $14 million, according to its director of housing. A subsidiary owns a profit-making company that provides data processing for the Hunts Point center and is run by a long-time Velez associate.
*Mr. Velez is also chairman of two manufacturing companies operated by a subsidiary of a nonprofit spinoff group, including one that pleaded guilty to bid-rigging and was barred from Federal work for three years. Mr. Velez said he had no knowledge of the illegal activity before it was uncovered by a Federal investigation.
*Close friends and allies of Mr. Velez hold key positions on the community advisory board of Lincoln Hospital and in a nonprofit home-care program with 400 employees. At times Mr. Velez has also wielded his influence over several other community boards and organizations, including the troubled boards of Community School Districts 7 and 12.
*Mr. Velez heads a development company and a consulting firm that together have received more than $1 million in contracts from nonprofit groups with which he has connections.
Conflict-of-interest rules vary from agency to agency, contract to contract, but at a minimum they require the disclosure of Mr. Velez's interests in enterprises that do business with his nonprofit agencies. In recent months, the City Comptroller and the State Health Department have each held up funds for the Hunts Point Multi-Service Center while they untangle Mr. Velez's web of business interests and see how they relate to the nonprofit corporation.
The Health Department intends to question him about his failure to disclose that he serves as president of the company that owns the building that houses the Hunts Point health clinic, said Peter Slocum, a department spokesman.
The Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, has objected to the renewal of any contracts with the Hunts Point center because, in 1991, Mr. Velez failed to disclose his involvement with four businesses, including one with the subsidiary that pleaded guilty to bid-rigging on Federal contracts. Mr. Velez says his lack of disclosure was, at most, an oversight and was not required anyway.
 
Adequate, Not Outstanding
 Beyond this, according to former Representative Herman Badillo, perhaps Mr. Velez's most persistent critic, is the sense that the programs provided by his social-service empire are adequate, but little more.
"The legacy has not been good," he said. "Look at evaluations over a 30-year period and you will find no outstanding pilot programs having been developed, no outstanding people coming out of this.
"The Hunts Point Multi-Service Center is there, but it's not outstanding. It doesn't have top people there. It's a mediocre thing."
 
Growth of an Organizer
From Farm Boy To Social Worker
Mr. Velez, an ample, agile-minded man, grew up the son of a farmer in the small Puerto Rican town of Hormigueros, outside Mayaguez. He came to the Bronx at 28. After a stint as a social worker, during which he says he was overwhelmed by the social ills and political powerlessness of his countrymen, he used his skills as an organizer to take control of chunks of Great Society money for groups he controlled.
Battles over these funds sometimes spilled into the street. In August 1969, a brawl over the division of $3 million in antipoverty funds ended with a car running down Edwin Rivera, a man identified by the police as an opponent of Mr. Velez. Three Velez allies were arrested on charges of murder, but the charges were dropped.
Bad feelings over the incident still linger in the Bronx, and over the years there have been repeated allegations of violence associated with Mr. Velez's operations. Veterans of Mr. Badillo's successful Congressional campaigns against Mr. Velez in the 1970's charge that some Velez campaign workers shot at them and vandalized their offices. Last year, the head of a Bronx group that distributes antipoverty money claimed Mr. Velez had put him in a headlock when the group voted to stop financing an organization run by Mr. Velez's ex-wife, whom Mr. Velez says he is planning to remarry.
In fact, the only crime he was ever charged with was assaulting a Village Voice reporter in Puerto Rico; he was acquitted.
 
Stories Spread by Opponents
 Mr. Velez says stories of violence were spread by political opponents or that, as in the case of the confrontation over funds to his wife's organization, his actions were in part provoked by personal attacks on close family members.
"I'm always for compromise," he said. "I gain nothing by fighting."
Even Mr. Velez's foes acknowledge that he has always been able to marshal cadres of campaign workers from the staffs of his agencies, and to turn out votes from the recipients of those agencies' social services.
"He ultimately has to take responsibility for getting the majority of our existing Latino elected officials into office in the Bronx," said Marlene Cintron, who heads Mayor David N. Dinkins' Office of Latino Affairs. "He did that with his machine and all of the housing projects that he developed through the years."
Early support came from Republicans like Mr. Lindsay and Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. But when Mr. Beame was elected on the shoulders of the Democratic machine, Mr. Velez became a cog in the Bronx organization and an influential ally of the former boss, Stanley Friedman. Contracts flowed.
 
Delivering for Establishment
 To John Mollenkopf, a political science professor at the City University Graduate Center and the author of a recent book on the mayoralty of Edward I. Koch, the key to Mr. Velez's success was an understanding of how antipoverty politics would play in New York.
"Instead of the leader of the antipoverty organization representingconstituents to people higher up in the political establishment," he said, "he became an agent for control of his clients on behalf of people higher up in the establishment."
Although Government funds for Mr. Velez's programs were frequently halted early in the tenure of Mr. Koch, who had assailed Mr. Velez as a "poverty pimp," they resumed within a few years.
In a recent interview, Mr. Koch said he had valued Mr. Velez's political support. "I'd rather have him on my side than against me," he said. "He's out in the street, and he campaigns."
Beyond this, he added, "I like him." He said he had reversed his earlier opinion because, "I always heard that he was dishonest, but every time the story was checked, it turned out that he was honest."
Calling back later, Mr. Koch added, "He is not a paragon. He wouldn't tell you that he is. I am not swearing for his integrity, but I know of nothing that reflects adversely."
 
Poor Management Charged
 Over the years, though, many of Mr. Velez's groups have been investigated and lost funds or government contracts because of poor management, questionable finances and the awarding of no-bid contracts. Mr. Velez himself was barred from participating in the Puerto Rican Day Parade for a decade after the State Attorney General's office questioned its financial practices. Mr. Velez was permitted to return to the parade after claims against him were dismissed in a later suit.
None of this was more than a rock diverting the stream of government money. To Mr. Velez and his supporters, that is evidence that the charges were the work of political opponents. To Edward Logue, the urban planner named by Mr. Koch to run a rebuilding effort in the South Bronx in the 70's, they indicated something else.
"I thought the empire never got the scrutiny it deserved," said Mr. Logue. "Nobody ever monitored it."
Susan E. Shepard, the city's Investigation Commissioner, said that the monitoring of agencies like Mr. Velez's is a growing problem, as nonprofit groups take on a greater social-service role. Last year, the city awarded 4,000 contracts worth $2.8 billion to community groups.
And since they are not subject to many of the background checks and ethics provisions that apply to government agencies, she said, "there are thousands of employees administering public funds without some of the safeguards we rely on."
 
Profit From Poverty
 The elaborate web of public and private enterprises is the underpinning of the Velez empire.
Between 1987 and 1990, according to Paul Bleifer, Mr. Velez's lawyer, Ravel Associates, a one-man consulting firm owned by Mr. Velez, received $900,000 in fees from South Bronx Community Management, now run by Ramon Velez Jr.
When asked what services he performed in 1988 when he was paid $235,000 -- and when his son and ex-wife were paid $123,601 as corporate officers -- Mr. Velez could not recall.
"Whatever it was, it was a good investment," he said.
He also serves as president of the Don Pancho Development Corporation, which owns the cramped four-story building that houses the Hunts Point Multi-Service Health Clinic. Hunts Point pays Don Pancho $99,000 a year in rent, a figure the Federal Government criticized as excessive. Mr. Bleifer, who is also the attorney for Hunts Point and Don Pancho, said the rent had been negotiated by the city and has not been raised since Don Pancho purchased the building in 1987.
Don Pancho also has the maintenance contract for South Bronx Community Management's largest development, the 340-unit O.U.B. Houses, Mr. Velez said.
 
Accusations of Self-Dealing
 The accusations of self-dealing within the Velez empire concern contracts large and small. In 1990, Mr. Velez's brother Paco, whom he had installed as head of the Ruth Fernandez Family Shelter, was dismissed after the city's Department of Investigation found that the shelter had improperly bought 10 mattresses manufactured by Paco Velez's private company, Mattresses Paco.
That same year, a major data-processing contract led to a conflict between public and profit-making interests. Bronx Computing Systems and Service, a profit-making subsidiary of South Bronx Community Management that is operated by an old Velez ally, handles data processing for the management company and Hunts Point; they are its only clients.
When it learned that Bronx Computing had been hired without competitive bidding by the Hunts Point methadone program, the State Division of Substance Abuse Services demanded that the group solicit other vendors or risk losing about $100,000 in support. The state already had been faulting the company for high costs and poor service.
Another company then submitted a bid that could have saved Hunts Point about $200,000 over 10 years, according to the Division of Substance Abuse Services. But Hunts Point stuck with Bronx Computing, walking away from the state money.
Mr. Velez said that he had wanted to keep jobs in the South Bronx, and that the other vendor would have saddled the methadone clinic with obsolete equipment.
But the state agency saw it differently. "When you run programs and try to pinch pennies and balance budgets, $100,000 is no small change," said Michael Melendez, a spokesman. "What they said to us is, 'We don't need your rules and regulations.' "
 
Stepping Back
'The Musclemen Are Getting Old'
These days, Mr. Velez says he sees himself removed from the political fray. "My time for politics is gone," he said.
Mr. Ferrer agrees, saying, "The musclemen are getting old, getting arthritis, heart attacks."
In the last year, such erstwhile adversaries as State Senator Pedro Espada and Councilwoman Lucy Cruz have begun to carve out niches in once-forbidden territory.
Even as much of the government money continues to flow, the Dinkins administration has been careful to keep its distance from Mr. Velez, at least publicly; top campaign officials say they have nothing to do with him. One senior administration official said that, these days, the political cost of a relationship with Mr. Velez outweighs the benefits of his clout.
Mr. Velez, however, has been counted out many times before. He says he expects to hear from the campaigns of all the mayoral candidates. Indeed, says Mr. Ferrer, what may be Mr. Velez's strongest suit politically these days is the lingering aura of power.
"If you perceive he has power, he's a powerful person," he said.
One recent afternoon, sitting back amid a lifetime's worth of political mementos, Mr. Velez gestured to a new addition -- an orange pennant from the Clinton-Gore inauguration.
Eyes flashing, he leaned forward and gave a thumbs-up sign.
Next: The rise and fall of a community health clinic.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1039 words

HEADLINE: New Jump in Inflation Rattles Markets;
Consumer Prices Rose 0.4% in April In Broad Increase

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A spurt in consumer prices last month, coming right after a surge in producer prices, increased concerns that inflation may indeed be creeping back, even though economic growth remains modest.
The Consumer Prices Index jumped four-tenths of a percent in April, the Labor Department reported yesterday. That was twice as much as many forecasters had predicted. The rise was pervasive, reflecting price increases in most of the goods and services Americans use every day. 
 The increase lifted gold prices and led many forecasters to raise their inflation predictions. It also unsettled the bond and stock markets. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 34.32 points. [Page D6.]
The figures were widely viewed as dashing expectations that inflation this year would be lower than last year, as well as any lingering hopes that the Federal Reserve would push interest rates further down.
 
Above Expectations, Again
 What bothered many analysts was not just the April jump, but the fact that three of the last four reports on consumer prices were higher than expected. The index has been climbing at a 4.3 percent annual rate so far this year, well above last year's 2.9 percent increase; the measure that excludes volatile food and energy prices has been rising at an even faster 4.5 percent annual rate.
"The inflation rate has bottomed out." said Joel Popkin, president of Joel Popkin & Company in Washington. Mr. Popkin has said for several months that the Fed's expectation of further gains on the inflation front this year was overly optimistic and that inflation would be a bit higher this year than last.
That could complicate matters for the Clinton Administration, which has been counting on lower long-term interest rates to offset the drag higher taxes would have on the economy.
But Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, held out hope for relief in coming months. "I'm not dismayed," she said. "It's hard to accept two or three months as evidence of a fundamental change in the trend."
President Clinton hit much the same note. "There is no -- at the present time -- no cause for long-term concern," he said. "It could be just a blip."
The unsettling inflation report stole the limelight from several reassuring economic reports yesterday. Jobless claims ticked down a bit in the latest week, while consumers spent more freely in April, especially on cars, after staying away from stores in March. Auto producers also reported that sales were strong in the first 10 days of May.
The inflation report pushed up interest rates generally and seemed to leave the Fed with less maneuvering room to respond to the slow-growing economy.
"The C.P.I. report would certainly foreclose any Fed easing in the near future," said William Poole, a monetary economist at Brown University.
"It's a classic dilemma," he added. "If we pay attention to the soft economy, we'd say monetary policy should ease. If we look at the inflation numbers, we might say the Fed should tighten a little."
 
No Quick Shift Expected
 Still, several analysts said the next crop of inflation reports is likely to be a little less grim than those from this winter and spring, and they suggested that the Federal Reserve, whose monetary policy committee meets next Tuesday, would probably wait before shifting toward tighter money.
The Fed said as recently as February that it expected inflation for this year to come in well below 3 percent. Now some economists are raising their forecasts to about 3.5 percent.
"Inflation is a little above where the Fed would like, and growth is a little weaker than the Fed would like," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Securities. "All in all, the Fed is on hold."
One negative for economists was that April's price increases were so ubiquitous.
"One doesn't want to make too much out of one month's data," said Patrick C. Jackman of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, "but the rise in the C.P.I. is not due to special factors, and it's pretty pervasive."
In six of the seven categories of goods and services that make up the Consumer Price Index, prices rose more in April than they increased in March. The only exception was a catch-all category that includes tobacco and education. A 3.5 percent rise in meat and vegetable prices was probably weather-related. A jump in hospital rates pushed up the price of medical care at an annual rate of more than a 7 percent. Car prices, which typically come down in the spring as dealers start discounting models, rose instead.
But most of the pick up in the inflation rate from March to April reflected higher housing costs -- both for renters and homeowners -- and firmer clothing prices, which had been falling.
 
Higher Prices, Modest Growth
 What could make inflation creep up in an economic expansion that has been sufficiently modest to keep the unemployment rate at 7 percent? Three things, economists say.
First, the economy's supply capacity may be smaller than thought. "There are signs that the long period of slow growth had an impact on supply," Mr. Popkin said, pointing to companies downsizing and shutting plants in four or five years of slow growth. "The effect is to reduce supply."
Second, productivity growth, which was stronger last year than in any year since 1972, will inevitably slow this year. That means that unit labor costs, a good indicator of basic inflation trends, are likely to rise a bit faster.
Finally, the Fed, while not overly easy, has supplied plenty of liquidity in recent quarters, judging by the rapid growth of bank reserves and currency in circulation, the relatively weak dollar and the large spread between short- and long-term interest rates.
The 1.2 percent rebound in retail sales in April suggested that consumers have not totally lost faith in the economic expansion and that a large part of the eight-tenths of a percent drop in sales in March did reflect the weather. Nonetheless, spending is still barely higher than December's level, and the outlook is for merely modest gains.
On the employment front, applications for unemployment insurance edged down by 3,000, to 339,000. But the four-week average still ticked up to 345,075.

HEADLINE: NATO Adrift? Allies Worry Over Bosnia Impasse

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's impasse with the European allies on military steps in the Balkans and subsequent indecision have left senior NATO officials feeling leaderless at a time when the alliance is struggling to find a new purpose.
Having failed to persuade the Europeans of the need to arm Bosnian Muslims and bomb Serbian targets, President Clinton has now discarded that option but given American officials no guidance on what to plan for instead, NATO and American officials say. 
 The United States and its allies appear to be heading toward a decision to do little about the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina other than to quarantine it by monitoring operations in an effort to keep the war from spreading.
Both European and United States officials acknowledge that this would be a major confession of failure, one that many of them ascribe to an absence of American leadership by two Administrations.
President Clinton's statement on Tuesday that he was considering sending American troops to Macedonia to aid peacekeeping forces there seemed to be an answer to European suggestions that if the United States wanted to lead the alliance into more effective action, it would have to become a player on the ground.
"It came as a surprise," said Fraser Cameron, a European Community official. "It is not an answer to what to do in Bosnia."
A senior NATO military official said that there was no overall strategy behind the suggestion, and that the President of Macedonia had recently told the alliance that he thought the 444 Scandinavian troops that were there now as observers were enough.
But the lack of an American military stake in the region has hampered the Clinton Administration's ability to get the allies who do have troops there -- France and Britain, principally -- to follow Washington's lead in dealing with the conflict. The result is a crisis that many NATO leaders fear could lead to permanent damage to the alliance's credibility, and to United States interests in Europe.
"We're in the woods," an American official at the alliance's headquarters here acknowledged. "I hope we'll get out soon."
This will not happen unless the United States leaves the allies in no doubt about how it sees its objectives in the Balkans, many diplomats believe.
That Europe itself has failed to address the crisis is something nobody here disputes.
"We are all looking to the United States to take the lead again," said Willem van Eekelen, secretary general of the Western European Union, a nine-nation military organization. "Our European credibility has fallen very low."
 
Did NATO Lose Opportunity?
 Morale is also low at NATO's military headquarters at Mons, south of Brussels, officers of the alliance say.
Searching for a new role now that the military threat from the former Soviet Union has largely collapsed, officers at the military headquarters say NATO may have missed its chance.
As many NATO officers see it, the Bosnian Serb forces have called their bluff. The failure of nerve is all the more galling to some because the alliance strategy adopted in Rome in November of 1991 said that with the Soviet threat gone, risks to allied security were more likely to arise from "the serious economic, social and political difficulties, including ethnic rivalries and territorial disputes, which are faced by many countries in Central and Eastern Europe."
When just such a crisis arose in Bosnia and Herzegovina, NATO showed itself to be ineffectual, many officers say. Some suggest that it would not have been if the United States had committed ground forces to United Nations missions in Croatia and Bosnia, as its European allies have already done.
 
U.S. Troops in Bosnia?
 Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator on Bosnia, has suggested that the United States should join its European allies in providing support on the ground, not just from the skies, for United Nations aid missions in Bosnia. And on Monday, European Community foreign ministers said they would welcome both American and Russian personnel in eventual international supervision of safe areas for civilian refugees and of the border between Bosnia and Serbia.
An American stake cannot be established if Washington is willing to become involved only by bombing Serbian artillery positions from the air, the European allies believe. If the United States committed troops to the United Nations relief and peacekeeping forces already in Bosnia and Croatia, officials here say, it might have much more leverage on its overseas partners.
With American troops on the ground, these Europeans believe, Washington would also be more sensitive to concerns that radical intervention like bombing could expose lightly armed peacekeeping forces to Serb retaliation and make them into hostages.
Even the French, who insist that any Western military intervention should be carried out under the authority and command of the United Nations rather than NATO, acknowledge that if the United States assumes a leading military role in the Balkans, it could do so only through the alliance.
"If the Americans want a large role on the ground in Yugoslavia, it will have to be done through NATO," an alliance official said. "The real divide is over what the course of action should be. Should the alliance take sides, by helping the Muslims roll back the Serbs with bombing, or should it come in only to help enforce a peace after the warring parties agree on one?"
A senior NATO official said that a military force sent in to enforce the peace agreement would probably require 70,000 troops.
At least 25,000 of them would have to come from the United States, alliance officials say, but none of the allies would be willing to make commitments until the United States took the lead.
Looking back at NATO's inability to take effective steps of its own so far, officials of four different countries agreed on the main reason for the failure. "There was no U.S. leadership," one said this week.

HEADLINE: Brazilian State Leads Way in Saving Children

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARACANAU, Brazil

 BODY:
In the dim, smoke-stained interior of a sharecropper's shack, 1-year-old Maria sat quietly on the dirt floor, her infant spark dulled by diarrhea and malnutrition.
With seven other children to care for, Maria's mother, Antonia Souza Lima, explained that she could not afford the time -- an hour-and-a-half walk -- or the 40-cent bus fare to take her listless baby to the nearest medical post. 
 Fading quietly, Maria seemed destined to become one of the 250,000 Brazilian children who die every year before turning 5.
But in a new effort to cut the devastating infant mortality rate here, a community health worker recently started to walk weekly to the Lima household, bringing oral rehydration formula for Maria and hygiene advice for her mother, who has a television setbut no water filter.
With the new public health program, involving a low-cost army of health workers, Ceara state is showing Brazil that even in times of economic austerity infant mortality can be cut.
In four years, Ceara, one of the poorest of Brazil's northeastern states, cut its infant mortality rate by nearly one-third. The number of babies who died before reaching their first birthday was 39 per 1,000 live births in 1990, the last year a survey was conducted, down from 57 per 1,000 in 1987.
Increasingly, Brazilians are discussing their child mortality record, one of the worst in the Americas, and health planners from other northeastern states are flocking to Ceara to study its program,
While Brazil has a $450 billion economy -- roughly the same size as those of Russia and China -- health workers point out that economic statistics do not always measure human welfare.
Brazil scores poorly on infant mortality, the number of babies who die before their first birthday. Although its $2,920 per capita income is eight times that of China, Brazil has an infant mortality rate two and a half times China's -- of every 1,000 live births, 55 Brazilian babies die before their first birthday.
"With the 'economic miracle,' middle-class infant mortality vanished, but it has not been dislodged from the shantytowns, from the rural northeast," said Nancy Scheper-Hughes, an anthropology professor at the University of California at Berkeley, referring to Brazil's explosive economic growth under the military Governments of the 1960's and 1970's.
While Brazil's ruling army generals prided themselves on building the world's biggest dam and the world's longest bridge, they never showed enthusiasm for programs that cut infant mortality, like education for women, day-care centers and the promotion of breast-feeding.
After civilian rule returned in 1985, Government mismanagement, corruption and heavy indebtedness undermined efforts to improve health conditions. Typically, a Government effort in 1991 to duplicate Ceara's health plan nationally was derailed when scandal forced the Health Minister to resign.
"The minister came here to look at our program," said Tasso Jereissati, who started the program as Ceara's Governor. "I said this has to be a simple as possible -- someone from the community, walking on foot with a little backpack."
 
Local Solutions Sought
 The program, called Viva Crianca, or Long Live the Child, was started in 1987 by Mr. Jereissati, a Social Democrat whose party in elections the year before turned out a group of conservative, landowning politicians. Declaring child survival a state priority, Mr. Jereissati drew up the program with the help of local doctors. The first community health agents were drawn from 6,000 people who were given temporary work in the 1987 drought.
Today, with the central Government largely paralyzed as 19 political parties jockey for power, more and more Brazilians look for local solutions.
Once a month, the 7,240 workers in the Ceara health program enter the homes of four million people, the poor majority of a state where most people's incomes are less than $1 a day.
In six years the locally financed program has lifted Ceara from near the bottom to near the top of Brazil's 26 states in child-protection indicators like vaccinations, child visits to pediatricians and duration of breast-feeding. To help the children of working mothers, the number of community-run day-care centers has soared, from 8 in 1987 to 257 today.
The program is intended to reverse the centralization of health resources found in much of the third world.
 
Costs 'Virtually Nothing'
 "Instead of having sick citizens clog hospitals, we opted for prevention and family visits," said Ciro Gomes, Ceara's 35-year-old Governor, who since taking office two years ago has extended the program to all 182 towns in the state. "The health agent program costs virtually nothing -- $500,000 a month."
In recognition of this achievement, Unicef is bestowing on "the people and the state of Ceara" the 1993 Unicef Maurice Pate Award, a prize that honors child-protection efforts. For the first time in the award's 27-year history the award is going to South America.
In a country where newspapers frequently report on people dying while waiting in lines at Government-run hospitals, the idea of decentralized, preventive medicine has increasing appeal. After 12 years of economic stagnation, many people argue that Brazil's children cannot afford to wait for the benefits of a hypothetical future growth to trickle down.
Viva Crianca stipulates that health agents be picked from the communities where they live. They earn Brazil's minimum wage -- currently $55 a month. The state recently started to distribute bicycles and baby scales to some agents.
"A bicycle would help," said Maria de Fatima Goncalves as she showed Mrs. Lima how to produce oral rehydration formula from salt, sugar and clean water. "Some of the houses are far away."
Dressed in a white T-shirt and denim shorts, Miss Goncalves carried the bare necessities in a small backpack: soap, scissors, an ointment for burns, a fine comb for lice and a medicine for scabies. The 22-year-old is responsible for visiting each month 82 rural families who live within a four-mile radius of her house.
To many in Ceara, where Viva Crianca is enormously popular, the home visits and referrals are the greatest value. "I tell the agents they are my eyes and ears," said Pedro Correia, a hospital surgeon in Morada Nova, a town 150 miles south of here.
And for the peasants in Brazil's outback, the arrival of health care workers is a welcome novelty. Erismar Rodrigues de Lima, a neighbor of the Limas, listened intently to instructions on filtering drinking water.
"I am the first member of my family to ever receive prenatal care," said the 22-year-old woman, who is expecting a baby in June.

HEADLINE: French Disavow Accord On Farm-Trade Subsidy

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 13

 BODY:
The new center-right French Cabinet unveiled a tough trade policy today, rejecting a trans-Atlantic agreement on farm subsidies reached in November, rebuking the United States for reprisals, and arguing that liberalism in world trade is not sufficient in itself at a time when many European jobs are threatened.
The five-page statement, released by Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, amounted to a call for a review of European trade policy as far-reaching as that being undertaken by the Clinton Administration. 
 With a backdrop of recession in Europe and unemployment exceeding 10 percent in the 12-nation European Community, the French leadership said that an opening of markets through lower tariffs must be carried out in a way that avoided "devastating effects on employment." Growing competition from industries using cheap labor in the former East bloc is causing increasing uneasiness among politicians and wage earners in Western Europe.
On the eve of trade talks by the United States, Canada, Japan and the European Community in Toronto on Friday, France's policy statement suggested that a long-sought world trade agreement, widely viewed as essential to revive many sagging economies, was still a long way off.
 
Gently Stated Warning
 Referring to the stalled negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which began in Uruguay in 1986, Mr. Balladur said, "If people want to go too fast and force our hand, I am sorry to say that they are likely to be disappointed."
The statement appeared to be addressed principally to the Clinton Administration. It defended some European subsidies, and revived a French belief that the cultural heritage of Europe needed to be defended -- in this case against an onslaught of American television programs. European Community television channels, it said, should show "a majority share of European programming."
On the matter of trade subsidies, France said that any accord negotiated in GATT talks should recognize that "general rules are not applicable to sectors, such as agriculture and aerospace, for which specific arrangements have been defined."
While the statement was presented as constructively conceived to overcome the long trade-talk impasse, it was uncompromising on almost all issues. In part, analysts said, this might reflect a tough initial stance that could be softened in negotiations.
 
Basis of U.S. Arguments
 European trade policies, and particularly European subsidies, have been the focus of persistent criticism by the Clinton Administration, which has said that the subsidies distort global trade and take a toll in American jobs by causing companies like Boeing to lose market share.
Among the policies that have been assailed in Washington are those on aerospace, agriculture, steel, intellectual property and procurement for public projects. Only on the procurement issue has a partial accord been reached.
"Commercial rows between the community and the United States have multiplied in recent months," the French statement acknowledged. "The Uruguay trade round cannot be concluded unless these differences are first resolved and the conditions for lasting trade peace accepted."
On agriculture, Mr. Balladur gave no hint of concessions. He dismissed the November accord on farm trade reached between the United States and the Europeans as "unacceptable in its present state." This accord had been seen as an important step toward a broad world trade pact.
In particular, France rejected a clause saying that European Community grain exports should be cut 21 percent over the next six years. It suggested that Europe required additional protection against some American farm products.
 
Anger Abroad Is Expected
 United States officials are likely to be annoyed by these French policy positions, particularly because the community's delegates were supposed to have been negotiating on behalf of all members when they signed the farm accord last year. Other community nations, eager to push forward toward a GATT agreement, are likely to be irritated, too.
Still, an American trade official who insisted on anonymity said in Washington today that the Administration had received no official notification from French officials of any change in policy. The official noted that the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, is scheduled to meet his French counterpart during a visit to Paris early next month.
Prime Minister Balladur's statement, however tough its content, tried to strike a conciliatory tone. It called for an "armistice" on all current disputes and an abandonment by Washington of "unilateral trade practices." This apparently referred to American trade legislation that allows formal steps to be taken against unfair competition.
In place of a cycle of threats, conflict and last-minute compromise that has increasingly characterized trans-Atlantic trade dealings, Mr. Balladur proposed the creation of a World Organization of Commerce to mediate and rule on trade conflicts.
 
Only an Allusion to Japan
 How this might function alongside GATT's existing structure was not clear, but France suggested that with world trade issues becoming increasingly complex, a group dedicated solely to enforcing trade agreements was needed.
The French statement, in contrast to its persistent references to the United States, did not directly refer to Japan. It did say:
"France wants third countries, particularly the most protected, to open their markets to European corporations. To achieve this, it is necessary to end the current confrontation between the community and the United States in order to restore a multilateral aspect to the trade negotiations, which is the only useful approach."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
India Suggests Talks
 NEW DELHI, May 13 (Special to The New York Times) -- India said today that it was prepared to negotiate afresh to meet concerns of the United States over patent protection for American companies. Two weeks ago, India was placed on a list of nations for possible trade sanctions.
Salman Khurshid, a ranking official in the Indian Foreign Ministry, said, "We want the U.S. to understand that this is not something you can do in a hurry." He declared that India's listing under provisions of the legislation by Mr. Kantor's office threatened to "obstruct" and "interfere with the ace" of economic reform.

HEADLINE: China Trade: Cash or Care?;
Clinton Must Endorse Money, Rights or Both

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Seven months after the candidate Bill Clinton accused the Bush Administration of ignoring China's human rights abuses, President Clinton finds himself forced to decide if the United States should risk its access to China's booming economy for the sake of political freedom there.
On one side are those who say trade is a lever the President must use to force China to improve its record on human rights and abide by international rules on trade in weapons. On the other are business executives appalled at the prospect of losing a major market. 
 The Administration is conducting a comprehensive review of American policy toward China, aimed at producing a single strategy on trade, the spread of arms and human rights issues. But although the President has the authority to make the trade decision himself, Congress can overrule him, and at least one legislator has already promised to force a vote on the House floor unless the President refuses to renew the favorable trade status China now enjoys.
 
Import Duties Could Soar
 If this "most favored nation" status lapses, import duties on Chinese goods would rise, on average, to 40 percent from 8 percent.
Mr. Clinton could count himself among those who say trade is a powerful tool to force China to alter its policies. In the Presidential debate on Oct. 11, Mr. Clinton said China's "most favored nation" trade status should be linked to whether it chose to "recognize the legitimacy of those kids that were carrying the Statue of Liberty" in the pro-democracy Tiananmen Square demonstrations in 1989.
In an earlier speech he had gone even further, saying that China's access to the American market should be cut off unless democratic changes were made by the end of 1992.
Federal law now requires President Clinton to choose in the next three weeks whether to extend China's favorable trade status for another year. The decision is complicated by the overwhelming consensus in the American business community that China has become one of the world's most attractive export markets.
More than 300 American corporations and trade associations, ranging from General Motors to the Chamber of Commerce, urged President Clinton in a letter on Wednesday to extend the trade status with no strings attached. The result has been an extraordinary struggle pitting executives against former torture victims and prison camp survivors and persecuted Christians in a competition to win the attention of Congress and the Administration.
 
U.S. Presence Called Helpful
 "I think our presence there has helped the human rights situation considerably" said Jack J. Murphy, chairman and chief executive of Dresser Industries, a large producer of oil field equipment, who signed the letter.
But Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who has led Congressional critics of China's human rights record, said the business community's lobbying was aimed at the wrong country. "If they spent one-tenth of the energy and time lobbying the Chinese on human rights restrictions that they spend on lobbying Congress on this issue, then we would be past this issue by now," she said.
The President has also received intelligence reports that the Chinese are exporting missile and nuclear weapons technology. President Clinton told a group of three dozen corporate chairmen at a closed-door meeting in March that if the United States did not confront China now about these exports, another terrorist bomb under the World Trade Center a decade from now might be a nuclear weapon, according to three people attending the meeting.
White House officials declined to comment, citing the confidentiality of the meeting. Administration officials provided details of the intelligence reports to highly classified meetings today of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.
 
Returned Empty-Handed
 China has been reluctant to make concessions. An American delegation that visited Beijing this week came away empty-handed, according to American officials.
But Chinese officials warn that restrictions on the trade status could harm relations, a prospect that appalls American executives hoping for Chinese Government contracts. And even Congressional critics of China have stopped short of discouraging American companies from business there.
At the same time, the Administration's human rights concerns persist. Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, took the unusual step a week ago of praising Levi Strauss & Company, the clothing manufacturer, for announcing that it would reduce its operations in China over human rights.
The most likely step now is for the Administration to renew the trade status with conditions on improvements in human rights and possibly with conditions on the spread of weapons, Administration and Congressional officials say. But no consensus has emerged from a series of interagency meetings this week, and the final decision will be President Clinton's, they said.
"You remember the old joke in the Bush Administration that the desk officer for China is the President?" asked Calman Cohen, a lobbyist. "Well, the desk officer is still the President."
The problem for the Administration is how to draft conditions that force Beijing to make changes, without being so tough that the Chinese Government dismisses them, yet appeasing China's critics in Congress.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales of U.S.-Produced Vehicles Up

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced vehicles rose 30.2 percent in early May, the nation's auto makers said today, extending the strengthening automotive market into a fourth straight month.
Demand for light trucks, which include mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, showed particular strength, with a 44.4 percent sales gain in the period from May 1 to May 10, to 126,324, compared with 87,497 in the comparable period a year ago. 
 Sales of domestically produced cars were 157,496, up 20.8 percent from last year's 130,408. Vehicle sales over all totaled 283,820, compared with 217,905 last year. Vehicles made in Canada and Mexico, as well as in the United States, are considered domestic, regardless of where the manufacturer is based.
The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for car sales was 6.4 million for the period, down from 6.9 million in late April, but up from 5.7 million in the corresponding period last year.
 
Rise for '93 Forecast
 Harold A. Poling, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said at the company's annual meeting today in Dearborn, Mich., that "although the U.S. economy has improved, the improvement has been slower and more modest than in previous recoveries." Ford is forecasting that the nation's vehicle sales will gain 5 percent in 1993, totaling about 13.7 million units.
Tom Webb, the chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said car sales "suffered a modest payback for their late April surge." But sales of sport utilities and mini-vans more than compensated, he said.
Some dealers, however, sounded mildly disappointed. "Early May was a little stagnant," said Mike Whitley, the manager of Roger Whitley Chevrolet in Tampa, Fla. "It's hard to figure why."
However, the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division, the backbone of the No. 1 auto maker, posted a remarkable increase over all. Chevy car sales rose 33.7 percent, to 28,869, and light-truck sales rose 51.9 percent, to 36,586.
G.M.'s car sales over all rose 12.9 percent, to 71,015, and light-truck sales rose 50.7 percent, to 48,251. Ford's car sales rose 19.1 percent, to 46,840; the company's light-truck sales rose 32.7 percent, to 41,629.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that car sales at the Chrysler Corporation rose 61.9 percent, to 18,700, while light-truck sales rose 46 percent, to 32,050. Chrysler posts its sales only monthly.
The Honda Motor Company sold 7,403 domestically produced cars, down 10.9 percent from 8,310 a year ago. The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 7,130 cars, up 38.2 percent from a year ago; Toyota also sold 1,621 domestically produced light trucks, a threefold increase from last year. The Nissan Motor Company sold 3,030 cars, up almost threefold from a year ago; Nissan's light-truck sales were 2,386, almost double last year's total.
The Big Three, which have been improving their share of the overall automotive market, saw a slight decline in their share of domestically produced vehicles sold. Big Three sales accounted for 90.8 percent of domestic production, compared with 91.1 percent in early May of last year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harold A. Poling, right, opened his final annual meeting of stockholders yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company. Mr. Poling, who is 67 and retiring this year, told shareholders that Ford was planning a new Mustang and a new mini-van. At left is Ford's president, Alexander J. Trotman. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Citing Loan, Dinkins Bars Bond Firm

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins dismissed Fleet Securities yesterday as an official underwriter of city bonds, saying that a loan from the firm's sister bank to the Senate campaign committee of Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman last year had created an "appearance of a conflict" that could threaten the city's reputation in the credit markets.
In a letter to Ms. Holtzman, Mr. Dinkins wrote: "I know we both agree that as public servants, we have a fundamental obligation to avoid not only conflicts but the appearance of conflicts. In this case, the appearance of a conflict in the elevation of Fleet Securities could post a threat to that reputation. In the final analysis, I believe we must avoid jeopardizing the public's confidence in our selection process." 
 Last week, the City Department of Investigation began an inquiry into whether Fleet Securities had been given favorable treatment by Ms. Holtzman's office because of a $255,000 debt that Ms. Holtzman's Senate campaign owed to Fleet Bank during the selection. Both the securities firm and the bank are part of Fleet Financial Group, based in Providence, R.I.
 
Appearance Called the Only Reason
 The loan was made to the campaign in August, and seven months later Ms. Holtzman's office recommended Fleet Securities as an underwriter. Ms. Holtzman has always said that she knew nothing of her office's recommendation, and that her deputy, Darcy Bradbury, made the recommendation without consulting her. Ms. Bradbury has said she knew nothing of the loan.
Mr. Dinkins, in his letter, made it clear that the sole reason he was dismissing Fleet was the appearance of conflict of interest. He said the banking company was competent and qualified to underwrite city bonds. And he said the city should not disqualify the company because of an unsettled class-action lawsuit alleging that another Fleet subsidiary engaged in discriminatory lending practices against blacks in Georgia.
Ms. Holtzman, in a news release, maintained that Mr. Dinkins's letter corroborated her contention that there had been no conflict of interest.
"I welcome the Mayor's decision," she said in the statement. "It vindicates our position that Fleet Securities was promoted on the merits and it corroborates the absence of a conflict of interest in the selection of Fleet."
On Friday, Mr. Dinkins temporarily suspended Fleet Securities from the 30-member syndicate of companies that underwrite the city's $3 billion-a-year municipal bond sales, to allow his Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Barry F. Sullivan, to review Fleet's qualifications.
At the same time, as the Investigation Department began scrutinizing the loan, Ms. Holtzman recused herself from future decisions involving Fleet and asked the Mayor to re-evaluate the decision. She said she had erred by not knowing that her office was recommending Fleet while her campaign was renegotiating a repayment schedule for a campaign debt to the company's sister bank.
Thomas Lavelle, the spokesman for Fleet Financial Group, said yesterday that the company was disappointed to lose its status as a manager of part of the city's bond business, though he added that it was pleased the Mayor had recognized that the company was well qualified. "We understand the city's concern with appearance and accept their decision as such," he said.
Fleet Securities will still be allowed to sell city bonds as part of a large pool of about 150 companies that buy a small number of bonds from the syndicate of official city underwriters. But it will not be one of the 30 designated underwriters who are assured a greater part of the city's business.
In New York City, the Mayor and the Comptroller jointly decide on a list of about seven large underwriters who will be chosen as "managers" to oversee the city's borrowing. Then they draw up a list of 30 "co-managers," who are assured a share of the underwriting business. Fleet was selected as a co-manager after years of being in the selling pool.
Mr. Sullivan said the decision to remove Fleet was fundamentally a business decision and that city investigators were still working to determine whether Ms. Holtzman had violated conflict of interest provisions in the city charter.
"We said there was an appearance of favor, and that our underwriting decision process requires public confidence, a belief that we handle the process fairly, equitably, and this called that into question," he said. "Because of that, we said we believe that Fleet should not then be promoted from a syndicate member to co-manager."
Mr. Dinkins said he initially moved only to suspend Fleet because did not want to take final action before Mr. Sullivan and the City Finance Director, Michael W. Geffrard, had a chance to meet with bank executives and hear their side of the story, Mayoral aides said. On Monday, Mr. Geffrard met with several Fleet executives in the city's offices to discuss the loan and the bank's lending practices in Georgia.
In August, Ms. Holtzman's campaign, which was short of cash and lagging in polls, borrowed $450,000 from Fleet Bank at an interest rate of 7 percent to pay for an advertising campaign. Ms. Holtzman was the sole guarantor of the loan, which was secured only with a pledge of future donations that never materialized.
Mr. Geffrard said that the Fleet officials said at the meeting that while they made few campaign loans, they had charged a justifiable interest rate for the Holtzman debt. Financing experts have said that such a low interest rate to a political campaign would usually require collateral like real estate or other securities.
By March, when Fleet Securities was chosen, Ms. Holtzman's campaign had missed two deadlines for repaying the debt and still owed the bank $255,000, according to campaign officials and election records. Joseph McDonald, a lawyer for the campaign, said Ms. Holtzman had attended at least two meetings with Fleet Bank officials to renegotiate a payment schedule, one in early March and one in early April.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS: New Jump in Inflation Rattles Markets;
Treasury Prices Plunge as the Fed Faces a Decision

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The surprisingly sharp rise in the Consumer Price Index yesterday jolted the bond market, sending Treasury prices down sharply and the yield on the 30-year bond to its highest level in more than a month. But the rise probably is more troublesome for the Federal Reserve.
The nation's central bank has to decide much sooner than expected between two courses: whether to raise short-term interest rates to signal its resolve against inflation or to blink at the higher prices and keep interest rates where they are to assure that the economy is moving ahead at a moderate but steady pace.
 
 
Results of Decision
 A Fed-led rise in short-term interest rates could slow the economy while reassuring traders and investors that the central bank was opposed to any signs of resurgent inflation. The combination of expected slow growth and a tough Fed could bring longer-term rates lower. But a Fed that does nothing while inflation appears to be moving higher would push long-term interest rates higher. 
 Whatever the answer, the speculation about what the Federal Reserve might do could jostle the bond market for some time, adding to its volatility and making it difficult for yields to break out of their current trading range.
Yesterday, the report of the four-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for April knocked the price of the 30-year bond down almost one and a quarter points and caused the yield to jump to 6.95 percent. In the last two days, the impact of the equally surprising producer price increase Wednesday and the consumer price report has lifted the yield on the 30-year bond from 6.81 percent as the price dropped more than one and three-quarter points.
The consumer price report also seemed to end any talk for now about the Federal Reserve lowering interest rates to stimulate the economy, a theme that had been bandied about recently.
The Federal Reserve will have to address the issue next Tuesday, when its Federal Open Market Committee meets in one of its regular sessions to steer the course of monetary policy.
In February, when it presented its annual report to Congress, the Federal Reserve predicted that the Consumer Price Index would rise between 2.5 percent and 2.75 percent this year, below the 2.9 percent increase of last year.
With the four-tenths of a percent increase reported yesterday, that prediction will be difficult to reach. It would take an average monthly increase of two-tenths of a percent for the rest of the year to keep inflation at 3 percent. Anything larger and the rate is higher.
"Obviously it's higher than any one of us would have liked to have seen," a Fed governor, Susan M. Phillips, said in a telephone interview. "It will take much stronger reports for the rest of the year to get back in the area we would like," she added, using the word "stronger" to describe lower inflation. But she would not say that the goal was impossible to meet or comment on what impact the data would have on the Fed.
David Jones, the chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said the inflation data might be even a more serious blow to the Fed because the members, including the chairman, Alan Greenspan, have been talking about getting inflation down to near zero.
 
 
Short-Term Rates
 Mr. Jones said that all this meant that the Fed would shift to a bias toward raising short-term interest rates by midyear and would actually start pushing them higher in the fall.
"I do not think the Fed wants to be perceived as waiting too long or as caving in," Mr. Jones said, recalling the striking picture on television and in print of Mr. Greenspan sitting next to the First Lady when President Clinton announced his economic plan to a joint meeting of Congress.
Lawrence A. Kudlow, the chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, agreed. "The Fed is going to snug up soon," he said, adding that the inflation numbers would prompt a big shift in expectations.
But Alan Lerner, the head of global markets-economics at Bankers Trust, disagreed. He said that while he expected inflation to move a little higher this year -- about 3.5 percent -- "it is much too early to get excited by that." He argued that the important number for the Fed is the sluggish 1.8 percent annual growth rate in the first quarter and the fact that raising interest rates would slow growth. "The Fed has to look at the economy and the extraordinary weak monetary aggregates," he said. "The Fed will not be doing anything for as long as the eye can see and for me that is usually about six months."
 
Treasury Market
 In the Treasury market, the sharp selloff in the morning seemed to help the auction of $8.26 billion of 30-year bonds because the cheaper price was more attractive for dealers. The price slump after the release of the six-tenths of a percent increase in the Producer Price Index for finished goods Wednesday gave the same lift to the 10-year note auction.
The 30-year bond, which is a new supply of the existing 7.125 percent bond first auctioned in February and due in 2023, was auctioned at an average rate of 6.97 percent. Despite all the negative inflation news, that was still the lowest auction average since the Treasury began to auction 30-year bonds regularly in 1977.
In the when-issued market, after the Treasury auction, the price of the 30-year bond rebounded a little as the yield in late trading was down to 6.95 percent. And with the quarterly auction finished, there might be some room for a small rebound in prices.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Warns Of Pension Financing

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 13

 BODY:
If interest rates stay low through Oct. 1, the unfunded pension liability of the General Motors Corporation could increase to $19 billion or $20 billion by the end of 1993, up from $14 billion, the auto maker said in documents distributed today.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, G.M. said it might be forced to take a $1.8 billion charge against equity by the end of the year to reflect the higher liability. The charge would not affect earnings but would reduce shareholder equity. 
 G.M. noted that long-term interest rates "are at their lowest level in 20 years," which depresses the yield on bonds held in the auto maker's pension portfolio. Rates dropped about one percentage point in the first quarter, but have gone back up about a quarter percentage point since April, a spokesman said. The $6 billion increase in unfunded liability would occur if the percentage-point drop held through October.
The possible increase in unfunded pension liability was disclosed after the stock market closed today. But the news should not have come as a surprise, analysts said, because G.M. had been quietly spreading the word for weeks.
"I've heard numbers as high as $20 billion," said Jack V. Kirnan, automotive analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York.
G.M. shares lost $1 today, closing at $40.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, on a day when the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 30 points.
If the forecast for a higher liability holds true, the rise may force G.M. to increase its contributions to the pension fund, putting additional pressure on cash flow for capital outlays and other corporate purposes, Mr. Kirnan said. And it may also provide a stark reminder to the United Automobile Workers union during contract talks this summer that G.M. is a weak company.
But a G.M. spokesman said that an increase of $5 billion or $6 billion in its pension liability would not affect the criteria used to determine the corporation's cash flow or its plan to fund the pension fund in full by 2000.
 The plan to cover the unfunded liability assumes the pension fund's assets will earn a return of approximately 10 percent a year -- a rate of growth that G.M. described as "realistic and prudent." The pension fund has earned, on average, 14.4 percent in the last 10 years, the company said.
Last year, G.M. contributed $1.2 billion to its pension fund, the spokesman said, and this year it will contribute at least $2 billion.
Lower interest rates may also have an impact on G.M.'s post-retirement health-care liability, raising it by $5 billion, to $43.4 billion, according to the S.E.C. filing.
Neither the increase in its unfunded pension liability nor the increase in its health benefit liability would have an impact on the company's earnings in 1993, the filing said.
