HEADLINE: 'The Corner': Where Immigrants and Jobs Intersect;
Mamaroneck's Informal Job Market Offers a Sweat-of-the-Brow Kind of Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 13

 BODY:
Dawn had just broken, but already the corner of Jefferson Avenue and Van Ranst Place was buzzing. As a red sports car pulled up to the curb, about a dozen men sprinted to its side from a nearby park, all of them craning to get a word with the driver.
Moments later, the crowd was dispersing, except for Benny Lorensana, a 22-year-old native of Guatemala, who climbed into the passenger seat, flashing the thumb's up sign as the car sped off. 
 For Mr. Lorensana and the other Hispanic immigrants who gather here every morning, "the corner," as it is known, is the only thing standing between them and destitution. The men, many of whom are living in this country without proper documentation, are day laborers. Each shows up here, rain or shine, with the hope of securing a day's work as a painter, gardener, construction worker or carpenter from contractors and small-business owners who need extra help.
"It's very hard to get a job in anything nowadays," said Sister Laura Reynolds of St. Vito's Church in Mamaroneck, who has helped the workers adapt to life here, away from their homes and the families that many of them left behind in Mexico, El Salvador, Peru and Honduras.
As many as 60 workers show up on the corner each day, and they estimate that each is selected to work about three of every six days that he stands on the corner.
"That's enough for them to live on and send money home," Sister Laura said. "I look at it as a kind of foreign aid. It's a sure way to get money into the hands of the poor people of their countries."
No one knows for certain how many corners like this exist in the New York metropolitan region. Miguel Maldonado, a community organizer with the Center for Immigrants Rights in Manhattan, said he counsels day laborers on this corner and a dozen others in Westchester County, Brooklyn, Queens and New Jersey. And he believes the struggling economy is making such spots increasingly attractive to employers and workers alike.
 
Learning About Laws
 Among the things that the workers in this Westchester village have learned from Mr. Maldonado is that, regardless of problems with their citizenship, they are protected by New York State labor laws, which entitle them to earn the minimum wage, $4.25 an hour, and to collect overtime.
The laborers, who have been gathering in Mamaroneck for about five years, have gradually earned the admiration of this community, which is heavily populated by descendants of a wave of Italian and Irish immigration in the early 20th century. But relations were not always smooth.
The workers' original meeting place, in front of the Mamaroneck Metro-North station, prompted a flurry of complaints from commuters, including reports that the men were sometimes urinating in public and tying up traffic, said Chief Joseph DelBianco of the village police.
Last spring local community groups and village officials helped work out a compromise with the men that moved them to their current location, several hundred yards behind the station. Chief DelBianco said the complaints had stopped. The workers' spirit, the Chief said, has reminded him of stories of his father's immigration to America from Italy.
"I know it was tough for my father, who was a stonemason when he got here," Chief DelBianco said. "He tried to hustle for a buck. I see the same work ethic in the Latinos. They want to build a life for themselves."
 
Formed Labor Association
 The workers have overcome problems with their employers, too, shunning those who have bounced checks or refused to pay them in full.
"The people who used to cheat us, we know them very well," said Jaime Savino, 34, who was born in Guatemala and has lived in Mamaroneck for four years. "We tell the brothers, 'This guy doesn't pay.' "
Thanks in part to Mr. Maldonado, the organizer who was recruited last year by local community groups, the men have formed their own labor association, established a minimum asking price ($60 for a day's work) and arranged to take free English classes three times a week at St. Vito's church. They hope to use proceeds from a planned raffle -- an electronic Spanish-English translator is among the prizes -- to rent an indoor meeting place someday.
With pride, the men point to success stories like Jorge Gonzalez, 43, a Peruvian who moved to Mamaroneck three years ago and who, because of his persistent efforts on the corner, has held a steady job as a painter for the last three months.
Mr. Gonzalez, whose wife and three children remain in Peru, said he still visited the corner before his job starts in the morning because of the camaraderie.
"We're not competitive," he said.
 
'A Needed Service'
 Once or twice a week, said Nick Condro, 37, the owner of a landscaping business in the village, he hires a man to help him maintain about 20 lawns and gardens in town.
"They provide a needed service for the community," he said, after motioning one of the men into his black van. "They don't bother anyone."
"I always like to make sure they eat because you never know," he added. "It may sound corny, but it's true."
Although Mamaroneck seems to have accepted the workers, Vernon Briggs, a professor of labor economics at Cornell University, said he was critical of any situation in which an illegal alien takes a job that could have been filled by an American citizen or someone with a green card.
"I think it undermines labor standards," he said. "I'm opposed to anything that encourages illegal immigration to exist or continue."
Nevertheless, Carlos Najara, 52, a Guatemalan who was elected the first president of the workers' association last spring, said he takes pride in what he and the other laborers have accomplished in Mamaroneck, particularly their dogged presence on the corner 7 days a week, 52 weeks a year.
"For us, there is no cold or heat," he said. "We're here."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher After Report Of Rise in Consumer Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against most leading currencies yesterday after the Government reported a bigger-than-expected gain in consumer prices and improved retail sales in April.
The dollar was buoyed early in New York by the Labor Department report that consumer prices over all rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April. Analysts had expected a two-tenths of 1 percent rise. 
 The increase in consumer prices, on top of Wednesday's report that producer prices also rose last month, means that the Federal Reserve is not likely to cut interest rates anytime soon. Lower American interest rates would make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors.
 
 
Retail Sales
 The Commerce Department's report that retail sales rose 1.2 percent in April is also likely to deter the Fed from reducing interest rates, traders said.
In New York, the dollar ended the day at 111.80 Japanese yen, up from 111.55 yen on Wednesday. The dollar also rose to 1.6175 German marks, up from 1.6105 marks Wednesday.
"There wasn't enough in the data to get us to 1.6200 marks," Earl Johnson, a foreign exchange adviser at Harris Trust and Savings Bank, said. "There's just too much uncertainty about the U.S. economy for the dollar to sustain an up move."
The dollar was also reined in by demand for German marks in the wake of Spain's and Portugal's decisions to devalue their currencies, traders said.
With the 8 percent devaluation of the Spanish peseta and the 6.5 percent devaluation of the Portuguese escudo "there was across-the-board demand for marks," said Carl Amendola, vice president at Bayerische Hypotheken- und Wechsel-Bank, said. "That capped the dollar's rise."
Meanwhile, the British pound slipped in New York to $1.5200 from $1.5340.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
There's no making sense of this spring's auctions in New York. Even the experts, trying to analyze the sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art in the last two weeks, are baffled. Taken as a whole, the sales at Sotheby's and Christie's were a four-night roller-coaster ride on which the highs rose beyond anyone's expectations and the lows hit with a resounding thud.
Instead of one solid auction market, this spring's sales, which ended on Wednesday night, showed a market divided. The difference between a weak market for contemporary art and a strong one for Impressionist and modern art was glaringly apparent, what with an utterly disastrous sale of Andy Warhols at Sotheby's one week and a record $28.6 million price for a Cezanne at the same house the next. 
 In contrast with the Impressionist and modern buyers, the players in the contemporary-art marketplace are a totally different and larger group who follow trends more closely. Even in more consistent times, it has historically been a more volatile segment of the market. Contemporary art saw the greatest inflation in the boom years of the late 1980's and the most violent crash in the slump that began two years ago. And judging by the results of the sales at both Christie's and Sotheby's last week, the contemporary-art market is still struggling.
To compare sales totals is to notice the difference between the two markets. Sotheby's sale of contemporary art totaled $15.4 million, while Christie's auction made $14.3 million. By contrast, Sotheby's Impressionist and modern auction made $86.84 million, and Christie's brought in $59.9 million.
 
The Champion: Impressionism
 The strength of the Impressionist and modern sales was by far the biggest surprise. At moments in both auctions, it felt like 1989 again, that golden year of record highs and bidding wars, when even paintings deemed hard to sell by the experts were fought over. This season, estate property, the bread and butter of the auction houses, was scarce, and many collectors who didn't have to sell preferred to hold off, waiting for a clear signal that prices were on the rise. But both Sotheby's and Christie's were able to secure a few great paintings. And each brought great prices.
By far the star of the last two weeks was Cezanne's "Still Life With Apples," from 1890-94, which sold for a staggering $28.6 million at Sotheby's on Tuesday night, setting a record for the artist. (The previous record for a Cezanne was $17.1 million paid at Christie's in London in November 1989, at the top of the market.) The price was particularly amazing when you consider that two years ago Sotheby's entire spring sale of Impressionist and modern works made only $18 million. The painting was sold by George Embiricos, the Greek shipping magnate who had bought it for $252,000 at a sale of the well-known Jakob Goldschmidt collection in 1958 at Sotheby's in London. "I don't think there was anyone who would have guessed the Cezanne would go that high," said Diana D. Brooks, Sotheby's president and chief executive. "It means a picture can bring more than $25 million again, and that's very encouraging."
Also encouraging for Sotheby's were results from several other top works up for sale that night. Among them was Matisse's "Fatma the Mulatto," from 1912, which sold for a healthy $14.3 million, just $200,000 shy of a record for the artist. The price surpassed Sotheby's estimate of $10 million to $13 million. "Fatma," one of the artist's great Moroccan figure paintings, was sold by the heirs of Josef Muller, a celebrated collector from Solothurn, Switzerland.
Perhaps the painting's price was a sign that the Matisse fever seen in November isn't over. Last fall's auctions coincided with the Museum of Modern Art's Matisse retrospective, an event that experts say helped inflate prices for the artist's works. Two works in particular, "Asia" and "Harmony in Yellow," sold in November for $11 million and $14.5 million, respectively. At Christie's on Tuesday night, a beautiful, though less important, Matisse fared well, too. "Laurette With a Cup of Coffee," from 1916-17, estimated at $800,000 to $1 million, was bought by the New York dealer Richard Feigen for $1.04 million.
 
The Middle Ground
 While Christie's sale on Wednesday night had no $20 million-plus paintings, the auction clearly rode the crest of Sotheby's success the night before. Its blockbuster work, Monet's "Jetty at Havre," sold for $9.6 million, just below Christie's high estimate of $10 million. The painting was being sold by Motoaki Ishizuka, a Japanese inventor who is an active collector. Another high price was paid for Degas's "Russian Dancers." from 1895, estimated at $2.5 million to $3.5 million. After a round of particularly aggressive bidding it finally brought $6.2 million, nearly double its pre-sale estimate.
"There was more bidding than at any sale I can remember, even at the top of the market," said Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York. But he warned that estimates should remain conservative. Indeed, while basking in the week's success, experts at both auction houses are cautious, pointing out that except for the top works, general price levels have fallen back to 1987-88 figures. "It's still a very tender market," Mr. Burge added. "But the fact that we saw more activity is an encouraging sign."
At Sotheby's the most expensive works sold beyond anyone's expectations, but the so-called middle-market, those works in the $500,000 realm that have suffered the most during the last two years, fell flat during the house's high-priced evening sale. At Christie's, on the other hand, it was just these mediocre works that caused a flurry of bidding as collectors from all over the world snapped them up in multiples. "There was a hunger to buy," said David Nash, the international director of Sotheby's Impressionist and modern art department. "A lot of collectors who bought at Christie's on Wednesday night were the same people who failed to get pictures at Sotheby's on Tuesday night. The money is there, and confidence is back."
There is money even for artists who couldn't get a bid two years ago. Two in particular, Renoir and Chagall, both of whom have been suffering since the Japanese dropped out of the market, made a surprising comeback. At Sotheby's on Tuesday night, Chagall's "Flowers," from 1925, expected to bring $800,000 to $1 million, nearly reached its high estimate, selling for $992,500. Each house had its share of Renoirs, and the best of them were fiercely fought over. At Christie's, "Leontine Lisant," from 1909, estimated at $2.8 million to $3.2 million, sold to an anonymous collector for $2.9 million. At Sotheby's, "Woman in the Garden" (1873) also provoked a bidding frenzy, selling for $6.7 million, well above its high estimate of $2.5 million to $3.5 million.
 
The Big Losers
 What happened to Magritte was another story. Last fall's hugely successful Magritte retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art did little to enhance the artist's worth. Three Magrittes went unsold at Sotheby's. At Christie's, two out of three found buyers, but just a little above their low estimates.
But no artist fared so badly as Warhol, whose poor performance was the talk of the art world. In a time when good contemporary art was hard for both auction houses to come by, Sotheby's, in what appeared to be a move of desperation, put 12 Warhols in one sale. Ten of them belonged to Frederick W. Hughes, who was Warhol's manager for 25 years and is now the executor of the artist's estate and chairman emeritus of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts. Two belonged to private collectors. Only two of the 12 works were sold, and barely. "Old Telephone," from 1961, estimated at $600,000 to $800,000, sold for $552,500. And "Princess Diana," from 1982, estimated at $60,000 to $80,000, sold for $57,500.
The Warhol failure affected the entire contemporary market. Sotheby's sale had a deathly air about it. Painting after painting elicited not so much as a bid. The total for the contemporary sale, a meager $8.8 million, was less than half the house's estimate of $18.4 million to $24.7 million. For one night, the market had sunk back to the levels of 1990-91, when experts said prices had bottomed out.
 
A Pollock in Dispute
 Christie's contemporary-art sale fared better the next night, but none of its four Warhols sold. What did sell successfully was Jackson Pollock's drip painting "No. 19, 1948," which was bought by an unidentified European for $2.4 million, right above its $2 million high estimate. While the price was respectable, Christie's is having a bit of a problem with the sale of the painting, whose ownership is being challenged in New York Surrogate's Court in Manhattan. The dispute is between the executor of the estate of Janet Hauck, widow of the Abstract Expressionist painter Fred Hauck, and her daughter, who contends that the painting is really hers. A hearing has been set for May 24. If a clear title can't be given, then the buyer must return the painting.
But even the title dispute, of which Christie's informed its audience the night of the sale, didn't stop bidding, which just goes to show that if the auction houses can obtain top material, they can sell it, and in many cases for extraordinary prices. Just who's been buying, however, is often veiled in a kind of mystery both auction houses relish. In fact, it's what keeps spectators coming to watch each season.
"All the old hands were bidding, less of the glitterati and more the people in the know," said Mr. Burge. He added that buyers were from both the United States and abroad, including Mexico and even Japan, for the first time in two years. "There were also dealers bidding," he added. "Some obviously buying for clients, but some for dealers' stock, which means they are willing to invest in the market's continued growth."

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Sheehan Seeks to Climb Higher Than the Pinnacle

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., May 13

 BODY:
After earning her way into the toughest Hall of Fame in sports, Patty Sheehan has taken on a new mission: to prove that her career is still thriving.
When Sheehan won the Standard Register Ping in Phoenix in March, she became only the 13th player to achieve the 30 victories needed for entry into the Ladies Professional Golf Association's Hall of Fame. It also made her an instant has-been. At the the next tournament, a note from a fellow Hall member, JoAnne Carner, was taped to her locker. It read, "Welcome to the Old Ladies Club." 
 But at age 36, in her 14th season on the L.P.G.A. Tour, Sheehan fiercely resists any suggestion that it is time for her to gracefully fade from the top echelon of the women's game.
"I just can't stop with getting into the Hall of Fame," said Sheehan today after she shot a three-under-par 68 in the first round of the McDonald's Championship, two strokes off the pace set by Laura Davies and Gail Graham.
"I'm not like that," she continued. "I'm not a quitter. I'll quit when I run out of fun and competitive juices, when I get tired of it. But I'm a long way from that. The Hall of Fame wasn't the end of anything. It was the beginning of the rest of my career."
Actually, Sheehan's career received a major shot of adrenalin last year when she won the United States Women's Open, at Oakmont, Pa., in an 18-hole playoff against Juli Inkster. That victory, her 29th, made the 5-foot-3-inch Vermonter with the flawless swing believe that her best golf is still ahead.
"There is more for me to do out here," she said. "I want to win another U.S. Open. I want to win a Dinah Shore. I want to be the L.P.G.A. player of the year again."
Still, golf hasn't been easy for Sheehan since her landmark victory in Phoenix. She finished no better than ninth in her five subsequent tournaments, including a missed cut at Atlanta and a tie for 54th last week in Nashville.
Sheehan admits experiencing "a tremendous feeling of relief," at entering the Hall of Fame. But she denies that she experienced an emotional letdown similar to that of Pat Bradley, who has not won since earning her 30th career victory in 1991. Bradley, who has admitted she is searching for a new goal, shot a 73 today.
"I can see the tendency would be for that to happen," said Sheehan, "but I haven't felt a letdown."
One reason is simple economics. Sheehan lost her northern California home in the October 1989 earthquake that hit the San Francisco Bay Area, and she says she still has a way to go before she feels economically secure.
"I have given myself another four or five years to play," she said, "but that's hard to say. But who is to know what will happen. I may have to play. I'm hoping I will be financially sound."
Sheehan still possesses a healthy dose of insecurity and the never-ending drive to overcome it.
"I want to win my 31st real bad," she said. "I want to stop people from asking me if I will ever win again. Of course, I always get in my own way when I try really hard."
Sheehan's round today was a relaxed affair in which she made four birdies and one bogey over the par-71 DuPont Country Club. It was her lowest 18 holes since the final round 65 at Phoenix.
In a tournament she has won twice, the last time in 1990, Sheehan should be dangerous.
"This would be a great way to get back on track," said Sheehan. "I'm so anxious to get on with the rest of my career."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: History by the Hour or the Day

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
SPRING is the season of noble intentions. The old, shriveled winter creature you behold in the mirror cries out for renewal, and so does the gray-tinged complexion. What better way to register the change of season than a self-improvement program that combines outdoor recreation with mental stimulation? Both in moderation, of course.
An ideal spring program is at hand in the dozens of small towns and cities across Connecticut, each with its own historical society, that offer walking tours. Some are guided by local historians, on a fixed schedule or as demand arises. Others are self-guided. That is, history-minded flaneurs can pick up a brochure and set forth, beholding the local wonders, free to think their own thoughts and form their own impressions. 
 A few towns, like Hartford and Litchfield, rent or sell audiocassette guides, allowing visitors to stroll or drive as they like. This may be the wave of the future. This summer, the Huntington Historical Society will offer a cassette guide to Southport narrated by Jason Robards.
Not all tours are created equal. Some focus on architecture, others on local worthies and eminent trees, while others memorialize the brief, sometimes ephemeral brushes with greatness every town likes to claim.
Wethersfield had its moment. Until the late 18th century, it was known primarily for its red onions and an infestation of witches in the 1640's that included a husband-and-wife team. In May 1781, however, destiny came knocking at the door of Joseph Webb, a merchant. Into his red clapboard house on Main Street walked George Washington, accompanied by the Comte de Rochambeau. The two men, sitting at a table in what is now called the Council Room, laid plans for a decisive southward push by American and French forces.
Washington slept not one but four nights at the stark, rather barnlike clapboard structure, which was built in the 1750's and still stands steady as a rock, flanked by two other mid-18th-century houses. Together, the three make up the Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum, and they are the subject of a one-hour guided tour that is strong on the details of domestic life and Colonial architecture.
Visitors who note with surprise the rather flashy interior colors of the Webb house, which includes a stunning china cupboard in blue, mustard and red with a scallop-shell dome, will find out that early American homes relied on bright interior paints to lighten rooms that had no electricity.
Visitors will take pleasure in the large and quite realistic plastic turkey on the dining room table of the Silas Deane house, and the surrounding pies and vegetable dishes indicating a Thanksgiving feast. (The meal is due to undergo a seasonal change.)
Because several of the Deanes fell victim to tuberculosis, an upstairs bedroom has been set up as a sickroom, with a handsome mahogany medicine chest on a night stand. One of the chest's small drawers contains strands of copper wire, and by way of explanation, my guide delivered the kind of eye-opening 30-minute treatise that fully justified the $5 cost of the tour.
"The copper wires were stirred in vinegar, and the resulting chemical reaction created verdigris," she said. "When you mixed it with a liquid to disguise the taste and then drank it, it alleviated chest pains, although it did nothing for the tuberculosis. So if you ever see a little drawer like that with copper wires in it, that's what they were for."
With my store of knowledge increased to the tune of one eminently repeatable fact, I felt edified, yet not fatigued. This was as good as anything in "Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure."
Wethersfield is the ideal town for a half-day history tour. One of the most perfectly preserved Colonial towns in Connecticut, it has 150 buildings dating before 1850, and the Olde Towne Tourism District -- yes, unfortunately, that's how it's spelled -- has a detailed brochure with an annotated map that allows visitors to stroll, look and absorb at their own pace.
For atmosphere, read "The Witch of Blackbird Pond," by Elizabeth Speare, or "Harvest Home" and "The Other," by Thomas Tryon. All are set in Wethersfield. Then walk up and down Main Street, making sure to press as far north as Wethersfield Cove, the town's thriving harbor until a flood in 1692 swept away six warehouses and permanently altered the Connecticut River's course. Overnight, the port became an inlet.
On the way back, take a detour to see the Buttolph-Williams House (1720) on Broad Street. Imposing and stern, it figures prominently in "The Witch of Blackbird Pond."
Finish up with a visit to the Ancient Burying Ground, where, legend has it, the nine victims of the 1637 massacre that touched off the Pequot War are buried. The Wethersfield Historical Society offers tours and a printed guide to the cemetery.
The Industrial Revolution passed Wethersfield by. Instead of machine shops and mills, the 19th century left the gentle, benevolent legacy of Comstock, Ferre (pronouced Ferry), the oldest continually operating seed company in the United States.
Stop in and buy a 79-cent packet of seeds for the famous Wethersfield red onion, which was once shipped from the cove to ports up and down the East Coast, and all the way to the Orient.
The store's manager, Roger Willard, is rather restrained in his sales pitch for the local product. "There's nothing so great about it," he said, "except that it made Wethersfield famous."
 
A Town Near Hartford
 Just a few miles west of Wethersfield is the once-mighty town of Farmington, so famous in the 19th century that when Mark Twain was introduced to Queen Victoria as a citizen of Hartford, he pointed out, helpfully, that Hartford was a town near Farmington.
Farmington is another half-day town with some good history to it, and, of course, a local historical society with a can-do attitude.
Visitors should make tracks to the Farmington Historical Society for a brochure on the Amistad Sights Walking Tour, a 10-stop proposition that traces Farmington's role in the events surrounding the first civil rights case to reach the Supreme Court.
In 1839, 53 adults and children from the Mende region of Sierra Leone, who had been captured and enslaved, were being transported from Havana to Puerto Rico aboard the ship Amistad. After a storm blew the ship out to sea, and rations were depleted, the Africans, led by Sengbe Pieh, known as Joseph Cinque, rose up, killed the captain and the cook, seized control of the ship and tried to head back to Africa.
Instead, the ship touched land at Montauk Point, L.I., where the Coast Guard picked up the men and transported them to New Haven, where they were put on trial for mutiny and murder. The court ruled that because the Africans had never been slaves before their abduction, they could not be returned to Cuba nor be held liable for their acts.
The decision was appealed and went to the Supreme Court, where John Quincy Adams helped argue the case for the defense. The high court upheld the lower court's decision.
The Amistad case galvanized the Abolitionist movement. Farmington, an abolitionist hotbed and a stop on the underground railroad, played host to the Mende natives, who lived and worked in the town while money was raised to send them back to Africa.
Carol Leonard, head of the Farmington Historical Society, occasionally leads tours of the Amistad Sights trail, by request.
A second local historian, Ernest R. Shaw, runs a little business called Heritage Trails Sightseeing Tours. Most of the time, he's busy taking small bands of tourists around Hartford, but his spring schedule includes two Farmington tours.
On the first, the "Ancient Evening Cemetery Tour," Mr. Shaw takes visitors through two graveyards, one dating from 1660. Informed sources say that there is sometimes a little surprise in one of them that elicits some shrieks. There are tours tomorrow and May 29 to 31, then a long pause before the Halloween season.
Every Saturday in May, Mr. Shaw explores the area's Indian heritage on his "Indian Canoe Adventure," which includes a canoe ride up the Farmington River and a historically accurate lunch of bear meat or wild fowl and ground corn. Tour members are sent into the fields to pick wild onions and ferns for a salad.
Mr. Shaw's most unusual tour takes place tomorrow, when he leads visitors along the locks and brownstone bridges of the old Farmington Canal. "Even Connecticut people are unaware there was an 80-mile canal, hand-dug, that ran from New Haven and ended up in Northampton, Mass., on the Connecticut River," he said. It's a striking illustration of the truth that economics is not beanbag. "The idea was to put Hartford out of business," Mr. Shaw said.
Hartford had the last laugh. The canal opened in 1828 and went bankrupt 19 years later, a victim of the railroads.
The saga of the Farmington Canal serves as a reminder that history more often than not has a harsh tale to tell. In the struggle to survive and prosper, some Connecticut towns won; others lost, and lost painfully.
 
The Brass Capital
 Waterbury, which won and lost in spectacular fashion, is a town that deserves its own Gibbon. Once known as the brass capital of the world, it employed tens of thousands of workers in vast factories that cast, rolled, stamped and worked brass, the 19th-century equivalent of plastic, into a thousand articles of domestic and industrial use, including pins, buttons, kettles, architectural hardware, lighting devices, photographic equipment and the famous Ingersoll dollar watches that sold in the millions. By 1890, the city was producing 60 percent of the nation's brass.
In the city's heyday, from 1850 to the end of World War I, the brass barons and the wealthy professionals of Waterbury built some dazzling houses and mansions in the Hillside District, which has 327 buildings listed with the National Register of Historic Places. The reigning style is Queen Anne, that is, an eclectic (some would say indiscriminate) conglomeration of turrets, towers, wraparound porches, peaks and gables, with bright colors pointing up the gingerbread details.
New Yorkers will find some familiar names in Waterbury. Fulton Park was created by the firm of Frederick Law Olmsted, who designed Central Park with Calvert Vaux. Waterbury's brick, marble and granite city hall is one of five buildings designed by Cass Gilbert, the architect who designed the Woolworth Building and the Custom House in Manhattan.
The Mattatuck Museum in downtown Waterbury is a lively little institution with an innovative program of history tours that allow visitors to get a fix on the social and architectural history of Hillside and the Gilbert district and also venture into the newer area of industrial history.
It offers a bicycle or trolley tour that retraces Waterbury's manufacturing history. In addition to stopping off at industrial sites, the tour takes pains to provide a kind of illustrated social history. On Wood Street and Oak Street, the Scovill Company built two-story single-family row houses during World War I, each with a different facade to reflect a different national style, for their managers. The workers got barracks.
The tour is also valuable in lending specificity to arid terms like "industrial decline" and "retooling for the future." It is a poignant reminder of how difficult it is for a town to refashion its self-image. The signs of that struggle are evident everywhere in Waterbury, which has sagged badly since the brass industry moved overseas in the 1950's.
"I've been really impressed with the craftsmen here," said Marianne Vandenburgh, a former Ohioan who now owns the House on the Hill, a bed-and-breakfast establishment on Hillside, who is in the midst of a kitchen renovating project. "I think it's because this is a town where people made things, and the tradition of working with your hands has been passed along from grandfather to father to grandson. That also may be a reason why it's hard for Waterbury to think of itself in a different way."
Despite its troubles, Waterbury has beauty and charm. As a historical text, it makes rich reading, and its most compelling chapters may well be those of sad decline, which, as Gibbon knew, speaks more truthfully about the human condition than the triumphant ascent.
 
 
3 Inviting Towns for Weekend Visitors

 
Wethersfield
 
HOW TO GET THERE: From New York City, take Interstate 287 north, then follow Interstate 95 north to Exit 48 (Interstate 91 north) at New Haven. Proceed north to Exit 26 for Wethersfield. Amtrak has service to Hartford, and Wethersfield, five miles south of Hartford, can be reached by taxi.
 
WHAT TO DO: The Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum offers tours and programs throughout the year. Tomorrow, it holds the Wethersfield Free for All, when the town's historic houses offer special events and demonstrations of Colonial crafts. This year's theme is "Witchcraft in Wethersfield." The museum also sponsors its "Wholesome and Toothsome" dinners in a barn behind the Webb house. The Wedding Feast takes place on June 17 and the Independence Day Feast and Ball on July 1. Each meal costs $30 a person. Reservations may be made through the museum, 211 Main Street, Wethersfield, Conn., 06109; (203) 529-0612. Through Oct. 31, the museum is open daily except Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission: $6 for adults; $5 for the elderly; $2.50 for ages 12 to 18 and college students with ID; $1 for ages 6 to 11; free for children under 6. The admission includes a tour of the three houses. Tours depart on the hour from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Group tours may be arranged on specific themes, like architecture or decorative arts. Admission to the Buttolph-Williams House, which the museum manages, is $2. A self-guided walking tour, "A Tour of the Old Village," is available from the museum. A discount admission to all four houses is $7.
 
The Wethersfield Historical Society, (203) 529-7656, manages three sites open to the public: the Old Academy at 150 Main Street, a free library (open from Tuesdays through Thursdays, noon to 4 P.M.; Saturdays, 1 to 4 P.M., and by appointment), the Keeney Memorial Cultural Center at 200 Main Street (admission $2 when an exhibition is on, otherwise free; open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., and Sundays, 1 P.M. to 4 P.M.) and the Captain James Francis House at 120 Hartford Avenue (open Saturdays from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. until Oct. 15, and by appointment; admission: $2 for adults; $1 for children).
 
WHERE TO STAY: Chester Bulkley House, 184 Main Street, Wethersfield, Conn., 06109; (203) 563-4236. Bed and breakfast in an 1830 Greek Revival house with five rooms, three with private bath, and a suite available on request. Rates: $65 for a room with shared bath; $75 for private bath; $85 for a king-size bed and private bath; $120 for a suite.
 
Butternut Farm, 1654 Main Street, Glastonbury, Conn., 06033; (203) 633-7197. Bed and breakfast in a Colonial farmhouse with antique furniture and a dynamic goose named Harry. Two rooms with shared bath; two apartments with private bath. Rates are $65 to $85. To reach the inn from New York, take Interstate 91 or Route 2 to Glastonbury. From the center of town, drive south on Main Street 1.6 miles to the inn. Enter from Whapley Road. From Wethersfield, take Route 3, cross bridge, and follow Route 2 east to Exit 8 (Glastonbury Center), which leads to Main Street.
 
Farmington
 
HOW TO GET THERE: From New York City, take the Hutchinson River Parkway and Merritt Parkway to Connecticut Route 8. Proceed north to Interstate 84, Exit 39 (Farmington). Follow Route 4 into the center of town. Bonanza buses run between the Port Authority Bus Terminal and Farmington. The fare is $24.95 for a same-day round trip, $35 round trip otherwise.
 
WHAT TO DO: The Farmington Historical Society offers group walking tours of Amistad-related sites by request, with groups of 8 to 20 preferred. The cost is $2 a person, with a $20 group minimum. Information is available from the Farmington Historical Society, P.O. Box 1645, Farmington, Conn., 06034; (203) 678-1645.
 
Information on the Farmington Valley may be obtained from the Farmington Valley/West Hartford Visitors Bureau, 41 East Main Street, P.O. Box 1550, Old Avon Village, Avon, Conn., 06001; (203) 674-1035 (in Connecticut) or (800) 468-6783.
 
Heritage Trails offers a variety of tours guided by Ernest R. Shaw, a historian. The Farmington Canal Tour, which takes place tomorrow, costs $39.95 and includes lunch in a 1795 hotel that once catered to the canal traffic. The Ancient Evening Cemetery Tours cost $29.95, which includes dinner at a Colonial inn. Heritage Trails also sells two 90-minute self-drive audiocassette tours of Farmington and Hartford ($9.95 each, plus $2.50 per order if ordering by mail). Information: Heritage Trails Sightseeing Tours, P.O. Box 138, Farmington, Conn. 06034; (203) 677-8867.
 
The Hill-Stead Museum, in a 1901 house designed by Stanford White, has a famous Impressionist art collection that includes three Monets, a Degas, a Manet and a Cassatt. It is at 35 Mountain Road, Farmington, Conn., 06032; (203) 677-9064. From May through October, the museum is open Wednesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The last tour begins at 4:00. Admission: $6 for adults; $5 for the elderly; $3 for children.
 
The Stanley-Whitman House, a restored 1720 saltbox with period furnishings, is open Wednesdays through Sundays from noon to 4 P.M. It is at 37 High Street; (203) 677-9222. Admission: $3 for adults; $2 for children and the elderly; $2.50 a person for groups of 10 or more.
 
WHERE TO STAY: Barney House, 11 Mountain Spring Road, Farmington, Conn., 06032; (203) 677-9735. Built in 1832, it sits on spacious grounds that were formerly the estate of a founder of the Pony Express and Wells Fargo. The inn has seven rooms, all with private bath. Rates are $79 for a single, $89 for a double, including continental breakfast.
 
Waterbury
 
HOW TO GET THERE: From New York City, take the Hutchinson River Parkway and Merritt Parkway to Connecticut Route 8 northbound, to Interstate 84 East, to exit 21; or take the Hutchinson River Parkway to Interstate 684 to Interstate 84 West, exit 21 (Meadow Street). Waterbury is on the Waterbury branch of Metro-North's New Haven Line.
 
WHAT TO DO: The Mattatuck Museum, in addition to its permanent exhibitions on the town's history, offers many historical tours, including one-hour walking tours of the Hillside District, the Cass Gilbert Historic District, the Waterbury Green, and Grand and Bank Streets. For a one-hour self-guided tour of the Hillside District, consult its brochure "Looking Up the Hillside." The museum also arranges group tours lasting from a half-day to two days on the region's architecture and history, as well as adventure tours. It also sponsors "Our Towns," a series of lectures, history-minded road rallies and walking tours. A full schedule is available on request. The museum is at 144 West Main Street, Waterbury, Conn., 06702; (203) 753-0381.
 
WHERE TO STAY: House on the Hill, 92 Woodlawn Terrace, Waterbury, Conn., 06710; (203) 757-9901. Bed and breakfast at the top of the Hillside District, in a 1888 Queen Anne extravaganza. Five rooms, each with private bath. Rates are from $75 to $100.
 
 
Walking in History
 Many towns and cities across Connecticut offer history tours. The state's 19 regional tourism councils have detailed information on local organizations and events. The councils' addresses and telephone numbers are listed in the booklet "Classic Connecticut," available from the Tourism Division, Connecticut Department of Economic Development, 865 Brook Street, Rocky Hill, Conn., 06067-3405; (800) 282-6863. Local historical societies are also good sources of information; they are listed in the Directory of Historical Societies and Agencies in the United States and Canada.
These towns and organizations offer unusually interesting or ambitious history tours:
THE FAIRFIELD HISTORICAL SOCIETY offers three self-guided tours, available at the society's headquarters, 636 Old Post Road, Fairfield. They are "Walking Through History: A Walking Tour of Black Rock and Southport Harbor" ($3.50), "Old Post Road and Town Center Walking Tour" (50 cents) and "Cameron Clark: Colonial Revival" ($1), a driving tour of Colonial Revival homes designed by Clark. Information: (203) 259-1598.
THE ANTIQUARIAN AND LANDMARKS SOCIETY owns and operates 11 historic houses and properties across the state, which are open from mid-May to mid-October. The society also has a particularly good self-guided tour of Suffield, prepared with the Suffield Historical Society. Color brochures of the society's properties or for Suffield may be obtained from the society, 394 Main Street, Hartford, Conn., 06103-9587; (203) 247-8996.
THE CONNECTICUT TRUST FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION occasionally publishes annotated bicycle tours with detailed route descriptions in its bimonthly newsletter. One recent tour was "Cycling to Historic Town Greens: Winsted to Colebrook to Winchester Center." Information is available from the trust, 940 Whitney Avenue, Hamden, Conn., 06517-4002; (203) 562-6312.
Norwich offers several self-guided tours of downtown, the Little Plain District, Chelsea Parade and the town's original settlement area, Norwichtown. Brochures are available from the SOCIETY OF FOUNDERS for $4 a set. They may be ordered by mail, with a check payable to the society, from the Society of Founders, P.O. Box 13, Norwich, Conn., 06360. They are also sold at Books Etcetera, 210 West Town Street, Norwich, (203) 889-5990. Dale Plummer, the town historian, leads tours by request for a negotiable fee; information: (203) 889-5990.
The NEW HAVEN PRESERVATION TRUST offers free guided tours of the New Haven Green, Yale architecture, and other architectural and historical topics. Information: (203) 562-5919.
THE LITCHFIELD HISTORICAL SOCIETY offers a guided group walking tour of historic Litchfield, as well as a self-guided brochure and audiotape tour. Information: (203) 567-4501
THE GREATER MIDDLETOWN PRESERVATION TRUST publishes two detailed self-guided tours, "A Walking Tour of Early Middletown, 1650 to 1850" and "A Walking Tour of Main Street, Middletown." The route may be obtained by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the trust at 27 Washington Street, Middletown, Conn., 06457.
THE GREATER HARTFORD ARCHITECTURE CONSERVANCY sells an audiocassette tour, "Hartford on Tour," for $6.99. Credit-card orders are taken by phone: (203) 525-0279.
THE SALISBURY CANNON MUSEUM publishes an unusually detailed fold-out brochure with a 25-stop tour called "A Capsule History and Historic Walking Tour of Salisbury Furnace at the Time of the American Revolution." It is available for $3 from the Salisbury Association, P.O. Box 553, Salisbury, Conn., 06068-0553.

HEADLINE: DEMOCRAT MOCKS HEALTH-CARE IDEA

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
An influential Congressman said today that managed competition, the health policy favored by President Clinton, is "a fairy tale" and would probably not be the basis for any legislation passed by Congress to overhaul the nation's health-care system.
Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, made the comments as he issued a report from the Congressional Budget Office. The report said the strategy of managed competition could reduce health-care spending, but the study expressed doubt whether Americans were willing to make the radical changes needed to achieve such savings. 
 Mr. Stark's comments came 15 days after Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, ridiculed managed competition by likening it to supply-side economics and "Star Wars." Quite apart from the merits of such criticism, it appears that the two Democrats are pleading publicly with the Administration to scale down and reconsider its plan to overhaul the health-care system.
 
Clinton Faces Party Critics
 Mr. Stark's position is no surprise. For years, he has argued that Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, should be expanded to cover all Americans. But the comments of Mr. Stark and Mr. Rostenkowski show that the President will have to deal with critics in his own party, including lawmakers who will be responsible for shepherding Mr. Clinton's proposal through Congress.
As chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Rostenkowski has a large role in writing health-care legislation and tax bills. Mr. Clinton has said he intends to send his proposal to Congress next month.
Hillary Rodham Clinton and her task force on health care say they have consulted extensively with Congress. But Mr. Stark said: "We are kept in the dark. We have been asked to support a bill or a plan without knowing the details."
Advocates of managed competition say it will empower consumers. Under the plan, individuals and small businesses would pool their resources and buy health care from competing networks organized by doctors, hospitals and insurance companies. In theory, these networks would vie with one another by offering high-quality care at low prices.
 
Dissent From White House
 The Congressional Budget Office observed that managed competition "has not been tried anywhere in the world." Mr. Stark likened it to a unicorn, "a beautiful animal in fairyland, but unseen on earth."
Mr. Stark said one of the problems with managed competition is that hardly anybody "can explain it." Indeed, he said, with reference to President Clinton, "I don't think he knows what it is."
Robert O. Boorstin, a White House spokesman, said: "We have not completely reviewed the report by the Congressional Budget Office. But I don't believe that it is a valid critique of the plan we are going to arrive at."

HEADLINE: Senator Sues Over Lost Trust Fund

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Senator Christopher S. Bond of Missouri sued Paine Webber Group Inc. and a former Paine Webber investment adviser today, charging that he lost more than $1 million from a blind trust because of the adviser's "Federal securities fraud."
Mr. Bond, a lawyer who comes from a wealthy brick-making family, opened the trust in 1973 to avoid the appearance of conflict of interest when he was elected Governor of Missouri. Such trusts became common after Watergate led to an increase in concern over politicians' ethics. 
 As a member of the Appropriations, Banking and Small Business committees, Mr. Bond, a Republican, has played a leading role in economic legislation.
Mr. Bond's suit in Federal court in St. Louis charges that William J. Reik of Manhattan, a former Paine Webber employee, mismanaged the Senator's portfolio by concentrating its assets in "three thinly traded and illiquid securities," according to a statement from the Senator.
The statement said that Mr. Reik had illegally manipulated the price of three stocks, had failed to follow instructions to diversify the portfolio and had neglected to disclose conflicts of interest "between his management of a Paine Webber fund and separate advisory accounts like Bond's."
 
'Totally Wiped Out'
 Under the terms of the trust, Mr. Bond was not supposed to know the identity or nature of his investments.
In the statement, Mr. Bond said: "My investments were totally wiped out. I have filed suit to recover what I have lost." The suit seeks $1,050,000 in damages.
Maureen Fantz, assistant manager of public relations for Paine Webber, said, "We're aware of the claim for the lawsuit, and we intend to defend it vigorously. We have no further comment."
Richard Martens, a lawyer in West Palm Beach, Fla., who represents Mr. Reik, said by telephone tonight that "we intend to defend what we believe is a frivolous lawsuit."
"Unlike the Senator," he added, "we do not intend to try this case in the press; we intend to try it in the courtroom, where it belongs."
Mr. Bond said in his statement that Mr. Reik had been employed by Paine Webber for 14 years before he was dismissed in 1991 "for compliance problems related to his handling of clients' accounts.
"He has been the subject of numerous customer complaints and various investigations by regulatory agencies," the statement said.
 
More Debt Than Assets
 Mr. Bond's staff made the lawsuit available for inspection in his office this evening. In the filing, Mr. Bond said he only learned of the full extent of his financial troubles early this year, after he notified the Ethics Committee of his intention to terminate the blind trust.
"Reik represented to Bond that his investment strategy was conservative," court papers say, adding that soon after, Mr. Reik liquidated the portfolio and invested the money in risky stocks.
The suit asserts that Mr. Reik persuaded Senator Bond to borrow money and add it to the trust fund to buy more stock, so that the trust fund became "in effect, a margin account."
In the fall of 1989, the Senator's older brother, Arthur D. Bond Jr., reviewed the portfolio and expressed concern about its concentration in the three stocks. According to the court filing, Senator Bond told Mr. Reik that his investments were "inappropriate and should be more diversified," but Mr. Reik failed to change the trust's portfolio.
By December 1990, the suit says, the Senator's investment in the three stocks -- Neutrogena, Tejon Ranch and Frisch's Restaurants -- had declined in value from $1 million to $543,000, against the portfolio's outstanding loans of $595,000.
Mr. Bond met Mr. Reik, an investment advisor at Mitchell Hutchins Asset Management, a registered agent of Paine Webber in Wilmington Del., in 1985 and transferred his trust account to him from Wilmington Trust.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON TAX BILL;
Clinton Readies A Drive to 'Sell' Budget to People

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Eager to show Congress that he still has the political wherewithal needed to muscle through his budget bill, President Clinton has planned a new offensive to sell it as a blueprint for tax fairness.
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton plans a spate of public appearances beginning Friday with his third formal news conference and continuing next week with a trip to New Mexico and California to show his commitment to turning the economy around. 
 One political adviser to the President described the rush of activity -- larded with full measures of anti-Washington rhetoric and populist imagery -- as a White House attempt to regain the initiative by "defining things our way."
The defining began today with a mild White House appraisal of potentially troubling economic news: a rise in consumer prices of 0.4 percent in April.
 
Hoping for a 'Blip'
 "It's not -- I want to watch it and we will be watching it, but it could be just a blip," the adviser said. "There are lots of things that could have produced it. We'll just have to see."
White House officials were pleased today when the House Ways and Means Committee approved the major portions of Mr. Clinton's tax plan, which includes higher rates for the wealthy and corporations. They were also happy to take the advice of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the committee, who said the President should do more to whip up support for his plan among the citizenry.
 
Striving for a Focus
 "The pitch you make to them is that this is a fair package," said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. "It balances between spending cuts and tax increases. It makes sure that those who made the most pay the most in taxes, and it makes sure that the middle class is treated fairly."
Mr. Clinton is striving for the focus that he admitted last week he had lost. When a businessman approached him today to advise him to push harder for a plan he has already endorsed -- the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act -- that would speed up highway construction spending, Mr. Clinton advised patience.
"Let's try to go ahead and pass the budget now and get out of this whole issue about whether it was increasing the deficit or not, blow that away, and then we'll try to see if we can't get people to focus on the, on the I.S.T.E.A. issue alone," he said.
As the President was honing a populist message, he was returning from a New York fund-raising event where he had helped the Democratic Party raise more than $3 million. Last Friday, he announced a campaign-finance reform plan that would limit contributions to political parties, including unregulated "soft money" contributions that made up part of Wednesday's take.
 
Playing by the Rules
 The $1,500-a-head dinner at Lincoln Center, which featured the entertainers Whoopi Goldberg, Barry Manilow, Carly Simon and Sharon Stone, allowed contributors to make donations to the party under current rules that allow $20,000 to be given in a calendar year. Mr. Stephanopoulos said the Clinton Administration would play by the new rules it has proposed when the legislation is passed -- not before.
"We're not going to engage in unilateral disarmament," he said.
Mr. Clinton has been building toward his latest appeal for several days. In travels to Cleveland and to the suburbs of Chicago earlier this week, he derided Washington politicians as out of touch, a theme he is likely to repeat when he holds a televised town meeting in San Diego on Monday night. He is also scheduled to visit Los Alamos, N.M., on Monday and Los Angeles on Tuesday.
Mr. Stephanopoulos resisted suggestions that Mr. Clinton might have a difficult time selling new taxes, especially in states like California that have been slow to join the recovery.
"Does the middle class have to contribute along with everyone else?" Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "Yes, a little bit. But all in the interest of bringing the deficit down and getting this economy moving again and creating jobs in the future."
 
Path to Salvation?
 But not all Democrats are convinced that the President is doing the best thing by hitting the road. "It's not where the President is," said Brian Lunde, a Democratic consultant. "It's what is he doing or saying."
Mr. Clinton, however, looks to the road that leads out of Washington as the path to his political salvation. Speaking before a friendly audience at a dinner of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights earlier this week, he gave voice to some of his frustration at learning the ways of Washington.
"Why don't we behave in Washington the way people behave in their normal lives?" he said. "We need opportunity and responsibility."

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON TAX BILL: Reporter's Notebook;
Some Familiar Fiddling In a Big, Stately Setting

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The cavernous hearing room of the House Ways and Means Committee is one of the most fabulous public spaces that the lower chamber has to show off.
Domed and semicircular, gilded and friezed, the room is a stage-designer setting for momentous governmental labors like fiddling with the tax code. 
 In October 1986 it was in this room, in the Longworth Office Building across the street from the Capitol, that the committee chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, marshaled his Democratic colleagues to back a Republican initiative, slashing income tax rates and closing scores of loopholes over the fang-and-claw opposition of lobbyists who filled the chamber and spilled into the marble halls.
Today Mr. Rostenkowski was back in the same room, raising the income tax rates he had lowered and reopening some of the loopholes he had closed, and calling it a "major victory" for the economy and the Democratic Administration of President Clinton. A huge pack of lobbyists, fangs bared and claws extended, filled the room and spilled into the marble hallway.
Afterward, an associate of the chairman said it was a bittersweet moment, but that no reform can -- or maybe should -- last forever.
 
The Ascent of Women
 When Mr. Rostenkowski presided over the 1986 version of tax overhaul, the lobbyists, excluded from the closed meetings, loitered in the elegant corridors for hours on end. Reporters nicknamed the hallways "Gucci Gulch" because many of the men wore Gucci loafers, the Air Jordans of the 1980's influence-seeker.
Gucci Gulch is back, with a twist: the designer logo is plastered on handbags, not loafers. In striking contrast to 1986, more than half the people in the crowd at today's climactic tax-writing session were women. And while many of those were paralegals or aides to more senior lobbyists, many more were not.
"There's the truckers; there's Du Pont," said one female lobbyist, identifying the women in the crowd by the interest they represented. "There are a lot more of us now. I think it's one area where people have gotten accustomed to working with women, because women have been on the tax staffs on the Hill for a while."
As for the Ways and Means panel, there was only only one woman on the committee in 1986 -- Representative Barbara Kennelly of Connecticut. Today there are two: Mrs. Kennelly and Nancy Johnson, also of Connecticut. "Some things," the lobbyist said, "haven't changed much at all."
 
The Quick and the Dead
 Having extracted as much money as could be taken comfortably from the living, the Ways and Means panelists have turned this week to the dead.
The story: For a decade now, the Social Security Administration has contracted with state vital statistics offices to buy rosters of the recently departed -- lately, at about 20 cents a head -- to insure that its monthly checks are not sent to recipients who no longer need them. Congressional aides say the program has averted a good deal of fraud, and Social Security officials have urged other Federal offices that convey benefits -- 123 of them, in all -- to avail themselves of the lists, too.
But the states have balked at the idea. Thirty-four have inserted exclusivity clauses into their contracts, barring Social Security from sharing any of the names with fellow agencies. And some are brazen about their motives, saying they like the money and want each of the 124 Federal offices to buy the names on its own.
News of this reached the Ways and Means Committee, and the panel is using its budget bill to send a message to the states, in the form of an amendment adopted on Wednesday. It says that if the states don't start allowing Social Security officials to pass around lists of the dead, it will stop allowing the states to use Social Security numbers -- for tax forms, drivers' licenses or anything else.
For a money-hungry Government, this is no small matter. One committee aide said that Federal agencies are dispensing millions of dollars to dead people every month. A General Accounting Office inquiry found that a Civil Service retiree received his monthly pension check until October 1990, although he died in November 1985. The extra payments amounted to $122,333.
"And that," the aide added, "includes cost-of-living adjustments."

HEADLINE: Dow Slides 34.32 as Inflation Fears Grow

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Driven by renewed inflation fears and pursuing the plunging bond market, the stock market fell headlong yesterday.
All major stock indexes dropped in heavy trading, including the American Stock Exchange index, even though vaulting gold prices and gold stocks on the exchange tended to lift it. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 34.32 points to close at 3,447.99, after being down more than 20 points for nearly the entire session. It was the Dow's sharpest drop since April 2, when the index fell 69 points, and it came only a day after the Dow hit a record high.
Yesterday's selloff swept a wide swath of stocks: 21 of the Dow's 30 blue-chip stocks were down. Eight stocks fell 1 point or more, led by J. P. Morgan. The big bank holding company was down 1 7/8, to 66 3/8.
Moreover, the Standard & Poor's 500, with a far greater variety of stocks, showed how broad and deep the selloff was. That index fell 5.57 points, to 439.23. An eye-catching 378 stocks of the index were down, led by such major companies as American Telephone and Telegraph and Pepsico.
 
Major Stock Groups Declining
 The major stock groups declining in the S.& P. 500 were dividend-rich electric utilities like Consolidated Edison, telephone companies and diversified health-care companies like Abbott Laboratories, the pharmaceutical company.
The Nasdaq composite index, dominated by smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, has tended to perform better than other indexes recently. Even so, the index lost 6.05 points, to 675.64.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index dropped 2.79 points, to 243.27, and losing stocks outnumbered winners, 1,412 to 597. About 293.9 million shares changed hands yesterday, compared with 255.7 million shares on Wednesday. The American Stock Exchange market value index dropped 0.52 point, to 427.91.
This week's schedule was heavy with Government economic indicators and three critical Treasury note auctions.
The four-tenths of 1 percent Consumer Price Index rise was double what analysts had expected and indicative of a 4.8 percent annualized inflation rate. That upended most investors' assumptions of a 1993 inflation that would parallel the 1992 rate of 2.9 percent.
Many stock traders had also assumed that with low inflation, the Federal Reserve Board would cut interest rates further, making the stock market an even more attractive place to invest.
After the consumer-price shock, gold contracts for June delivery rose $7.50, to $369.30 an ounce. Five of the 10 most active stocks on the New York and American stock exchanges were gold stocks.
Echo Bay Mines, on the Amex, was the most active gold stock, with 9.1 million shares changing hands. It closed up 3/4 point, to 11 1/4. An exception to the booming gold stocks was Newmont Mining, whose sale of a large stake to George Soros, the financier, helped spark the recent interest in gold. Newmont, on the Big Board, closed down 1/2, to 50.
The most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange was Royal Dutch Petroleum at 13.4 million shares. It closed up 2 1/8 points, to 93 1/8, on surprisingly higher quarterly earnings and the better analyst assessments that followed.

HEADLINE: Trust Me

 BODY:
The details of Bill Clinton's latest pledge to reduce the budget deficit do not matter nearly as much as their symbolism and what they say about Mr. Clinton's determination to repair his own political vulnerability. Having engaged in endless musing about drift and disarray in his Administration, he now seems ready to do something about it.
This week he proposed to sequester "every penny of new taxes and budget cuts" in a "trust fund" to be used only to reduce the Federal deficit. That won't change the outlines of his budget, which calls for $496 billion in deficit reduction from extra taxes, spending cuts and lower interest payments. But it may persuade the public he's serious. 
 Mr. Clinton's credibility on the deficit urgently needed repair. He has been losing the public relations war ever since the long and unsuccessful fight over the stimulus package, which gave opportunists like Bob Dole and Ross Perot all they needed to portray Mr. Clinton as a devious spendthrift.
Democratic leaders warned him that his entire economic package could suffer the same fate if he allowed his opponents to present it as a spending scheme without offsetting cuts. Others worried that a defeat for the tax bill would, by dooming the rest of his economic program, strangle Mr. Clinton's infant Presidency in its crib. The opinion polls were not reassuring either.
Mr. Clinton then hit the road for a week's worth of public repositioning, with the trust fund as his trump card. Republicans like Senator Phil Gramm accused him of a "transparent attempt to mislead." Mr. Dole said he gave "smoke and mirrors" a bad name. Friendlier voices argued that the fund simply gave the public another badly needed level of reassurance that painful tax increases would not be diverted to new programs.
This reading of Mr. Clinton's purposes was embraced by Representative Charles E. Schumer, co-sponsor of a bill establishing a legally separate trust fund. "There is a problem of credibility. The public does not believe we will really cut the deficit when we say we will. . . . Everywhere I went in my district people said, 'We are willing to tighten our belt, but we don't believe you.' "
The Administration's tax proposals passed their first big test when the House Ways and Means Committee approved them yesterday. The President's recent barnstorming was irrelevant because the outcome was foreordained. But stiffer tests lie ahead in the Senate, where Mr. Clinton's newfound fervor on the deficit could make the difference.

HEADLINE: More Power to the Powerful

BYLINE: By Richard Burt; Richard Burt, an assistant secretary of state and Ambassador to West Germany in the Reagan Administration, is a partner at McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is time to transform the Group of Seven, a loose and often ineffective cluster of rich countries, into a real international steering committee that can deal with the economic and security challenges of the post-cold-war world.
The need for collective action is mounting. With the Balkans in turmoil, Russia unraveling, the world economy stagnating and weapons of mass destruction proliferating to renegade nations such as North Korea, the United States and its G-7 partners can watch the world drift into chaos or can assert leadership. At another turning point, after World War II, Washington provided such leadership. Today, America cannot -- and should not -- play this role on its own. 
 The United Nations is more active but is still hampered by political disagreements, budgetary constraints and an unresponsive bureaucracy. Hopes that the European Community might exercise greater influence have not panned out: Europe's failure in the Yugoslav crisis is a case in point.
The answer is not to invent new international machinery but to give the Group of Seven a bigger mandate. Unlike the United Nations Security Council, the G-7 includes Germany and Japan; the other members are Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- all economically strong, politically democratic and linked to Washington.
The governments, of course, already work together in several areas. But except for regular sessions of finance ministers and central bankers, cooperation has tended to be limited or ineffective. For example, the G-7 has not followed up on a 1992 agreement to develop a program for coping with the potential disasters posed by aging nuclear power plants in the former Soviet Union. It remains to be seen whether and how the new agreement on a rescue package for Russia will be carried out.
The most organized and visible activity, the annual meetings of the seven heads of government, has evolved into an elaborate photo-op, "offering platitudes," as Jacques Delors, the European Commission president, observed.
America's key partners are likely to resist added responsibilities. The alternative, however, is not the free ride provided by Washington but a breakdown of international order; their self-interest is likely to bring them around. The very fact that they are prepared to rely on the G-7 format to attack problems like the Russian crisis is a good sign.
To fulfill its enormous potential, the the group must change. It needs concrete goals. In the political-security realm, it must continue to help the Russians while working to stabilize the other former Soviet republics. In the economic area, the main goal should be to achieve the concessions necessary for a new global trade agreement.
Over the long term, the agenda should include slowing the spread of nuclear arms technology, managing China's emergence as a world power and dealing with the rise of religious fundamentalism and the collapse of order in the third world.
The G-7 should also be institutionalized. It should meet three or four times a year. This would give the leaders more time for real problem-solving and strengthening the habits of cooperation. Consultations by finance ministers should be complemented by regular meetings of foreign and defense ministers, trade negotiators and environmental heads. A small, permanent secretariat should be created, mainly to insure better preparation for group deliberations and better execution of decisions.
Transforming the G-7 along these lines will not reduce the need for other international organizations, like a better-managed U.N., for crisis management. Nor will it rule out the need for Washington to take unilateral steps from time to time. In the end, however, an upgraded G-7 can set a global agenda and realize it.

HEADLINE: Trade Agreement Will Cost Jobs and Revenue;
The Cleanup Bonanza

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Free Trade's Huge Costs" (Op-Ed, May 2), Jerry Brown mentions the words "environment" and "environmental" half a dozen times without once hinting at the huge opportunities for United States suppliers of environmental technologies and services that the North America Free Trade Agreement represents.
After more than a decade of pollution-based economic growth, Mexico -- like most of Latin America -- plans to spend tens of billions of dollars on environmental cleanup. This is a response to indigenous middle classes fed up with tainted air and water, and a consequence of the growing synergism between less wasteful (less polluting) manufacturing and international competitiveness. 
 The only question is whether the $130 billion-a-year United States environmental cleanup industry will get the lion's share of this export bonanza or, if the continental market that the treaty would bring into being fails to materialize, the Germans and Japanese win the prize.
The environment, as this country's best and brightest business people realize, and Mr. Brown clearly does not, is emerging as the wealth-producing mechanism for American workers and entrepreneurs in the 1990's that autos, computers and military spending were in years past.
Failing to approve the trade agreement would be a giant step toward throwing away our national dominance of the continental green marketplace.
 
MICHAEL SILVERSTEIN
Philadelphia, May 3, 1993
 
The writer heads a company that publishes environmental reports.
