HEADLINE: THE CLINTON TAX BILL;
Something for (or From) Everybody

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
From the top of the income ladder to the bottom, from the big-city professional with a portfolio of tax-free bonds to the single parent on the minimum wage, people would face important changes under provisions of the tax law approved today by a Congressional committee.
The fundamentals of the proposal adopted by the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee are easy enough to state. For example, just as the Clinton Administration proposed, it would raise the top income tax rates to nearly 40 percent, and it would expand the tax credit that adds cash to the earnings of many poor workers. 
 But nothing in tax law is ever quite that simple. So to carry out these objectives, Congress finds itself making many detailed decisions that will help, or punish, some people more than others; that will raise, or cost, millions of dollars; and that will steer people toward, or away from, certain types of spending and investment.
For the wealthy, the fine print highlights the inevitable consequences of backing away from the tax-cutting 1980's, when top tax rates came down and tax shelters became scarcer.. Now that the opposite is true, Congress and the Administration are on guard against the resurgence of shelters.
 
Obscure but Important
 For the poor, the fine print illustrates the new Administration's determination to get people off welfare and out of poverty, even if that is done by subsidizing jobs, whether through direct payments that create negative tax rates for the low-income working class or through tax breaks for companies that provide jobs in depressed cities.
Some of the changes have drawn little attention but are considered major precedents by tax specialists.
For example, for the first time President Clinton would give an earned-income tax credit, which is a cash benefit meant to help low-income workers rise above the poverty level, to people without children. Although they could only get a modest credit of a few hundred dollars, the feature could become an important one in a program that has steadily expanded over the years.
And in another change, the earned-income tax credit would be made available to some people who earn as much as $28,000 a year. Such an expansive program is aimed partly at offsetting the effects of possible energy taxes on those with relatively low incomes, a new twist on the anti-poverty measure.
 
Changes at the Top
 At the upper end of the income scale, too, there are important changes being considered, aside from the most obvious one: the increase in the top tax rate.
Especially notable are provisions meant to prevent the wealthy from avoiding income taxes by shifting investment income from ordinary interest, which will be more heavily taxed, to capital gains, which will not.
Under the President's plan, people who earn more than $250,000 would pay the 36 percent top tax rate plus a 10 percent surcharge, for an effective tax rate on ordinary income of 39.6 percent.
That new top tax rate would be 40 percent higher than the tax on long-term capital gains, providing a powerful incentive to shift income into investments that provide capital gains.
So the Clinton proposal includes five complex provisions that would discourage upper-income investors from designing investments tailored to provide capital gains instead of ordinary income.
 
Change on Bond Income
 For example, the wealthy will find that it is no longer safe to buy zero-coupon tax-free bonds at a discount from face value on the assumption that the growth in value as the bond approaches maturity will be taxed as a capital gain, as it is now. From now on, that gain would be treated as ordinary income and taxed accordingly.
And people who borrow money to finance their investments would face a change in rules governing the deductibility of interest on the loans. The point of this change would be to prevent people from using a deduction to obtain a 40-percent tax savings on something that was only taxable at 28 percent.
Under current law, taxpayers who borrow to buy securities can deduct their interest expenses from the taxable amount earned through dividends, interest earnings, and net long-term capital gains.
But under the proposed new rules, an investor usually could not count net long-term capital gains as investment income for purposes of deducting interest expenses.
 
Closing a Loophole
 The proposed rules would also be tightened on claiming capital-gains treatment for the money received when an investor sells shares in a partnership. That would close a loophole involving inventory owned by a partnership that has appreciated in value.
And the proposal would change the tax treatment of preferred stock that is stripped of its dividends and sold at a discount. This device is often used to generate automatic capital gains so that people (or companies) with capital losses can write them off against the gains.
The tax bill's authors are clearly worried that some investors would set up financial transactions that are effectively loans masquerading as capital investments.
For example, a taxpayer might buy 100 shares of stock for $1,000 and at the same time enter into a contract to sell the stock a year later for $1,060. In effect, that is a loan at a 6 percent interest rate, but under current law it would be treated as a capital gain of $60. The Clinton proposal would treat much or even all of the gain as interest and tax it at the ordinary income rate.
The rich have not been alone in coping with complexities in the tax law. A perennial complaint about the earned-income tax credit for the working poor has been its complexity.
 
Searching for Simplicity
 The tax credit varies with income and family size, rising to a peak and then tapering off at higher income levels. Along with the basic credit, the program in recent years has included supplemental grants for people with newborn children and for those who buy health insurance.
In search of simplicity, the supplemental credits would disappear under the proposal endorsed by the House committee today.
Not all the working poor would be gaining equally under the provisions, and the incentive to work -- the main reason for expanding the credit -- would vary according to circumstances.
Indeed, some analysts have noted that the credit, which under the draft bill would be as much as 40 percent, is growing to the point that some people who have been hiding income might be tempted to report it, or even to claim to have earned more than they really did. Eugene Steurle of the Urban Institute has called this prospect "the superterranean economy" -- a twist on the age-old underground economy.
As the tax credit is shaping up, someone earning $12,500 who has one child would get a credit of $1,838 in 1994, and if the child was under 1 year old the credit would be $400 more. But under the new formulas, the same person would get a maximum credit of just $1,820 next year.
By contrast, a person with $6,000 income and one older child would get $1,596 under the new formulas in 1994, compared with $1,380 under the old rules; the payment would go up to $2,062 in 1995.
Notably, somebody who had at least two children and earned $24,000 would have received nothing under the old system. Under the new rules, that person would get $631 in 1994 and $793 in 1985.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 15, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about provisions of tax legislation approved by the House Ways and Means Committee misstated the tax treatment of certain tax-free bonds purchased for less than their face value. The increase in value of such bonds as they approach maturity is usually free of taxes. But under current law in some cases -- including those in which bonds were purchased for less than the original offering price -- part of the gain from the sale is taxed as a capital gain. Under the proposed legislation, that part would be taxed as ordinary income.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Tax Bill: A Work in Progress"
 
Highlights of the President's tax proposals, and adjustments approved yesterday by the House Ways and Means Committee. Items markek with an asterisk (*) were changed by the committee from the President's original budget, proposed last month.
 
PERSONAL TAXES
 
INCOME TAX: Under current law, the top tax rate on ordinary income is 31 percent.
 A new top marginal tax rate of 36 percent would be applied to taxable income in excess of $140,000 for married people filing joint returns or more than $115,000 for single people.
The tax on ordinary income, but not on capital gains, would be increased by an additional 10 percent for incomes above $250,000, for an effective top income tax rate of 39.6 percent.
 
CAPITAL GAINS: Under current law, the top tax rate is 28 percent.
This would be unchanged.
SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS: Under current law, half of Social Security benefits earned by retires makeing more than $35,000 (married people) or $25,000 (singles) is taxed.
 Benefits to those people would be taxed at higher rates. They would have to include 85 percent of their Social Security payments as taxable income.
 
EARNED-INCOME TAX CREDIT: Under current law, the credit supplements the wages of low-income workers with children.
The credit would be expanded. By 1995, the credit would equal nearly 40 percent of the earnings of taxpayers with two or more children, up to a maximum credit of $3,460, more than double the maximum credit available this year. The maximum credit would be reduced by about $200 for every $1,000 of earnings in excess of $11,000. For the first time, some people without children would qualify.
 
DIVERSION OF INCOME: To thwart taxpayers who might respond to the higher income tax rates by shifting ordinary income into lower-taxed capital gains, the bill includes provisions that would change the tax treatment of zero-coupon municipal bonds, preferred stock that has been stripped of dividends, and other financial instruments.
 
LUXURY TAXES*: Under current law, there is a special tax on planes, boats, furs and jewelry, but would index the value of cars so that inflation would not push cars into the luxury category over the years.
 
ENERGY TAXES: Under current law, there is no broad-based energy tax. Federal exicse taxes are imposed on many fuels and would be extended.
 
B.T.U. TAX*: The new legislation would tax virtually all forms of energy at a base rate of about 26 cents per million British thermal units, or B.T.U.'s, a measure of energy content. A supplemental tax of about 60 cents per million B. T.U.'s would be put on petroleum products other than home heating oil and liquefied petroleum gases.
 
ELECTRIC UTILITIES*: The tax will be passed on to consumers as a separate line on their electricity bills, insuring that state regulators do not force the utilities to bear the tax.
 
ALUMINUM*: and other industries that use power in electrolytic processes would be exempted from the B.T.U. tax, just as industries that use oil as a feedstock were exempted in the Administration's proposal.
 
FARMERS*: who use gasoline and diesel fuel on the farm would not have to pay the supplemental B.T.U. tax on those fuels. But in exchange, farm interests had to give up the exemption from the tax that the Administration had proposed for ethanol and methanol, which would be taxed at the same rate as petroleum fuels.
 
THE B.T.U. TAX*: will be assessed on imported goods whose value is more than 2 percent attributable to direct energy inputs. That way they will not have a competitive advantage over companies that manufacture comparable products in the United States and have to pay the tax.
 
CORPORATE TAXES
 
LARGE BUSINESSES*: The current top tax rate is 34 percent.
 The new top rate, for companies with profits of more than $10 million, would be 35 percent, not 36 percent as the Administration proposed.
 
SMALL BUSINESSES*: Under current law, businesses can write off not more than $10,000 in equipment.
 They would be allowed to write off in one year, rather than several, the cost of equipment up to $25,000.
 
INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT*: was eliminated.
 
BUSINESS DEDUCTIONS: Under current law, 80 percent of the cost of meals and entertainment is deductible. Now half of those expenses would be deductible. Companies could not deduct executives; salaries above $1 million.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Reaches Its High Mark Since Late '91

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
A gale of commodity market wagering and a puff of inflation swept gold prices yesterday to the highest levels since late 1991.
Gold rose $7.50 an ounce to $369.30 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Open interest in call options, which allow buyers to multiply their gains from a rise in gold prices, vaulted to a record. 
 Traders pointed to activity by Sir James Goldsmith, the European financier, as the main impetus behind the price rise. Sir James has been a major purchaser of the call options that expire today, which give him the right to buy gold for delivery in June at prices below current levels. Those who wrote, or sold, June options would have to buy gold at any price today to settle with Sir James or other option holders.
Some strategists said that Paul Tudor Jones, a leading American trader, and perhaps also the Sultan of Brunei, were busy in the gold market.
"It's been a wild and crazy day," said Ian MacDonald, precious-metals marketing manager for Credit Suisse in New York. "The options dealers had to do a lot of scrambling."
Many dealers and some investment funds have been routinely selling call options, giving buyers the right to purchase gold at fixed but higher prices by a certain deadline. As long as gold prices were depressed, the options expired worthless and the dealers pocketed the extra income from the option sales. But a burst of activity, and surges in prices, in the last two months have left these dealers with large losses, analysts said.
The most precious commodity now seems to be any insight into what Sir James will do today.
"If he holds and takes delivery, we could go higher," said Alan Posnick, who runs precious-metals operations at MTB Bank. "If he liquidates, I don't know where, on the way down, the market stops."
Sir James bought gold options last month with several hundred million dollars in proceeds from selling a 10 percent stake in Newmont Mining to George Soros, another formidable money manager and speculator.
It was unclear whether Sir James had followed the same course with $287 million he made this week from selling a further 9.5 percent interest to three investment banks. Although some of his options expire today, any sudden liquidation might hurt the value of his other options, which extend for several months.
Attempts to reach Sir James and officials of Brunei were unsuccessful. A spokesman for Mr. Jones had no comment.
Mr. Posnick said that commodity-market machinations were shaking the market much harder than any inflation figures. But some evidence of inflation's return, other analysts said, has made it that much easier for big speculators to set off a stampede.
 
Inflation and China Factors
 The markets were confronted yesterday with news that consumer prices had risen four-tenths of 1 percent in April, about twice as much as expected, following Wednesday's report that producer prices had bounded higher. Gold is a classic refuge from inflation, and thus gains in price on the fear of revived inflation.
Heavy gold investments by China, which last year surpassed the United States as the world's largest buyer, have contributed, as well, to gold's rise from an eight-year low of $326.90 in March.
Yesterday, Commodity Exchange prices reached an intra-day peak of $373 yesterday before pulling back late in the session.
Comex officials estimated the day's volume at 100,000 contracts, each for delivery of 100 ounces -- about twice last year's average volume. The total of open interest in call options, those not offset by any other investments, reached 131,093 yesterday, breaking the record of 130,117 set on Sept. 13, 1990.
Gold stocks, usually more volatile than the metal, were mixed. Echo Bay Mines gained 75 cents, to $11.125, but Newmont fell 50 cents, to close at $50.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Oil Prices Fall
 By Reuters
Oil prices dropped below $20 a barrel yesterday because of strong refinery output and a demand by Kuwait for a higher production quota from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, crude oil for delivery in June fell 42 cents, to $19.78 a barrel; June heating oil fell 1.11 cents, to 54.03 cents a gallon, and June unleaded gasoline dropped 1.29 cents, to 59.34 cents a gallon. natural gas firmed, rising 5.6 cents, to $2.271 for a million British thermal units.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 19, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about the surge in gold prices misstated the day on which a record was set for "open interest" in call options on gold futures -- that is, for the number of such options that were not exercised, not closed out and not allowed to expire. The record, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, was set last Wednesday, not Thursday.

HEADLINE: Dying Nebraska Town Finds New Hope in Outcast Doctor

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARGENT, Neb.

 BODY:
In the America of shopping malls, cul-de-sacs and home-delivered pizza, Dr. Bernardo G. Bilang would hardly be the first choice of a family looking for a doctor. As a result of questionable medical procedures, he has been forced to surrender his right to practice in one state and has agreed never again to deliver babies in another.
And in February he was arrested on Federal bank fraud charges. 
 But choice is a luxury unfamiliar to far-flung little towns like Sargent, where the train no longer stops and abandoned farmhouses creak in the wind. The townspeople regard Dr. Bilang as a savior, the only general practitioner who was willing to settle here in the middle of Nebraska.
 
Seeking Another Chance
 It was Dr. Bilang who saved an elderly man with emphysema when he came into the Sargent hospital's emergency room not long ago, gasping for air. People here say the man would not have survived the hour's drive to the doctor in Broken Bow.
Nonetheless, the state's hospital board has denied a permanent license to Dr. Bilang, who had been practicing on a three-month permit since arriving here in January. A ruling on an appeal is expected soon.
Without a doctor, the Sargent hospital would probably have to close, so this town of 710 people has mounted a petition drive to persuade the board to reverse its decision and give the Dr. Bilang, and the town, another chance.
"We're not asking for some fancy doctor," Bill Gumb said as he threw down his cards in a tavern game with three other men in overalls. "What's going to happen when a farmer gets hurt in the field, or a kid gets hit on a bicycle, or an old person has a heart attack?"
Hidden away in the hilly countryside here in the heart of Nebraska, nearly 80 miles from an interstate highway, Sargent has seen its population fade by 50 percent in the last half-century. On its gap-toothed Main Street, the Harvest Baptist Church and Forget Me Not craft shop sit among boarded storefronts. High school graduation ceremonies are tearful farewells to young people who will move far away to find jobs.
Dr. Bilang, a soft-spoken 60-year-old immigrant from the Philippines, where he received his medical training, has become a popular figure here in cowboy-hat country. Even now, after all the accusations of wrongdoing have become public, people drop by his house on Custer Street to buoy his spirits, mow his lawn, ask if he'd like to take a drive in the countryside.
His problems date to 1986, when he was put on probation in Florida for prescribing drugs to a patient without first ordering the required tests. Two years later, he surrendered his Florida medical license after state regulators said he had improperly documented the treatment of a woman who had died in his care.
 
'Restricted in Kansas
 He later moved to a small town in Kansas, where an investigation was ordered after his use of forceps during a birth resulted in an infant's suffering partial facial paralysis, nerve damage and bleeding in the brain. On Dec. 14 Dr. Bilang signed a stipulation agreeing never again to practice obstetrics in Kansas.
"The mistakes weren't so bad that he couldn't learn from them," said Jean Piper, the 51-year-old hospital administrator, who began work here 27 years ago as a nurse's aide.
In February, the doctor was arrested in his office here by agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of bank fraud. Prosecutors say he lied about his income to get loans totaling $75,000 from banks in Florida and Utah. He later defaulted on the debts. Dr. Bilang has said his income dropped when he lost a job.
But in this farming community, which was hit by a rash of foreclosures in the 1980's, nobody is about to side with the banks.
"Around here, if the price of cattle drops $20 a head before market and we can't pay our loans, we could all be charged with bank fraud," said Danny Gibbons, a farmer who is vice chairman of the hospital board. When Dr. Bilang was taken by the Federal agents to a hearing in Lincoln, then left without money or a car, the hospital wired him money for food and a motel room. And Mr. Gibbons made the five-hour drive to retrieve him.
If the outpouring of support for Dr. Bilang underscores the desperation for health care here, it also reflects a measure of empathy and the capacity for forgiveness in rural communities.
"When you live in a small town, you don't have any choice but to forgive and forget," said 82-year-old Helen Huss, who has lived in the same house on Main Street here since 1921. "I know my neighbors' faults, and they know mine. You can't hide. You've got to live with each other."
Until the last few years, it was much easier for doctors with checkered medical records to move undetected from one state to another. But in 1990, Congress enacted the National Practitioners Data Bank, which keeps a list of doctors, now numbering about 4,000, who have been disciplined by state medical boards. While the names on the list are not public, they are available to hospitals and medical boards.
 
Unserved in the Heartland
 Since 1979, the number of rural communities without enough doctors has nearly doubled, to about 1,600, according to the Federal Center for Rural Health Policy. About 100 remote counties have no doctors. In Nebraska alone, seven rural hospitals have closed since 1986, and health experts have predicted that 10 to 15 others in the state face a daunting future.
Rural health experts say that most young doctors do not want to live in such an isolated place. Older doctors, meanwhile, do not want the overwhelming workload that comes with being on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week. During his short tenure here, Dr. Bilang saw an average of 25 patients a day.
Some little towns offer rewards to anyone who can find a doctor, and a Federal program sends young doctors to rural areas in exchange for paying their student loans. Even so, the waiting list is long.
 
Fulcrum of Town's Economy
 With his fate in the balance, Dr. Bilang sat at his kitchen table the other day, passing the time by playing a chess game against his computer.
"It's beating me," he said.
Dr. Bilang contends that he would would have been vindicated if he had fought the disciplinary actions. But at the time, he said, he was facing dire financial problems, so he decided instead to sign agreements that he would move on. He now believes that was a mistake. He declined to comment on the bank fraud charges.
"I will be very sad if I have to leave here," he said. "They have treated me like royalty."
A man and his 14-year-old son dropped by to mow his lawn. The telephone rang with words of support. One woman told Dr. Bilang she had refused to see another doctor, out of loyalty.
"Oh, I don't think that's a good idea," he told her.
The doctor is the fulcrum of the town's economy. Without him, the hospital will almost certainly close, putting 44 people out of work. The drug store here can scarcely survive without a doctor to write prescriptions. And the future of the 40-bed nursing home would be clouded, since a doctor would not be available in emergencies.
Townspeople with loved ones in the home would face a painful decision: Should their parents or grandparents be kept in a town without a doctor, or transferred to a nursing home many miles away?
Mick Kozeal, the town's mayor and a construction crew foreman, said he would face such a decision with his mother, who has Alzheimer's and lives in the nursing home. Most of the time, she cannot even recognize the faces of her children or grandchildren, he said.
"But there are days when she knows everything," he added. "Those are precious moments. I don't want to lose them."
 
Hugs in the Grandstand
 Before Dr. Bilang arrived, the town had been without a regular doctor for almost six months. The hospital paid $750 a day for temporary doctors, who were usually retired, but the costly service depleted its cash reserves.
The hospital also spent about $40,000 in its search for a new doctor. Townspeople sent donations in $5 and $1 bills. A barbecue was held to raise money for the effort.
Just as some of the townspeople had started to lose hope, word came one Friday night last fall that Dr. Bilang had signed a contract. At the time, almost everyone in town was at the high school football game. The hospital administrator, Ms. Piper, climbed to the top of the grandstands, with tears in her eyes, to announce the good news: "A doctor is coming to Sargent."
At the same time, a boy on the Sargent team broke into the open and ran for a 50-yard touchdown, and as the grandstands erupted in thunderous applause, it was impossible to tell what brought the loudest cheers. But there was a lot of hugging in the grandstands that night.
"You know, we're like a family here," Ms. Piper said. "And we're worried about each other."

HEADLINE: Circling Back to Square One: Fixing the Economy

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
If there was any doubt left about President Clinton's determination to refocus attention on the economy, he dispelled it at his news conference today by twice dismissing questions about homosexuals in the military with terse one-liners that could not possibly make the evening news.
"You know what my position is; I have nothing else to say about it," the President said at one point in a clipped voice. 
 When the network reporter tried to dig further for a sound bite, Mr. Clinton was already scanning the crowd, pointing to someone else he presumably hoped would ask about the economy.
Mr. Clinton's performance was an essential element in the first mid-course correction of this young Presidency. He is trying to go back to basics. Ask him about homosexuals in the military, and he now answers, in effect, "The deficit." Ask him about Bosnia, and he answers, "The deficit." Ask him about helping out Democratic Party special-interest groups, and he answers, "The deficit."
 
An In-House Analysis
 From his road trip to Cleveland on Monday to his speech in New York City on Wednesday to his news conference in the Rose Garden today, the new Clinton strategy is clear: Keep the White House focused on deficit reduction rather than on new spending plans, on American problems rather than on Balkan ones, and on middle-class issues rather than on special interests. Then get the President out of Washington to sell these themes personally.
This course correction grows out of the Administration's own in-house analysis of where it has gone off track in its first few months.
The first problem they are trying to resolve, aides say, is that of conflicting signals on the economy. While the President understood what he meant when he said that the country suffered from "two deficits" -- the budget deficit and the deficit in new spending on job-creating projects -- the public never quite seems to have got it.
That was why the Republicans, with the help of many conservative Democrats, were able to defeat the President's plan first to stimulate the economy with $15.5 billion in new deficit spending before attacking the deficit.
 
Governing and Politics
 There was an economic logic to that stimulus package, but it was not immediately apparent to most Americans how more deficit spending in the short run was going to help deficit cutting in the long run, and the Republicans adroitly used that confusion to paint Mr. Clinton as a tax-and-spend Democrat. While the President is not abandoning his long-term investment ideas, it is his long-term deficit-cutting ideas that he played up last week.
The second change the White House made this week -- one that few people would have predicted that Bill Clinton would ever need to make -- was remembering the connection between governing and politics. Mr. Clinton's staff relentlessly disparaged President George Bush as dropping proposals on Congress and then letting them sit there, never bothering to go out and sell them to the public.
Mr. Bush, they contended, did not understand the seamless connection between governing and politics, between making decisions and then selling them. Mr. Clinton, they boasted, would have a "permanent campaign" to sell his budget ideas. It lasted seven days.
"I think we had about a week's worth of strategy after Feb. 17 to sell this, and what we needed was about three months' worth of strategy," Mr. Clinton said in an interview that appeared in today's Washington Post, when asked about his budget. "I believe this is my fault."
How did such an inveterate politician, such a natural pitchman for his own politics, get diverted? In part it was the pressure of governing -- having to suddenly devise policies to deal with turmoil in Russia and torment in Waco, Tex., while also assembling a budget and health-care plan.
"I'm trying to do hard things, and I can't do hard things and conduct an ongoing campaign at the same time," Mr. Clinton said today at his news conference.
But there also seems to be a tension between the campaigner in Mr. Clinton, who gets energized by selling his ideas to the crowds, and the student of policy, who can endlessly debate policy options.
"I think Clinton got caught up in the excitement of governing during his first 100 days," said Thomas Mann, a Congressional expert at the Brookings Institution, a research group. "He got so involved in indulging his interest in different aspects of policy that he forgot about the politics of selling it. He thought that his policy discussion sessions inside the White House were sufficient.
"But they were not. Not enough was being conveyed to the public about what exactly his Presidency was up to."
In any event, the President's corrective efforts are now clear. Not only is he emphasizing the deficit-reducing elements of his budget, but to prove it he also offered to lock up every bit of new tax revenue and every net spending cut in a trust fund that would be bound by law to be spent exclusively on reducing the deficit.
 
Bought Schumer's Idea
 Clinton aides acknowledge that they simply misread the depth to which the public wanted to be assured that deficit reduction would take precedence over every other economic priority.
Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, who pushed the idea of the deficit-reduction trust fund, said the White House finally bought the idea after enough Congressmen told the President that their constituents were telling them that they were ready to sacrifice, that they were ready to pay more taxes, but only if they had the ironclad assurance that the White House was going to do something about the deficit.
Hence the new Clinton mantra, as he spelled it out today: "Until we can prove that we have the discipline to control our budget, I don't think we'll have the elbow room necessary to have the kind of targeted investments we need. I think the more we do budget control, the more we'll be free to then be very sharply discriminating in investing in those things which actually do create jobs. I don't think we have any other option at this time."

HEADLINE: Clinton Asks Reserve Board Not to Raise Interest Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Seeking to salvage his troubled economic program, President Clinton urged the Federal Reserve Board today not to raise interest rates, at least until there is "more evidence" of rising inflation.
Mr. Clinton's comments came in answer to a question about Federal Reserve policy at a news conference in the White House Rose Garden, where he defended his leadership style and asserted that he had taken on tougher challenges than his two immediate predecessors. 
 In an effort to put behind him the weeks of self-examination over his performance as President, Mr. Clinton made a renewed pitch for his economic remedies. They could be jeopardized, he said, if the Reserve reacts to a sharp increase in consumer prices last month by raising interest rates. White House officials say they are concerned that as the Administration moves to raise taxes, higher rates would be a further drag on the economy.
 
Consumer Prices Up 0.4%
 The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported Thursday, reflecting price increases in most of the goods and services that Americans use every day. The report added to concerns that inflation may be creeping back; the index has been rising at a 4.3 percent annual rate so far this year, well above the rate in 1992.
"There are some clear, underlying reasons for this last inflationary bulge which don't necessarily portend long-term inflation," the President said today. "I think it's, of course, a cause of concern. But we ought to wait until we have some more evidence before we raise interest rates in an economy where industrial capacity is only at 80 percent."
The Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve, meets eight times a year and has scheduled its next session for Tuesday. The meetings are held in secret and the members never discuss their plans in public. While there has been no clear signal that the Reserve is preparing to increase interest rates, there has been speculation on Wall Street that to combat inflation, the nation's central bank may increase short-term rates to make it more difficult to obtain money.
The Federal Reserve operates independently of the White House, and the President has no control over it except through suasion. Since the election, Mr. Clinton and the Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who is a conservative Republican, have sought to emphasize that they have a cordial relationship. President George Bush frequently criticized Mr. Greenspan's policies.
 
Emphasis on the Deficit
 Mr. Clinton said repeatedly today that he was pleased by the House Ways and Means Committee's approval of his tax-increase proposal on Thursday, and asserted that the emphasis should remain on cutting the deficit.
"The prevailing opinion at the Fed and the prevailing opinion in the economic community has been that the most important thing we can do is bring down long-term interest rates by bringing down the deficit," he said.
Seeking to discourage the new worries about inflation, the President said. "If you look at all the underlying long-term things, long-term trends in energy prices, industrial capacity, the kinds of things that really shape an economy, there is no reason at this time to believe that there could be any cause for resurgent inflation."
Mr. Clinton was alternately relaxed and combative as he fielded questions about his handling of issues at home and abroad, and about polls that show public confidence in his performance declining.
"You know, I'm doing things that are hard, that are controversial," he said. "And anybody who doesn't want to assume responsibility can stand on the sidelines and criticize. I never expected that I could take on some of these interests that I've taken on without being attacked."
 
'Let the Chips Fall'
 Brushing aside his poll ratings, the President said, "My job is to do my job and let the chips fall where they may."
He reacted almost with disbelief when a reporter asked if he had surrounded himself with too many young, inexperienced aides. "You think I ought to let some of them go?" he asked.
And he looked offended when he was asked about Bosnia. Glancing down at the reporters in front of him, Mr. Clinton pointedly suggested that his record on foreign policy compared favorably to that of Mr. Bush.
"I realize it may be frustrating for all of you to deal with the ambiguity of this problem, but it is a difficult one," he said, referring to the Bosnia impasse. "I have a clear policy. I have gotten more done on this than my predecessors did, and maybe one reason he didn't try to do it is because if you can't force everybody to fall in line overnight, the people that have been fighting each other for centuries, you may be accused of vacillating. We're not vacillating. We have a clear, strong policy."
 
Frustrated Over Criticism
 The President said his threat of military intervention and arming the Bosnian Muslims still stands, despite opposition from European allies. "We're just going to keep working and pushing in this direction," he said. "And I think we'll begin to get more and more results."
Turning to defend his performance on domestic matters before abruptly ending the 40-minute news conference, Mr. Clinton expressed his own frustration over the criticism. "One day people say, 'He's trying to do too much, he's pushing too hard, he wants too much change,' " Mr. Clinton said. "And then on the other day say, 'Well, he's really not pushing very hard.' I think we're getting good results."
As his own political strategists travel to Texas in an effort to help Senator Bob Krueger, a Democrat who faces a difficult special election next month, the President indicated that he would not campaign on behalf of Mr. Krueger.
"I've always been skeptical about the question of whether any of us can have any impact on anyone else's races," he said.
For his part, Mr. Krueger has distanced himself from the President, particularly on the economic plan that the Republicans killed last month.
When pressed about simply accepting the loss of a Democratic seat in the Senate, Mr. Clinton responded: "I'm not resigned to losing it. I think Bob Krueger can still win the race. But it depends on -- as with all cases -- it depends on how he frames the issues, how his opponent frames the issues, and what happens there."
 
Defends Civil Rights Nominee
 Mr. Clinton offered a vigorous defense of Lani Guinier, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania who is his nominee to head the Justice Department's civil rights division. Her writings on race relations have been attacked by conservatives as divisive. In any event, he said, Congress and not his Administration would set civil rights policy.
"I nominated her because there had never been a full-time practicing civil rights lawyer with a career in civil rights law heading the civil rights division," he said. "I expect the policy to be made on civil rights laws by the United States Congress, and I expect the Justice Department to carry out that policy."
Asked about Webster Hubbell, his nominee for Associate Attorney General, the President said Mr. Hubbell should not be disqualified because of his membership in a predominantly white country club in Little Rock, Ark. He said Mr. Hubbell had tried for years to integrate the club.
Mr. Clinton refused to answer questions about his efforts to overturn the ban on homosexuals in the military. But he said that he had watched "quite a lot" of the testimony this week at Senate hearings on the matter, and that it was "quite moving and straightforward."

HEADLINE: MOYNIHAN EXPECTS TAX BILL SUCCESS

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Republicans will provide no votes for President Clinton's tax bill when the Senate Finance Committee considers the measure next month, but the committee chairman said Democrats would manage to produce a bill anyway.
"Don't worry, your taxes will be raised," the chairman, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, told reporters today with a laugh. Mr. Moynihan, a New York Democrat, and said that in the end all 11 Democrats on the committee would back the bill while all nine Republicans would oppose it. 
 The Senator said he had been told by Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the committee, that "there will not be any Republican support for the tax bill."
A spokesman for Senator Packwood confirmed that statement, saying the bill approved Thursday by the House Ways and Means Committee -- a measure to raise almost $250 billion in taxes over the next five years -- had no support from the Republicans.
 
Minimum of Partisanship
 Nonetheless, Mr. Moynihan noted, the Finance Committee has historically been one of the less partisan committees in the Senate, usually getting significant minority support for bills that the majority favors. Indeed, Mr. Moynihan played a major role in a triumph for Mr. Packwood in 1986, when the Republican was chairman of the committee, supporting him in a successful effort to eliminate many tax loopholes.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who is Senator Moynihan's predecessor as chairman of the committee, also predicted success for President Clinton's tax package today. But he said it would probably undergo some changes to satisfy all the Democrats on the panel. "Every Congress makes some changes and this one will be no exception," Mr. Bentsen told reporters at the White House.
Both Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Bentsen offered similar rationales for their predictions. "Bringing the deficit down is our most important economic responsibility," Mr. Bentsen said.
Senator Moynihan asserted, "The only political business that will be transacted in the last decade of the 20th century will be to lift the paralysis" of ever-increasing deficits.
Mr. Moynihan made it plain that he had no enthusiasm for some elements of the bill.
 
Restaurants and Cattle
 For example, reducing the deductibility of meals and other forms of business entertainment from 80 percent to 50 percent would injure the restaurant business in New York, he said. "I'm going to be for the President's bill," he added. "Will it hurt? You're darn right it will."
Senator Moynihan said he was willing to support measures that pinched some constituents at home if fellow Democrats showed a comparable spirit of sacrifice. "I try to remind my friends who have cattle that we have restaurants," he said.
He noted that the bill no longer includes a temporary investment tax credit opposed by him as well as by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. But Mr. Moynihan said their doubts about it did not translate into opposition to Mr. Clinton. "The President ended up not wanting it that much," Mr. Moynihan said.
In all, the Senator said, "there is no pleasure in this," adding, "We're just trying to raise some money to keep the deficit from going higher." And that was essential, he said, because "your country is on the verge of instability."

HEADLINE: BELGRADE MEETING BACKS PEACE PLAN

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 14

 BODY:
At a tumultuous meeting marked by insults, accusations and angry walkouts, three Serbian legislatures endorsed an international peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina today and urged the Bosnian Serbs to sign it.
But a boycott of the meeting by Serbs from both Bosnia and Croatia raised questions whether the endorsement would have any effect. Bosnian Serb leaders, who have already rejected the plan three times, said they would ignore the resolution and proceed with a referendum this weekend that is expected to produce a resounding vote against the plan. 
 In another effort to get the Bosnian Serbs to accept the peace plan, Belgrade announced an embargo of goods other than food and medicine. [United States intelligence reports said today that truck traffic into Bosnia has declined, but that fuel tankers and other vehicles are still entering Bosnia.]
 
Meeting Called by Serbia
 The meeting today had been called by Serbian leaders in Belgrade to press their Serbian comrades in Bosnia and Herzegovina to end the 13-month war and accept the peace plan put forward by Cyrus R. Vance, the former United Nations mediator on the Balkans, and Lord Owen, the European Community representative.
"We support the peace plan for Bosnia as the only solution offered by the international community for the cessation of hostilities," said the resolution adopted by legislators from the Yugoslav Federation and its two component republics, Serbia and Montenegro. "We call on the Serbian people in Bosnia to accept the peace plan and continue their struggle for national independence through negotiations."
The Bosnian Serbs refused to attend today's meeting. Their self-styled parliament voted to reject the peace plan at a special meeting on May 5 and called for a referendum of all Bosnian Serbs to be held this weekend on the issue.
In a televised interview from the Bosnian town of Pale, the Bosnian Serbs' leader, Radovan Karadzic, predicted that Bosnian Serbs would reject the plan in this weekend's vote because it would mean "pushing the Serbian people into misery and into disaster."
"We realize that now we are completely alone and that only God is with us, although we are defending Christianity against militant Muslim fundamentalism," Dr. Karadzic said.
 
Hopes of Easing Sanctions
 More than 200 representatives of the self-declared Serbian republic in the Krajina region of Croatia also boycotted the meeting today in Belgrade, and 139 members of the Radical Party, the most ardently nationalist legislative bloc in Serbia, stalked out in protest.
The no-shows and walkouts undercut the authority of the assembly, which had been summoned by the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, in an effort to override the Bosnian Serb parliament's rejection of the peace plan.
Mr. Milosevic, who was the principal sponsor and arms supplier of the Bosnian Serbs, has pushed for acceptance of the plan in an effort to get the United Nations to lift economic sanctions that are wrecking the Yugoslav economy.
If all the Serbian legislators had accepted the invitation, today's assembly would have brought together as many as 680 delegates, most of them controlled by Mr. Milosevic and able to outvote the 82 Bosnian Serbs and others opposed to the peace plan.
But by the time the vote was cast, the chamber held only slightly more than 200 delegates, less than a third of those who had been invited. A handful of Serbs from Bosnia and Krajina attended, but only as observers, and the leader of the militant Radical Party, Vojislav Seselj, led his delegates out of the hall before the vote.
"It is impossible to pass a resolution while the Bosnian Serbs are not present," he said later.
At a rally Thursday, Mr. Seselj threatened to launch missiles against Italy if Rome allowed Italian bases to be used for planes participating in future bombing of Bosnian Serb positions. Italian officials responded by ordering tighter security around their bases, but Italy's Foreign Minister, Beniamino Andreatta, dismissed Mr. Seselj's party as "a lunatic group."
The session today was held in Belgrade's luxurious Sava Center, which in better days was an international convention complex but now is used only for occasional local events.
 
Arguing Rules of Debate
 More time was devoted to arguing about rules of debate than was spent discussing the peace plan, and delegates spent much of the session hurling accusations at each other. One was denounced for allegedly enriching himself through illegal lumber exports. Another was said to have "a dual personality" because his mother is of Croatian descent.
The leader of the self-styled Bosnian Serb assembly, Momcilo Krajisnik, dismissed the action in Belgrade today.
"This parliament has not contributed anything important to the whole situation," Mr. Krajisnik said, "especially since a large number of delegates walked out."
The assembly vote and the Bosnian Serbs' defiant reaction underlined the ostensible gulf that has emerged in recent days between Serbia and Serbs in Bosnia.
Bosnian Serb leaders are convinced that the Vance-Owen peace plan would destroy their hopes for making an independent country out of the lands won by Serbs in 13 months of fighting. The Serbian leadership in Belgrade is urging them to sign the plan, stop fighting, and then present their complaints at a conference table, though many, especially the Bosnian Muslims, suspect that Belgrade is merely trying to reduce the sanctions before resuming overt support for the Serbian nationalists in Bosnia. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Truck Traffic Slows
WASHINGTON, May 14 (Special to The New York Times) -- The flow of truck traffic carrying fuel and other goods into Bosnia from Serbia has declined in recent days, but fuel tankers and other vehicles are continuing to make their way into the country, Government officials said today.
The officials said an assessment by United States intelligence agencies reported that it was unclear how much cargo is being carried in the continuing shipments. But they said a vast network of secondary roads allowed trucks to enter Bosnia without being subjected to the new border checks ordered by Belgrade.
The assessment speculates that Mr. Milosevic, the Serbian leader, will do "the minimum necessary" to persuade Western governments that he is enforcing the blockade on all but food and other relief that he ordered last week. But while it cautioned that its judgment remained preliminary, it described actual enforcement of the embargo as no more than sporadic.
Among the biggest loopholes in the blockade, the Government officials said, is a provision that allows Serbian trucks to carry goods across Bosnia to reach Krajina, a Serbian region of Croatia. They said there is little provision for insuring that fuel and other goods are not delivered to Serbs in Bosnia instead.
 
Balkan Update
 In BELGRADE, Serbian legislators unanimously endorsed an international peace plan, but Bosnian Serb leaders said that they would ignore the resolution.
Serbian militia members attacked Muslims near the northeastern town of BRCKO.
Officials also reported clashes between Muslims and Croats in MOSTAR and VITEZ. The Croats opened a detention camp near Mostar to reporters.
At the UNITED NATIONS, the Security Council planned a rare meeting of foreign ministers to review progress toward peace in Bosnia; and France called on the United States and Russia to send troops to help protect SARAJEVO, SREBRENICA, TUZLA, BIHAC, ZEPA and GORAZDE.
In WASHINGTON, President Clinton reiterated his proposals on Bosnia, but said America will not send troops to support one side in the conflict.
BULGARIA said it will enforce tighter sanctions against Yugoslavia, but American officials said supplies are still getting to the Bosnian Serbs.

International
Trade Ministers from the United States, Europe, Japan and Canada made significant progress in concluding seven years of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. There was nearly complete agreement on a package of tariff cuts, including ones that could spur imports to Japan. [Page 35.] 
 The United States trade representative's coalition of state and local officials in support of the North American Free Trade Agreement prompted a Democratic Congressman to call for an investigation of whether the group violates Federal law. [44.]
The European Community's efforts to protect its airline industry could fuel a trans-Atlantic trade war. [34.]
Nine former Soviet republics signed a declaration to form an economic union to try to restore cohesion to their relationships. [3.]
 
The Economy
Industrial capacity during the last five years has grown more slowly than previously thought, according to the Federal Reserve, adding to the worries of some economists who think that America's industrial base has been lagging. [35.]
President Clinton urged the Fed not to raise interest rates until there is "more evidence" of rising inflation. [9.]
The Senate Finance Committee is likely to pass the tax bill despite receiving no votes from Republicans. [9.]
 
Companies
Citibank asked a bankruptcy judge to bar Canadian influence over the American arm of Olympia & York. The unit's biggest creditor asked that John Zuccotti, head of Olympia & York USA, be put in sole control of the company and its assets. [35.]
Carl C. Icahn offered $1.18 billion cash for E-II Holdings, continuing his effort to acquire the bankrupt owner of Culligan water systems, Samsonite luggage and Botany 500 suits. [35.]
Fujitsu may buy I.B.M.-compatible computers from Taiwan to sell under its name in Japan. The move reflects a price war initiated in Japan by Compaq Computer. [37.]
Boeing is discussing offering the Air Force military versions of its 767 and 747 jetliners for transport use. The talks come as McDonnell Douglas's C-17 transport plane is in jeopardy. [37.]
Frank Lorenzo's Friendship Airlines asserted the Administration bowed to pressure to hold hearings on its fitness. [37.]
The F.D.I.C. plans to offer shares in the failed Crossland Federal Savings Bank to big institutional investors. [37.]
Cross Colours, which makes a line of hip-hop clothing that mainstream merchants are clamoring for, has been honored. [37.]
 
Markets
The stock market struggled to erase Thursday's sharp losses, but the Dow fell 4.98 points. For the week, however, the blue-chip index gained 5.82 points. [36.]
Treasury securities ended mixed, with longer-term securities outperforming shorter maturities amid inflation jitters. [44.]
Gold prices retreated but remained near 17-month highs. Other metals also fell. [46.] The dollar declined. [46.]
 
Your Money
New 401(k) rules starting Jan. 1 will provide participants with additional investment alternatives and reduce employers' risk of being held responsible if an investment turns out badly. [33.]
There may be no safe stocks in the 90's, analysts say, and making money may be mostly a matter of avoiding bad issues. [33.]
Frequent fliers who are a few miles short of qualifying for free trips can make up the difference without flying. [33.]
More people are likely to fall under the alternative minimum tax under the Clinton tax proposal. [33.]
Credit card issuers are offering incentives to new customers, but fees and interest could exceed the benefits. [34.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Industry's Sluggish Pace

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
People have been worrying for years that America's industrial base, if not shrinking outright, has at the very least been expanding quite slowly.
Yesterday, in a routine monthly report on industrial production, the Federal Reserve reported that industrial capacity during the last five years has indeed been growing more slowly than previously thought -- at an average of just 1.7 percent a year, not 2.4 percent as Fed figures had previously shown. That is half the pace of the early 1980's. 
 Productivity capacity in factories, mines and utilities is about 4 percent lower than the Fed had previously reported, the revised index of capacity showed.
 
Gauging the Cutbacks
 The new figures seem to support two kinds of concerns: one was that plant closings and cutbacks have taken a bigger bite out of productive capacity than had been realized.
"The Fed is validating the notion that there may be have been a hollowing out of Smokestack America in the 1980's," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley. "These companies were aggressive at plant closings because they thought they needed to cut out the fat to survive. The risk is that they may have gone a little too far."
The second concern has been that sluggish investment has added insufficiently to the productive base.
 
One Official's Worry
 "Secretary Reich has been saying that we have an investment deficit," said Lawrence F. Katz, chief economist of the Labor Department, speaking of Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary. "These numbers reinforce that message."
The Fed's revisions are based on more comprehensive data it obtained from the 1992 census of manufacturers, a survey taken every five years. The Fed revises its production, utilitization and capacity data every few years. The last revision was in April 1990.
Yesterday's report also showed that manufacturing output in April was expanding at a decent clip -- increasing four-tenths of 1 percent -- and that the 1991-92 recession in manufacturing was less severe than initially believed and the recovery so far a bit stronger. Overall industrial production, including utilities, rose one-tenth of 1 percent.
The emerging picture is that the economy is much closer to production limits than the Federal Reserve had believed, a situation that could result in bottlenecks and higher prices, unless business invests at a faster clip.
"The size of the recession has been reduced significantly," said Steven Strongin, vice president, economic policy and research at the Chicago Federal Reserve.
What some economists found stunning was the Fed's estimate that the factory utilization rate in April, 81.4 percent, which is roughly the long-run average, was unexpectedly high for an economy that is only two years into a relatively modest recovery. The factory utilization rate in March was 79.9 percent.
"All of a sudden, there is less running room than we thought," said David Kelly of the Boston Company Economic Advisers. "Assuming that the economy resumes reasonable growth in the second half, you could easily be in the mid-80's by early 1994, a zone typically associated with the ability to jack up prices."
Because these figures present another sign that the economy might be a little stronger than people had thought, it could make President Clinton's job bill a more difficult sell.
Still, tighter capacity could be a positive sign for companies that supply capital goods, from computers to electrical generators. Capacity utilization of about 81.9 percent usually represents territory associated with stronger investment.
David Wyss, an economist at Data Resources Inc., noted that the report showed more capacity shrinkage among military suppliers than previously estimated. This suggests that the painful process of cutting back the arms industry may be further along than people thought.
"It suggests we're farther into that adjustment process," he said. "Companies haven't just been sitting back waiting for their orders to disappear. They actually thought about this ahead of time, and took action."
To be sure, economists say, capacity figures are hardly exact, and the shift to flexible manufacturing may allow manufacturers to use what capacity they have better. Furthermore, there is still plenty of spare capacity in other industrial countries, including Canada, and those nations would be only too happy to increase their imports to the United States.
 
Broad-Based Changes
 Despite these caveats, economists view capacity utilization as an important indicator. A Fed economist, who said he would not speak for attribution, noted that the downward revisions of capacity were broad based and not confined to a couple of industries. "A lot of the changes are not dramatic," he said, "but there are so many of them that they add up."
The Fed's revisions are sure to raise questions again about the reliability of Government statistics -- especially at a time when inflation looks slightly more worrisome and growth looks less than satisfactory. Such statistics are widely followed not only by business executives and investors, but also by the Federal Reserve and other agencies as they make policy decisions.
And these revisions come on the heels of a report in The Washington Post that the Bureau of Labor Statistics is about to release a revision of data, this time showing that it overstated job losses during the recession and undercounted the number of new jobs created so far in the recovery. The Post's report has been confirmed by the Labor Department.
 
Altering the Recession Data
 The Federal Reserve also revised its estimates of industrial production back to 1987 yesterday. While the new data show that production grew less before the end of the 1980's expansion than had previously been thought, they also show that the recession in industry was milder than previously thought.
Production fell just 4 percent, not 5.1 percent, from its pre-recession peak in September 1990 to its recession trough in March 1991. And the subsequent recovery in industrial production has been a bit stronger, up 7.3 percent from March 1991, rather than the original estimate of 6.7 percent
Reports yesterday also shed light on the recent state of the economy.
The Commerce Department reported that business inventories rose at their fastest rate in nearly three years in March, jumping eight-tenths of 1 percent and pushing up the inventory-sales ratio a tad, while sales edged up only two-tenths of 1 percent. The department has, however, already reported that retail sales rebounded 1.2 percent in April.
 
A Rebound in Output
 The Federal Reserve's report yesterday showed that factory output rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, suggesting that the manufacturing sector seems to be recovering reasonably well from the big inventory pileup in March.
Overall industrial production was flat in April, rising only one-tenth of 1 percent, because it had been drawn down by a sharp 3.6 percent drop in utility output that occurred when the weather turned warmer.
"It's a decent performance, all things considered," Mr. Wyss said. "It's certainly not a runaway recovery, it's still half speed, but at least it's a recovery.

GRAPHIC: Graphs showing industrial capacity from 1981 to 1993, industrial production, capacity utilization, and inventory-sales ratio from Jan. 1992 to April 1993 (Sources: Federal Reserve Board, Commerce Department)
