HEADLINE: Excerpts From Clinton's News Conference in the Rose Garden

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday in the Rose Garden at the White House, as transcribed by Reuters.
 
OPENING STATEMENT

Three months ago, I presented a plan to our country and to the Congress designed to address what I believe are the significant challenges of this time. For more than 40 years our country was organized to stand up against Communism, to try to help develop the free world, and for most of that time we took our economic prosperity for granted. 
 It is now clear that at the end of the cold war we must organize ourselves around the obligation we have to be more competitive in the global economy and to enable our people to live up to their full potential.
That means we have to do a lot of things to turn this economy around, beginning with a serious effort to reduce our national debt, to invest in jobs and new technologies, to restore fairness to our tax code and to make our political system work again.
This week I was able to go back again to the American people, to take my case into the country, and to Cleveland and Chicago and New York, and here, in Washington, there were new efforts to break the gridlock and to put the national interest above narrow interests.
The results were particularly impressive in the work done by the House Ways and Means Committee. Achieving over $250 billion in deficit reduction through spending cuts with two dollars in spending cuts for each dollar in new investment in jobs and education, the program provides significantly everything that I presented to the Congress, even though there were some changes. In fact, some of the changes I think made the bill better.
Let me reiterate them. No. 1, significant deficit reduction. No. 2, taking on entitlements issues that have for too long been left on the table. No. 3, real investments for small businesses, and for big businesses, incentives to get people to invest money in this economy to create jobs.
And perhaps most importantly, a break for working-class families, a huge increase in the earned-income tax credit for people with incomes under $30,000, to relieve them of the impact of the energy tax and to say for the first time, people who work 40 hours a week with children in the home would be lifted above poverty.
And finally, of course, the plan was very progressive, 75 percent of the revenues coming from the top 6 percent of the American taxpayers.
I also reiterated that I don't want a penny in taxes without the spending cuts, and I proposed in New York that we create a deficit-reduction trust fund into which all the taxes and all the budget cuts could be put and kept for the five-year life of this budget.
This is a very important thing. I realize some have said it is little more than a gimmick, but the truth is there is no legal protection now for the life of the budget for these funds. This will provide it, in stone, in law.
In every element of this there has been some willingness on the part of those who have supported our efforts to take on powerful vested interests in behalf of the national interest, whether it is in repealing the lobby deduction, or in going for a direct loan program for college loans that will save $4 billion, but which will remove a Government-guaranteed income from several interests who like the system as it is now.
The Congress also moved this week to reinvigorate our democratic process by ending the filibuster and passing the motor voter bill.
These are the kinds of changes that the American people expect of us. They do not expect miracles, but they expect solid, steady progress, and I am determined to stay on this course. It has been a good week, and if we are willing to take more tough decisions, there will be more good weeks for the American people ahead.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
U.S. Role in Bosnia

Q. Mr. President, you've said that the United States will not go it alone with military action in Bosnia, and yet the European allies have refused to sign on to your proposals. If the allies refuse to follow suit, where does that leave the United States?
A. Let me reiterate what I have said because I think that the United States has taken the right position, and I think that we've gotten some good results. I have said, and I will reiterate, I think that the United States must act with our allies, especially because Bosnia is in the heart of Europe, and the Europeans are there. We must work together through the United Nations.
Secondly, I do not believe the United States has any business sending troops there to get involved in a conflict in behalf of one of the sides. I believe that we should continue to turn up the pressure, and as you know, I have taken the position that the best way to do that would be to lift the arms embargo with a standby authority of air power in the event that the present situation was interrupted by the unfair use of artillery by the Bosnian Serbs.
That position is still on the table. It has not been rejected out of hand. Indeed, some of our European allies have agreed with it and others are not prepared to go that far yet. But we have to keep the pressure up.
And I would just remind you that since we said we would become involved in the Vance-Owen peace process, two of the three parties have signed on, we've gotten enforcement of the no-fly zone through the United Nations, we've been able to airlift more humanitarian supplies there, and we've been able to keep up a very, very tough embargo on Serbia, which I think led directly, that and the pressure of further action, to the statement that Mr. Milosevic made to the effect that he would stop supporting the Bosnian Serbs.
Where we go from here is to keep pushing in the right direction. As we speak here, the United Nations is considering a resolution which would enable us to place United Nations forces along the border between Serbia and Bosnia, to try to test and reinforce the resolve of the Milosevic government to cut off supplies to the Bosnian Serbs.
If that resolution passes, and in its particulars it makes good sense, that is a very good next step. We're just going to keep working and pushing in this direction, and I think we'll begin to get more and more results.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, there's a widespread perception that you're waffling, that you can't make up your mind. One day you're saying, in a few days, we'll have a decision, we have a common approach. The next day, you're saying, we're still looking for a consensus.
Will American troops be in this border patrol that the U.N. is voting on? And you know, where are we?
A. Well, first of all, I have made up my mind and I've told you what my position was and I made it as clear as I can. But I also believe it is imperative that we work with our allies on this. The United States is not in a position to move unilaterally, nor should we. So that is the answer to your question.
 The resolution being considered by the United Nations, I think, contemplates that the Unprofor [United Nations Protective Force] forces would be moved and expanded and moved to the border. At this time, there has been no suggestion that we would be asked to be part of those forces.
 
Military's Gay Ban
 Q. A domestic question. Could you tell us, how were you affected by the testimony of Col. Fred Peck, whose son is a homosexual, who said that nonetheless he could not in good conscience support lifting the ban?
A. I thought all the testimony given in that hearing, and I saw quite a lot of it from more than one panel, was quite moving and straightforward. I still think the test ought to be conduct.
Q. Do you think that -- do you -- does this allow for the possibility of the "don't ask, don't tell," the compromise that would allow ----
A. You know what my position is. I have nothing else to say about it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Civil Rights Appointment
 Q. Your nominee to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division [Lani Guinier] has expressed what many regard as rather striking views about voting rights and a number of other areas, including expressing some misgivings about the principle of one man, one vote. And I wonder if you are familiar with all these views and if you support them, and if you do not, why you chose her?
A. I nominated her because there had never been a full-time practicing civil rights lawyer with a career in civil rights law heading the Civil Rights Division. I expect a policy to be made on civil rights laws by the United States Congress, and I expect the Justice Department to carry out that policy.
Insofar as there is discretion in the policy, that discretionary authority should reside either in the president or the attorney general, in terms of what policies the country will follow. I still think she's a very well-qualified civil rights lawyer, and I hope she'll be confirmed, and I think she has every intention of following the law of the land as Congress writes it. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Federal Reserve
 Q. Mr. President, what would you say or what do you say to Federal Reserve officials who are arguing for a slight rise in short-term interest rates because they're concerned about resurging inflation?
A. I would say that the month before last, we had virtually no inflation, and you can't run the country on a month-to-month basis. You've got to look at some longer trends. There are some clear underlying reasons for this last inflationary bulge, which don't necessarily portend long-term inflation. I think it's, of course, a cause of concern, we ought to look at it, but we ought to wait till we have some more evidence before we raise interest rates in an economy where industrial capacity is only at 80 percent.
If you look at all the underlying long-term things -- long-term trends in energy prices, industrial capacity, the kinds of things that really shape an economy -- there is no reason at this time to believe that there could be any cause for a resurgent inflation.
Q. The argument is made at the Federal Reserve that higher taxes, higher burdens on business through health care fees or other things like that will indeed raise inflation while the economy stays weak.
A. Well, just a few weeks ago some people were arguing that all this would be deflationary and would repress the recovery. So I guess you can find an expert to argue any opinion, but there is no evidence of that.
The prevailing opinion at the Fed and the prevailing opinion in the economic community has been that the most important thing we can do is to bring down long-term interest rates by bringing down the deficit. You can't have it both ways. We're either going to bring down the deficit or we're not. And everything in life requires some rigorous effort if you're going to have fundamental change.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Opinion Polls
 Q. Mr. President, in your opening statement you said this has been a good week for you, but the latest CNN-USA Today-Gallup poll, as you probably saw, shows a 10 percent decline in your job-approval rating since the end of April, from 55 to 45 percent.
Why do you think that's happening? And is it your fault, or what can be done?
A. Well, for one thing, I'm trying to do hard things, and I can't do hard things, and conduct an ongoing campaign at the same time.
You know, I'm doing things that are hard, that are controversial, and anybody who doesn't want to assume responsibility can stand on the sidelines and criticize them. I never expected that I could actually do anything about the deficit without having some hits.
I never expected that I could take on some of these interests that I've taken on without being attacked. And whenever you try to change things, there are always people there ready to point out the pain of change without the promise of it, and that's just all part of it.
If I worried about the poll ratings I'd never get anything done here. My only -- the only thing I'd remind you is, for 12 years we've seen politicians in the Congress and the executive branch worry about their poll ratings every month, and then at the end of every four years things are a lot worse.
If things are better at the end of the period that I was given to serve, then the poll ratings now won't make any difference, and if they're not, they won't make any difference. So my job is to do my job and let the chips fall where they may. Yes?
<Hb>Warring in Balkans
 Q. There seems to be a Catch-22 emerging on Bosnia. One would be that you have consistently said that you want to have a consensus with the U.S. allies, but until that consensus is formed, you've found that it seems very difficult to explain to the American people precisely how that war should be defined. Is it a civil war? Is it a war of aggression? And also not necessarily what the next step should be, but what are the principles, the overriding principles that should guide U.S. policy?
What can you tell the American people right now about that?
A. First, that it is both a civil war and a war of aggression. Because Bosnia was created as a separate legal entity, it is both a civil war, where elements of people who live within that territory are fighting against one another, and there has been aggression from without -- from the Croatians and from the Serbs, principally from the Serbs. That the inevitable but unintended impact of the arms embargo has been to put the United Nations in the position of ratifying an enormous superiority of arms for the Bosnian Serbs that they got from Serbia. And that our interest is in seeing, in my view at least, that the United Nations does not fore-ordain the outcome of a civil war. That's why I've always been in favor of some kind of lifting of the arms embargo -- that we contain the conflict and that we do everything we can to move to an end of it and to move to an end of ethnic cleansing.
Those are our interests there, and those are the ones I'm trying to pursue, but we should not introduce American ground forces into the conflict in behalf of one of the belligerents, and we must move with our allies.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Youth in the White House
 Q. Mr. President, one of the charges leveled by critics of you in Arkansas and now at the beginning of your term as President is that you've surrounded yourself with too many young people and put them in too many senior positions. How do you respond to that criticism?
A. Like Lloyd Bentsen and Warren Christopher?
I mean, who are you referring to? Mr. McLarty, Mr. Ruin, Ms. Rasco and Mr. Lake, to name four, and I, are all I think older than our counterparts were when President Kennedy was President.
There are a lot of young people who work here but most of the people in decision-making positions are not particularly young. And I'm amazed sometimes that, you know -- you think I ought to let some of them go? 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Cutting the Deficit
 Q. Mr. President, you've been talking a lot recently about deficit reduction, the deficit reduction trust fund. You're talking now about having to stretch out your investment programs, postpone some of the things. What do you say to people in urban areas, some of the liberal congressmen on the Hill, who say, wait a minute, we're the ones who elected this guy and now the programs that have been starved for 12 years that we need aren't going to be able to get money? What sort of political position does that put you in with your core supporters?
A. Well, I ask them, first of all, to look at the five-year budget. The enormous squeeze on domestic spending, including investment spending, began 12 years ago. I can't turn it around overnight. And I ask them to look at the five-year budget and look at in light of the fact that the deficit numbers were revised upward after the election by $50 billion a year in three of the next four years.
And I ask them also to consider this: until we can prove that we have the discipline to control our budget, I don't think we'll have the elbow room necessary to have the kind of targeted investments we need. I think the more we do budget control, the more we'll be free to then be very sharply discriminating in those things which actually do create jobs. I don't think we have any other option at this time.
 
Crisis of Hope
 Q. Mr. President, in your New York speech this past week at Cooper Union, you spoke of a crisis of belief and hope, and earlier Mrs. Clinton in a speech talked about a crisis of meaning. How do you see these crises manifesting themselves, what are the causes of them, and how severe do you see this?
A. Well, I think they manifested themselves in people's honest feelings that things are not going very well in this country and that they haven't gone very well in a long time, in the alienation people feel from the political process, and in the alienation they often feel from one another in the same neighborhoods and communities.
There are real objective reasons for a lot of these problems. After all, for most people the work week is lengthening and incomes are declining, the job growth of the country has been very weak, the crime rate is high, and there's a sense of real alienation there. And I don't think we can speak to them just with programs. I think that in our different ways that's what both Hillary and I were trying to say.
And the thing I was trying to say to the American people at the Cooper Union that I want to reiterate today is that you can never change if you have no belief in the potential of your country, your community or yourself, and that the easy path is cynicism, the easy path is to throw rocks. The better path is doing the hard work of change.

 	 	 		. . .	 	As I said at Cooper Union, when President Kennedy occupied that office, nearly three-quarters of the American people believed that their leaders would tell them the truth and that their institutions worked and that problems could be solved.
So there was a lot more elbow room there. You know, a year or two years could go by, people could be working on something with maybe only slightly measurable progress, but the country felt that it was moving forward. That is what we have to restore today, a sense that it can be done, and it cannot be done by the President alone, but the President has to keep saying that, that faith is a big part of this.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Justice Dept. Nominee
 Q. Okay. I'd like to go back to your Justice Department for just a second, Mr. President, since during the campaign you said it was a mistake and in fact apologized for playing golf at an all-white country club in Little Rock, shouldn't it disqualify your nominee for associate attorney general, Webb Hubbell? Is there an exception because he's a family friend and, and are the local ----
A. Absolutely not.
Q. ---- are the local civil rights leaders wrong when they say that his attempts to integrate the club appear to have been a last-minute political conversion?
A. No, as a matter of fact, if you go back -- first of all, let me, let me -- the first question is no, he should not be disqualified. The second question is, is it a last-minute conversion? The African-American who joined the club testified that Webb Hubbell had been trying for years to get him to do it and he had not agreed. That's what the record shows.
Thirdly, my belief is that the overwhelming majority of African-American leaders in my state would very much like to see him confirmed.
He's always had a reputation as being a strong advocate of civil rights whether as Mayor of Little Rock or chief justice of the Supreme Court of my state.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Strength of Policy
 Q. Mr. President, I want to go back to a question that Helen asked earlier about your indecisiveness over Bosnia. I'm wondering how you think that's affected perceptions of you as a leader. There is a concern reflected in polls and in some comments from Democratic members in Congress that you are indecisive and perhaps not tough enough to tackle all the problems.
A. Well, I'd just like to ask you what their evidence is. When Russia came up the United States took the lead and we got a very satisfactory result. When I took office, I said we were going to try to do more in Bosnia. We agreed to go to the Vance-Owen peace process, and two of the three parties signed on. We got enforcement of the no-fly zone. We began to engage in multinational humanitarian aid.
We got much, much tougher sanctions. We got the threat of military force on the table as a possible option, Milosevic changed his position all because this Administration did more than the previous one.
And every time I have consulted the Congress, they say to me in private this is a really tough problem, I don't know what you should do, but you're the only president that ever took us into counsel beforehand. Instead of telling us what you were going to do, you actually ask us our opinion. I do not believe that is a sign of weakness. And I realize it may be frustrating for all of you to deal with the ambiguity of this problem, but it is a difficult one.
I have a clear policy. I have gotten more done on this than my predecessor did, and maybe one reason he didn't try to do it is because if you can't force everybody to fall in line overnight, the people that have been fighting each other for centuries, you may be accused of vacillating. We are not vacillating. We have a clear, strong policy.
In terms of the other issues, who else around this town in the last dozen years has offered this much budget cutting, this much tax increases, this much deficit reduction, and a clear economic strategy that asks the wealthy to pay their fair share, gives the middle class a break and gives massive incentives to get new investment and new jobs in the small business community and from large business as well?
I think -- you know, I don't understand what -- on one day people say he's trying to do too much, he's pushing too hard, he wants too much change; and then on the other day says, well, he's really not pushing very hard.
I think we're getting good results. We've been here three months, we've passed a number of important bills, and I feel good about it.
I think the American people know one thing: that I'm on their side, that I'm fighting to change things, and they're finding out it's not so easy. But we are going to get a lot of change out of this Congress if we can keep our eye on the ball and stop worrying about whether we characterize each other in some way or another and keep thinking about what's good for the American people.
Every day I try to get up and think about not what somebody characterizes my action as, but whether what I do will or will not help to improve the lives of most Americans. That is the only ultimate test by which any of us should be judged.
Thank you very much.

HEADLINE: Santiago Journal;
Is He 'Merchant of Death' or Scapegoat for U.S.?

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
He has been called the "merchant of death" and a "black widow spider" by United States officials, but he is known around town by diplomats and officials as Carlos, the man who amassed hundreds of millions of dollars by making lethal weapons and exporting them to Iraq.
For two years the United States has been investigating Carlos Cardoen Cornejo in connection with the illegal export of zirconium for use in cluster bombs for Iraq in the late 1980's. 
 Instead of lying low, Mr. Cardoen is fighting the investigation with a public relations offensive, accusing Washington of "business terrorism." He asserts that he is the scapegoat for an ill-fated effort by the United States to arm Iraq for its war with Iran in the 1980's, an idea that eventually backfired on the United States when President Saddam Hussein's forces invaded Kuwait in 1990.
"At the time, everyone was assisting him," Mr. Cardoen said of Mr. Hussein during the 1980's. "We all thought he was the defender of the Western world when he was fighting the Iranians. Everyone was happy about my selling arms. American officials patted me on the back. And now the good guy has turned into the bad guy, and there is witch hunt out for me."
 
A Pariah, He Says
 Formerly Chile's most important arms manufacturer, Mr. Cardoen is now fighting for his economic life. He says the publicity surrounding the inquiry has made him a pariah, shunned by companies he had profitable business relationships with.
His contract to service Bell Helicopters was revoked. His license to manufacture Lee jeans in Chile was canceled. Talks with the defense contractor General Dynamics stopped, and at the request of his partners, Mr. Cardoen had to pull out of a mining service business he started in Utah in the 1970's.
United States officials have also seized real estate development projects worth an estimated $30 million in Florida and impounded one of his helicopters, accusing him of intending to send it to Iraq for military use.
Mr. Cardoen does not deny that he got rich from dealings with Iraq. After establishing ties with the Baghdad Government in the early 1980's, he eventually sold Iraq 29,000 cluster bombs worth more than $200 million, as well as other military hardware like fuses, bringing his estimated sales to more than $400 million.
"I am a businessman and produce a number of things, and I have manufactured weapons under the laws of Chile," he said. "They decided to investigate me over two years ago, without so far any charges or findings. Nobody has come with any proof of the rumors and obscenities they had said. My reputation is on the floor. I don't know how to gain my reputation back."
 
Concentrating on Chile
 But as he awaits the outcome of the investigation, which is expected to be announced in May, the Chilean businessman says he has sold holdings in weapons companies in Greece, Italy and Spain. He is now concentrating on Chile, where he owns forest land, grows kiwi and other fruits for export, owns the Tarpaca vineyard and is making steel and aluminum.
His cluster-bomb plant in the northern town of Iquique is padlocked and in the process of being transferred to a Government company, he said.
Mr. Cardoen says his dealings with Iraq were common knowledge to the United States. During an interview in his paneled office, which is lined with paintings including one of the coronation of Napoleon, he brings out photographs that show him talking with American ambassadors and military officers at arms shows where his cluster bomb was on display.
He acknowledges that the export licenses in question were not filled out correctly and that an employee who completed the form did not indicate that the zirconium would be used for military explosives. But he maintains that the United States knew the controlled material would be used for bombs for Iraq and that he was not aware at the time that the application had been filed incorrectly.
Between 1984 and 1988, Cardoen Industries bought 100 tons of zirconium from the Teledyne Corporation. Zirconium increases the heat of a blast, enabling it to penetrate armor. It is used to enhance the explosion of a cluster bomb, which detonates above a target and rains bomblets and shrapnel over a large area. The Iraqis are said to have used the bombs against Iranians who surged in "human waves" against the Iraqis on the battlefield.
 
Miami Offices Raided
 In 1991 the United States started moving against Mr. Cardoen's companies in Florida. As the United States was bombing Iraq, Federal agents stormed Cardoen Industries in Miami and seized files and documents.
In April 1992, Federal prosecutors filed a civil suit in Miami, accusing Mr. Cardoen of money laundering and illegally exporting zirconium. The Government also obtained court permission to seize almost $30 million in his properties.
At the time, Carol Hallett, Commissioner of the Customs Service, called him a "black widow" spider with a web of companies and bank accounts that "circled the entire globe," and said he was "one of the world's most notorious merchants of death."
His Washington lawyer, Roger Zuckerman, argues that the Federal authorities "decided Cardoen was politically expendable in early 1991, so he went from being a friend to a foe, because United States policy changed."
 
Chile Rebuffs Investigators
 But the investigation has hit some snags. Attempts to solicit help from the Chilean Government were rebuffed. Mr. Cardoen has deep connections with the political right as well as strong ties to the current center-left Government of Patricio Aylwin.
Eduard Palmer, Assistant United States Attorney in Miami, would not comment on the case. The Government's investigation into Mr. Cardoen's activities was set back in April, when a Florida judge presiding over the civil case ruled that the Government had not shown enough evidence of criminal activity to justify a delay in the civil suit. Federal prosecutors had been trying to delay discovery proceedings by Mr. Cardoen's lawyers, arguing that they would impede the criminal investigation.
The charges against Mr. Cardoen may in the end go far beyond the problem of an incorrect export application. United States officials are also looking into allegations that Mr. Cardoen helped President Hussein build a chemical weapons plant, supplied special equipment to build a uranium concentrator that was part of Iraq's nuclear program, and in fact kept trying to send weapons to Iraq after the United Nation's arms embargo was enacted. Mr. Cardoen flatly denies this.
But his recent statements that he communicated with American officials, including the Central Intelligence Agency, about his Iraqi dealings, could, if substantiated, greatly weaken the Government's lawsuit. Moreover, any public trial could disclose embarrassing details of the relationships Iraq had with the Reagan and Bush Administrations.

HEADLINE: Tariff Cuts Advance in New Talks

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 14

 BODY:
Trade ministers from the United States, the European Community, Japan and Canada breathed new life into moribund global trade talks today.
As part of what the ministers described as significant progress here, the United States and the European Community were in nearly complete agreement on a package of tariff cuts, including a significant series of cuts offered by Japan that could spur imports to Japan and even more business between the world's two largest trading entities. 
 Substantial tariff cuts are envisaged for products like wood, paper, pharmaceuticals, construction equipment, spirits and beer and medical and scientific equipment, according to a senior American official.
 
Plenty of Roadblocks
 Disagreements remain in electronics, where resistance comes from Europe, and textiles, where the United States is balking. And a statement issued on Thursday by the new French Government of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur appeared to complicate prospects for the talks, sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and known as the Uruguay Round.
"We are working aggressively to overcome any differences we might have," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative.
Sir Leon Brittan, the Commissioner for International Trade of the 12-nation European Community, echoed that sentiment, adding, "If there is a recession in the world, the way to deal with it is to reduce barriers and increase trade."
Japan, which had been repeatedly pressed to do far more to open its markets, came up with a new tariff-cutting offer that could mean greater access in electronics, construction machinery, medical science equipment, chemicals, film and rubber, according to the Japanese Trade Minister, Yoshiro Mori.
 
Criticism by Washington
 Japan registered a global trade surplus last year of $136 billion, about a third of which was with the United States, and has been the target of unusually sharp criticism recently from Washington.
But in reacting to Mr. Mori's offer, Mr. Kantor was full of praise for the Japanese. "I was very pleased with the representation of the Japanese Government, as I think my colleagues were," said the American trade chief. "Minister Mori," the American added, "played his role well as a cleanup hitter."
The Japanese offer relates to 770 products, and 90 percent of the tariffs on them would be cut to zero. It would bring the average Japanese tariff to 1.6 percent from 1.9 percent. Still, officials here noted that the impenetrability of the Japanese market owed more to innumerable nontariff barriers.
The French have expressed opposition to a trans-Atlantic agreement on farm subsidies reached last November, and have threatened a veto within the framework of the European Community. "If people want to go too fast and force our hand," the Balladur statement said, "I am sorry to say that they are likely to be disappointed."
The ministers here said they had not had time to study the French document and withheld comment, except for Sir Leon, who noted that he would be seeing Mr. Balladur in Paris on Monday and that the French were seeking "an outcome of the Uruguay Round that is balanced and fair."
A veto would throw the European Community into a deep political as well as economic crisis, and many analysts doubt the French would go that far.
Yet today's meeting, despite the French statement, put in place an intensive process for achieving agreements on substantial tariff cutting by the time of the Tokyo economic summit meeting of the heads of the seven powerful industrial nations in Tokyo July 7.
"We agreed that we want to achieve a positive outcome to the round this year," said the Canadian Minister for International Trade, Michael H. Wilson, who was chairman of the meeting.
 
New Deadline for Talks
 Today's meeting set out a series of mileposts for getting at least a tariff-cutting agreement in the works by the July summit meeting. The hope is to bring other countries aboard by a new deadline for the round's completion, next Dec. 15. More than 100 countries are participating.
The same four ministers said that they would meet again in Paris on June 2 and then in Japan on June 24. There will be meetings as well of senior officials and trade negotiators in the efforts to create a package of global concessions.

HEADLINE: Treasury Securities End Day Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday, with longer-term securities outperforming shorter maturities as inflation jitters continued to dominate trading.
The mixed performance came as the week's reports of rising consumer and producer price inflation brought speculation that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates to curb inflation. While many bond traders do not believe the central bank is prepared to push up interest rates soon, the sentiment nevertheless hurt shorter-term maturities. 
 Higher interest rates would hurt prices at the short end of the Treasury market the most, since the central bank sets monetary policy by manipulating rates of shorter-term maturities. Higher interest rates hurt the value of existing securities, tending to push down their price.
Longer-term bonds, whose value is eroded the most by inflationary increases, could conceivably benefit from a less inflationary Fed policy.
 
30-Year T-Bond Price Rises
 Yesterday, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond rose 3/32 point. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 6.94 percent from Thursday's 6.95 percent.
In remarks apparently designed to soothe battered financial markets, President Clinton said at a news conference that longer-term inflation remained subdued despite the week's reports of an unexpected surge in prices last month. But the bond markets failed to recover on his words, which came after a morning report of industrial production that reinforced fears of inflation.
"Clinton has no real power to make policy," said Russell Abbott, a trader in Government securities at the First Boston Corporation. "The sentiment is the only thing relevant. And the sentiment is that the front end has problems."
In its morning report, the Federal Reserve said capacity utilization, a measure of production at factories, was 81.4 percent for April, the same as a revised figure for March.
 
'Another Little Signal'
 "It's another little signal out that there could be some room for inflation pressures to be building," said David Ader, a market strategist for Technical Data in Boston.
The news reinforced this week's two Government reports showing key measures of inflation rose in April much more rapidly than expected. However, reports that the Federal Reserve bought intermediate securities in late trading yesterday morning, possibly for a foreign central bank, helped lift intermediate notes off their lows. The Fed typically does not comment on such purchases or sales, but market participants said that the buying apparently had focused on five-year notes as part of a mix of midrange maturities.
The purchases helped the five-year note recover nearly half its losses during secondary trading, Mr. Ader said .
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities fell between 1/8 point and 3/16 point and intermediate maturities were off between 3/32 point and 5/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 2.99 percent as the discount rose 0.03 percentage point, to 2.94 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.14 percent as the discount rose 0.04 point, to 3.06 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 3.31 percent as the discount rose 0.02 point, to 3.20 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 101 11/32, down 1/32 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.86 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Other Metals Slip As a Volatile Week Ends

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices retreated yesterday, but remained near their 17-month highs, capping a volatile trading week caused by fears of inflation and tighter supplies.
Other metals also retreated. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for June delivery lost $1, to $368.30 a troy ounce. May silver slipped 1.6 cents, to $4.444 a troy ounce.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum for July delivery settled $5.70 lower at $386.10 a troy ounce. June palladium fell $2.25, to $119.85 a troy ounce.
In addition, copper dropped sharply, with the July contract falling 3.55 cents a pound, to 79.65 cents, on the Comex.
 
Recovering Since March
 The gold market hit an eight-year low of $326.90 in March. It has slowly recovered since then. But on Wednesday and Thursday June gold skyrocketed a total of $12 an ounce.
Traders had expected yesterday's gold trading to be to be hectic because a large number of gold options owned by Sir James Goldsmith, the European financier, were due to expire. The gold call options, giving him the right to buy gold at prices below current levels, were forcing traders who sold the options to buy gold futures to cover their positions.
But Ian MacDonald, the manager of precious metals marketing at Credit Suisse in New York, said most traders who sold gold options had covered their positions by Thursday, when gold rose sharply. Yesterday, he said, "We were quite amazed at how steady it was."
 
Demand Remains High
 Among the factors pushing up gold prices were Government reports showing that inflation was rising.
In addition, Gold is being mined in fewer places and demand remains strong, particularly in China.
In other commodity markets, energy prices continued to slide because of large inventories of petroleum products.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for June delivery fell 30 cents, to $19.48 a barrel. June heating oil fell 0.43 cent, to 53.60 cents a gallon; June unleaded gasoline dropped 0.49 cents, to 58.85 cents a gallon, and June natural gas fell 0.009 cent, to $2.26 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops as Hopes Dim For Rate Cuts in Germany

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar slid yesterday amid declining hopes for a cut in German interest rates and concerns about the strength of the American economy.
High German interest rates have attracted investors to the German mark at the expense of the dollar. 
 Expectations that German rates might come down had supported the dollar, but remarks by German officials quickly changed the market's view.
Lothar Meuller, a board member of the Bundesbank, said the German central bank was being cautious about cutting its official interest rates because of a rise in long-term market rates.
On Thursday, the Bundesbank's president, Helmut Schlesinger, said the central bank would not adopt "a sledgehammer" approach to lowering interest rates.
Several American economic reports released yesterday were mildly negative for the dollar. A report of a one-tenth of 1 percent rise in industrial output in April offered a glimmer of hope for the economy, but that was offset by a separate report showing a large pileup in unsold goods in March.
Also, the University of Michigan survey of economic confidence showed a significant decline in early May.
"None of the numbers were very encouraging, but the reason the dollar didn't come even lower is because the German economy is so bad," said Jack Griffin, a foreign exchange dealer at the Fuji Bank.
The dollar fell to 1.6013 marks in late New York trading, down from 1.6170 on Thursday. Earlier in London, the dollar ended at 1.6015 marks, down from 1.6165 on Thursday.
The Japanese yen rose amid reports that Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said a stronger yen was helping American manufacturers. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 110.80 yen in late dealings, down from 111.80 on Thursday. It ended in Tokyo at 111.65 yen, down from 111.68 late Thursday.
The British pound firmed to $1.5400 in New York, from $1.5220 late Thursday. Earlier in London, the pound traded at $1.5375, up from $1.5215 Thursday.

HEADLINE: Survey Shows Confidence Off

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Consumer confidence waned in May for the fourth consecutive month, according to a survey by the University of Michigan.
The university's preliminary consumer sentiment index for May fell to 81.9 from 85.6 in April, people with access to the survey said. 
 Economists said the decline in confidence made it hard to accept that inflation was accelerating, as this week's Government reports indicated, since it did not indicate that consumers were prepared to pay higher prices.
The Michigan report "suggests to me the economy will continue to muddle along and that inflation is not now a problem," said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
The Michigan index hit its lowest reading since October, when it stood at 73.3. The index jumped in the months after President Clinton's election last November and has fallen since his inauguration.
The record high for the sentiment index is 97.9, set in January 1989. The record low is 63.9, set in October 1990.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: BY Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Finding Net Worth
 
Q. How can I calculate my net worth?
 MARK JACKLER, Scotch Plains, N.J.
A. Net worth represents the difference between an individual's or a family's assets and liabilities - and can be easily calculated. The most common assets are cash, securities, real estate and personal property. Other assets include the cash value of life insurance, a vested interest in retirement plans and loans to others. 
 Determining the value of certain kinds of assets is more difficult than it is for others. "There are a number of ways to value stock in a family business, such as book value or a multiple of earnings," said Stanley H. Breitbard, national director of personal financial services of Price Waterhouse. "In valuing real estate, such as a personal residence, you should look at recent sales of comparable properties."
Liabilities typically are mortgages, credit-card debt, personal loans and taxes that are due.
 
Credits vs. Deductions
 
Q. Why are credits more valuable than deductions when calculating your income tax?
 WALTER BORON, Manhattan
A. A credit is usually a dollar-for-dollar subtraction from a tax. For example, if your tax would have been $100 and you have a $30 credit, the tax is reduced to $70. Most credits can only offset the tax otherwise due, but a few will result in the Government writing you a check to make sure you get their full value.
A deduction, on the other hand, is subtracted from your taxable income and its value is equal to your highest tax rate. For instance, if you are in the top tax bracket of 31 percent and contribute $100 to a charity, you receive a $31 tax deduction and the real cost of your contribution is $69.
"When your income is high enough to be triggered into the alternative minimum tax, you have to recompute your tax liability without most of your deductions," said Richard M. Cummins, a partner of Coopers & Lybrand. And that means the amount you pay will be greater than if your tax is computed the regular way.
 
Annual Percentage Rates
 
What does the term annual percentage rate mean in connection with a loan?
 NANCY LESSER, Manhattan
A. The annual percentage rate, or A.P.R., is a term defined by Federal banking regulations and is the best benchmark for customers who want to measure and compare the cost of credit. Other interest rates do not give you a picture of the real finance charge and should be converted into the A.P.R.
Essentially, the A.P.R. is the cost of credit on a yearly basis, expressed in the form of a simple percentage. According to the Consumer Credit Protection Act, every consumer loan agreement must disclose the A.P.R. in large bold type.
"For most loans, the A.P.R. includes all costs associated with getting the credit, including the interest, points, appraisal fees and credit report fees," said Nessa Feddis, senior Federal counsel of the American Bankers Association. "For mortgage loans, however, points are part of the A.P.R., but other standard fees are not included."

HEADLINE: My Hopes, My Fears, My Disease

BYLINE: By Dennis deLeon; Dennis deLeon is New York City Human Rights Commissioner.

 BODY:
For four years, I have been torn about when and how to say publicly that I carry H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. There were always too many compelling reasons not to say anything. Every such excuse started with the word "fear" -- fear of employment discrimination, fear of the politics of AIDS, fear of becoming a pariah.
When I contemplated disclosure, I felt that my hope to continue contributing to society as a lawyer and human rights activist was threatened. Would I be evaluated on my merits if I sought to be a judge, a law professor, a law firm member or a governmental appointee? 
 Mayor David N. Dinkins has known of my H.I.V. for two years and has remained supportive of me and committed to my abilities. But what about my next employer? As Commissioner of Human Rights, I have overseen hundreds of cases in which H.I.V.-positive New Yorkers and their families have been shunned by colleagues and employers. Often, the person is transferred into a meaningless position, passed over for advancement or fired. Such treatment is often made to appear superficially legitimate but is frequently revealed through investigation to be based on discrimination. Why should I put up with this?
Another reason for not discussing my status was the crazy quilt of social activist roles I am given to play as a Latino, a gay man and a person with H.I.V. These are not easy paths to simultaneously follow. New York's Puerto Rican and Latino political agenda has never recognized the needs of the thousands of us who are gay and lesbian.
Conversely, gay and lesbian leaders rarely speak to the needs of the racial and ethnic minorities. A cursory glance at the boards of most gay organizations reveals only token recognition of the city's Latino homosexual presence. The unspoken rule is that you can exist only as one thing at a time -- a Latino or a gay man -- with no recognition of reality's complexity.
Add an H.I.V. diagnosis to this mix and it gets complicated. A few Latino leaders seek to portray AIDS organizations as a powerful white presence that takes things away from women, families and racial minorities with H.I.V. These leaders often want to redirect state AIDS funds away from mainstream gay groups to Latino-run organizations with little experience in dealing with gays and lesbians. On the other hand, some gay and lesbian service providers, such as the Gay Men's Health Crisis, have tried to cover all the city's ethnic groups when Latinos may be better served through developing our own H.I.V. service organizations.
I have been concerned about what the words "person with H.I.V." would do to my self-image. But I now know that I will not let a phrase control my potential. If I don't feel sick, why should I tell myself I am? I avoid the crepe hangers and knowing looks of pity. Why become the prisoner of uninformed beliefs about the productive potential of persons living with H.I.V.?
Given all of these reasons for not being public about the disease, why come out? Why put my professional and economic life in jeopardy? Why subject my partner of 15 years (who is H.I.V. negative) to possible reprisals just for living with me?
The simple answer is hope. If more people proclaim their H.I.V. status, we will change the way society treats persons with the virus. My hope is not based on any expectation that discrimination will end tomorrow but on a sense that it is good to show society that people with H.I.V. are leading productive lives and will tenaciously resist attempts at exclusion.
We need more role models like Thomas K. Duane, the New York City Council member; Ronald Johnson, the Mayor's AIDS services coordinator, and the hundreds of others who have disclosed their H.I.V. status. Every time the public sees one more person with the virus leading a productive life, the possibility of eliminating AIDS-based bigotry becomes more tangible.
Ultimately, the decision to disclose rests with every individual. But it's time for more of us with the virus to begin thinking about crossing the threshold. For me, hope lies on the other side of fear.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Landmarks Preservation Works for New York

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Some disgruntled applicants to New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission are described in an April 28 news article. But put in perspective, the Commission has almost 19,000 buildings in its purview, and the 10 preservationists on its staff annually issue approximately 4,000 permits for alterations to them. Ninety percent of these permits are reviewed and granted in a few weeks and materialize as improvements to the city's most treasured buildings.
In the TriBeCa West Historic District, for example, in the first 18 months after it was designated May 7, 1991, 52 of the area's 220 buildings received permits for work. That is, almost 25 percent of the buildings in the district underwent renovation and reinvestment, in an otherwise sluggish economic climate. 
 The largest of the projects approved is the New York Blood Center, planned for a 175,000-square-foot 19th-century warehouse, with a $25-million acquisition and construction budget, and a projected payroll of 500 to 600 jobs. Plans for the blood center were presented to the Landmarks commissioners and approved on the same day.
Smaller projects include scores of residential loft conversions and shops, restaurants and other small businesses, which are increasingly important to New York City's economy. More than 200 business owners in TriBeCa recently joined a committee in support of proposed TriBeCa east, north and south historic districts, affirming their enthusiasm for landmarks designation and the value it has for them.
Landmarks preservation has immeasurably improved the city's quality of life. The complaints of a few should not overshadow the benefits to many.
 
ERIC WM. ALLISON
President, Historic Districts Council
New York, May 6, 1993
